DIVISION 8. LABOR DAY PARADE ADVISORY BOARD 48
 
Notes
48 See §
   9-111 et seq., of this Code.
Sec. 2-295. Established; Purpose:
A Labor Day Parade Advisory Board is hereby established in the City. The
purpose of the board shall be the planning and coordinating of an annual Labor
Day parade to be held in September. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-296. Duties:
Duties of the Labor Day Parade Advisory Board shall be:
      (1)   To identify, and encourage groups, organizations, and individuals
to participate in a Labor Day parade which represents the rich labor history in
the City of Rock Island.
      (2)   Foster civic pride in the City's cultural, social, business,
educational and political accomplishments.
      (3)   Foster and encourage a family-oriented event to promote the general
welfare of the community. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-297. Membership; Appointment:
The Labor Day Parade Advisory Board shall consist of at least eight (8) board
members to be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. All
board members, including the Chairperson and the Treasurer of the board, shall
be citizens of the City except for one board member who may reside outside the
City. The present volunteers who have been involved in the planning of the
Labor Day parade shall be given first consideration for appointment to the
advisory board. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-298. Term:
The terms of the Labor Day Parade Advisory Board members shall be four (4)
years except for the first appointments, wherein half of the board members will
have a two (2) year term and the other board members a four (4) year term.
Thereafter, all appointments shall be for a four (4) year term. (Ord. 89-2, 1-
23-1989)
Sec. 2-299. Municipal Parade Fee Waived:
The Municipal parade fee is expressly waived for the Labor Day parade organized
by the Labor Day Parade Advisory Board. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-300. Participants To Be Held Harmless From Claims:
The City will hold harmless any participants in the annual Labor Day Parade
sponsored by the City from any claims that might arise because of those
individuals' participation in said parade. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
DIVISION 8A. NEIGHBORHOOD PARTNERS BOARD
Sec. 2-300A. Board Created:
   (a)   Created: There is hereby created the Neighborhood Partners of Rock
Island, referred to in this division as "Neighborhood Partners", which shall
consist of full and associate members. Only full members shall be voting
members of the board. One-third (1/3) of the full membership, which is
determined at the annual membership meeting, will consist of City appointments.
The membership of the board shall be broadly representative of neighborhood
interests in the City.
   (b)   Appointments: The one-third (1/3) City representatives on the board
shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council.
Replacement appointments to the board shall be made as vacancies occur. The
number of City appointments will be reevaluated at the annual membership
meeting in February of each year so that the same ratio of appointments will
continue from year to year. The revised number of City appointments will be
made by the Mayor and City Council no later than April 30 following the annual
membership meeting. The Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, shall
appoint the member organizations. Each member organization shall appoint its
own representative(s) to the board.
   (c)   Terms: Members shall be appointed for a period of three (3) years.
Appointees may serve only two (2) consecutive terms, but may be appointed again
after a three (3) year waiting period. All initial terms will officially begin
with the first membership meeting in February 1997.
   (d)   Meetings: The neighborhood partners shall meet at least three (3)
times each year, and at such further times as meetings are called by the board
president, board secretary or at least one-third (1/3) of the members of the
board. All neighborhood partners' meetings shall be held at such times and in
such locations as shall be convenient for the attendance of the membership.
(Ord. 96-75, 10-7-1996)
Sec. 2-300B. Purpose And Intent:
The neighborhood partners shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city
council and shall counsel on the following purposes:
      (1)   To build stronger working partnerships among neighborhoods, city
government, nonprofit agencies, schools, churches and businesses;
      (2)   To improve quality of life and pride in Rock Island neighborhoods
through education, resident self-sufficiency and enhanced, user friendly
municipal services; and
      (3)   To provide input on a coordinated municipal service delivery
process that responds to citizen needs, influences resource decisions, and
develops and implements action strategies at the neighborhood level by advising
a city interdepartmental team to address these issues and bringing in other
expert organizations, agencies and individuals on an as-needed basis. (Ord. 96-
75, 10-7-1996)
DIVISION 9. SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT ADVISORY TEAM
Sec. 2-300.1. Establishment:
There is hereby established a sustainable development advisory team
(hereinafter SDAT) for the city of Rock Island, Illinois, whose primary purpose
shall be to offer advice, input and guidance on the application of sustainable
development principles for projects and activities for the city of Rock Island,
Illinois. (Ord. 003-2007, § 1, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.2. Duties:
SDAT will serve in an advisory capacity as a resource for suggested methods and
processes for the incorporation of sustainable design concepts, methods and
technologies into public and private operations and/or into the construction or
remodeling of buildings or properties within the city of Rock Island, Illinois.
(Ord. 003-2007, § 2, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.3. Objectives:
The primary objectives of the SDAT will be as follows:
      (1)   To provide the city of Rock Island, Illinois, with the unique
development tool to assist businesses desiring to expand or locate in the city
of Rock Island, Illinois;
      (2)   To reinforce concepts, principles and benefits of sustainable
design and development;
      (3)   To serve as a resource for input and advice on the sustainable
design and construction of facilities as they pertain to the built environment;
      (4)   To provide suggestions and guidance on the application of
sustainable principles for city projects. (Ord. 003-2007, § 3, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.4. Membership, Appointment And Term:
   (a)   The SDAT shall consist of eight (8) members appointed by the mayor
with the consent of the city council. Appointees shall represent the following
professions: two (2) members shall be attorneys; two (2) members shall be
architects; two (2) members shall be engineers, and two (2) members shall be
urban planners.
   (b)   The term of the SDAT membership shall be four (4) years. (Ord. 003-
2007, §§ 4, 5, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.5. Meetings:
The community and economic development director or his designee shall call
meetings of the SDAT at such time when a public or private party wishing to
utilize the service of the SDAT requests a review of a project or process. The
advice, guidance and input provided by the SDAT shall be given at no cost to
the party requesting the service, shall be advisory in nature, and shall not be
binding on the requesting party. (Ord. 003-2007, § 6, 1-8-2007)
DIVISION 10. POLICE COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION
Sec. 2-300.10. Generally:
   (a)   Created: There is hereby created the Rock Island Police Community
Relations Commission, referred to in this division as the "Commission," which
shall consist of seven (7) members who are residents of the city. Community
leaders will have the opportunity to recommend members to the Mayor, who shall
make appointments to the Commission and submit them to the City Council for
approval. The membership of the commission shall be broadly representative of
the community, including representative of diverse racial, cultural, sexual
orientation, and gender groups, and shall include: (1) one current or former
member of law
enforcement, (2) one returning resident or convicted felon, (3) and five
members at large. The Commission shall endeavor to recruit members reflective
of the demographics of the City. Appropriate Commission members will
demonstrate integrity, open-mindedness, problem-solving abilities, and a
commitment to the main purposes of the Commission.
   (b)   Purpose: The primary purposes of the Commission are to: (1) build a
trusting relationship between law enforcement and communities that have
historically lacked trust with law enforcement, (2) promote policies and
procedures that support just and equitable treatment for all residents
regardless of race, national origin, ancestry, sex, gender, sexual orientation,
religion, marital status, disability status, and/or unfavorable discharge from
military service, and (3) safeguard the rights of all residents as defined by
the Constitution of the United States and state and local laws.
   (c)   Objectives: The objectives of the Commission shall be:
   (1)   To receive, review, explore, and gather data through statutory
processes on complaints filed by residents against the Rock Island Police
Department. The Commission does not review or otherwise engage with current,
pending complaints. Once the Commission's review is complete, the data and
recommendations will be presented to the Rock Island Mayor, City Council, City
Manager, Police Chief, and Rock Island residents. A mechanism to receive
complaints will be established by the Commission.
   (2)   To review the data gathered through statutory processes in all Rock
Island Police cases where officer(s) is/are subjected to review from the Rock
Island County Integrity Task Force. The Commission's primary responsibility
will be to review the incidents and provide feedback on the officers' and
residents' actions and provide suggested input on future interactions to
prevent future negative outcomes. Once the Commission's review is complete, the
Commission will present their completed review to the Rock Island County
State's Attorney's Office, Rock Island Mayor, City Council, Rock Island Police
Chief and Rock Island residents. The Commission will not include case sensitive
information to the public that is not already a matter of public record.
   (3)   To recommend and implement programs with the Chief of Police that
address the diversity of the community and police department.
   (4)   To develop procedures to anticipate, prepare for and help ease
community discomfort that may arise from police and community tensions.
   (5)   To work for greater resident participation in the planning and
execution of public policy in all phases of policing within Rock Island.
   (6)   To host quarterly community meet-and-greets with Rock Island law
enforcement and the community as a whole, preferably at different community
venues/places.
   (7)   To periodically host a community-wide meet-and-greet for all newly
hired Rock Island police officers.
   (8)   To review data gathered through statutory processes regarding hiring
and promotion patterns and decisions and provide recommendations on strategies
to attract, recruit, inspire, and prepare the next generation of police
officers in Rock Island with a focus on retaining existing resident talent.
   (d)   Appointments: The members of the Commission shall self-nominate or be
nominated by
community leaders before being appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the
city council.
   (e)   Term: Members shall be appointed to three (3) year terms
   (f)   Meetings: The Commission shall meet monthly at city hall or other
venues as decided by the chairperson and with increased frequency as decided by
the chairperson or majority of the members. A majority of the Commission shall
constitute a quorum which shall be required before any business may be
conducted. Commission members shall elect a chair and vice chair who shall
serve for a term of one year.
   (g)   The chair of the Commission, in coordination with the Chief of Police,
shall develop written standards for orientation, training, and continuing
education for the commission members. All commission members must complete the
initial training before participating in any data review. (Ord. 046-2021, 9-14-
2021; amd. Ord. 038-2023, 8-14-2023; Ord. 03-2024, 1-22-2024)
Sec. 2-300.11. Duties and Powers:
   (a)   Generally: The commission shall advise and consult with the Mayor,
city manager and city council on all matters involving police community
relations.
   (b)   Report: The Commission shall render an annual report to the Mayor,
city council and publicly to Rock Island residents.
   (c)   Community Groups: The commission shall invite and enlist the
cooperation of racial, religious, and ethnic groups, community organizations,
fraternal and benevolent societies, veterans' organizations, professional and
technical organizations, and other groups in the city in carrying out its work.
The Commission may aid in the formation of local community groups in such
neighborhoods as it deems necessary or desirable to carry out specific programs
designed to lessen tensions or improve understanding in the community.
   (d)   City Departments: The Commission shall request and receive such
cooperation, assistance, and data from city departments through the city
manager as is reasonably necessary to carry out its work. (Ord. 046-2021, 9-14-
2021; amd. Ord. 038-2023, 8-14-2023; Ord. 03-2024, 1-22-2024)

Sec. 2-301. Permanent Registration:

Sec. 2-302. Wards:
The boundaries of the various wards of the city shall be as follows:
   (1)   First Ward: That part of the city the boundaries of which are as
follows:
Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of 17th Street and the shore of
the Mississippi River; thence meandering westerly and southerly along the
shoreline of the Mississippi River to the centerline of 18th Avenue; thence
easterly along the centerline of 18th Avenue to its intersection with the
centerline of 20th Street; thence north on the centerline of 20th Street to its
intersection with 12th Avenue; thence west along the centerline of 12th Avenue
to its intersection with the centerline of 17th Street; thence northerly along
the centerline of 17th Street to the place of beginning.
   (2)   Second Ward: That part of the city that lies south of a line described
as follows:
The centerline of 18th Avenue extending east from the shore of the Mississippi
River to its intersection with the centerline of 9th Street; thence southerly
along the centerline of 9th Street to its intersection with the centerline of
35th Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 35th Avenue to its
intersection with the centerline of 12th Street; thence southerly along 12th
Street to its intersection with the centerline of 11th Street; thence
southeasterly along the centerline of 11th Street to its intersection with the
shore of the Rock River; all territory west and south of the above-described
boundary to the shore of the Mississippi River and north of the Rock River;
also, that part of the city which lies south of the Rock River.
   (3)   Third Ward: That part of the city the boundaries of which are as
follows:
Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of 18th Avenue and the
centerline of 9th Street; thence easterly on the centerline of 18th Avenue to
its intersection with the centerline of 24th Street; thence southeasterly on
the centerline of 24th Street to the shore of the Rock River; thence meandering
westerly along the shoreline of the Rock River to its intersection with the
centerline of 11th Street; thence northwesterly along the centerline of 11th
Street to its point of intersection with the centerline of 12th Street extended
southerly; thence northerly along the centerline of 12th Street to its point of
intersection with the centerline of 35th Avenue; thence westerly along the
centerline of 35th Avenue to its point of intersection with the centerline of
9th Street; thence northerly along the centerline of 9th Street to its
intersection with the centerline of 18th Avenue to the point of beginning.
   (4)   Fourth Ward: That part of the city the boundaries of which are
described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of 18th Avenue and the
centerline of 24th Street; thence easterly along the centerline of 18th Avenue
to the point of intersection with the centerline of 30th Street; thence
southerly along the centerline of 30th Street to the point of intersection with
the centerline of 20th Avenue; thence easterly along the intersection of 20th
Avenue to the point of intersection with the centerline of 38th Street; thence
southerly along the centerline of 38th Street to the point of intersection with
the centerline 31st Avenue; thence westerly along the centerline of 31st Avenue
to the point of intersection with the centerline of 30th Street; thence
southerly along the centerline of 30th Street to the shore of the Rock River;
thence westerly along the shore of the Rock River to the point of intersection
with the centerline of 24th Street extended southerly; thence northerly along
the centerline of 24th Street to the point of intersection with the centerline
of 18th Avenue to the point of beginning.
   (5)   Fifth Ward: That part of the city the boundaries of which are
described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of a point on the shore of the Mississippi River
and the centerline of 30th Street extended northerly; thence southerly along
the centerline of 30th Street to the point of intersection with the centerline
of 18th Avenue; thence westerly along the centerline of 18th Avenue to the
point of intersection with the centerline of 20th Street; thence northerly
along the centerline of 20th Street to the point of intersection with the
centerline of 12th Avenue; thence westerly along the centerline of 12th Avenue
to the point of intersection with the centerline of 17th Street; thence
northerly along the centerline of 17th Street to the point of intersection with
that centerline and the shore of the Mississippi River; thence easterly along
the shore of the Mississippi River to the point of intersection with the
centerline of 30th Street extended northerly to the point of beginning.
   (6)   Sixth Ward: That part of the city the boundaries of which are
described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of a point on the shore of the Mississippi River
and the centerline of 30th Street extended northerly; thence southerly along
the centerline of 30th Street to the point of intersection with the centerline
of 20th Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 20th Avenue to the
point of intersection with the centerline of 38th Street; thence northerly
along the centerline of 38th Street to the point of intersection with the
centerline of 18th Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 18th Avenue
to the point of intersection with the centerline of 39th Street; thence
northerly along the centerline of 39th Street to the point of intersection with
the centerline of 14th Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 14th
Avenue to the eastern limits of the city; thence northerly along the eastern
limits of the city to the intersection of the eastern limits and the shore of
the Mississippi River; thence westerly along the shore of the Mississippi River
to the point of intersection with the centerline of 30th Street extended
northerly to the point of beginning.
   (7)   Seventh Ward: That part of the city the boundaries of which are
described as follows:
Beginning at a point which is the centerline of 14th Avenue and the eastern
limits of the city; thence meandering southerly along the eastern limits of the
city to the intersection of the shore of the Rock River; thence meandering
westerly along the shore of the Rock River to the point of intersection with
the centerline of 30th Street extended southerly; thence northerly along the
centerline of 30th Street to the point of intersection with the centerline of
31st Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 31st Avenue to the point
of intersection with the centerline of 38th Street; thence northerly along the
centerline of 38th Street to the point of intersection with the centerline of
18th Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 18th Avenue to the point
of intersection with the centerline of 39th Street; thence northerly along the
centerline of 39th Street to the point of intersection with the centerline of
14th Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of 14th Avenue to the eastern
limits of the city to the point of beginning.
(Code 1963, Ch. II, Art. II, § 1; Ord., § 1, 9-3-1964; Ord., § 1, 12-3-1964;
Ord., § 1, 7-12-1965; Ord., § 1, 12-12-1966; Ord., § 1, 12-10-1968; Ord., § 1,
9-25-1978; Ord., § 1, 11-20-1978; Ord., § 1, 9-15-1980; Ord. 83-56, § 1, 2-6-
1984; Ord. 84-37, § 1, 8-27-1984; Ord. 92-114, §§ 1, 2, 8-24-1992; Ord. 92-145,
§ 1, 12-14-1992)
Sec. 2-303. To Be Nonpartisan:
The election of all city officials shall be on a nonpartisan basis, and the
ballots used in those elections shall designate no party, platform political
principle, appellation, or mark whatever, nor shall any circle be printed at
the head of the primary ballots. (Ord. 84-8, § 1, 4-23-1984)
Sec. 2-304. When Primary Election Not Necessary:
No primary shall be held for any position or office for which no more than four
(4) candidates have filed. (Ord. 84-8, § 2, 4-23-1984; Ord. 065-2009, § 1, 10-
12-2009)
Chapter 3
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR 50
 
Notes
   Cross references--Buildings and building regulations,
   ch. 4; emergencies, ch. 5; health,
   ch. 7; licenses and business regulations,
   ch. 8; motor vehicles and traffic,
   ch. 9; recreational and cultural facilities, ch. 14; taxation, ch. 15; zoning,
   app. A; possession of alcoholic liquors on public right-of-way, § 10-51.
   State law reference--Local liquor regulations, 235 ILCS 5/4-1.
   Annotation--The possibility that the city would not issue a liquor license did
50 not authorize a city officer to refuse to accept the license fee. People ex
   rel. Baumann v. Gest, 148 Ill. App. 560 (1909).
   The revocation of a liquor license will be upheld unless the findings and
   conclusions on which it was based are against the manifest weight of the
   evidence. Lambrech v. Illinois Liquor Control Commissions, 5 Ill. App. 2d 481,
   126 N.E. 2d 38 (1955).
   A person's liquor license can be revoked for a violation of an ordinance only
   if there is evidence to support a finding that a violation took place and the
   licensee had some control over the prohibited conduct. Childers v. Illinois
   Liquor Control Commission, 67 Ill. App. 2d 07, 213 N.E. 2d 595 (1966).
Sec. 3-1. Definitions.
The following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them:
   Alcohol: The product of distillation of any fermented liquid, whether
rectified or diluted, whatever may be the origin thereof, and includes
synthetic ethyl alcohol. It does not include denatured alcohol or wood alcohol.
   Alcoholic Liquor: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid
or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and
capable of being consumed by a human being and containing more than one-half of
one percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume.
   Applicant: An individual applying for a liquor license within the City of
Rock Island, IL.
   Bar: Any facility for serving or dispensing alcoholic liquor located on
premises which have a valid liquor license.
   Bartender: Any male or female over the age of twenty-one (21) employed in
the mixing, pouring, or drawing of alcoholic liquor.
   Beer: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of and infusion or
concoction of barley, or other grain, malt and hops in water, and includes
among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
   Caterer Retailer: A person, corporation or business entity who serves or
sells alcohol at a "catering location" as defined herein, as an
incidental part of its food preparation and service business. Prepared meals
and the sale or service of alcoholic liquor must be for a price agreed upon
under contract and may include a cash bar.
   Catering Location: A location that may or may not be open to the general
public where, pursuant to an agreement with an event sponsor or host, the
catering retailer licensee is providing prepared food and/or liquor at either a
private or public function. The caterer retailer licensee is limited to serving
or selling alcohol only for consumption at the catering location.
   Convenience Store: A retail establishment which offers for sale, a variety
of food and nonfood items including pop, cigarettes, snacks and toiletries,
etc., in a limited physical space.
   Deliver or Delivery: The actual constructive or attempted transfer of
possession of alcoholic liquor.
   Discount Store: A retail establishment which concentrates in mass
merchandising for the purpose of offering goods for sale at reduced prices.
   Distributor: Any person, corporation or business entity, who is engaged in
the city in purchasing, storing, possessing, or warehousing any alcoholic
liquors for resale.
   Drugstore: A retail establishment which offers the service of a licensed
pharmacist to fill prescriptions of licensed physicians, surgeons and dentists,
as well as the sale of over the counter medication and everyday home and office
supplies such as toiletries, cosmetics and stationery.
   Golf Course: A green available to the general public which is run by the
Rock Island Park board and contains at least nine (9) holes. This terrain shall
be devoted to the game of golf only. Miniature golf shall not be included in
this description.
   Grocery Store: A retail establishment which offers for sale all types of
foodstuffs both perishable and nonperishable for consumption off the premises.
To a smaller extent, toiletries, magazines, cigarettes and other pharmaceutical
supplies are offered for sale. In some instances, a bakery, delicatessen and
meat section within the establishment may also be included in this definition.
   Hotel/Motel: A single- or multi-story building where overnight
accommodations are available for at least twenty-five (25) travelers and guests
for an adequate fee.
   Illinois Liquor Control Act: An act passed by the Illinois General Assembly
entitled "An act relating to alcoholic liquors", approved January 31, 1934, as
amended.
   Illinois Liquor Control Commission or State Commission: The commission
created by the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/3-1.
   Licensee: All persons: (1) who are issued a license or permit for the sale
of distribution of alcoholic liquor pursuant to this Chapter; or (2) who are
owners or are in control of any place where the sale or distribution of
alcoholic liquor is carried on, whether they be individuals, partners,
corporations, joint stock companies, fiduciaries or officers, directors,
stockholders of corporations, or otherwise.
   Liquor Store: A licensed establishment which engages in the retail sale of
packaged alcoholic liquor for use off the premises.
   Live Entertainment: The availability of music, singing, dancing or acting
whether it be live performance, recorded music or instrumental.
   Manager: A person employed by a licensee for the purpose of overseeing the
operation of a licensed business and exercising discretionary authority on
behalf of the licensee during the hours that the manager is on duty.
   Minor: Any person under the age of twenty-one (21).
   Motor Fuel Station: A retail establishment which offers the sale and pumping
of gasoline as well as vehicle maintenance items and repairs as its primary
business.
   Officer: Any director, stockholder, owner/manager or person who has a
financial interest of any nature in a private club or directs any policy of a
private club.
   Original Package: Any bottle, flask, jug, can, cask, barrel, keg, hogshead,
or other receptacle or container whatsoever, used, corked or capped, sealed and
labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor, to contain and to convey any
alcoholic liquor.
   Package Liquor: Alcoholic liquor in its original package for consumption off
the premise where it is sold.
   Premises: The location at which alcoholic liquor is licensed for retail
sale. Except as otherwise provided hereunder, parking lot areas shall not be
considered part of the licensed premises.
   Private Club: A corporation organized under the laws of the state, not for
pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the
sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors as defined by § 1-3.24 of the Liquor
Control Act of 1934 (ILCS Ch. 235, Art 5, § 1-3.24) that complies with the
General Not for Profit Corporation Act of 1986 (ILCS Ch. 805, Act 105, §
101.01).
   Private Function: A prearranged private party, function, or event, lasting
no longer than three (3) days and is for a specific social or business
occasion, either by invitation or reservation, and not open to the general
public, where guests and attendants are served in a room, rooms or area
designated and used exclusively for the private party, function or event.
   Restaurant: Any public place, licensed under Class F or G of this Chapter,
where meals are prepared and served by workers specifically hired for such
duties; where overnight accommodations are not available; and the sale of
alcoholic liquor is only incidental to the serving of meals.
   Retail Sales: The sale for use or consumption and not for resale.
   Sale: Any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner, including the sales
made by any person whether principal, proprietor, agent, servant or employee.
   Spirits: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed
with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum, whiskey,
gin or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended or
otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances.
   Tavern: Every building or structure, licensed under Class D or E of this
Chapter, which is kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the public,
other than a club, hotel, motel, or restaurant, where alcoholic liquor is sold
and consumed on the licensed premises as the primary monetary function of the
business.
   Video Gaming Establishment: Any public place kept, used, maintained,
advertised and held out to the public as a "licensed establishment" per the
Illinois Video Gaming Act, 235 ILCS 40/1 et. seq., where alcoholic liquor is
sold for consumption on the premises and whose principal purpose is the
operation of video gaming terminals as defined under the Act and
Chapter 5  of this Code. The sale of alcoholic liquor and/or food at a video
gaming establishment shall be incidental to the operation of video gaming
terminals.
   Wine: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural
contents of fruits, or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages
when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-2. Purpose:
   This Chapter shall be liberally construed, to the end that the health,
safety, and welfare of the people shall be protected and the consumption and
sale of alcoholic liquors shall be fostered and promoted by sound and careful
control and regulation of the sale and distribution of alcoholic liquor.
(Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-3. Liquor Control:
   (a)   The Mayor shall be the Local Liquor Control Commissioner for that area
which lies inside the corporate limits of the city and shall be charged with
the administration of the laws of the state and the city as they relate to
licensing within the city and with the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   The Mayor Pro Tem shall act as Deputy Local Liquor Control
Commissioner during a temporary absence or disability of the Mayor, or when the
Mayor may not be available to conduct a hearing, or as otherwise directed by
the Mayor, and shall possess the powers of a Local Liquor Control Commissioner
as provided for in the Illinois Liquor Control Act.
   (c)   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall possess all the powers and
duties as provided for in the Illinois Liquor Control Act, including but not
limited to the following:
      (1)   To grant or deny all licenses, permits or certificates applied for
or issued under this chapter to persons for premises within their jurisdiction;
      (2)   To enter into and to authorize any investigator, inspector, or
police officer to enter onto any licensed premises to determine whether any of
the provisions of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, or of this chapter, or of
any rules and regulations adopted by the Commissioner, or by the state
commission has been violation.
      (3)   To investigate by all means, in accordance with law, violations of
this Code or of the Illinois Liquor Control Act.
      (4)   To exercise all the powers, functions, and duties which now or may
hereafter may be granted to him by the Illinois Liquor Control Act, or by this
chapter.
      (5)   To suspend or revoke any license, permit or certificate issued
under this chapter or assess a fine for each violation of law or ordinance.
(Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024; amd. Ord. 50-2025, 4-29-2025)
Sec. 3-4. Persons Ineligible To Be Licensed:
   (a)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter to:
   (1)   A person who does not live within thirty five (35) miles from the City
of Rock Island, City Hall located at 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, IL.
   (2)   A person who has been convicted of a felony unless they are granted a
license pursuant to paragraph (c) of Sec.
3-7 of this chapter.
   (3)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or has
forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation.
   (4)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning gambling.
   (5)   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a
license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon
      for the full period for which the license is to be issued.
   (6)   A person whose license, issued under this chapter or under the
Illinois Liquor Control Act, has been revoked for cause, or whose license is
actively suspended.
   (7)   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   (8)   A person whose place of business is supervised by a manager, unless
said manager possesses the same qualifications required by the licensee and
resides within thirty five (35) miles from the City of Rock Island, City Hall,
located at 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, IL.
   (9)   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated
by the licensee.
   (10)   A co-partnership, unless all the persons forming a part of such co-
partnership shall be qualified to obtain a license, except that only one
partner shall be required to reside within thirty five (35) miles from the City
of Rock Island, City Hall located at 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, IL.
   (11)   A corporation, unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is
a foreign corporation qualified under Illinois law to do business in the state,
and the establishment is managed by an individual who resides within thirty-
five (35) miles from 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, IL.
   (12)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of
such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any
reason other than citizenship and/or the requirement to reside within thirty
five (35) miles from the City of Rock Island, City Hall located at 1528 3rd
Avenue, Rock Island, IL.
   (13)   Any law enforcing public official, including the Commissioner, Mayor,
members of the city council, or any president or member of a county board; and
no such official shall be interested directly in the manufacture, sale or
distribution of alcoholic liquor, except that license may be granted to such
official in relation to premises which are not located within the territory
subject to the jurisdiction of that official if the issuance of such license is
approved by the state liquor control commission.
   (14)   Any person or entity who is ineligible for a State Liquor License
pursuant to 235 ILCS 5/6-2. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-5. Licensing Procedure:
   (a)   Generally: No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any
alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') from the property boundaries of
any church, school, other than an institution of higher learning, hospital,
home for aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children or
any military or naval station; provided that this prohibition shall not apply
to hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to
restaurants, food shops or other places where the sale of alcoholic liquor is
not the principal business carried on, nor to the renewal of a license for the
sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on premises within one hundred feet (100')
from the property boundaries of any church or school where such church or
school has been established within such one hundred feet (100') since the
issuance of the original license. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner has the
authority to waive
this restriction, only for good cause shown, and approval by the Planning and
Zoning Division within the City of Rock Island.
Nothing in this section shall prohibit the issuance of a license to a church or
private school to sell at retail alcoholic liquor if any such sales are limited
to periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion
of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors.
   (b)   Adjacent Business: No liquor licenses shall be granted to any
applicant, or any premises not presently being used for the sale of alcoholic
liquors within the corporate limits of the city where the same is located in
any zone in the city which is at the time of the application either wholly or
partly devoted to business uses, unless the following first occurs:
   (1)   A notice letter will be mailed to all adjacent property owners within
three hundred feet (300') from the property boundaries of the proposed
location, and said letter shall be signed and mailed by the city clerk who will
also be the designated person to receive any written responses relating to an
objection to the proposed site. The letter shall contain the address of the
location, identity of the applicant, the type of liquor license requested, and
the opportunity to file any objections to the approval of the application
within two (2) weeks upon receipt of the letter.
   (2)   The applicant shall pay an additional fee of twenty five dollars
($25.00) for cost of mailing all letters and for staff time.
   (3)   The applicant shall file an affidavit stating that they have posted
the notice provided by the City Clerk on the proposed licensed premises.
   (4)   The notice letters described above shall be deposited in the U.S. mail
at least three (3) weeks prior to the granting of a liquor license, and a copy
of said letter shall be furnished to the applicant.
   (5)   In the event any location shall become and remain vacant for a period
of twelve (12) or more months consecutively, no new license shall be issued to
those premises without first following the notice requirement in accordance
with provisions of this section.
   (6)   If the Liquor Commissioner receives any objections to the granting of
the license, the Commissioner may, within their discretion, conduct further
investigation, or set the matter for hearing following the provisions of Sec.
3-12 of this Chapter.
   (c)   Stores:
   (1)   A grocery store, drugstore, convenience store or other store where
goods are sold at retail and where the primary business of such store consists
of sales of goods other than alcoholic liquor (is ineligible for a license);
provided, such stores shall not be an ineligible location if the alcoholic
liquor is separated from such other goods by way of turnstiles, fencing,
chains, walls, display racks, or other means suitable to the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner. It is the intent of this subsection to prohibit the
licensing of stores in which the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the primary
business unless there are adequate controls to monitor those who enter and make
purchases of alcoholic beverages. For the purposes of this subsection, the
primary business in sales of goods other than alcoholic liquor shall be
determined by more than fifty percent (50%) of the gross revenue of all goods
sold being derived from the sale of goods
      other than alcoholic liquor, but shall not apply to restaurants and
hotels.
   (2)   Plan Required: All initial applications for licensing of stores or
upgrading of license classification for stores shall be accompanied by a plan
detailing the area, including cooler locations, where alcoholic liquor is to be
located and the means for separation. Such plan shall be reviewed and approved
by the local liquor commissioner or their designee prior to issuance of a
license.
   (d)   Motor Fuel Station: A motor fuel station located within the city shall
be an ineligible location for licensing hereunder, except that such locations
may obtain a Class C license which shall allow the sale of beer and wine in
sealed packages only, but not for consumption on the licensed premises.
   (e)   Private Clubs: A "private club" as defined in section
3-1  of this chapter unless having first obtained a valid Class K liquor
license. Private clubs licensed hereunder shall be subject to all of the
provisions of this chapter the same as any licensee. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-6. Locations Ineligible For License:
   (a)   No liquor license shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter
unless the applicant has completed the following application process:
   (1)   Application Form: All applicants shall complete an application form
which shall include, but not be limited to, the following information:
      a.   The applicant's name, address, telephone number, date and place of
birth, social security number, driver's license number, employment history and
criminal arrest record. In the case of a co-partnership or corporation, the
aforementioned information shall be provided on all officers of the
corporation, partners, and managers.
         1.   Any party required to register pursuant to either the Illinois
Liquor Control Act or this Chapter, shall submit their fingerprints to the Rock
Island Police Department and submit the required, nonrefundable processing fee
for the purpose of conducting a criminal history check.
      b.   The name, address, and telephone number of the location which is to
be licensed.
      c.   The type of license and any options requested.
      d.   If the applicant is a corporation, the date and place of
incorporation.
      e.   The length of time the business or corporation has been engaged in
the sale of alcoholic liquor.
      f.   The name and address of the landlord if the proposed location is not
owned by the applicant, and a copy of any lease for the proposed licensed
premises.
      g.   A statement that the proposed location is not located within one
hundred feet (100') of any church, school, hospital, home for the aged or
indigent persons, or for veterans, their wives or children, or any military or
naval base.
   (2)   Application Fee: All applications for initial licensing shall be
accompanied by a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) nonrefundable application fee.
   (3)   Affidavit, Signed: All applicants shall sign an affidavit stating that
the statements made in the application form are true and that any untruths or
omissions shall be grounds for revocation of a license. The affidavit shall
further state that the applicant agrees to observe all laws of the United
States, the state and the city in the conduct of their business.
   (4)   Proof Of Dram Shop Insurance: All applicants shall show evidence of
dram shop liability insurance or other proof of financial responsibility
satisfactory to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner prior to issuance/renewal
of any license.
   (5)   Private Clubs; Supplemental Information: All applicants for licensing
under the provisions of this chapter herein defined as a "private club"; shall
also submit the following application materials:
      a.   A list of all club officers and their addresses for the preceding
three (3) years. Whenever such officers shall change, a revised list shall be
forwarded to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner within ten (10) days.
      b.   A copy of the articles of incorporation and bylaws if the applicant
is a corporation, or articles of association, or bylaws, if the applicant is an
association. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-7. Licenses Generally:
   (a)   Right Of Entry And Inspection: The right of entry and inspection of
any licensed premises by any officer or agent of any department of the city
shall be a condition uponwhich every license hereunder shall be issued and the
acceptance of any license issued hereunder.
   (b)   Review And Investigation: All applications for licensing hereunder
shall be reviewed and investigated by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner
and/or its designee.
      (1)   If upon investigation the Local Liquor Control Commissioner is
satisfied that the information contained therein is true and that the applicant
has complied with all the requirements of the state and the city, and the
Commissioner determines the issuance of the license is in the public's best
interests and will not adversely affect or have a substantial impact upon the
public health, safety or welfare, then the Commissioner shall approve the
application.
   (c)   Criminal Convictions: The Commissioner, upon a finding that an
applicant for a license was convicted of a felony or a violation of any federal
or State law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic
liquor, shall consider any evidence of rehabilitation and mitigating factors
contained in the applicant's record including any of the following factors and
evidence, to determine if the conviction will impair the ability of the
applicant to engage in the position for which the license is sought:
      (1)   The lack of direct relation of the offense for which the applicant
was convicted to the duties, functions and responsibilities of the position for
which the license is sought;
      (2)   Whether eight (8) years since a felony conviction or five (5) years
since release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is later, have
passed without a subsequent conviction;
      (3)   If the applicant was previously licensed or employed in this State
or other states or jurisdictions, then the lack of prior misconduct arising
from or related to the licensed position or position of employment;
      (4)   The age of the person at the time of the criminal offense;
      (5)   Successful completion of sentence;
      (6)   Evidence of the applicant's present fitness and professional
character;
      (7)   Evidence of rehabilitation or rehabilitative effort during or after
incarceration, or during or after a term of supervision, including, but not
limited to, a certificate of good conduct under Section 5-5.5-25 (730 ILCS 5/5-
5.5-25) of the Unified Code of Corrections or a certificate of relief from
disabilities under Section 5-5.5-10 (730 ILCS 5/5-5.5-10) of the Unified Code
of Corrections; and
      (8)   Any other mitigating factors that contribute to the person's
potential and current ability to perform the duties and responsibilities of the
position for which a license or employment is sought.
   (d)   Denial Of License:
      (1)   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is vested with the power to
refuse the issuance of a license if, after investigation it is determined upon
a finding of good cause that the issuance of the license would not be in the
public's best interest.
      (2)   If the Commissioner refuses to issue a license to an applicant,
then the Commissioner shall notify the applicant of the denial in writing with
the following included in the notice of denial.
         a.   A statement about the decision to refuse to issue a license;
         b.   A list of any convictions that the Commissioner determined will
impair the applicant's ability to engage in the position for which a license is
sought;
         c.   Any factor the Commissioner considered in determining that the
issuance of the license was not in the public's best interest; and
         d.   A summary of the appeal process or the earliest the applicant may
reapply for a license, whichever is applicable.
      (3)   Administrative Hearing: Upon any denial of issuance or renewal, the
licensee/applicant may request an administrative hearing before the City
Council to review such decision. Such hearing is a prerequisite to review by
the State Liquor Commission. The hearing procedures in Sec.
3-12  of this chapter shall be followed.
   (e)   Disclaimer: It is the responsibility of the applicant and/or licensee
to get both Local and State approval prior to operation.
(Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024; amd. Ord. 49-2025, 4-28-2025)
Sec. 3-8. Types Of Licenses And Fees:
   (a)   Generally: No person shall sell, barter, transport, deliver, solicit
or receive orders for, keep or expose for sale, keep with intent to sell, or
furnish any alcoholic liquor for sale at retail within the corporate limits of
the city without first having obtained a valid liquor license from the same.
   (b)   Shifting Devices: The giving away of any alcoholic liquor or any other
shift or device to evade the provisions of this chapter, shall be
unlawful and shall be punishable as unlawful selling. The dispensing of wine by
any church or religious organization for sacramental purposes shall, however,
not be subject to the licensing provisions of this chapter.
   (c)   Frequenting Unlicensed Premises: It shall be unlawful for any person
to frequent premises where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for sale unless
there is conspicuously displayed on the premises a liquor license issued by the
city. Any person found to be frequenting unlicensed premises shall be subject
to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (d)   Change Of Location: Any license issued hereunder shall embrace only
one place of business and shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the
premises described in the application and license. The location may be changed
only upon written permission to make the change issued by the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner.
   (e)   Transfer Of License:
   (1)   Except as provided in subsection (e)(2), a license shall be purely a
personal privilege, valid for not to exceed one calendar year, unless sooner
revoked as provided in this chapter. It shall not constitute property, nor
shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution; nor shall it be
alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being
encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by the laws of
testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the
licensee.
   (2)   A person holding a license under this subchapter who desires to sell
his or her place of business, together with the license, may do so provided:
      a.   The license must be surrendered to the city;
      b.   The name of the prospective purchaser must be furnished the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner;
      c.   The prospective purchaser must demonstrate to the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner that he or she meets all the requirements for a license
under this subchapter
      d.   Upon the foregoing being fully complied with, a new license shall be
issued to the purchaser for the unexpired term of the surrendered license; and
      e.   No refund shall be paid to the person surrendering the license. If
the purchaser is refused the license, the license shall be returned to the
original licensee.
   (f)   Changes In Managers Or Agents: If during any licensing period the
previously designated manager or agent is replaced, the licensee shall notify
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner no later than ten (10) days following the
appointment of a new manager or agent; and the manager or agent shall provide
to the Local Liquor Commissioner the information required under subsection (1)
a of Sec.
3-6  of this Chapter for the purpose of investigating their eligibility to hold
such position.
   (g)   Licensing Period: The local liquor commissioner shall have the right
to grant retail liquor licenses for the selling at retail of alcoholic liquor
for the period beginning on May 1 of any year and ending on April 30 of the
next or succeeding year.
   (h)   Semiannual Renewal Option: Liquor licenses issued hereunder on a
semiannual basis shall be subject to a fifty dollar ($50.00) handling fee to be
paid with the regular license fee for the
second six (6) month period of any licensing year.
   (1)   Semiannual Renewal Option: Liquor licenses issued hereunder on a
semiannual basis shall be subject to a fifty dollar ($50.00) handling fee to be
paid with the regular license fee for the second six (6) month period of any
licensing year.
   (i)   Renewal Of Licenses: All liquor licenses issued hereunder must be
renewed annually. Applications for renewal must be received by the liquor
commissioner at least thirty (30) days prior to the expiration date of the
license. All requests for renewal shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating
that the activities of the establishment have not deviated from the original
application and classification of the license. Failure to meet the deadline for
renewal may necessitate the filing of a new application by the licensee.
   (1)   Investigation: The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall review the
renewal application for any updates that require further investigation and
shall issue the renewal unless the renewal application or further investigation
identifies information prohibiting the issuance of a license pursuant to the
municipal code or other reasons provided in this Chapter. Upon denial of any
renewal, the Commissioner shall provide a written notice to the applicant
stating the reasons for denial and opportunity for an administrative hearing to
present evidence and have the decision reviewed.
   (2)   Fees: No license shall be renewed unless the licensee has paid the
annual fee for the applicable classification of their license pursuant to this
chapter, and any taxes, fees, assessments or penalties owed to the city or
state in connection with the operation of any business conducted on the
licensed premise by the licensee. No renewal shall be granted until the
licensee has paid any outstanding food and beverage taxes owed to the City,
water bills, judgments, fines, or any other amount outstanding and due to the
City.
   (j)   Payment Of License Fees: All license fees established hereunder shall
be paid to the city collector prior to issuance of any license or the renewal
of any license. License fees established hereunder shall be reduced in
proportion to the number of full calendar months which have expired in the
licensing period set forth in subsection (g) or (h) of this section; however,
no license shall be issued for any term less than the balance of the unexpired
license period. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-9. Supplemental License Options And Fees:
   (a)   Hours Of Operation: All licenses issued hereunder shall allow the
licensee to be open Monday through Saturday from five o'clock (5:00) A.M. to
one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and Sunday from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. Class F and G licenses may reopen one hour after closing,
but the service of alcoholic beverages may only occur during the hours herein
identified. The hours established herein shall be Central Standard Time, except
when daylight saving time is in effect and then those hours shall be Central
Daylight-Saving Time.
   (b)   Within the B-2 (downtown business) zoning district, no license holder
shall offer for sale package liquor, or any alcohol for consumption off
premises, before five o'clock (5:00) P.M. This shall apply to all days of the
week. Breweries and Restaurants within the B-2 zoning district, however, shall
be exempt from this restriction. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-10. Minors:
   Effective the 2024 licensing year, the following class of licenses shall be
in full force and effect. A license previously issued, and subject to renewal,
may be reclassified into the appropriate class by the applicant or the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner. The Commissioner shall have the right to
investigate, and determine the appropriate Class for each license holder.
   (a)   Class A, Packaged Sales Only - Primary Business: License shall be
issued when the sale of alcoholic liquors is the primary business of the
licensee. "Primary business" shall mean that (i) twenty five percent (25%) or
more of the square footage of the store available for sales is dedicated to the
displays or promotion of alcoholic liquors, or (ii) if fifty percent (50%) or
more of its total gross revenue in any month is derived from the sale of
alcohol. A license shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquor on the
premises where sold, except that reasonable tasting/sampling of alcoholic
liquor by patrons may be allowed on the licensed premises of establishments.
   (1)   The annual fee for a Class A licenses shall be one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (2)   Minors are not allowed in a Class A licensed premises.
   (b)   Class B, Packaged Sales Only - Secondary Business: License shall be
issued when (i) less than twenty five percent (25%) of the square footage of
the store available for sales is dedicated to the displays or promotion of
alcoholic liquors and (ii) less than fifty percent (50%) of the gross revenue
in any month from the operation of the licensed premises is derived from the
sale of alcohol. A license shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquor on
the premises where sold, except that reasonable tasting/sampling of alcoholic
liquor by patrons may be allowed on the licensed premises of establishments
over ten thousand (10,000) square feet in size.
   (1)   The annual fee for a Class B licenses shall be one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (c)   Class C, Packaged Sales Only - Beer And Wine: License shall be issued
when less than twenty five percent (25%) of the square footage of the store
available for sales is dedicated to the displays or promotion of alcoholic
liquors, (ii) less than fifty percent (50%) of the gross revenue in any month
from the operation of the licensed premises is derived from the sale of
alcohol, and (iii) and the licensee sells only beer or wine. A license shall
permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquor on the premises where sold, except
that reasonable tasting/sampling of alcoholic liquor by patrons may be allowed
on the licensed premises of establishments over ten thousand (10,000) square
feet in size.
   (1)   The annual fee for a class C license shall be one thousand dollars
($1,000.00).
   (d)   Class D, Tavern With Packaged Sales: License shall permit the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor in sealed packages for consumption off premises, as
well as for consumption on the licensed premises.
   (1)   The annual fee for a class D license shall be one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (2)   Minors are not allowed in a class D licensed premises.
   (e)   Class E, Tavern: License shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor for consumption on the licensed premises.
   (1)   The annual fee for a class E license shall be one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (2)   A Class E Licensee may sell cocktails, mixed drinks, or single
servings of wine placed in a retailer's sealed container or a manufacturer's
original container for off-premises consumption, subject to 235 ILCS 5/6-28.8.
   (3)   Minors are not allowed in a class E licensed premises.
   (f)   Class F, Restaurant: License shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor for consumption on the premises where sold.
   (1)   Service of alcoholic liquor shall be only during the time that food is
prepared on the premises and is available to be served, a full menu is in
effect, and a cook or chef, whose primary duties shall not include bartending
or the service of alcoholic liquor, is in attendance.
   (2)   A Class F licensee may sell cocktails, mixed drinks, or single
servings of wine placed in a retailer's sealed container or a manufacturer's
original container, for off-premises consumption, subject to 235 ILCS 5/6-28.8
   (3)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a class F license
pursuant to this section for the purposes other than the purchase or
consumption of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a
bar.
   (4)   The annual fee for a Class F license shall be one thousand one hundred
dollars ($1,100.00).
   (g)   Class G, Restaurant - Wine And Beer Only: Licensee meets all the
requirements of a Class F license except that the restaurant serves only wine
and beer.
   (1)   Service of wine and beer shall be only during the time that food is
prepared on the premises and is available to be served, a menu is in effect,
and a cook or chef, whose primary duties shall not include bartending or the
service of alcoholic liquor, is in attendance.
   (2)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a class G license
pursuant to this section for the purposes other than the purchase or
consumption of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a
bar.
   (3)   The annual fee for a Class G license shall be seven hundred dollars
($700.00).
   (h)   Class H, Consumption On Premises - Incidental Purpose: License shall
permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption only on the premises
where sold, and not for resale in any form. The primary business of the
establishment shall not be for the sale or alcohol. This includes but is not
limited to, live theaters, performing arts centers, movie theaters, bowling
centers, recreational centers, and any private or public state-chartered
college or university.
   (1)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a class H license
pursuant to this section for the purposes other than the purchase or
consumption of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a
bar.
   (2)   The annual fee for a class H license shall be one thousand one hundred
dollars ($1,100.00).
   (i)   Class I, Hotel/Motel: license shall permit the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises whether for private events or
public consumption in a tavern, lounge area, or banquet room only, and not for
resale in any form to other portions of a premises which meet the definition of
a hotel as defined in Sec.
3-1  of this chapter.
   (1)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a class I license
pursuant to this section for the purposes other than the purchase or
consumption of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a
bar.
   (2)   The annual fee for a Class I license shall be one thousand one hundred
dollars ($1,100.00).
   (j)   Class J Banquet Facilities: license shall permit the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for consumption only on the premises where sold and not for
resale in any form to premises which meet the definition of a hotel as defined
in section
3-1  of this Chapter.
   (1)   Sales for consumption on the premises used exclusively for private
functions: Hors d'oeuvres, meals or other foods from the licensee or a licensed
food establishment must be served at every private function when alcohol is
being served.
   (2)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a Class J license
pursuant to this section for the purpose other than the purchase or consumption
of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a bar.
   (3)   The annual fee for a Class J license shall be one thousand one hundred
dollars ($1,100.00).
   (k)   Class K, Private Clubs/Fraternal Organizations: License shall permit
the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the licensed premises,
as well as other retail sales of packaged alcoholic liquor for consumption off
the licensed premises for an organization that meets the definition of private
club as defined in Sec.
3-1  of this chapter.
   (1)   Packaged alcoholic liquor sold for off premises consumption shall not
comprise greater than fifty percent (50%) of the total annual sales of all
alcoholic liquor for said licensee.
   (2)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a class K license
pursuant to this section for the purposes other than the purchase or
consumption of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a
bar.
   (3)   The annual fee for a Class K license shall be one thousand one hundred
dollars ($1,100.00).
   (l)   Class L, City Owned Facilities: License shall permit the retail sale
of beer, wine and distilled spirits at city owned facilities and also permits
the sale of beer and wine at identified facilities operated or maintained by
the City.
   (1)   May include the use of fifty milliliter (50 ml) bottles (typically
referred to as airline bottles) to pour and serve mixed drinks at city owned
golf courses.
   (2)   This license shall not allow the retail sale of beer, wine or
distilled spirits for consumption off the licensed premises of city owned
property, to include golf courses and any other designated park facilities.
   (3)   This license shall only be in effect during regular business hours or
during authorized events.
   (4)   The sale of alcoholic beverages at the Sunset Marina shall be
controlled by the provisions of this chapter, except that the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner shall have the discretion to prorate the license fee for
those premises for the period of time during the license year that the premises
are open for business.
   (5)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a Class L license
pursuant to this section for purposes other than the purchase or consumption of
alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a bar.
   (6)   The annual fee for a class L license shall be two hundred and seventy-
five dollars ($275.00).
   (m)   Class M, Caterer's License: License shall permit restaurants or
caterer retailers, as defined in Sec.
3-1  of this Chapter, whether located inside or outside of the City of Rock
Island, to cater food and/or alcoholic beverages at catering locations within
the City of Rock Island.
   (1)   Caterers and Restaurants serving food shall have a valid City of Rock
Island food license.
   (2)   The hours that alcohol may be served or sold, unless a variance is
granted by the liquor commissioner, is Sunday from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to
one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the next day and Monday through Saturday from six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. to one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the next day.
   (3)   At least thirty (30) days prior to the private function's scheduled
date, the licensee must advise in writing the liquor commissioner of the date,
times and location of the event.
   (4)   Prior to the issuance of this license the licensee must provide
verification to the liquor commissioner that its dram shop insurance covers
catering events and locations.
   (5)   Minors may be allowed on premises licensed as a class L license
pursuant to this section for the purposes other than the purchase or
consumption of alcoholic liquors; however, no minor may be allowed to sit at a
bar.
   (6)   The annual fee for a Class M license shall be three hundred and fifty
dollars ($350.00) for caterers and restaurants located within the City of Rock
Island, and seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for caterers and
restaurants located outside the City of Rock Island.
   (7)   The requirement that the licensee shall live within thirty five (35)
miles of 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, IL, in Sec. 3-4 of this Chapter shall
not apply to those seeking a Caterer's license for an establishment outside of
the City of Rock Island.
   (n)   Class N, Bring Your Own Beverage (BYOB): Which shall authorize the
consumption of beer and wine only that is brought onto the licensed premises of
a business, restaurant, or craft brewery.
   (1)   Class N licenses shall be issued subject to the applicant's compliance
with all the following conditions:
      a.   Patrons may bring onto the premises no more than seventy-two (72)
ounces of unopened beer and/or no more than seven hundred and fifty (750)
milliliters of unopened wine per two (2) patrons over the age of twenty-one
(21).
      b.   This license shall permit beer or wine to be consumed only in
conjunction with the purchase and consumption of a meal served in a manner that
complies with City codes and regulations, or when a patron is receiving
services such as at cosmetic facilities, spas, art studios, or other live
entertainment establishments.
      c.   All employees performing corkage, pouring, or serving duties must
receive all training required of a licensee.
      d.   The licensee may charge a corkage fee.
      e.   The licensee shall not permit any customer to leave the premises
with any open beer container or any open wine container other than wine secured
in compliance with the requirements of section 6-33 of the State Liquor Control
Act (235 ILCS 5/6-33).
      f.   The annual fee for such license shall be two hundred and fifty
dollars ($250.00).
   (2)   No liquor license shall be issued to any fast food or convenience-type
store, establishment or facility.
   (3)   Video gaming is prohibited in businesses that possesses a Class 'N'
license.
   (4)   Class N licensees shall not retain any alcoholic beverage on the
premises after the patron who brought it has departed.
   (o) - (r)   Reserved.
   (s)   Special Event Liquor License: Authorizes the sale of alcohol at an
approved designated site for special events, including festivals, markets, food
truck events, and other approved events.
   (1)   The following special event liquor licenses are available for the
purpose of special events on city owned properties:
      a.   Parks And Recreation Department Operated Property Or Facility: Upon
the approval, first by the Parks and Recreation Director or their designee, and
then by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, a "special event liquor license"
may be granted to an approved Rock Island license holder to sell alcohol for
special events at any property or facility operated by the parks and recreation
department.
      b.   City Properties Not Under The Jurisdiction Of The Parks And
Recreation Department: Upon the approval of the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, a "special event liquor license" may be granted to an approved
Rock Island license holder to sell alcoholic liquor at any designated city
owned location.
      c.   Upon the approval by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, a
license holder may be granted a "special event liquor license" to transfer a
portion of its alcoholic inventory from its licensed premises to a designated
site within the city for a special event.
   (2)   A special event liquor license may be issued for the purpose of
special events not on City owned properties. The property owner is responsible
for providing proof of dram shop insurance for the site.
   (3)   The special event liquor license holder may invite other retailers or
caterers to serve alcohol at the special event, without the invitees applying
for a separate caterer's license.
   (4)   A special event liquor license cannot exceed three (3) days in
duration and days must be consecutive.
   (5)   The area designated where the alcohol sales are to take place must be
located within a demarcated area, with all appropriate safeguards to control
the sales, age requirements, and safety indicated.
   (6)   For events that are to be for one day or less in duration, the fee
shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per event/location
   (7)   For events that are to be for two (2) or three (3) consecutive days,
the fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per event/location.
   (8)   A Class L license holder may apply for a special event license for a
single themed event, which would be characterized by an event with the same
theme and at the same location, but may run nonconsecutive days for up to
fifteen (15) days in duration, or additional days upon the Commissioner's
approval.
   (9)   The fee for a single themed event shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) per event. After receiving prior approval by the appropriate policy
making board and/or property owners, all special use permit liquor license
applications must be received by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner's office
no later than twenty-one (21) days in advance of the first day of the scheduled
event.
   (10)   Said applications shall include, but are not limited to, the
following information:
      a.   Name and contact information of applicant/liquor license holder for
the event;
      b.   A description of the event;
      c.   The date(s) and time(s) that the event will be held;
      d.   The address and location of the event;
      e.   The proposed area(s) inside of the designated location where the
alcohol sales are to occur;
      f.   The name/type of event being proposed;
      g.   Submission of proof of dram shop insurance to the maximum limit that
has been secured for this event, naming, where applicable, the city of Rock
Island, Illinois, as an additional insured;
      h.   Proof of approval by the policy board or property owner that
operates the property or facility.
   (t)   Class T, Temporary License: Upon approval by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, a Class T or temporary license to sell alcoholic liquor at retail
may be granted to organized clubs, societies, associations, fraternal
organizations, duly constituted churches or other not for profit organizations.
A temporary license may be issued pursuant to this subsection for one day, two
(2) consecutive days, or three (3) consecutive days. The license shall specify
on its face the duration.
   (1)   No organization shall be issued more than one temporary license during
any thirty (30) day period. This restriction may be waived by the Commissioner,
and, if so waived, the fee for such additional temporary license shall be one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.
   (2)   All applications for temporary licenses must be received by the
Commissioner at least thirty (30) days prior to the dates being requested.
   (3)   All applicants for temporary licenses shall show evidence of dram shop
liability insurance or other proof of financial responsibility prior to
issuance of such license.
   (4)   The fee for a Class T license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
per day.
   (u)   If any premises, which initially applies for and is licensed, later
wishes to reclassify the license to another class of license, it shall be
considered by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and may be treated as a new
license application, and all application procedures contained in this chapter
may apply. (Ord. 09-2024, 2-12-2024)
Sec. 3-11. Operation:
   (a)   License Options; Generally: Upon approval of the liquor commissioner,
license holders may apply for supplemental license options. All supplemental
license options shall be issued on the same qualifications, terms and
conditions required for the original license.
   (1)   Extended Hours Option:
      a.   Extended Hours Two O'Clock (2:00) A.M. Option: All Class D, E, F, G,
and K liquor license holders may apply for an "extended hour two o'clock (2:00)
A.M. license option". As of April 30, 2013, the license holders in
classifications who currently have this option available will still be able to
retain it, even though their classification may have changed. A holder of this
license may be open all days except Sunday from five o'clock (5:00) A.M. to two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the following day and on Sundays from seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the following Monday. The annual fee for
the "extended hours two o'clock (2:00) A.M. option" shall be five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
      b.   Recording System/ID Scanners:
         1.   Effective the 2025 license year, all liquor license holders with
an extended hours option shall be required to install and maintain a
functioning recording system both inside and outside of the licensed premises.
Said videos shall be maintained in proper working order and be made available
for viewing by all law enforcement personnel.
         2.   Effective the 2025 license year, all Class D and E liquor license
holders with an extended hours option shall be required to implement and
require the use of identification (ID) scanners prior to any entry at and after
ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. License holders that had a valid extended license for
the year 2023 are exempt from this requirement. This exemption is non-
transferrable to any future license holders on the premises.
         3.   Failure to maintain a functioning recording system and ID Scanner
shall result in the liquor license being suspended until such recording system
and ID Scanner are in working order.
   (2)   License Options, Live Entertainment - Limited: All class D, E, F, G,
H, I, J, K, and L license holders may apply for a "Live Entertainment -
Limited, License Option." The option shall permit the licensed establishment to
have live entertainment on Friday and Saturday nights of every week. The annual
fee for the live entertainment - limited option shall be two hundred twenty
dollars ($220.00).
   (3)   License Options, Live Entertainment - Continuous: All Class D, E, F,
G, and K license holders may apply for a "Live Entertainment - Continuous
Option." The option shall permit the licensed establishment to have live
entertainment seven (7) days per week. The annual fee for the live
entertainment - continuous option shall be four hundred forty dollars
($440.00).
   (4)   Amusement Features Permitted: The entertainment authorized in
subsections (a)(2) and (a)(3) of this section shall permit any amusement
feature including music, vaudeville, comedy, singing, acting, dancing or
contests, and disc jockey, whether by personal performance or instrumental
device.
      a.   It shall be cause for revocation or suspension as herein provided if
the licensee, his manager or agent, shall allow any live person to appear or
have reasonable cause to believe that any live person shall appear in any
licensed premises in a state of nudity to provide entertainment, to provide
service, to act as hostess, manager or owner, or to serve as an employee in any
capacity.
      b.   For the purposes of this subsection, the term "nudity" shall mean
the showing of the human male or female genitalia, pubic area or buttocks, or
the human female breast, including the nipple or any portion below the nipple
with less than a full opaque covering.
   (5)   License Options, Outdoor Events: License Options; Outdoor Events: Upon
approval of the local liquor commissioner and the city council, holders of
class D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K and L licenses shall be allowed to conduct outdoor
events provided that the following conditions are met:
