hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each
day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-
1982)
Sec. 7-58. Administration; Appeals:
   (a)   General: This article shall be administered by the City's chief
building inspector or his designated representative except for those provisions
dealing with the construction of the recreational vehicle park roadways,
walkways, parking areas, service buildings and water, sewer and electrical
systems. During construction of a recreational vehicle park, those City
officials established as having jurisdiction shall assure that said park is
constructed to meet all requirements of this article and all other codes and
ordinances which may apply.
   (b)   Right Of Inspection: Upon a presentation of proper credentials, City
officials or their duly authorized representatives may enter at reasonable
times any recreational vehicle park or building therein in the City to perform
any duty imposed upon them by this article.
   (c)   Right Of Appeal: Any person aggrieved by any ruling of any City
official charged with the administration of this article may take any appeal to
the appropriate Appeal Board as provided in other City codes and ordinances.
   (d)   Jurisdiction:
      (1)   Construction: Appeals taken from requests relating to construction
of the recreational vehicle park shall be filed with the appropriate Appeal
Board subject to the procedures established under other codes and ordinances.
      (2)   Operation: Appeals taken from requests relating to operation of the
recreational vehicle park shall be filed with the Health Code Board of Appeals,
subject to the procedures established under article II of this chapter.
      (3)   Expansion: Expansion of a recreational vehicle park and its
facilities shall be subject to authorization by the Health Code Board of
Appeals in accordance with the procedures established under section 7-60 of
this article, even if said expansion does not increase the total area of nor
change the boundaries of the recreational vehicle park. Construction of
additional systems, facilities and campsites not shown on the approved plot
plan of the recreational vehicle park shall be considered as expansions of said
park. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-59. Establishment Of Park:
   (a)   Authorization: Any person wishing to establish a recreational vehicle
park shall submit to the Rock Island Board of Zoning Appeals a request for
authorization in accordance with appendix A, article V of this Code. Said parks
are allowed only in B-4 (Highway Business) and C-1 (Conservation) Zoning
Districts.
      (1)   Plan Approval: Plans, specifications and/or construction drawings
for water and sewer facilities, roadways and buildings shall be prepared by a
registered Illinois engineer or architect, and shall be approved by the
appropriate City authorities prior to the authorization of the recreational
vehicle park by the Board of Zoning Appeals.
      (2)   Contents: A plat plan of the recreational vehicle park shall be
approved by the Public Works and Fire Department, and the chief building
inspector prior to the authorization by the Board of Zoning Appeals. Said plat
plan shall include the following information:
         a.   The area and dimensions of the park site and surrounding zoning.
         b.   The number, type, size and location of all campsites and parking
areas.
         c.   The location, right-of-way and surfaced roadway width, the
surfacing material of roadways and walkways and the interior vehicular and
pedestrian circulation patterns.
         d.   The location of all service buildings and sanitary stations.
         e.   The location of all water and sewer lines, riser pumps, all
lighting, electric and gas systems and all drainage easements.
   (b)   Permits Required: Upon receiving authorization from the Board of
Zoning Appeals, all permits required by the City shall be secured from the
appropriate authorities for construction of the recreational vehicle park.
   (c)   As-Built Drawings: If the construction of the recreational vehicle
park varies from the approved plans, specifications and/or construction
drawings, as-built drawings shall be filed with the City Engineer. If said
construction does not vary from said plans, an affidavit so certifying shall be
filed with the Director of Public Works or his designated representative. The
as-built drawings or affidavit shall be accepted by the appropriate authorities
prior to the issuance of a license for the operation of the recreational
vehicle park. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-60. Operation Of Park:
   (a)   License Required: The operator of a recreational vehicle park shall
secure from the City a license prior to the operation of the park. Said license
shall be issued by the City's chief building official or his designated
representative following the approval of the recreational vehicle park by the
Board of Zoning Appeals and the acceptance of the as-built drawings or
affidavit.
      (1)   Application: The application for said license shall be made with
the chief building official or his designated representative on forms provided
by his/her office.
      (2)   Fee: The annual fee for said license shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00), plus five dollars ($5.00) per recreational campsite, payable at the
City Finance Department prior to May 1 of each year. The licensing year shall
begin on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of the next succeeding calendar
year. All licenses shall expire on said April 30 in each calendar year.
   (b)   Park Occupancy: There shall be no permanent year-round occupancy of
any recreational campsite in a recreational vehicle park. Storage of
recreational vehicles at a recreational vehicle park shall be allowed. (Ord.
82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 042-2017,
11-6-2017)
Sec. 7-61. Standards For Parks:
   (a)   Water Supply: All recreational vehicle parks shall be adequately
served by City water in accordance with chapter 16, article II of this Code.
      (1)   Water Distribution System: All components of the water system of a
recreational vehicle park, including plumbing, shall be installed and
maintained to meet or exceed City specifications.
      (2)   Drinking Fountains: All outlets established for the provision of
drinking water, except for the filling of recreational vehicle water storage
tanks, shall consist of drinking fountains. Common drinking cups shall be
prohibited.
      (3)   Water Stations: There shall be at least one water station for each
one hundred (100) independent recreational vehicle campsites or portion
thereof. The fill hose shall be suspended so that no part of said hose or
appurtenances shall come in contact with the ground. A sign shall be posted at
each water station indicating that said water is potable and not to be used for
flushing wastes from recreational vehicle holding tanks.
   (b)   Sewage Disposal: All sewage disposal for recreational vehicle parks
shall be through the City sanitary sewer system in accordance with chapter 16,
article III of this Code.
      (1)   Sewage System: All components of the sewage system of a
recreational vehicle park, including plumbing, shall be installed and
maintained to meet or exceed City specifications.
      (2)   Sanitary Dumping Stations: There shall be at least one sanitary
dumping station with a hose for each one hundred (100) independent recreational
vehicle campsites or portion thereof. A sign shall be posted at each sanitary
dumping station indicating that the water is not potable and is to be used only
for flushing wastes from recreational vehicle holding tanks.
   (c)   Bathhouses: Bathhouses to be used by both sexes simultaneously shall
be divided into two (2) parts, separated by a tight partition and designated
for men and women. The entrances and exits shall be screened to break the line
of sight. Floors, drains, walls, partitions, fixtures, lighting and ventilation
shall be installed to conform with all City requirements. All walls, floors and
partitions shall be constructed of nonabsorbent materials. Bathhouses shall
provide both cold and hot (90 degrees Fahrenheit) water at a rate of three (3)
gallons per minute.
      (1)   Toilets: One toilet for each sex shall be provided for each twenty
(20) dependent recreational campsites or portion thereof.
      (2)   Lavatories: Two (2) lavatories for each sex shall be provided for
each twenty (20) dependent recreational campsites or portion thereof.
      (3)   Showers: One shower for each sex shall be provided for each twenty
(20) dependent recreational campsites or portion thereof.
      (4)   Cleanliness: All bathhouses shall be maintained in a clean and
sanitary condition.
   (d)   Laundry Facilities: When provided for the occupants of a recreational
vehicle park, all laundry facilities shall be properly installed and connected
to the water, sewer and electrical or gas systems of the recreational vehicle
park. For each one washing machine provided, there shall be provided at least
one dryer. Commercial dryers having capacities of greater than one washing
machine load may be substituted for the number of single-load dryers needed to
equal the capacity of the multi-load dryer.
   (e)   Refuse Disposal: The storage, collection and disposal of refuse
produced in a recreational vehicle park shall be conducted in accordance with
chapter 13, article II of this Code. The recreational vehicle park shall be
kept free of litter and accumulations of rubbish, and shall be maintained in a
sanitary condition at all times.
   (f)   Food Service: Food service, when provided, shall be conducted in
accordance with article III of this chapter.
   (g)   Buildings: All buildings in recreational vehicle parks shall be
constructed to meet or exceed all City requirements.
   (h)   Roadways And Parking Areas: All roadways and parking areas in a
recreational vehicle park shall be of a dustless surface.
      (1)   One-Way Roads: One-way roads with no parking shall have a surface
width of at least twelve feet (12'), and those with parking on one side shall
have a surface width of at least eighteen (18) feet. One-way streets with
parking on both sides shall not be allowed.
      (2)   Two-way roads. Two-way roads with no parking shall have a surface
width of at least eighteen (18) feet, those with parking on one side shall have
a surface width of at least twenty-five (25) feet and those with parking on
both sides shall have a surface width of at least thirty-one (31) feet.
      (3)   Parking areas. There shall be provided within the recreational
vehicle park at least one parking space for each two (2) recreational campsites
in addition to the required parking pads. Parking lots, spaces and access
drives shall comply with the size requirements for parking areas in the Rock
Island zoning ordinance.
   (i)   Campsites. Each recreational campsite shall contain at least one
thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet.
      (1)   Density. Each campsite shall be occupied by no more than one
recreational vehicle or two (2) tents at any one time.
      (2)   Setbacks. No part of any recreational vehicle (including awnings),
tent or other vehicle shall be placed on a recreational campsite closer than
two (2) feet to any campsite line.
      (3)   Parking pad. Each recreational campsite shall contain a stabilized
vehicular parking pad of shell, marl or other suitable, dustless material.
      (4)   Vehicle restriction. At no time shall a dependent recreational
vehicle be allowed to occupy an independent recreational campsite.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 4), 9-27-82)
Cross reference--Zoning, App. A.
Sec. 7-62. Safety.
   (a)   Building and fire codes. The grounds, buildings, utilities, roadways,
parking areas and other facilities shall be constructed, maintained and used in
accordance with applicable city building codes and fire prevention regulations.
   (b)   Flammable liquids. Liquid petroleum gas, fuel oil, gasoline and other
flammable liquids shall be handled and used in a safe manner and shall not be
stored inside or beneath any recreational vehicle.
   (c)   Play areas. Play equipment, when provided for children, shall be
designed for safety, maintained in good repair and placed in play areas which
are free from hazards.
   (d)   First aid. All recreational vehicle parks shall have at least one
first aid kit as recommended by the American Red Cross, one stretcher and one
blanket for each two hundred (200) recreational campsites or portion thereof.
   (e)   Communications. One telephone for each two hundred (200) recreational
campsites or portion thereof shall be reasonably available for emergency use.
The telephone numbers of the city police, state police, city fire department,
ambulance service and the closest hospital shall be posted near each telephone.
   (f)   Fires. Fires shall be allowed only in facilities such as fireplaces,
fire pits or charcoal braziers which have been provided for such purposes. No
fire shall be left unattended, left unextinguished upon vacation of a
recreational campsite or fueled by materials which emit dense smoke or
objectionable odors.
   (g)   Park location. Recreational vehicle parks shall not be located in
areas which may create health hazards for occupants of the park. Surface water
within two hundred (200) feet of park buildings shall be drained, filled,
constructed or treated to prevent mosquito breeding.
   (h)   Vector control. Implementation of preventive and control measures for
use against flies, ticks, mosquitoes, rats and other potential vectors of
disease in and around recreational areas shall be in accordance with city
health codes.
   (i)   Occupant list. A register containing the names, addresses and
recreational vehicle license plate numbers of all recreational vehicle park
occupants shall be maintained at all times.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 5), 9-27-82)
Cross references--
   Buildings and building regulations,
Ch. 4 ;
   fire prevention and protection,
Ch. 6 .
Sec. 7-63. Recreational activities.
   (a)   Setbacks. All buildings used for recreational activities provided at
recreational vehicle parks shall meet the setback requirements for such uses
identified in the Rock Island zoning ordinance.
   (b)   Swimming facilities. All swimming areas and related facilities for use
by recreational vehicle park occupants shall be constructed and maintained in
accordance with state regulations.
   (c)   Boating facilities. All boating facilities for use by recreational
vehicle park occupants shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with
state regulations.
   (d)   Fish cleaning facilities. All fish-cleaning facilities for use by
recreational vehicle park occupants shall provide for the storage and safe
disposal of fish offal and shall be maintained in a sanitary condition.
   (e)   Stables. All stables for use by recreational vehicle park occupants
shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be conducted in
accordance with all applicable provisions of the Rock Island zoning ordinance.
   (f)   Commercial establishments. No commercial establishments shall be
operated in any recreational vehicle park except those operated by the owner of
said park for recreational vehicle park occupants. Such establishments shall
present no visible evidence from any street outside the recreational vehicle
park of their commercial character which would attract customers other than
recreational vehicle park occupants.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 6), 9-27-82)
Cross reference--
Zoning, App. A .
Secs. 7-64--7-80. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. MOBILE HOME PARKS 1
 
Notes
1 Cross references--Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 4; motor vehicles
  and traffic, Ch. 9; subdivisions, App. B.
Sec. 7-81. Definitions.
The following definitions shall apply in this article:
   Accessory structure: A building subordinate to and smaller than a principal
building or mobile home, that contributes to the comfort, convenience or
necessity of the occupants of the principal building or mobile home.
   Chief building inspector: The legally designated health authority or his
authorized representative of the City of Rock Island, Illinois.
   Dependent mobile home: A dependent mobile home means a trailer home which
does not have a toilet or bath or shower facilities, and its use is prohibited
in the mobile home park.
   Independent mobile home: A transportable non-permanent single-family
dwelling unit suitable for year-round occupancy and containing the same water
supply, waste disposal, heating and air conditioning and electrical
conveniences as conventional housing, meeting "American Standard Association"
construction requirements of 1974, and subsequent revisions. This definition is
not intended to include travel trailers or camper buses.
   Mobile home: Any transportable nonpermanent single-family dwelling unit
suitable for year-round occupancy.
   Mobile home lot: A parcel of land designed for the exclusive use of the
occupants of a single mobile home, also termed mobile home space.
   Mobile home park: An area of land upon which two (2) or more occupied mobile
homes are harbored either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and this
shall include any building used or intended for use as a part of the equipment
of such mobile home parks. This does not include travel trailers, tents or
camper buses.
   Mobile home stand: That part of an individual lot which has been reserved
for the placement of the mobile home, appurtenant structures or additions.
   Permit: A written permit issued by the chief building inspector or his
designated representative permitting the mobile home park to operate under this
health code and regulations promulgated hereunder.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 1(A--L)), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-
87)
Sec. 7-82. Penalties.
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each
day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 13), 9-27-82)
Sec. 7-83. License--Required.
No person shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate a mobile home park
without first obtaining a license from the chief building inspector or his
designated representative. Such license shall be issued for one (1) year and
shall expire April 30th of each year, and the license shall be renewed from
year to year upon payment of the annual license fee provided in this article.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 2), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87; Ord.
No. 89-16, § 1, 4-3-89)
Cross reference--Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 8.
Sec. 7-84. Same--Application.
In order to obtain a permit to construct, or an original license to operate a
mobile home park, the applicant shall file with the chief building inspector or
his designated representative a written application containing the following
information:
   (1)   The full name and address of the applicant or applicants, or names and
addresses of the partners if the applicant is a partnership, or the names and
addresses of the officers if the applicant is a corporation.
   (2)   Location and legal description of the tract of land drawn to a scale
of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet, or larger.
   (3)   The proposed and existing facilities in the park for water supply,
sewage, garbage and waste disposal.
   (4)   The proposed method of lighting the structures and land upon which the
park is to be located.
   (5)   All corners and points of tangency are to be marked by galvanized or
wrought iron pipe or iron or steel bars at least eighteen (18) inches in length
and not less than one-half inch in diameter. The top of the pipe or bar is to
be set level with the established grade of the ground.
   (6)   The plat plans of the park drawn to a scale of one hundred (100) feet
to an inch, building plans and specifications for existing buildings and
facilities, and the plans and specifications for new buildings and facilities
or the proposed alterations in existing facilities, all showing compliance with
the provisions of this article. The plat plans shall contain, among other
things, the following:
      a.   The date on which such plat plans were prepared.
      b.   An arrow indicating north.
      c.   All mobile home sites properly numbered on the plat plans.
      d.   Complete information regarding storm sewers.
      e.   Storm water runoff.
   (7)   A copy of the soil and water conservation district report prepared in
accordance with 70 ILCS 405/22.02a.
   (8)   Where a permit to construct as well as an original license to operate
is sought by the applicant, request therefor shall be made in the same
application. Each application for a permit to construct or for an original
license shall be accompanied by an application fee amounting to twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) for each ten (10) acres of land, or fraction thereof, proposed
to be used as a park. Each application fee shall be paid to the city clerk, and
said application fee, once so paid, shall not be refunded.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 3), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87)
Sec. 7-85. Inspections.
   (a)   Upon receipt of an application for a permit to construct a park or an
application for a license to operate and maintain the same, the chief building
inspector or his designated representative shall, if the park is or the
proposed park will be, in conformity with this health code, issue a permit to
construct or an original license, as the case may be.
   (b)   If the application for a permit to construct or a license is declined,
the chief building inspector or his designated representative of the city shall
give the reasons therefor in writing to the applicant, and if the objections
can be corrected, the applicant may amend his application and resubmit it for
approval.
   (c)   If a permit to construct a park has been issued, the applicant shall,
upon completion thereof, notify the chief building inspector or his designated
representative, who shall then inspect the park and, if completed in accordance
with the accepted application, shall issue the license. The chief building
inspector, the electrical inspector, the plumbing inspector and the director of
public works or his designated representative must approve any new park or
additions before the inspection division will issue a permit to construct or a
license for occupancy of the mobile home park.
   (d)   No change in any methods of water supply, sewer, drainage, garbage, or
waste disposal, and no change in the plat plan, shall be made without first
making a written application to the chief building inspector or his designated
representative and receiving a permit therefrom. Such application shall be made
in the way and manner hereinbefore set forth, except that a fee of ten dollars
($10.00) for each ten (10) acres or fraction thereof used to harbor mobile
homes thereon shall accompany each application for a permit to alter such
mobile home park. No application fee shall be required to accompany an
application for a permit to alter a park where such alternative involves only a
reduction in the number of trailer spaces to a smaller number than the license
for such park currently authorizes. Such change or changes shall comply with
such safety and sanitary code, building code, rules and regulations as are
applicable thereto.
   (e)   Such permit does not relieve the applicant from securing any other
permit required or from complying with any other ordinance of the city. No
license to operate and maintain a park shall be issued if such a park is, at
such time, in violation of any other ordinance or regulation of the city.
   (f)   The annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus
five dollars ($5.00) for each mobile home lot. All fees shall be made payable
to the city.
   (g)   Applications for license shall be made to the chief building inspector
or his designated representative, who shall issue a license upon compliance by
the applicant with the provisions of this health code and of any regulations
adopted pursuant thereto, and for any other applicable legal requirements. No
license or permit shall be transferable.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 4), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, §§ 22, 25, 2-23-87;
Ord. No. 91-14, § 9, 2-11-91)
Sec. 7-86. Notices; hearings; orders.
   (a)   Whenever the chief building inspector or his designated representative
determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a
violation of any provision of this article or of any regulation adopted
pursuant hereto, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person
to whom the permit was issued, as provided in this section. Such notice shall:
      (1)   Be in writing.
      (2)   Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance.
      (3)   Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires.
      (4)   Be served upon the owner or his agent as the case may require,
provided that a notice or order shall be deemed to have been properly served
upon such owner or agent when a copy thereof has been sent by registered mail
to his last known address, or when he has been served with such notice by any
other method authorized or required by the laws of this state.
      (5)   Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect
compliance with the provisions of this health code and with regulations adopted
pursuant hereto.
   (b)   Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection
with the enforcement of any provisions of this article, or of any regulation
adopted pursuant hereto, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the
matter before the health code board of appeals, provided that such person shall
file in the office of the chief building inspector or his designated
representative a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a
statement of the grounds therefor within ten (10) days after the day the notice
was served. The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of
the notice and of the suspension, except in the case of an order issued under
subsection (e). Upon receipt of such petition, the chief building inspector or
his designated representative shall set a time and place for such hearing and
shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At such hearing, the
petitioner shall be given an opportunity to speak and to explain why such
notice should be modified or withdrawn.
   (c)   After such hearing, the health code board of appeals shall make
findings as to compliance with the provisions of this article and regulations
issued thereunder and shall issue an order in writing sustaining, modifying or
withdrawing the notice which shall be served as provided by subsection (a)(4).
Upon failure to comply with any order sustaining or modifying a notice, the
permit of the mobile home park affected by the order shall be revoked.
   (d)   The proceedings at such hearing including the findings and decision of
the health code board of appeals, together with a copy of every notice and
order related thereto, shall be entered as a matter of public record in the
office of the chief building inspector or his designated representative, but
the transcript of the proceedings need not be transcribed unless judicial
review of the decision in any court of competent jurisdiction as provided by
laws of this state is undertaken.
   (e)   Whenever the chief building inspector or his designated representative
finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the
public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the
existence of such emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he may
deem necessary to meet the emergency, including suspension of the permit.
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, such order shall be
effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall
comply therewith immediately, but, upon petition to the chief building
inspector or his designated representative, shall be afforded a hearing before
the health code board of appeals as soon as is possible.
   (f)   Any person operating or constructing a mobile home park may petition
the health code board of appeals of the city for a variance from any of the
provisions of this article.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 5), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87)
Sec. 7-87. Environmental, open space and access requirements.
   (a)   Existing parks generally. Mobile home parks in existence on the
effective date of this article which have less than the minimum prescribed
requirements, other than the minimum area requirements specified in subsection
(b), may continue to operate.
   (b)   Minimum area. Present existing mobile home parks shall not be required
to comply with the minimum area requirements of this article, but may continue
to operate with their present minimum area of not less than one thousand five
hundred (1,500) square feet for each mobile home.
   (c)   Expansion of size. Any presently existing mobile home park that
expands the size of its park shall be required to comply with all provisions of
this article in its expanded area.
   (d)   Nonresidential uses. No part of any mobile home park shall be used for
nonresidential purposes, except such uses that are required for the direct
servicing and well-being of park residents and for the maintenance of the park.
No commercial establishments shall be operated in any mobile home park except
those operated by the owner of said park for mobile home park occupants. Such
establishments shall present no visible evidence from any street outside the
mobile home park of their commercial character which would attract customers
other than mobile home park occupants.
   (e)   Setbacks on lot. Mobile homes shall be located not less than six (6)
feet from the side or rear lot lines of the lot upon which they are located,
except that every mobile home lot shall contain a minimum of three thousand two
hundred (3,200) square feet. All roofed-over patios and carports shall be
considered part of the mobile home.
   (f)   Accessory structures. Any accessory structure, such as storage
facilities, shall be located no closer than three (3) feet from the side and
rear lot lines and three (3) feet from the mobile home and shall be located on
the rear half of said lot.
   (g)   Setbacks, buffer strips and screening generally.
      (1)   All mobile homes shall be located at least twenty-five (25) feet
from any park property boundary line abutting upon a public street or highway
and at least ten (10) feet from any other park property boundary lines. There
shall be a minimum distance of ten (10) feet between an individual mobile home,
including accessory structures attached thereto, and adjoining pavement of park
street or sidewalk, or common parking area, or other common areas accessible to
park residents.
      (2)   All mobile home parks shall be provided with a screening buffer
strip at least five (5) feet wide along all property boundary lines. Where
effective visual barriers do not already exist along such property boundary
lines, the buffer strip shall be furnished with screening at least five (5)
feet high and consisting of fences, free-standing walls or natural growth. Such
growth shall consist of a compact growth of shrubbery, hedges, evergreens or
other suitable plantings sufficient to serve as an effective visual screen.
Fences or walls shall not contain electrical charges, barbed wire, broken glass
or other material designed to do bodily harm.
   (h)   Park street system.
      (1)   General requirements. All mobile home parks shall provide safe,
continuous and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or
roads to each mobile home space. For purposes of this article, all streets or
roads providing such vehicular access hereinafter shall be referred to as the
"park street system" and shall be maintained by the owner or owners.
      (2)   Primary entrance road. The primary entrance road connecting the
park street system with a public street or road shall have a minimum road
pavement width of forty-one (41) feet, where guest parking is permitted at both
sides; or a minimum road pavement width of twenty-five (25) feet, where guest
parking is limited to one side. Where the primary entrance road is more than
one hundred (100') feet long and does not provide access to abutting property
within such distance, the minimum road width may be twenty-five (25) feet,
provided parking is prohibited at both sides.
      (3)   Secondary entrance road. In addition to the required primary
entrance road, all parks containing twenty-five (25) or more acres in total
area and/or providing for the accommodation of two hundred (200) or more mobile
homes, shall have at least one secondary entrance road connecting the park
street system with a public street or road. Such a secondary road or roads
shall have a minimum pavement width of twenty-five (25) feet. Where primary and
secondary entrance roads connect to the same public street or road, there shall
be a minimum separation of one hundred-fifty (150) feet between such access
points. Where this is not feasible or possible, there shall be clearly marked
one-way entrance and exit lanes with a pavement width of each one-way road to
be at least twenty-two (22) feet.
      (4)   Interior streets. All interior streets in the park street system
shall have a minimum pavement width of twenty-five (25) feet on a twenty-five-
foot right-of-way with parking prohibited on one side. Dead-end streets shall
be limited in length to one thousand (1,000) feet and shall be provided at the
closed end with a turn-around having an outside roadway diameter of at least
sixty-five (65) feet.
      (5)   Street construction standards shall meet the requirements of the
subdivision regulations of the city, as amended.
   (i)   Parking: Off street parking shall be provided in all parks for the use
of park occupants. Such areas shall be furnished at the rate of at least two
(2) car spaces for each mobile home. Parking bays shall be located so as to
provide convenient access to mobile home spaces.
   (j)   Sidewalks: All mobile home parks shall provide safe, convenient, four
foot (4') wide, four inch (4") Portland cement concrete sidewalks on both sides
of the park street system between each mobile home space and all open areas,
community structures and facilities.
   (k)   Electricity; Lighting: All mobile home parks shall be furnished with
sufficient electrical systems and lighting units at the owner's expense, so
spaced and equipped with luminaires placed at such mounting heights as will
provide the average maintained levels of illumination for the safe movement of
pedestrians and vehicles at night, as required for city streets by the city
engineer, with guidance from Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company. (Ord. 82-
28, § 1(Art. V, § 6), 9-27-1982)
Sec. 7-88. Water Supply:
Each mobile home park shall be provided with a complete water distribution
system adequate to serve the entire park. The water system must be designed in
conformance with the requirements of the subdivision regulations of the city
and meet the approval of the director of public works or his designated
representative. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 7), 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-
23-1987)
Sec. 7-89. Storm Water Sewers:
Each mobile home park shall be provided with a storm water sewer adequate to
serve the entire park. The storm water sewer system must be designed in
conformance with the requirements of the subdivision regulations of the city
and meet the approval of the director of public works or his designated
representative. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 8), 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-
23-1987)
Sec. 7-90. Sanitary Sewers:
Each mobile home park shall provide for the satisfactory disposal of sanitary
sewage. The sanitary sewer system shall be designed in conformance with the
requirements of the subdivision regulations of the city and meet the approval
of the director of public works or his designated representative. (Ord. 82-28,
§ 1(Art. V, § 9) 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-91. Refuse Disposal:
Disposal of refuse shall follow the standards set in chapter 13, article II of
this code. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 10), 9-27-1982)
Sec. 7-92. Electrical Distribution System:
The electrical system of each mobile home park shall be adequate to serve the
entire park. The electrical system shall be designed in conformance with the
requirements of the subdivision regulations of the city and approved by the
director of public works or his designated representative. (Ord. 82-28, § 1
(Art. V, § 11), 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-93. Safety:
Liquid petroleum gas, fuel oil, gasoline and other flammable liquids shall be
handled and used in a safe manner and shall not be stored inside or beneath any
mobile home. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 12), 9-27-1982)
Secs. 7-94-7-110. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. ANIMALS 1 , 2
 
Notes
  See § 10-8, "Cruelty To Animals Generally"; § 10-24 et seq., noisy animals; §
1 10-49, "Steel Jaw Animal Traps"; § 10-69, "Police Dogs"; and § 13-29, "Dead
  Animals", of this code.
2 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 7-111. Definitions:
The following words and phrases when used in this article shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   Animal: Any animal, poultry, bird, reptile or any other dumb creature.
   Animal Control Officer: Any person employed by the department for the
purpose of enforcing the animal control ordinances or having custody and
control of the city animal shelter and of animals therein.
   Cat: Except where specifically distinguished means all animals of the feline
species of the age of four (4) months or older.
   Dangerous Animal:
      (1)   Any animal that while off the property of the owner or custodian of
the animal unreasonably and without provocation causes injury to a person.
      (2)   Any animal that while off the property of the owner or custodian of
the animal unreasonably attacks another domestic animal and causes serious
physical injury or death to the other domesticated animal.
      (3)   Any animal that while on the property of the owner or custodian of
the animal unreasonably attacks and causes injury to any person lawfully on the
property of the owner.
      (4)   Any animal that has been declared a "potentially dangerous animal"
on one prior occasion and is found upon investigation of a new incident to meet
the definition of "potentially dangerous animal".
   Department: The department of police, unless otherwise specifically
designated.
   Distemper And Hepatitis Injection: Any serum approved by the Illinois
department of agriculture for temporary use.
   Dog: Except where specifically distinguished means all animals of the canine
species of the age of four (4) months or older.
   Impounded: Taken into the custody of the public pound in the city or county
where the animal is found.
   Inoculation: The injection, subcutaneously or in such other manner as may be
approved by the department of agriculture of the state of Illinois pursuant to
the rabies control law of the state, of antirabic vaccine meeting standards
approved by the department of agriculture of the state and by the United States
department of agriculture.
   Licensed Veterinarian: Any veterinarian duly licensed as such under the laws
of the state of Illinois or of any other state which by law provides for the
licensing of veterinarians.
   Owner Or Keeper: Any person who shall harbor, suffer or permit any dog or
cat to remain on any premises within the city of Rock Island under his charge.
   Potentially Dangerous Animal:
      (1)   Any individual animal while off the premises of the owner and when
unmuzzled, unleashed, or not under the control of its owner or custodian that
behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe poses a serious and
unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death to a person or
domesticated companion animal.
      (2)   Any animal that has been declared a "dangerous animal" on a prior
occasion and that is not properly confined as required by subsection
7-117.1(g) of this division.
      (3)   Any animal that while off the property of the owner or custodian of
the animal unreasonably attacks and causes injury to another domesticated
animal.
   Serious Physical Injury: Shall include, but not be limited by, those
instances where the animal causes serious or permanent disfigurement or
impairment to health or bodily function of the person.
   Unreasonably Attacks: An unprovoked and unjustified direct action on the
part of the animal.
   Vicious Animal:
      (1)   Any animal that unreasonably attacks a person and causes serious
physical injury or death.
      (2)   Any animal that has been declared a "dangerous animal" on one prior
occasion and is found upon investigation of a new incident to meet the
definition of "dangerous animal". (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-25, § 1, 9-13-
1982; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§§ 1-3), 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, § 1, 11-3-1986; Ord. 87-
81, § 1, 10-5-1987; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-112. Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this article shall be
seventy five dollars ($75.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation
of this article and does not wish to contest said allegation prior to the time
a complaint is issued for the violation, the person so accused may pay to the
city, at police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of seventy five dollars
($75.00) for and in full satisfaction of said violation. (Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord.
82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984; Ord. 91-136, 12-9-1991)
Sec. 7-113. Animal Shelter:
The city shall provide and maintain an animal shelter suitable for the
impounding and maintenance of dogs and other small animals and shall provide
and furnish all other equipment and supplies required in the application of
this article. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-114. Animal Control Officer:
   (a)   The animal control officer shall be a staff member of the department
of police and shall be directly responsible to the chief of police in the
application of this article and the proper operation of the animal shelter.
   (b)   The animal control officer shall have the care, custody, control and
supervision of the animal shelter of the city and of all dogs and other animals
confined and impounded therein, and shall have the care, custody and control of
all trucks and other paraphernalia used by him or his assistants in and about
the impounding of such animals.
   (c)   All assistants assigned to the animal control program shall be
responsible to the chief of police in the performance of their duties.
   (d)   While on duty, the animal control officer shall wear a star engraved
"Animal Control Officer" as an emblem of this authority.
   (e)   The animal control officer shall deliver to the city collector, at
least once a month, all fees and monies collected by him.
   (f)   Any animal kept or found under the conditions which may constitute a
violation of this article may be impounded by the animal control officer.
(Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, 11-3-1986)
Sec. 7-115. Cruelty To Animals 3 :
No person or owner shall beat, cruelly treat, torment, starve, overwork or
otherwise abuse any animal. Each owner shall provide for each of his animals:
   (1)   Sufficient quantity of good quality, wholesome food and water, served
in clean containers with water available at all times;
   (2)   Adequate shelter and protection from the weather; and
   (3)   Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering.
No owner shall abandon any animal where it shall become a public charge or
shall suffer injury, hunger, or exposure. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-
1982; Ord. 86-56, 11-3-1986)
 
Notes
3 510 ILCS 70/3.01.
Sec. 7-116. Running At Large Generally:
   (a)   No domestic animal, including horses, mules, cattle, sheep, swine or
domestic fowl of the species of geese, ducks, turkeys, chickens, or barn fowl
shall be suffered, allowed or permitted to run at large within the corporate
limits of the city.
   (b)   Any dog shall be considered to be running at large if it leaves the
premises of its owner or keeper when not under control by leash and a person
who is willing and able to prevent the dog from violating any city ordinance.
   (c)   Every animal running at large within the city shall be liable for
impoundment at any time by the animal control officer or other member of the
police department. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 54-2003, § 1,
7-14-2003)
Sec. 7-117. Vicious Animal:
   (a)   Vicious Animals Prohibited: No person shall own, keep, harbor, sell,
abandon or give away any animal found to be vicious within the city, whether or
not owned by such person, except to relinquish the animal for impoundment. Such
animals are hereby declared nuisances and are subject to impoundment and
disposal.
   (b)   Declaration Of Animal As Vicious; Procedure:
      (1)   The Rock Island animal control officer or law enforcement officer
shall classify an animal as vicious if probable cause is established to believe
that the animal falls within the definition set forth for "vicious animal" in
section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division.
The finding must be based upon: a) the written complaint of a citizen who is
willing to testify that the animal has acted in a manner which causes it to
fall within the definition of "vicious animal" as set forth in section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division; or b) the reports filed with the police
department; or c) actions of the animal witnessed by any animal control
officer, law enforcement officer or citizen who is willing to sign a complaint;
or d) other substantial evidence.
      (2)   Once the police department becomes aware of an animal that may fall
within the definition of "vicious animal" as set forth in section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division, an animal control officer or law
enforcement officer shall complete an investigation within five (5) days with a
recommendation as to whether or not the animal should be declared a vicious
animal. During this investigation, the animal shall be impounded at the animal
control facility utilized by the city.
This recommendation shall be reviewed with the animal's owner and the victim,
or the victim's parent/guardian if the victim is a minor. If either of these
persons should choose to dispute this recommendation, the investigating animal
control officer or law enforcement officer shall consult: a) a board certified
veterinarian who deals with this type of animal or b) an animal behavior
specialist who has completed a certification or formal program of education in
a related field or has at least three (3) years of work experience in a related
field. The opinion of the veterinarian or animal behavior specialist shall then
be used as the basis for the final recommendation on the declaration of the
animal as vicious. The results of this consultation shall also be shared with
the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's parent/guardian if the
victim is a minor.
      (3)   The declaration of vicious animal shall be in writing and shall be
served on the owner in one of the following methods: a) certified mail to the
owner's last known address; or b) personally; or c) if the owner cannot be
located by one of the first two (2) methods, by publication in a newspaper of
general circulation in this community.
      (4)   The declaration shall state at least: a) the description of the
animal; b) the name and address of the owner of the animal, if known; c) the
whereabouts of the animal, if it is not in the custody of the owner; d) the
facts upon which the declaration of vicious animal is based; e) the
availability of a hearing in case the person objects to the declaration, if a
request is made within ten (10) days; f) the fact that the animal shall be
euthanized after ten (10) days unless a request for a hearing has been
received.
   (c)   Owner Objection To Declaration Of Vicious Animal: If the owner of the
animal wishes to object to the declaration of the animal as vicious:
      (1)   The owner may request a hearing before the code hearing officer, by
submitting a written request and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00)
administrative review fee to the city within ten (10) days of receipt of the
declaration, or within ten (10) days of the publication of the declaration
pursuant to subsection (b)(3) of this section.
      (2)   If the code hearing officer finds that there is insufficient
evidence to support the declaration, it shall be rescinded, and the penalty to
be imposed thereby annulled.
      (3)   If the code hearing officer finds sufficient evidence to support
the declaration, the owner may appeal such decision to the circuit court,
pursuant to the administrative review act.
      (4)   During the entire appeal process, the animal shall be held at the
animal control facility utilized by the city.
   (d)   Disposal Of Vicious Animal: Following a declaration of an animal as
vicious and the exhaustion of any appeal therefrom, the animal shall be
euthanized. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-25, 9-13-1982; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982;
Ord. 86-56, 11-3-1986; Ord. 87-81, 10-5-1987; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-117.1. Dangerous Animal:
   (a)   Directing Animal With Malicious Intent Prohibited: No person having
control or custody of any animal shall, without legal cause or justification,
direct, encourage, cause, allow, or otherwise aid or assist any animal to
threaten, charge at, intimidate, bite, harass, menace, or attack any person
within the city.
   (b)   Use Of Animal In Illegal Activity Prohibited: No person shall keep,
maintain, control, or retain custody of any animal in conjunction with or for
the purpose, whether in whole or in part, of aiding, abetting, or conducting
any illegal activity or committing any crime within the city.
   (c)   Directing Animal With Malicious Intent Toward Public Safety Officer
Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person having control or custody of
any animal to allow, direct, encourage, cause, or otherwise aid or assist any
animal to threaten, charge, intimidate, bite, harass, menace, or attack any
public safety officer engaged in the conduct of his/her duties.
   (d)   Probable Cause To Impound: Any law enforcement officer having probable
cause to believe that any person has violated the restrictions against
dangerous animals hereof may impound or cause to be impounded any animal. Such
impoundment shall be subject to all other sections of this article and all
other municipal laws, including, but not limited to, this code dealing with
animals.
   (e)   Declaration Of Animal As Dangerous; Procedure:
      (1)   The Rock Island animal control officer or law enforcement officer
shall classify an animal as dangerous if probable cause is established to
believe that the animal falls within the definition set forth for "dangerous
animal" in section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division.
The finding must be based upon: a) the written complaint of a citizen who is
willing to testify that the animal has acted in a manner which causes it to
fall within the definition of "dangerous animal"; or b) reports filed with the
police department; or c) actions of the animal witnessed by any animal control
officer, law enforcement officer or citizen who is willing to sign a complaint;
or d) other substantial evidence.
      (2)   Once the police department becomes aware of an animal that may fall
within the definition of "dangerous animal" set forth in section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division, an animal control officer or law
enforcement officer shall complete an investigation within five (5) days with a
recommendation as to whether or not the animal should be declared a dangerous
animal. During this investigation, the animal shall be impounded at the animal
control facility utilized by the city.
This recommendation shall be reviewed with the animal's owner and the victim,
or the victim's parent/guardian if the victim is a minor. If either of these
persons should choose to dispute this recommendation, the investigating animal
control officer or law enforcement officer shall consult: a) a board certified
veterinarian who deals with this type of animal or b) an animal behavior
specialist who has completed a certification or formal program of education in
a related field or has at least three (3) years of work experience in a related
field. The opinion of the veterinarian or animal behavior specialist shall then
be used as the basis for the final recommendation on the declaration of the
animal as a dangerous animal. The results of this consultation shall also be
shared with the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's parent/guardian
if the victim is a minor.
      (3)   The declaration of dangerous animal shall be in writing and shall
be served on the owner in one of the following methods: a) certified mail to
the owner's last known address; or b) personally; or c) if the owner cannot be
located by one of the first two (2) methods, by publication in a newspaper of
general circulation in this community.
      (4)   The declaration shall state at least: a) the description of the
animal; b) the name and address of the owner of the animal, if known; c) the
whereabouts of the animal, if it is not in the custody of the owner; d) the
facts upon which the declaration of dangerous animal is based; e) the
availability of a hearing in case the person objects to the declaration, if a
request is made within ten (10) days; f) the restrictions placed on the animal
as a result of the declaration of dangerous animal; g) the penalties for
violation of the restrictions, including the possibility of destruction of the
animal, and/or fining of the owner.
   (f)   Owner Objection To Declaration Of Dangerous Animal: If the owner of
the animal wishes to object to the declaration of dangerous animal:
      (1)   The owner may request a hearing before the code hearing officer, by
submitting a written request and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00)
administrative review fee to the city within ten (10) days of receipt of the
declaration, or within ten (10) days of the publication of the declaration
pursuant to subsection (e)(3) of this section.
      (2)   If the code hearing officer finds that there is insufficient
evidence to support the declaration, it shall be rescinded, and the
restrictions imposed thereby annulled.
      (3)   If the code hearing officer finds sufficient evidence to support
the declaration, the owner may appeal such decision to the circuit court,
pursuant to the administrative review act.
   (g)   Confinement Of Dangerous Animal: Following a declaration of dangerous
animal and during the entire appeal process or after the exhaustion of any
appeal therefrom, it shall be unlawful for the person owning or having care of
such dangerous animal to allow or permit such animal to: 1) be unconfined on
the premises of such person; or 2) go beyond the premises of such person unless
such animal is securely leashed and muzzled. The leash shall be no longer than
six feet (6') in length. The muzzle shall be made in such a manner that it will
not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but
will prevent it from biting or causing injury to any person or animal. Being
confined on the premises shall consist of the animal being kept: 1) within the
residence or other building, or 2) within an enclosure from which the animal
cannot escape and with openings no more than two and one-half inches (21/2") in
width, or 3) on a run line or chain within an area enclosed by a fence that the
animal is unable to reach and that prevents the entry of small children.
Additionally, signs indicating the presence of a dangerous animal on the
property shall be posted on any enclosure and at the most conspicuous points of
entry to the property. The dangerous or potentially dangerous animal shall not
be returned to the person owning or having care of such animal until these
conditions are met to the satisfaction of the animal control officer.
   (h)   Notification Of Status Of Dangerous Animal: The owner of an animal
which has been classified as dangerous shall immediately notify the police
department when the animal: 1) is loose or unconfined; 2) has bitten a human
being or attacked another animal; 3) is sold or given away, or dies; 4) is
moved to another address.
   (i)   Sale Of Dangerous Animal: Prior to selling or giving away an animal
that has been classified as dangerous, the owner shall provide the name,
address, and telephone number of the new owner to the police department and
shall certify to the police department that the new owner has been notified of
such classification. The new owner shall comply with all of the requirements of
this section.
   (j)   Custodial Liability: In the event the owner or keeper of the dangerous
animal is a minor, the custodian, parent, or guardian, legally responsible for
such minor shall be liable for all injuries and property damage sustained by
any person or domestic animal caused by an unprovoked attack by said dangerous
animal.
   (k)   Penalty For Violation: Any person who violates a provision of this
section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount not
exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). In addition, any person found
guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter,
food, veterinary expenses for identification or certification of the breed of
the animal or boarding and veterinary expenses necessitated by the seizure of
any animal for the protection of the public, and such other expenses as may be
required for the destruction of any such animal. Any dangerous animal that is
in violation of the restrictions contained in subsection (g) of this section or
restrictions imposed as part of a declaration as a dangerous animal shall be
seized and impounded. (Ord. 98-09, 1-19-1998; Ord. 54-2003, § 2, 7-14-2003;
Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-117.2. Potentially Dangerous Animal:
   (a)   Declaration Of Animal As Potentially Dangerous; Procedure:
      (1)   The Rock Island animal control officer or law enforcement officer
shall classify an animal as potentially dangerous if probable cause is
established to believe that the animal falls within the definitions set forth
for "potentially dangerous animal" in section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division.
The finding must be based upon: a) the written complaint of a citizen who is
willing to testify that the animal has acted in a manner which causes it to
fall within the definition of "potentially dangerous animal"; or b) reports
filed with the police department; or c) actions of the animal witnessed by any
animal control officer, law enforcement officer or citizen who is willing to
sign a complaint; or d) other substantial evidence.
      (2)   Once the police department becomes aware of an animal that may fall
within the definition of "potentially dangerous animal" set forth in section
7-111, "Definitions", of this division, an animal control officer or law
enforcement officer shall complete an investigation within five (5) days with a
recommendation as to whether or not the animal should be declared a potentially
dangerous animal. During this investigation, the animal shall be impounded at
the animal control facility utilized by the city.
This recommendation shall be reviewed with the animal's owner and the victim,
or the victim's parent/guardian if the victim is a minor. If either of these
persons should choose to dispute this recommendation, the investigating animal
control officer or law enforcement officer shall consult: a) a board certified
veterinarian who deals with this type of animal or b) an animal behavior
specialist who has completed a certification or formal program of education in
a related field or has at least three (3) years of work experience in a related
field. The opinion of the veterinarian or animal behavior specialist shall then
be used as the basis for the final recommendation on the declaration of the
animal as a potentially dangerous animal. The results of this consultation
shall also be shared with the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's
parent/guardian if the victim is a minor.
      (3)   The declaration of potentially dangerous animal shall be in writing
and shall be served on the owner in one of the following methods: a) certified
mail to the owner's last known address; or b) personally; or c) if the owner
cannot be located by one of the first two (2) methods, by publication in a
newspaper of general circulation in this community.
      (4)   The declaration shall state at least: a) the description of the
animal; b) the name and address of the owner of the animal, if known; c) the
whereabouts of the animal, if it is not in the custody of the owner; d) the
facts upon which the declaration of potentially dangerous animal is based; e)
the availability of a hearing in case the person objects to the declaration, if
a request is made within ten (10) days; f) the restrictions placed on the
animal as a result of the declaration of potentially dangerous animal; g) the
penalties for violation of the restrictions, including the possibility of
destruction of the animal, and/or fining of the owner.
   (b)   Owner Objection To Declaration Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: If the
owner of the animal wishes to object to the declaration of potentially
dangerous animal:
      (1)   The owner may request a hearing before the code hearing officer, by
submitting a written request and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00)
administrative review fee to the city within ten (10) days of receipt of the
declaration, or within ten (10) days of the publication of the declaration
pursuant to subsection (a)(3) of this section.
      (2)   If the code hearing officer finds that there is insufficient
evidence to support the declaration, it shall be rescinded, and the
restrictions imposed thereby annulled.
      (3)   If the code hearing officer finds sufficient evidence to support
the declaration, the owner may appeal such decision to the circuit court,
pursuant to the administrative review act.
   (c)   Restriction Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: Following a declaration
of potentially dangerous animal and during the entire appeal process or after
the exhaustion of any appeal therefrom, it shall be unlawful for the person
owning or having care of such potentially dangerous animal to allow or permit
such animal to go beyond the premises of such person unless such animal is
securely leashed and muzzled. The leash shall be no longer than six feet (6')
in length. The muzzle shall be made in such a manner that it will not cause
injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but will
prevent it from biting or causing injury to any person or animal.
   (d)   Notification Of Status Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: The owner of
an animal which has been classified as potentially dangerous shall immediately
notify the police department when the animal: 1) is loose; 2) has bitten a
human being or attacked another animal; 3) is sold or given away, or dies; 4)
is moved to another address.
   (e)   Sale Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: Prior to selling or giving away
an animal that has been classified as potentially dangerous, the owner shall
provide the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner to the police
department and shall certify to the police department that the new owner has
been notified of such classification. The new owner shall comply with all of
the requirements of this section.
   (f)   Custodial Liability: In the event the owner or keeper of the
potentially dangerous animal is a minor, the custodian, parent, or guardian,
legally responsible for such minor shall be liable for all injuries and
property damage sustained by any person or domestic animal caused by an
unprovoked attack by said potentially dangerous animal.
   (g)   Penalty For Violation: Any person who violates a provision of this
section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount not
exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). In addition, any person found
guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter,
food, veterinary expenses for identification or certification of the breed of
the animal or boarding and veterinary expenses necessitated by the seizure of
any animal for the protection of the public, and such other expenses as may be
required for the destruction of any such animal. Any potentially dangerous
animal that is in violation of the restrictions contained in subsection (c) of
this section or restrictions imposed as part of a declaration as a potentially
dangerous animal shall be seized and impounded. (Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-
2005)
Sec. 7-118. Surrender Of Unclaimed Impounded Animals For The Purposes Of
Medical Research:
   (a)   Whenever any reputable institutions of learning, hospitals, research
laboratories or their allied institutes within a reasonable distance of the
city shall make application to the chief of police or his authorized agent for
permission to use humanely unclaimed impounded animals for the good of mankind
and the increase of knowledge relating to the cause, prevention, control and
cure of disease, the chief of police or his authorized agent, upon being
satisfied that the animals are to be so used, shall, from time to time, release
such acceptable unclaimed impounded animals for medical research or otherwise
as above specified.
   (b)   In order to give the owners of impounded animals time within which to
reclaim the same, no animal shall be surrendered for such uses until it has
been impounded for a period of at least seven (7) days.
   (c)   No impounded animal wearing an unexpired county tag may be released
for purposes of medical research. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982;
Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-119. Authority To Enter Premises:
For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this article upon the
department, the animal control officer, any sworn police officer or any member
of the department is hereby authorized and directed to enter upon any premises
upon which any dog or cat is kept or harbored and to demand the exhibition by
the person owning or having charge or control of such dog or cat, of the
license tag for such dog or cat. Whenever there are reasonable grounds to
believe that there has been a violation, each member of the department or any
sworn police officer is hereby authorized and directed to enter upon any such
premises for the purpose of inspecting the same to ascertain if any provision
of this article or of any law of the state relating to the care, treatment or
impounding of dumb animals or for the prevention of cruelty thereto is being
violated. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-120. Animal Bites:
All bites or attacks on human beings by any animal within the city shall be
immediately reported to the chief of police. In the event of a bite by an
animal, a detailed report shall be completed by the receiving officer including
the complainant's name, address and phone number, the name and address of the
owner of such animal, if known, and the doctor treating the wound. (Ord., 12-3-
1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-121. Public Nuisance:
It is unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any
dangerous or potentially dangerous animal to leave the premises of its owner
when not under control by leash or other recognized control methods.
Professionally trained guide dogs for the blind or hearing impaired, support
dogs for the physically handicapped, and sentry, guard, or police owned dogs
are exempt from this section; provided, an attack or injury to a person occurs
while the dog is performing duties as expected. To qualify for exemption under
this section, each such dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies in
accordance with 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8. It shall be the duty of the
owner of such exempted dog to notify the animal control officer of this city of
changes of address. In the case of a sentry or guard dog, the owner shall keep
the animal control officer advised of the location where such dog will be
stationed. The animal control officer shall provide police and fire departments
with a categorized list of such exempted dogs, and shall promptly notify such
departments of any address changes reported to him. (Ord. 87-81, 10-5-1987;
Ord. 54-2003, § 3, 7-14-2003; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Secs. 7-122-7-135. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. DOGS AND CATS GENERALLY
Sec. 7-136. Inoculation Required:
   Every owner or keeper of a dog or cat within the limits of the city shall
have a valid rabies inoculation certificate issued by the state department of
agriculture. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 002-2020, 1-13-
2020)
Sec. 7-137. Rabies:
Any animal which comes under the Illinois rabies control law will be handled as
provided by this law. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 002-2020,
1-13- 2020)
Sec. 7-138. Nonresident Owners:
   The provisions of this article relating to the licensing of dogs and cats
shall not apply to dogs or cats of nonresidents remaining temporarily in or
passing through the city, provided that such dogs or cats have a license from
some other jurisdiction. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 002-
2020, 1-13-2020)
Sec. 7-139. Licensing:
   (a)   Every person other than those excepted that owns, harbors, keeps, or
controls a dog or cat within the City of Rock Island shall within thirty (30)
days of acquisition of the dog or cat, register the dog or cat or cause it to
be registered for a license with the County of Rock Island. The license tag
shall be securely attached to a substantial collar or harness and shall at all
times be kept on the dog or cat for which the license is issued.
   (b)   New residents and persons acquiring in any manner whatsoever a new dog
or cat shall have thirty (30) days in which to obtain a county license. (Ord.
002-2020, 1- 13-2020)
Sec. 7-140. Display of License-Tag:
   It shall be a violation for any person to be in control of a dog over the
age of six (6) months that does not have a visibly displayed license tag
affixed to its collar when it leaves the premises of its owner or keeper. In
the event a dog is found to be without a license tag displayed, the animal
control officer or other member of the police department may impound or cause
to be impounded said dog. Said dog shall be released from impoundment upon
proof of a valid license tag issued by the city or other government body having
jurisdiction over the dog's owner or keeper or proof that such jurisdiction has
no such requirement. (Ord. 54-2003, § 4, 7-14-2003; Ord. 002-2020, 1-13-2020)
Sec. 7-141. Sanitation:
   The owner or keeper of any dog or cat in the city shall keep the area where
the animal is kept clean and odor free at all times. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-
41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 002-2020, 1-13-2020)
Sec. 7-142. Defecation on Public Property:
   No owner or keeper of any pet shall permit said pet to defecate on any
public way or public property or upon any private property without the
permission of the occupant or the owner of the private property without
immediately removing said defecation and depositing same in a refuse container
or similar depository. (Ord. 86-21, 5-5-1986; Ord. 56-2004, § 1, 5-10-2004;
Ord. 002-2020, 1-13-2020)
Sec. 7-143. Health and Cruelty:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any animal owner or person to cruelly deprive
food, water, shelter, and protection to any animal under their control and/or
custody, or to abandon, poison, cruelly beat, cruelly whip or kill any animal
under their, another's or no one's control and/or custody, or to mutilate,
overdrive, overload, overwork, torment, torture or otherwise cruelly ill use
any animal. This section shall not apply to wild animals killed in the hunt
(not within city limits) by customary and non-brutal methods nor to wild rats,
mice, insects, fish, arthropods or vermin; nor shall this section apply to
medical research organizations duly licensed and/or otherwise recognized or
supported by state or federal law.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any animal owner to permit, either willfully
or through failure to exercise due care and control, any animal to bark, cry,
howl, whine or cause other objectionable noises which disturb the comfort,
peace, quiet or repose of any person residing in the vicinity.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any animal owner, either willfully or through
failure to exercise due care and control, to maintain an animal or the premises
upon which the animal is maintained, in such a manner as to emit such offensive
odors which disturb the comfort, peace or repose of any person residing in the
vicinity.
   (d)   It shall be unlawful for any animal owner to abandon any animal where
it may become a public charge, or may suffer injury, hunger or exposure.
   (e)   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 92-149, § 3,
12-21-1992; Ord. 002-2020, 1-13-2020)
Sec. 7-144. Commercial Kennels, Pet Shops, Breeders, And Animal Rescuers And
Rehabilitators:
   (a)   Definitions:
   Animal Care Facility: An animal control center or animal shelter, maintained
by or under contract with any state, county, or municipality, whose mission and
practice is, in whole, or significant part, the rescue and placement of animals
in permanent homes or rescue organizations.
   Animal Rescue Organization: Any not-for-profit organization which has tax-
exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue
Code, whose mission and practice is, in whole or in significant part, the
rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes. This term does not include
any entity, which is, or is housed on the premises of, a breeder or broker,
obtains dogs from a breeder or broker in exchange for payment or compensation,
or resells dogs obtained from a breeder or broker and provides payment or
compensation to such breeder or broker.
   Breeder: A person or persons who own or breed dogs and/or cats primarily for
personal recreational use, such as participation in recognized conformation
shows, field or obedience trials, racing, scenting, specialized hunting or
working trials, and water trials, and for the purpose of improving the physical
soundness, temperament, and conformation of a given breed to standard, such
person to sell or exchange, at retail only, and other than for purposes of
research, testing, or experimentation, dogs or cats bred from male/female dogs
or cats owned or leased by the breeders.
   Commercial Kennel: A structure or premises where dogs and cats over four (4)
months of age are kept, or boarded for commercial purposes, excluding animal
hospitals, clinics and pet shops.
   Offer for Sale: To sell, offer for sale or adoption, advertise for the sale
of, barter, auction, give away or otherwise dispose of an animal including dogs
and cats.
   Pet Shop: A retail establishment where live animals are sold, exchanged,
bartered or offered for sale as pet animals to the general public at retail.
Such definition shall not include an animal care facility or animal rescue
organization, as defined.
   (b)   No pet shop shall sell, deliver, offer for sale, barter, auction, give
away, or otherwise transfer or dispose of cats or dogs. Nothing in this section
shall prohibit pet stores from collaborating with animal care facilities or
animal rescue organizations to offer space for such entities to showcase
adoptable dogs and cats. (Ord. 002-2020, 1- 13-2020)
Secs. 7-145–7-155. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. IMPOUNDMENT
Sec. 7-156. Authorized.
   (a)   The owner, possessor or keeper of any dog or cat shall keep his dog or
cat under restraint at all times. Such dog or cat shall not be at large off the
premises or property of such owner, possessor or keeper unless under the
control of a competent person.
   (b)   A dog is under restraint within the meaning of this section if it is
controlled by a leash attached to a collar or harness, "at heel" beside a
competent person and is obedient to that person's commands, or when under the
control of a competent person on or within a vehicle being driven or parked on
the street.
   (c)   A cat is under restraint within the meaning of this section if it is
controlled by a leash or confined.
   (d)   (1) Every dog or cat running at large within the city shall be subject
to impoundment at any time by the animal control officer.
      (2)   The owner of any dog or cat that is impounded and claims that
animal shall pay a penalty of the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first
impoundment.
      (3)   Any dog or cat that is impounded a second time within a one year
period shall be altered. The owner shall pay a penalty in the sum of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for a second impoundment and in addition thereto the
reasonable cost for the mandatory altering of the animal if the altering would
not endanger the health of the animal. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§
2), 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, § 1, 11-3-1986; Ord. 92-149, § 4, 12-21-1992; Ord.
88-2004, § 1, 9-20-2004)
Sec. 7-157. Duty Of Animal Control Officer Generally:
The animal control officer shall impound, or cause to be impounded, and shall
dispose of according to the provisions of this article, all dogs running at
large within the city and shall keep a record of every dog so impounded,
describing the breed, color and sex, together with the time and place such dog
was captured or received and the final disposition made of each dog, together
with such other information as may come to his attention. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-
1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 4), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-158. Records:
The animal control officer or the person in charge of the animal shelter to
which any dog or cat is taken in accordance with the provisions of section
7-156 of this division, shall immediately enter in a register the breed, color
and sex of such dog or cat, whether licensed or not, and if licensed, the name
and address of the owner or keeper. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§
2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-159. Notice To Owner:
When the owner of any impounded dog or cat is known, he shall be notified by
telephone or mail immediately after its impoundment by the person in charge of
the animal shelter. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-160. Claiming After Impoundment:
The owner of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article must
claim the animal within seven (7) days from the date of impounding upon payment
of the following fees to the animal control officer:
      (1)   The amount of the license fee for the current year, if not paid.
      (2)   The amount of the current veterinarian fee for rabies inoculation,
if a valid certificate is not shown.
      (3)   The amount for the temporary hepatitis and distemper injection for
dogs under one year of age.
