      (4)   A redemption fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first
impounding and a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for subsequent impounding within
a year and in addition thereto the cost of altering as set forth in section
7-156 of this division if there has been a second offense.
      (5)   Residents shall pay a fee of three dollars fifty cents ($3.50) for
each day the animal has been impounded. Nonresidents shall pay a fee of five
dollars ($5.00) for each day the animal has been impounded. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-
1973; Ord., § 1, 3-17-1975; Ord., § 1, 11-7-1977; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-
1982; Ord. 85-30, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. 87-34, § 13, 4-6-1987; Ord. 92-149, § 5,
12-21-1992)
Sec. 7-161. Animals Sold To New Owners:
Any person may purchase an animal impounded under the provisions of this
article after seven (7) days of impoundment, by complying with the following
fee schedule:
      (1)   Dogs under four (4) months of age, the sum of twenty dollars
($20.00) plus the cost of temporary hepatitis and distemper injection, and an
adoption in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) to cover the cost of neutering
or spaying.
      (2)   Dogs over four (4) months of age, the sum of twenty dollars
($20.00) plus the cost of rabies inoculation and an adoption deposit in the
amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) to cover the cost of neutering or spaying.
      (3)   Cats, the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) plus the cost of rabies
inoculation, if the cat is over four (4) months of age, and an adoption deposit
in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00) to cover the cost of neutering or
spaying. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord., § 1, 5-19-1975; Ord., § 2, 11-7-1977;
Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982; Ord. 85-30, § 2, 8-26-1985; Ord. 87-34, §§
10-12, 4-6-1987)
Sec. 7-162. Disposition Of Dogs Or Cats Not Claimed:
If any dog or cat impounded under the provisions of this article is not claimed
within seven (7) days after being impounded, the animal control officer may
dispose of such animal in a humane way by approved methods. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-
1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-163. Injured Animals:
The animal control officer shall remove from any street or public place within
the city any injured animal not being attended and properly cared for by the
owner and shall, if he deems it necessary, impound and confine such animal with
some veterinarian within the city. If such veterinarian shall treat such
animal, he shall advise the animal control officer of the cost of such
treatment and in the event such dog is claimed as provided in this article, the
person so claiming such animal shall also pay the charges of the veterinarian.
If such animal is not claimed, it shall be disposed of in the manner herein
provided. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 4), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-164. Animals That Cannot Be Impounded:
If any dangerous, fierce or vicious dog or cat cannot safely be taken up and
impounded, such dog or cat may be slain by any sworn officer; provided,
however, that in all cases where any dog or cat so slain has bitten any person
or caused an abrasion of the skin of such person, it shall be the duty of the
officer slaying such dog or cat to immediately deliver the carcass and the head
of such dog or cat to the animal control officer. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord.
82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-165. Animals Released To Animal Shelter For Disposal:
Any nonresident releasing an animal to the animal shelter for disposal shall
pay a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per animal or ten dollars ($10.00) for a
litter. (Ord. 87-34, § 14, 4-6-1987)
Sec. 7-166. Penalty:
Any person violating the provisions of this article which is not covered by a
specific fee and/or fine listed herein as a first offense shall be subject to a
citation, which citation shall be paid at the police department in the amount
of twenty five dollars ($25.00); if paid within seven (7) days of the date
issued the amount shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). Any second and subsequent
violation of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 92-149, §
6, 12-21-1992)
DIVISION 4. URBAN CHICKENS
Sec. 7-167. Purpose:
   The purpose of this ordinance is to establish certain requirements which are
intended to reduce problems that may otherwise be associated with the keeping
of chickens in urban areas and to encourage high quality chicken keeping
practices. (Ord. 004-2020, 3-9-2020)
Sec. 7-168. Definitions:
   Chicken: Any breed or stage of the common domesticated fowl, Gallus gallus
domesticus.
   Chicken Tractor: A lightweight portable chicken coop and/or enclosure that
allows chickens to be moved around and forage in various locations. These are
prohibited.
   Chicken Keeper: A person who is responsible for the maintenance of a chicken
coop/enclosure and its resident chickens as well as all associated materials,
equipment, and products.
   Coop: A structure where chickens are kept and can roost.
   Enclosure: A secure fenced area inside of which a coop and its resident
chickens are kept.
   Hen: A female chicken.
   Rooster: A male chicken. These are prohibited. (Ord. 004-2020, 3-9-2020)
Sec. 7-169. Licensing:
   (a)   No person shall keep chickens within the City without first obtaining
the appropriate license issued by the City. Coops cannot be established until a
license is issued. Licenses shall be renewed annually.
   (b)   At the time of application for a chicken keeping license, the
applicant shall submit the following.
      (1)   A completed application as provided by the City.
      (2)   A scaled site plan of the proposed coop and enclosure that shows
compliance with this article.
      (3)   Proof of successful completion of an urban chicken keeping class
that is approved by the City.
      (4)   Proof that all adjacent property owners have been notified of the
proposed coop and enclosure.
      (5)   When the applicant is leasing the subject property, proof that the
property owner consents to the establishment of a chicken enclosure.
Additionally, in the case of a multi-family dwelling, proof that all households
in the dwelling consent to the establishment of a chicken enclosure on the
property.
   (c)   A decision to deny an application or renew a license shall be
presented in writing to the applicant and shall specify the reasons for the
denial.
   (d)   Applicants may appeal the denial of their application or renewal of
their license to the Planning Commission. An appeal must be filed within thirty
(30) days of the denial. Once filed, the appeal shall be heard by the Planning
Commission within sixty (60) days. A simple majority vote of the Planning
Commission shall be sufficient to overturn or affirm the initial denial. The
Planning Commission may also grant reasonable accommodations requested by
applicants who are appealing. The applicant must demonstrate that unique
circumstances prevent them from achieving compliance with certain requirements
of this article. Adjacent property owners shall be notified of the requested
accommodations and given an opportunity to object.
   (e)   Decisions of the Planning Commission may be appealed to the City
Council within thirty (30) days of the Commission's denial. Once filed, the
appeal shall be heard by the City Council within sixty (60) days. A simple
majority vote of the City Council shall be sufficient to overturn or affirm the
decision of the Planning Commission. The City Council may also grant reasonable
accommodations requested by applicants who are appealing. The applicant must
demonstrate that unique circumstances prevent them from achieving compliance
with certain requirements of this article. Adjacent property owners shall be
notified of the requested accommodations and given an opportunity to object.
   (f)   Applicants must wait one (1) year before filing a new application for
the same property.
   (g)   The annual fee for a chicken license shall be twenty-five dollars
($25). (Ord. 004-2020, 3-9-2020)
Sec. 7-170. Location:
   (a)   All chicken enclosures shall be located in a rear yard or on a flat
roof top and be at least ten feet (10') from neighboring property lines. On
properties one (1) acre in size or larger, the enclosure may be located in a
side or front yard provided that the enclosure is at least one hundred feet
(100') from the neighboring property lines.
   (b)   When a chicken enclosure is located in a rear yard, the rear yard must
be fully enclosed with a six-foot (6') fence so that it is secure from
unauthorized persons. On properties one (1) acre in size or larger, a fence
shall not be required provided that the enclosure is at least one hundred feet
(100') from the neighboring property lines. When an enclosure is located on a
flat roof top, access to the roof must be restricted so that it is secure from
unauthorized persons. (Ord. 004-2020, 3-9-2020)
Sec. 7-171. Coops And Enclosures:
   (a)   Enclosures shall be secure fenced areas that prevents entry by
predators from below, above, and the sides. It shall at a minimum consist of
wire fencing or mesh with openings no larger than one inch (1"). Coops and
their resident chickens shall be kept inside an enclosure at all times.
   (b)   Coops and enclosures shall be secured so as to impede the entrance of
rodents, birds, and other predators or nuisance species. They shall also be
kept clean, dry, odor free, neat, and sanitary at all times.
   (c)   Coops shall be designed with a minimum of four (4) square feet per
chicken. They shall also be enclosed on all sides, have a roof, secured
entrance, and adequate ventilation. Chickens shall be secured within a coop
between dusk and dawn.
   (d)   The materials used in making coops and enclosures shall be uniform for
each element of the structure such that the walls are made of the same
material, the roof has the same shingles or other covering, and any windows or
openings are constructed using the same materials. The use of scrap, waste
board, sheet metal, or similar materials is prohibited.
   (e)   There shall be no more than one enclosure and one coop therein on any
given property.
   (f)   Chickens outside of an enclosure shall be deemed at-large and subject
to capture and removal by the Rock Island animal control officer or their
designee. No dog or cat that harms or kills a chicken at-large shall be
considered dangerous or aggressive for that reason alone. (Ord. 004-2020, 3-9-
2020)
Sec. 7-172. Food, Water, And Health:
   (a)   Chicken keepers shall provide adequate feed to chickens and secure
said feed in such a fashion as to avoid attracting predators or nuisance
species.
   (b)   Chicken keepers shall ensure that a fresh, convenient source of water
is available to chickens at all times.
   (c)   Chicken manure shall be stored in a covered container and shall not
exceed three (3) cubic feet in volume. All manure not used for composting or
fertilizing on the property shall be removed.
   (d)   Chickens shall be monitored for health problems common to their
species and cared for using common best practice methods. Chickens found to be
infested with parasites or disease that may result in unhealthy conditions may
be removed by the Rock Island animal control officer or their designee. (Ord.
004-2020, 3-9-2020)
Sec. 7-173. Maintenance:
   (a)   All items associated with the chickens must be kept in sound and
usable condition. Chicken keepers shall ensure that no refuse or related
materials are left on the ground of the enclosure.
   (b)   In any instance where a chicken becomes hostile by exhibiting
aggressive characteristics such as pecking or scratching, it shall be removed
from the property.
   (c)   It is a suggested practice that insecticides, pesticides, and similar
chemicals not be used at the property on which chickens are located. (Ord. 004-
2020, 3-9-2020)
Sec. 7-174. Conduct and Requirements:
   (a)   Chickens that are not licensed by the City shall be considered a
nuisance.
   (b)   A person shall not keep chickens on property owned or occupied by
another person without first being granted written permission from the owner or
occupant.
   (c)   It is unlawful for any person keep chickens on any property in a
manner that threatens the public health or safety, or creates a nuisance.
   (d)   It shall be unlawful to keep roosters. Only hens shall be permitted.
   (e)   It shall be unlawful to slaughter chickens within the City.
   (f)   Chicken tractors or other mobile enclosures are prohibited.
   (g)   It is unlawful for any person to keep chickens as part of a business
in a zoning district in which such a business would not be licensed.
   (h)   Keeping chickens shall be done in accordance with this Article and any
other applicable laws. (Ord. 004-2020, 3-9-2020)
Secs. 7-175 – 7-180. Reserved:
ARTICLE VII. HOUSING CODE 1

Sec. 7-181. Adopted:
The International Code Council, International Property Maintenance Code, copies
of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, is hereby adopted by
reference and shall serve as the housing code of the City of Rock Island
subject to the amendments which were recommended by the Rock Island Housing
Code Advisory and Appeals Board which are attached to ordinance 99-66 on file
in the office of the City Clerk and made a part hereof by reference. (Ord. 90-
75, § 1, 10-15-1990; Ord. 92-64, § 1, 4-13-1992; Ord. 99-6, § 1, 8-23-1999;
Ord. 035-2019, 7-8-2019)
Secs. 7-182-7-220. Reserved:
ARTICLE VIII. REGULATION OF PIGEON LOFTS AND CARRIER OR RACING PIGEONS
Sec. 7-221. Purpose And Definitions:
   (a)   Purpose: The purpose of this Article is to protect the health and
safety of the community by regulating and controlling the raising, keeping, and
exercising of carrier and racing pigeons in order to prevent disease and
nuisance.
   (b)   Definitions:
      (1)   Carrier Pigeon: Homing and racing pigeons which have the name of
the owner stamped upon the wing or tail, or are banded upon the leg with the
name or initials of the owner or with an identification or registration number
stamped on the band.
      (2)   Health Authority: The Chief Building Inspector or his designated
representative of the City of Rock Island.
      (3)   Loft: Any structure in which carrier, homing and racing pigeons are
housed.
      (4)   Racing Pigeon: A pigeon registered with a national pigeon racing
organization and used as a game competitive bird. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord.
87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-222. Permit:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a loft or raise, keep, or exercise
carrier and racing pigeons without first obtaining a permit from the health
authority in the manner prescribed in this Article. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-223. Application:
The applicant shall file an application for such a permit with the Chief
Building Inspector or his designated representative on a form he shall
prescribe. At this time, the applicant shall pay a filing fee of twenty dollars
($20.00). The application shall include a statement in writing by the applicant
and adequate evidence showing that the construction and operation of the
proposed loft will conform to the standards set forth in Section
7-224 of this Article. The application shall also include the name of the
pigeon club or organization the birds are registered with, a contact person
within the organization and a phone number where this person can be reached.
(Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord. 87-2, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-224. Standards:
No permit shall be issued by the health authority unless such authority shall
find:
   (1)   That no odor related to the keeping of pigeons is to be present at the
property line at any time.
   (2)   That the droppings be handled in a sanitary manner within a closed
container to prevent fly breeding and odor.
   (3)   That the pigeons shall be controlled by their owner so that they will
not constitute a nuisance to neighboring property owners. A nuisance may, among
other actions, be defined as the exercising of pigeons at an unacceptable time
of day.
   (4)   That all lofts constructed after passage of this Article shall be in
no yard other than the rear yard; nor shall it occupy more than thirty percent
(30%) of a required rear yard. It shall not exceed fifteen feet (15') in height
and shall be distant at least three feet (3') from alley lines of adjoining
lots and at least six feet (6') from alley lines and any other building or
structure on the same lot.
   (5)   That the construction of the structure meet all other City
regulations, including but not limited to Building Code regulations. (Ord. 86-
47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-225. Conditions And Safeguards:
   (a)   Prior to the granting of such a permit, the health authority shall
stipulate such standards as described in Section
7-224 above.
   (b)   Said permit, when granted, shall be in full force and effect only as
long as the owner of said loft retains ownership at that particular location.
(Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-226. Authority And Inspection:
The Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative is hereby
authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of this Article. (Ord.
86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-227. Fees:
An annual license fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be charged. (Ord. 86-47,
9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-228. Penalties:
   (a)   Finding Of Violation: Upon finding a violation of the provisions of
this Article, or the conditions specified by the health authority, the Chief
Building Inspector or his designated representative shall notify the owner of
the pigeons and the club contact person as specified at the time of licensing.
The owner shall then have fourteen (14) days to remedy the violations. After
this fourteen (14) day period, the Chief Building Inspector or his designated
representative shall reinspect the loft to determine if violations still exist.
   (b)   Revocation Of Permit: If violations continue to exist past the
fourteen (14) day period, the Chief Building Inspector or his designated
representative shall revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this
Article.
If a license is cited for violation of this Article three (3) times in a twelve
(12) month period, said license shall be permanently revoked.
   (c)   Civil Remedy: If said pigeon loft is not dismantled and pigeons
removed from the premises upon revocation of said permit, then action shall be
brought by the City Attorney, his designee, or by designated representative of
the Community Services and Development Department. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord.
87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-229. Appeals:
   (a)   Prior to the revocation of said permit on grounds of violation which
do not constitute a nuisance to neighboring property owners, including but not
limited to subsection 7-224(4) and (5), the Chief Building Inspector or his
designated representative shall provide written notice to the permit holder
stating the reasons for which the permit is subject to revocation and advising
that the permit shall be permanently revoked at the end of five (5) days
following service of such notice, unless a written request for a hearing before
the appropriate board is filed with the health authority by the permit holder
within such five (5) day period.
   (b)   Revocation of the permit shall occur prior to an appeal hearing if the
violations constitute a nuisance to neighboring property owners, including but
not limited to subsection 7-224(1), (2), and (3).
   (c)   If revocation is a result of violations of subsection 7-224(4) of this
Article, appeals will be made to the Board of Zoning Appeals within five (5)
days following service of a notice of revocation by the Chief Building
Inspector or his designated representative. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; 87-22, 3-
23-1987)
Sec. 7-230. Applicability:
Owners of existing pigeon lofts as well as proposed lofts shall be subject to
the provisions of this article. Existing lofts shall be exempted from the
requirement found in subsection 7-224(4) of this chapter. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-
1986)
ARTICLE IX. NUISANCES AND REFUSE
Sec. 7-231. Definitions:
See chapter 13, article II, "Solid Waste", of this code. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-
1996; Ord. 035-2019, 7-8-2019)
Sec. 7-232. General Conditions:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any refuse upon any
street, alley, lane or public or private property in the city.
   (b)   It shall be the responsibility of the owner of record to keep the
property in compliance with this article. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996 ; Ord. 035-
2019, 7-8-2019)
Sec. 7-233. Nuisances:
   Within the territorial jurisdiction of the city it is hereby declared a
nuisance for any person:
      (1)   Nuisances At Common Law: To cause any of those acts or omissions
that are declared to be nuisances by the state and such as are known as
nuisances to the common law of the land, not hereinafter specially enumerated.
      (2)   Premises To Be Kept Clean: To keep or suffer to be kept within the
city limits in a foul, offensive, nauseous, or filthy condition any building,
lot, yard, premises or junkyard.
      (3)   Junk: To keep or suffer to be kept within the city limits in a
foul, offensive, nauseous, filthy, dilapidated or unsafe condition any vehicle,
machinery, appliance or household item.
      (4)   Furniture: For the owner or keeper of any lot or premises to suffer
to remain thereon, to the annoyance and detriment of other persons outside the
buildings located on the premises, any furniture not designed for outdoor use.
      (5)   Garbage And Rubbish Storage And Pick Up Areas: It shall be the
responsibility of the owner of record to keep the garbage and rubbish storage
and pick-up areas on public rights of way (defined in chapter 13 of this code)
free from garbage and rubbish on the ground.
      (6)   Refuse Disposal: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or premises
to place or allow to be placed any refuse container, yard waste or brush at the
street, curb or alley on the public right-of-way pick up site earlier than
twelve o'clock (12:00) noon the day before pick up or to allow any refuse
containers to remain at the pick-up site no later than twelve o'clock (12:00)
noon the day after pick up.
      (7)   Brush: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or premises to allow
brush or brush in piles to remain on the property longer than thirty (30) days
of breaking or cutting.
      (8)   Animals: For the owner or keeper of any lot or premises to allow
animal wastes to accumulate to a point where odors are present at the property
line or the presence of insects creates a health hazard for surrounding
properties. Animal wastes shall be handled as garbage.
      (9)   Unburied Animals: For the owner or possessor of an animal which may
die within the city to leave the same unburied less than twenty four inches
(24") below ground or properly dispose of the carcass therein for more than
eight (8) hours after its death, or for any person to bring and leave the
carcass of any such animal within the city. In case the animal is not removed
within the eight (8) hour period after notification, the inspection division
shall cause the removal of said animal and certify the cost of such removal as
a lien against the property. Notification shall consist of a posting on the
premises.
      (10)   Slaughter Of Animals: To kill or slaughter any animals within the
city limits, to the injury, discomfort or annoyance of any inhabitants of the
neighborhood.
      (11)   Animal And Vermin Harborage: For the owner and/or tenant of any
residential lot or premises to allow any material such as lumber, boxes,
barrels, scrap iron, construction material or any other materials which would
provide harborage for rats, mice, snakes or other vermin. Firewood must be
neatly stacked and elevated a minimum of four inches (4") above the ground.
      (12)   Vector Control: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or
residence to permit water to stand in containers of any kind unless mosquito
controls have been taken or allow animal or vermin harborages under any garage,
shed, porch, residential structure or other buildings on the premises without
taking necessary measures to destroy or capture the animals or vermin. Poisons
may not be used unless placed in areas not readily accessible to persons or
domesticated animals. For single user nonowner occupied lots or premises, the
owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for the extermination of any
rodents, vermin or other pests of public health significance therein on the
premises. In multi-tenant lots or premises, the owner and/or tenant is
responsible for extermination of such pests.
      (13)   Offensive Matter In River: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot
or property to allow or suffer to allow any blood, bone, offal, and any other
offensive matter to run, fall, or get into any storm drain, drainage ditch or
other watercourse which leads into the Mississippi River. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-
1996; Ord. 035-2019, 7-8-2019)
Sec. 7-234. Penalties For Nuisance Violations:
   Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to the
following penalties.
   (1)   Upon detection of a nuisance violation, the respective property owner
shall be issued a courtesy notice directing them to abate the violation within
seven (7) days of the date of the courtesy notice. No fine shall accompany the
courtesy notice.
   (2)   If the property owner fails to abate the nuisance within seven (7)
days of the courtesy notice, the City shall be empowered to abate the nuisance.
The Building Official and the Public Works Director, or their respective
designees, shall direct the abatement by either City staff or a contractor. The
costs incurred by the City to abate the nuisance shall be charged to the
property owner on their municipal utility bill, in the form of a lien on the
property, or in any other manner consistent with the Code of Ordinances.
Further, the City Attorney is authorized and directed to initiate litigation in
court to recover costs incurred. The cost of abatement will be accompanied by a
fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or ten percent (10%) of the cost of
abatement, whichever amount is greater.
   (3)   A property owner who has been cited and had a nuisance abated on their
property by the City three (3) or more times in a one (1) year period shall be
considered a habitual violator. Habitual violators shall receive notice that
they are so considered and said notice shall inform them that all subsequent
violations shall result in immediate abatement by the City without additional
courtesy notices. The costs incurred by the City to abate the nuisance and the
associated fine shall be charged to the property owner in the same manner as
above. Designation as a habitual violator may be discontinued when the property
owner in question has not been cited for a minimum of one (1) year.
   (4)   Property owners may appeal a nuisance citation to the Municipal Code
Enforcement Service (MUNICES). Said appeal must be in writing and explain how
there is not a nuisance violation present using photographic evidence. The
appeal must be delivered to the Building Official prior to the end of the seven
(7) day period following the issuance of the courtesy notice. Appeals received
late shall not be considered. The Building Official shall ensure that the
appeal is heard at the next regularly scheduled MUNICES hearing. At said
hearing, the Building Official or their designee shall present evidence that a
nuisance violation is present. The property owner or their designee shall
present evidence to the contrary. Should the presiding Code Hearing Officer
decide that a nuisance does exist, the City may proceed with abatement
immediately. Should the presiding Officer decide that no violation is present
or that the violation is less severe, they may dismiss the citation in whole or
in part. The respective parties shall retain, however, the right to take civil
action in local court. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996; Ord. 085- 2014, 12-1-2014; Ord.
035-2019, 7-8-2019; Ord. 028-2023, 7-24-2023)

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 8-1. Licenses Subject To Ordinances:
All licenses which may at any time be issued under any ordinance of the City
shall be subject to all ordinances and regulations of the City which may be in
force during the period of such license, or any portion of such period, and
shall also be subject to all laws of the State and conditioned upon their
faithful observance, and a violation of any of the provisions of said
ordinances or laws by any licensed person shall, in addition to the penalties
which may be provided for such violation, subject him to a revocation of his
license. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-2. How Issued; Terms:
All licenses which may be issued under any ordinance of the City, unless such
ordinance shall otherwise provide, shall be signed by the City Clerk under the
Corporate Seal of the City, and shall specify the kind of license. Fees shall
be payable at the City Finance Department prior to May 1 of each year. The
licensing year shall begin on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of the
next succeeding calendar year. All licenses shall expire on said April 30 in
each calendar year. In the case of new businesses, new license applications, or
additional licenses for existing businesses only where the application for the
license is made after October 31 of any year, the fee for the license shall be
one-half (1/2) of the stated fee for the remainder of that license year only.
(Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-3. Assignment; Surrender; New License; Bond:
   (a)   Except as provided in this section, licenses are not transferable.
   (b)   Any person to whom a license may have been issued under any ordinance
of this City may, with the permission of the Council, or other authorized City
official, have the same transferred or surrender such license and have the same
cancelled and have a like license issued for the unexpired term of the one so
surrendered to the person or place of business to which he may wish to transfer
the same upon the licensee named in such new license giving bond (if bond is
required in such case) and complying with the ordinances and laws under which
the license is issued. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-4. Revocation By Mayor Or Council:
Any license granted under the provisions of an ordinance of the City may be
revoked at any time, upon written notice by the Council or other authorized
City official, when it shall appear that the licensed party has violated or
failed to comply with any provision of any ordinance of the City or the laws of
the State applicable to the person, business occupation or place so licensed.
(1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-5. Register Of Licenses:
The City Clerk shall keep a record of all licenses issued; the date, term and
kind of license, the amount paid therefor and the name and place of business of
the licensee. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-6. Garage And Yard Sales 1  2 :
Garage, yard and related sales are hereby authorized on residentially zoned
property in the City only upon compliance with the following conditions:
   (1)   The sale on the premises shall not exceed a seventy two (72) hour
period.
   (2)   No residentially zoned premises in the City shall be used for the site
of a sale more than twice in any calendar year.
   (3)   Property to be sold in said sale shall be limited to items of personal
property owned by the persons on whose premises the sale is being conducted.
   (4)   Any person authorized by this section shall be allowed to place a sign
advertising same on his or her premises or on other private property when
authorized by the owner thereof during the time of said sale and said sign
shall be removed at the end of said sale period. No sign shall be placed or
permitted on a public right-of-way. (Ord., 10-13-1975; Ord., 11-3-1975; Ord.,
11-10-1975; Ord. 87-34, 4-6-1987; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 96-89, 11-11-
1996)
 
Notes
1 See § 4-46 et seq., "Signs", of this Code.
2 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3.
Sec. 8-7. Sound-Amplifying Equipment 3 :
   (a)   Definitions: As used in this section:
      Person: Any corporation, partnership or two (2) or more individuals
having a joint or common interest.
      Sound-Amplifying Equipment: Any machine or device for the amplification
of the human voice, music or any other sound. It shall not be construed as
including sound-amplifying devices when used and heard only by occupants of the
vehicle or building in which located, or such devices when used for authorized
traffic-safety purposes.
   (b)   License - Required: No person either as principal or agent shall
operate or cause to be operated any sound-amplifying equipment, either
stationary or mounted on vehicles, in the City, without a license as provided
in this section.
   (c)   License - Application: Any person, within the meaning of this section,
desiring to use "sound-amplifying equipment", as herein defined, shall make,
and file with the City Clerk, a written application stating the applicant's
name, residence, place of business, kind of business, the purpose for which the
sound-amplifying equipment shall be used, the proposed hours of operation, the
number of days of the proposed operation, a general description of said
equipment and the maximum sound-producing power of the equipment, including the
following:
      (1)   The wattage to be used.
      (2)   The volume in decibels of sound which will be produced.
      (3)   The approximate maximum distance from which sound will be thrown
from the equipment.
   (d)   License - Fee; Issuance: The applicant shall, at the time, pay to the
City Collector as a license fee twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day or
part of a day for each unit. Such license shall be issued by the City Clerk.
   (e)   Regulations For Use: The use of sound-amplifying equipment and its
operation shall be subject to the following regulations:
      (1)   The only sounds permitted are music and the human voice.
      (2)   Operation is permitted between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. each day except on Sundays and legal holidays,
when no operation shall be authorized.
      (3)   Sound shall not be emitted within one hundred (100) yards of
hospitals, schools, churches or courthouses.
      (4)   The human speech and music amplified shall not be profane,
slanderous or obscene as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20.
      (5)   The volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be
audible for a distance in excess of one hundred feet (100') from the sound
amplifying equipment, and so that said volume is not unreasonably loud,
raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of
audibility. (1963 Code art. 6-2(Q); Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991)

Sec. 8-8. Gasoline Filling Stations 1 :
Any person operating a filling station for the sale of gasoline or other motor
fuel in the City and any person to whom a license to operate such filling

Sec. 8-9. Going Out Of Business Sales:
   (a)   State Law: All persons holding going out of business sales shall
comply with 815 Illinois Compiled Statutes 350/1 through 350/12, which provides
for the licensing and regulation of said sales as defined therein.
   (b)   Inspection: In addition to the regulations and requirements set forth
in said State Statute, any person conducting a sale defined in said Act shall
comply with the inspection requirements as set forth in this section. The Mayor
shall, upon the filing of an application for a sale, appoint an inspector or
inspectors, not to exceed three (3) in number, accordingly as the requirements
of the situation seem to demand, said inspector or inspectors to be residents
of the City and who may be City officials or employees or otherwise, whose duty
it shall be to inspect and investigate the inventory submitted with the
application for license, and the stock of goods or merchandise offered for sale
thereunder, and who shall either singly, or as a body, as directed by the
Mayor, attend the sale held under the license when issued, and report to the
Mayor whether any goods not listed in the inventory had been offered for sale,
and whether the other requirements of this section are being complied with. The
Mayor shall require that the articles enumerated in said inventory be numbered
in sequence and that tags, corresponding to the numbers so shown in the
inventory, be placed on each article when offered for sale and accompany the
article when sold. Such inspector or inspectors attending any sale shall have
with them a copy or copies of the inventory as originally furnished with the
application and shall check or compare the articles offered for sale with the
inventory. For the purpose of such inspection said inspector or inspectors
shall have access to the place where such sale is to be held at any time prior
to the opening of any such sale. Such inspector or inspectors shall not receive
any compensation for duties performed hereunder prior to the opening of any
such sale, but shall each be compensated at the rate determined by the City
Council for attendance at any sale held under any license granted hereunder.
Provided, however, that no City employee attending any such sale hereunder
shall be entitled to or receive any extra compensation above his regular salary
or wage. Any person holding a sale within the meaning of this section shall
deposit with the City Collector prior to the issuance of a license as
aforesaid, a cash deposit in an amount to be determined by the Mayor, not to
exceed one-half of one percent of the cost inventory of the goods to be sold,
to guarantee payment to the City of a sum equal to the cost of inspection as
above defined. (1963 Code art. 6-2(P))
Sec. 8-10. Sale Of Merchandise On Street, Etc.:
No person shall place or allow to be placed on public sidewalks or public ways,
any merchandise or goods for the purpose of advertising or selling same without
prior approval of the City Council. (Ord., 6-23-1975)

ARTICLE II. ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS AND USERS 1
 
Notes
1 Cross reference--Police, ch. 12
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-26. Title:
This article shall be known and may be cited as the ROCK ISLAND CITY ORDINANCE
REGULATING BURGLAR AND HOLDUP ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS, AND USERS. (Ord., 10-
2-1978)
Sec. 8-27. Definitions:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meaning given herein:
   Alarm Agent: Any person who is employed by an alarm business, either
directly or indirectly, whose duties include selling, maintaining, leasing,
servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing on or in any
building, structure or facility, any alarm system. Exemption: The provisions of
this article do not apply to a person who engages in the manufacture or sale of
an alarm system from a fixed location and who neither visits the location where
the alarm system is to be installed, nor designs the scheme for physical
location and installation of the alarm system in a specific location.
   Alarm Business: The business by any individual, partnership or corporation
or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, inspecting, servicing,
repairing, moving or installing any alarm system in or on any building,
structure or facility. Exemption: Said definition shall not apply to persons
engaged solely in the manufacture or sale of alarm system components from a
fixed location, and who do not install, alter, maintain, service or plan the
alarm system for a specific location.
   Alarm System: Any mechanical or electrical device which is designed or used
for the detection of an unauthorized entry into a building, structure or
facility or for alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act within a
building, structure or facility, or both; and which emits a sound or transmits
a signal or message when actuated and to which police are expected to respond.
In this article, the term "alarm system" shall include the terms "audible
alarm", "automatic dialing device", "burglar alarm system" and "holdup alarm
system" as those terms are hereinafter defined.
   Answering Service: A telephone answering business providing among its
services receiving, on a continuous basis through trained employees, emergency
signals from alarm systems, and thereafter immediately relaying the message by
live voice over a signal channel circuit to the communication center of the
Police Department.
   Appellant: A person who perfects an appeal pursuant to this article.
   Applicant: A person, firm or corporation that files an application for a new
or renewal permit as provided in this article.
   Audible Alarm: A device designed for the detection of unauthorized entry on
premises which generates an audible sound on the premises when it is actuated.
This audible alarm may or may not be combined with a method of transmitting a
signal to a remote point. Exemption: The provisions of this article are not
applicable to audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles.
   Automatic Dialing Device: An alarm system which automatically sends over
regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice
message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation
that the alarm system is designed to detect.
   Burglar Alarm System: A method of detecting and signaling the presence,
entry or attempted entry of an intruder into protected premises.
   Central Station System: A system or group of systems, usually operated from
its customers by a person, in which the operations of protected circuits and
devices are transmitted to, recorded in, maintained and supervised from a
central station having trained operators and guards in attendance at all times,
that have the duty to take appropriate action upon receipt of a signal or
message including the relaying of messages by a signal channel circuit to the
communications center of the police department.
   City: The city of Rock Island or its authorized employees or agents.
   Direct Alarm System: An alarm system which has the capability of
transmitting signals to and receiving them at the communications center of the
Rock Island police department.
   False Alarm: The intentional or unintentional activation of an alarm system
through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the
negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or
agents which necessitates response by the Rock Island police department where
an attempted or actual burglary or holdup does not exist. Such terminology does
not include, for example, alarms caused by tornadoes, earthquakes or other
violent conditions.
   Holdup Alarm System: An alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted
robbery.
   Modified Central Station: An office to which remote alarm and supervisory
signaling devices are connected, where operators supervise the circuits and
relay the messages by a "signal channel circuit" to the communications center
of the police department.
   Police Chief: The chief of the police department of the city of Rock Island,
or his authorized representative.
   Primary Trunk Line: A telephone line leading into the communications center
of the police department, that is for the purpose of handling emergency calls
on a person to person basis, and which line is identified by a specific listing
among the emergency numbers in a telephone directory issued by the telephone
company serving the city.
   Protected Premises: That part of a building, structure or facility to which
protection is afforded by an alarm system.
   Signal Channel Circuit: A telephone service that only provides a two-way
telephone service from one location to another location. In the police station,
it will be used to report emergency signals from an "answering service", a
"central station" or from a "modified central station" to the police
communication center on a person to person basis.
   Subscriber: A person who buys and/or leases, or otherwise obtains an alarm
signaling system and thereafter contracts with or hires an alarm business to
monitor and/or service the alarm device. (Ord., § 3(A-V), 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-28. Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this article shall be one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). In the event a person is accused of a
violation of this article and does not wish to contest said allegations prior
to the time a complaint is issued for said violation, the person accused may
pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) for and in full satisfaction of said violation. (Ord.
005-2011, 2-7-2011)
Sec. 8-29. Purpose:
The purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards and regulations
applicable to burglar and holdup alarm systems, alarm businesses, alarm agents
and alarm users; require permits therefor; establish fees; and provide for
punishment of violations of provisions as defined in this article. (Ord., § 2,
10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-30. Standards And Regulations Prescribed By Police Chief:
The police chief may prescribe reasonable minimum standards and regulations for
the construction and maintenance of all alarm systems installed within the
city. All devices shall meet or exceed such standards and regulations before
permits may be issued pursuant to this article. The police chief may require
inspection and approval of all alarm systems installed within the city. (Ord.,
§ 4, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-31. Audible Alarms:
All alarm systems that emit an audible signal that may be heard by persons
outside the protected building, structure or facility shall conform to the
following requirements:
   (1)   Every person maintaining an audible alarm shall provide the police
chief with the names and telephone numbers of the persons to be notified to
render repairs or service and secure the premises during any hour of the day or
night that the alarm system is activated. It is the responsibility of every
person maintaining an alarm system to assure that the names and telephone
numbers recorded with the police department are kept current.
   (2)   No person shall install an audible alarm system which creates a sound
similar to that of an emergency vehicle siren or a civil defense warning
system.
   (3)   No person shall install an audible alarm system which does not
automatically discontinue emitting an audible sound within one-half (1/2) hour
after it is activated. (Ord., § 5, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-32. Prohibited Systems:
   (a)   Automatic Dialing Devices: No alarm system using an automatic dialing
device will be allowed to send a prerecorded voice message or coded signal over
a primary trunk line or direct line into the communications center of the
police department.
   (b)   Panic Alarm: Panic or trouble alarms used to signal any type of fight,
disturbance or any other activity other than an actual or attempted burglary or
holdup will not be allowed. (Ord., § 6, 10-2-1978; Ord. 82-23, § 1, 8-9-1982)
Sec. 8-33. Automatic Dialing Device; Intermediary Services:
   (a)   Persons owning or leasing an automatic dialing device may have the
device interconnected to a telephone line transmitting directly to:
      (1)   A central station;
      (2)   A modified central station; or
      (3)   A licensed answering service.
   (b)   The relaying of messages by intermediate services to the police
department shall be over a signal channel circuit on a person to person basis.
   (c)   The police chief may limit the number of "signal channel circuits"
that come into the communications center of the police department. (Ord., § 7,
10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-34. Police Alarms:
No alarm system equipment, unless police owned and operated, shall transmit any
message on the police base radio frequency. (Ord., § 8, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-35. Responsibility For Alarm Response:
Every person who has on his premises under his control or ownership an alarm
system, audible or silent, shall, upon notification that the alarm system is
giving a signal, proceed within twenty (20) minutes to the premises and render
all necessary services. Provided, however, that the owner of the premises may
enter into an agreement with an alarm business to respond in his stead. Failure
to respond to an activated alarm shall be considered a violation of this
provision and shall result in a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) ($25.00 if
paid within 30 days). (Ord., § 24, 10-2-1978; Ord. 91-17, § 1, 2-18-1991; Ord.
91-74, § 1, 6-17-1991; Ord. 93-65, § 1, 6-14-1993)
Sec. 8-36. Service Available:
Each alarm business shall have licensed alarm agents and supplies and equipment
so located as to be able to respond to a request for repair or adjustment on
any alarm system that such an alarm business sold, maintained, or inspected
within four (4) hours of the request for this service. They shall respond
within four (4) hours of the request, except that if the request occurs within
the hours that protected premises is open for business or otherwise
substantially occupied, repair or adjustment may be made at any time prior to
closing of the protected premises. (Ord., § 25, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-37. Liability Of City:
The city shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals
received by the city are given appropriate attention and are acted upon with
dispatch. Nevertheless, the city shall not be liable for any defects in
operation of any alarm devices or signal lines system, for any failure or
neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such a source,
nor for the failure or neglect of any person with a permit issued pursuant to
this article, in connection with the installation and operation of equipment,
the transmission of alarm signals or the delaying of such signals. In the event
the city finds it necessary to disconnect a defective automatic protective
device or signaling device, the city shall incur no liability by such action.
(Ord., § 27, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-38. Conflict Of Interest:
No employee of the police department nor member of any such employee's
immediate family shall have any interest, directly or indirectly, in any alarm
business within the limits of the city. No such employee or member of his
immediate family shall be employed by an alarm business, subject to the
provisions of this article. (Ord., § 28, 10-2-1978)
Secs. 8-39-8-50. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 8-51. Generally:
   (a)   Alarm System Permit: No person shall possess or use an alarm system
without first applying for and receiving an alarm system permit therefor in
accordance with the provisions of this article. The permit shall be kept on the
premises where the alarm system is located. The police chief may issue an
appropriate identification number and establish requirements for its posting.
   (b)   Alarm Business Permit: No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on
an alarm business without first applying for and receiving an alarm business
permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. This
includes a central station, modified central station and an answering service.
The permit shall be kept on the premises where the business is located. The
police chief may issue an appropriate identification number and establish
requirements for its posting.
   (c)   Agent Permit: No person shall engage in, conduct or operate as an
alarm agent without first applying for and receiving an alarm agent permit
therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article.
      (1)   Every person engaged in the business of repairing, servicing,
altering, replacing, removing, designing, selling, leasing, maintaining or
installing alarm systems shall carry on his person at all times while so
engaged a valid alarm agent permit and shall display the permit to any police
officer upon request.
      (2)   It shall be a violation of this article for the applicant to
wilfully fail to return an identification card to the issuing agency or
business upon termination of his employment with an alarm business. It shall
also be a violation of this article for the alarm business to fail to return to
the police chief an identification card issued by the police chief upon
termination of the employment of the alarm agent.
   (d)   Direct Alarm System Permit: No direct alarm system shall be permitted
within the police department except such as is connected to an indicator panel
installed in uniform consoles with uniform operation within the communication
facilities of such department pursuant to a permit issued in accordance with
the provisions of this article.
      (1)   An owner or lessee of an alarm system may authorize an alarm
business or alarm agent to connect such system to an indicator panel installed
in the communication facilities of the police department in accordance with
this article, upon first obtaining a permit therefor.
      (2)   If the location of the communication facilities of the police
department shall be changed at any time, the cost of moving any alarm system or
parts thereof shall be borne by permittees.
      (3)   The police chief may limit the number of such permits and may set
standards and regulations governing direct alarm systems. (Ord., § 9, 10-2-
1978)
Sec. 8-52. Application-Form:
Applications for all permits required under this article shall be on a form
prescribed by the chief of police and may request such information as is
necessary to evaluate and act upon the permit application. Applications shall
be accompanied by a nonrefundable requisite fee. The fee is established to
cover part of the cost of investigating and processing the applications and
permits. (Ord., § 10, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-53. Application-Investigation; Denial:
   (a)   Alarm Business; Alarm Agent: Every application for an alarm business
or alarm agent permit shall require a picture and fingerprints of the
applicant. The police chief shall conduct an appropriate investigation of the
applicant to determine whether the permit shall be issued. The police chief may
require additional information of applicants which he deems necessary to
conduct his investigation. The permit shall be denied by the chief of police
if:
      (1)   The character or reputation of the applicant is determined to be
inimical to the safety or general welfare of the community;
      (2)   The applicant for the alarm business permit or alarm agent does not
comply with the standards and regulations adopted pursuant to this article;
      (3)   The applicant, his employee or agent has knowingly made any false,
misleading or fraudulent statement of a material fact in the application for a
permit; or
      (4)   The applicant has had a similar type permit previously revoked for
good cause within the past year unless the applicant can show a material change
in circumstances since the date of revocation.
   (b)   Alarm Systems; Direct Alarm Systems: The permit shall be denied by the
police chief if the alarm system does not comply with the standards and
regulations adopted pursuant to this article. The permit shall be issued to the
person owning, using or possessing the alarm system. If the permit is denied,
the reasons for denial shall be set forth in writing and provided to the
applicant. If the basis for denial can be corrected, the writing shall so state
and shall explain how these corrections may be made and set a reasonable time
limit for making such corrections. The notice of denial shall inform the
applicant that he may appeal the denial and set forth the procedure for appeal.
(Ord., § 15, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-54. Application-Notice Of Information Change:
Whenever any change occurs relating to the written information requested by
this article, the applicant or permittee shall give written notice thereof to
the services division of the police department within fifteen (15) days after
such change or at any hearing conducted under this article if such hearing is
conducted before the notice has been given. (Ord., § 11, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-55. Fees:
   (a)   Permit fees under this article shall be paid to the city collector.
Said fees are as follows:
      (1)   For an alarm system permit, sixty dollars ($60.00).
      (2)   For an alarm business, central station, modified central station or
telephone answering system permit, one hundred dollars ($100.00) annual fee
payable in advance of July 1 of each year.
   (b)   The city reserves the right to own all indicator panels and accessory
equipment for direct alarm systems located within the station. In such case,
each permittee, in addition to the annual permit fee, shall pay an initial
installation fee and an annual user fee, as the same may be established by
ordinance, and uniformly applied to cover the cost of the maintenance of such
facilities. In the event the city decides not to own the equipment within the
station, but to provide for its installation and maintenance by a third party,
it shall establish and regulate reasonable fees and charges which may be
charged permittees. All such fees provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this
section to be charged by the city shall be payable on the date of installation
and shall cover the system until the resident or occupant changes.
   (c)   Regardless of the status of an alarm permit, the members of the police
department will always respond as promptly and effectively as possible to any
and all alarm actuations. However, there will be a service charge for each
false alarm that the police department responds to while the alarm permit is
under suspension or revocation. A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) will be
assessed for each false burglary alarm and a fee of twenty five dollars
($25.00) will be assessed for each false holdup alarm that the police
department responds to during this period. This service charge will be
deposited into the city's general citizens' fund. This service charge will not
exempt the permit holder from the violation penalty adopted pursuant to this
article. (Ord., §§ 12, 16, 10-2-1978; Ord. 82-23, § 2, 8-9-1982; Ord. 87-34, §§
8, 9, 4-6-1987; Ord. 91-17, §§ 2, 3, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, §§ 2, 3, 6-17-1991;
Ord. 35-2003, § 1, 4-28-2003; Ord. 012-2009, § 1, 2-2-2009)
Sec. 8-56. Failure To Pay Ad Valorem Taxes:
No permit shall be issued or renewed pursuant to this article if any ad valorem
taxes upon any real property or personal property used directly or indirectly
in connection with the proposed business or service are delinquent. A receipt
of payment of ad valorem taxes shall be provided for inspection to the city
clerk at the time of issue or renewal of a permit. Where a permit has been
issued and ad valorem taxes on such property thereafter become delinquent, the
permit shall be subject to cancellation immediately without notice and without
right of appeal. (Ord., § 26, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-57. Issuance:
Upon approval by the chief of police of applications for a permit or for
renewal thereof, the chief shall endorse his approval thereon and transmit the
application to the city clerk, who shall be responsible for the issuance of
such permit or renewal thereof. (Ord., § 14, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-58. Suspension Or Revocation-Violation Of Article:
Any permit issued under this article may be suspended by the police chief for
violation of any of the provisions of this article. (Ord., §§ 16, 17, 10-2-
1978)
Sec. 8-59. Suspension Or Revocation-Additional Grounds:
The following shall constitute grounds for suspension and/or revocation of a
permit issued under this article:
      (1)   Where an alarm system is knowingly activated by a subscriber, his
employee or agent in a situation where no burglary or robbery is actually in
progress;
      (2)   Where the permittee, his employee or agent has knowingly made any
false, misleading or fraudulent statement of material fact in the application
for a permit or in any report or record required to be filed with any city
agency;
      (3)   Where any alarm business permittee or alarm agent is charged with a
crime involving moral turpitude or where the character, reputation or moral
integrity of the permit holder or his employee is determined inimical to public
safety or the general welfare of the community;
      (4)   Where the permittee has had a similar type permit previously
revoked for good cause within the past year, unless the applicant can show a
material change in circumstances since the date of revocation; or
      (5)   Where an alarm system, while under a valid permit, actuates
excessive false alarms, it shall constitute a public nuisance. There shall be
no penalty for the first two (2) false alarms by the system in any one calendar
year. Thereafter, there shall be a penalty for the third false alarm violation
in said year in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) each or
seventy five dollars ($75.00) if paid within thirty (30) days of the issuance
of the citation. For any additional false alarms in said year, there shall be a
penalty of two hundred dollars ($200.00) each or one hundred dollars ($100.00)
if paid within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the citation. (Ord., § 16,
10-2-1978; Ord. 91-17, § 5, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, § 5, 6-17-1991; Ord. 93-102,
§ 1, 11-15-1993; Ord. 67-00, § 1, 9-11-2000; Ord. 01-2003, § 1, 1-6-2003)
Sec. 8-60. Suspension Or Revocation-Procedure:
   (a)   The police chief, in the case of suspension, shall serve the permittee
with a written order of suspension which shall state the reasons for such
suspension. The order shall be effective immediately if personally served, or
forty eight (48) hours after the same has been deposited in the course of
transmission in the United States postal service. Immediately upon such an
order becoming effective, the permittee shall discontinue the use of any alarm
system requiring a permit under this article and cease all operations conducted
under the authority of any permit issued pursuant to this article.
   (b)   The suspension shall become a revocation fifteen (15) days after the
order of suspension becomes effective unless the permittee files an appeal of
the order of suspension in the manner set forth in this article. Where an
appeal is filed, the order of suspension shall be stayed, pending a final
determination of the appeal. The suspension shall become a revocation if the
decision of the city manager upholds the suspension, unless said decision is
overruled by the city council. The suspension shall be dissolved immediately if
the decision of the city manager reverses the suspension. (Ord., §§ 18, 19, 10-
2-1978)
Sec. 8-61. Appeal Procedure:
   (a)   The permittee shall have a period of ten (10) days after the issuance
of a ticket in order to present to the chief of police or his designee as to
the circumstances surrounding the incident which the permittee considers to be
beyond the control of the permittee or its alarm agent. The chief shall have
the authority to dismiss the ticket upon good cause shown.
   (b)   Failure to file a letter of appeal within the said fifteen (15) days
shall constitute a waiver of appellant's right to review, but the city manager,
in his discretion, may nevertheless grant such review.
   (c)   If the city manager affirms the decision of the chief of police, the
appellant may have a hearing before the city council on said matter. If the
city manager does not approve the decision of the chief, he shall transmit this
decision to the chief, who will comply with same. (Ord., §§ 21-23, 10-2-1978;
Ord. 91-17, § 6, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, § 6, 6-17-1991)
Sec. 8-62. Surrender Of Permit:
If any permit is revoked pursuant to this article, the permittee shall
surrender the permit to the services division of the police department. (Ord.,
§ 20, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-63. Renewal:
   (a)   Alarm business permits and alarm agent permits issued pursuant to this
article shall expire annually on June 30. All applications for renewal of such
permits shall be filed with the chief of police on forms provided for that
purpose. The fee for renewal of each permit required hereunder shall be the
same as the initial permit fee and shall be paid to the city collector prior to
the time the permit is issued.
   (b)   Alarm system permits need not be renewed. Any modifications of or
additions to an alarm system will require a new permit and may require an
inspection as determined by the chief. (Ord., § 13, 10-2-1978; Ord. 91-17, § 4,
2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, § 4, 6-17-1991)
DIVISION 3. FIRE ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS, AND USERS
Sec. 8-64. Title:
This division shall be known and may be cited as the ROCK ISLAND CITY ORDINANCE
REGULATING FIRE ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS, AND USERS. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-
2002)
Sec. 8-65. Definitions:
   Alarm Agent: Any person who is employed by an alarm business, either
directly or indirectly, whose duties include selling, maintaining, leasing,
servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing on or in any
building, structure or facility, any alarm system. Exemption: The provisions of
this division do not apply to a person who engages in the manufacture or sale
of an alarm system from a fixed location and who neither visits the location
where the alarm system is to be installed, nor designs the scheme for physical
location and installation of the alarm system in a specific location.
   Alarm Business: The business by any individual, partnership or corporation
or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, inspecting, servicing,
repairing, moving or installing any alarm system in or on any building,
structure or facility. Exemption: Said definition shall not apply to persons
engaged solely in the manufacture or sale of alarm system components from a
fixed location, and who do not install, alter, maintain, service or plan the
alarm system for a specific location.
   Alarm System: Any mechanic or electrical device which is designed or used
for the detection of fire or its byproducts in a building, structure or
facility or for alerting others of a fire hazard within a building, structure
or facility, or both; and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message
when actuated and to which the fire department personnel are expected to
respond. In this division, the term "alarm system" shall include the terms
"audible alarm", "automatic dialing device" and "fire alarm system" as those
terms are hereinafter defined. Exemption: The provisions of this division shall
not apply to those detection devices and systems that are not monitored by an
alarm business.
   Answering Service: A telephone answering business providing among its
services receiving, on a continuous basis through trained employees, emergency
signals from alarm systems, and thereafter immediately relaying the message by
live voice over a signal channel circuit to the communications center of the
police and fire departments.
   Appellant: A person who perfects an appeal pursuant to this division.
   Audible Alarm: A device designed for the detection of fire or its byproducts
on premises, which generates an audible sound on the premises when it is
actuated. This audible alarm may or may not be combined with a method of
transmitting a signal to a remote point. Exemption: The provisions of this
division are not applicable to audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles.
   Automatic Dialing Device: An alarm system, which automatically sends over
regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice
message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation
that the alarm system is designed to detect.
   Central Station System: A system or group of systems, usually operated from
its customers by a person, in which the operations of protected circuits and
devices are transmitted to, recorded in, maintained and supervised from a
central station having trained operators and guards in attendance at all times,
that have the duty to take appropriate action upon receipt of a signal or
message including the relaying of messages by a signal channel circuit to the
communications center of the police and fire departments.
   City: The city of Rock Island or its authorized employees or agents.
   False Alarm: The intentional or unintentional activation of an alarm system
through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the
negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or
agents which necessitates response by the Rock Island fire department where an
actual fire or emergency does not exist. Such terminology does not include, for
example, alarms caused by tornadoes, earthquakes or other violent conditions.
   Fire Chief: The chief of the fire department of the city of Rock Island, or
his authorized representative.
   Modified Central Station: An office to which remote alarm and supervisory
signaling devices are connected, where operators supervise the circuits and
relay the message by a "signal channel circuit" to the communications center of
the police and fire departments.
   Nuisance Alarm: An alarm caused by mechanical failure, malfunction, improper
installation, or lack of proper maintenance.
   Primary Trunk Line: A telephone line leading into the communications center
of the police and fire departments, that is for the purpose of handling
emergency calls on a person to person basis, and which line is identified by a
specific listing among the emergency numbers in a telephone directory issued by
the telephone company serving the city.
   Protected Premises: That part of a building, structure or facility to which
protection is afforded by an alarm system.
   Signal Channel Circuit: A telephone service that only provides a two-way
telephone service from one location to another location.
   Subscriber: A person who buys and/or leases, or otherwise obtains an alarm
signaling system and thereafter contracts with or hires an alarm business to
monitor and/or service the alarm device. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-66. Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this division, unless
otherwise provided, shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is
issued a notice of a violation of this division and does not wish to contest
said allegations prior to the time a complaint is issued for said violation,
the person accused may pay to the city finance office a penalty in the sum of
fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction of said violation. (Ord.
37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-67. Purpose:
The purpose of this division is to provide minimum standards and regulations
applicable to fire alarm systems, alarm businesses, alarm agents and alarm
users and to provide for punishment of violations of the provisions of this
division. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-68. Standards And Regulations Enforced By Fire Chief:
The fire chief shall enforce reasonable minimum standards and regulations for
the construction and maintenance of all fire alarm systems installed within the
city as provided in NFPA 72 (the national fire alarm code handbook). All
devices shall meet or exceed such standards, regulations and adopted codes
before their operation is allowed within the city. The fire chief may require
inspection and approval of all alarm systems installed within the city. (Ord.
37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-69. Audible Alarms:
All alarm systems that emit an audible signal that may be heard by persons
outside the protected building, structure or facility shall conform to the
following requirements:
      (1)   Every person maintaining an audible alarm shall provide the fire
chief with the names and telephone numbers of the persons to be notified to
render repairs or service and secure the premises during any hour of the day or
night that the alarm system is activated. It is the responsibility of every
person maintaining an alarm system to assure that the names and telephone
numbers recorded with the fire department are kept current.
      (2)   No person shall install an audible alarm system, which creates a
sound similar to that of an emergency vehicle siren or a civil defense warning
system. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-70. Prohibited Systems:
   (a)   Automatic Dialing Devices: No alarm system using an automatic dialing
device will be allowed to send a prerecorded voice message or coded signal over
a primary trunk line or direct line into the communications center of the
police and fire departments.
   (b)   Panic Alarm: Panic or trouble alarms used to signal the need for help,
medical assistance or any other activity other than an actual fire will be
allowed. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-71. Automatic Dialing Device; Intermediary Services:
   (a)   Persons owning or leasing an automatic dialing device may have the
device interconnected to a telephone line transmitting directly to:
      (1)   A central station;
      (2)   A modified central station; or
      (3)   A licensed answering service.
   (b)   The relaying of messages by intermediate services to the fire
department shall be over a signal channel circuit to the communications center
of the police and fire departments on a person to person basis.
   (c)   The police and fire chiefs may limit the number of "signal channel
circuits" that come into the communications center of the police and fire
departments. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-72. Fire Alarms:
No alarm system equipment, unless city owned and operated, shall transmit any
message on the fire base radio frequency. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-73. Responsibility For Alarm Response:
Every person who has on his premises under his control or ownership an alarm
system, audible or silent, shall, upon notification that the alarm system is
giving a signal, proceed within twenty (20) minutes to the premises and render
all necessary services, provided, however, that the owner of the premises may
enter into an agreement with an alarm business to respond in his stead.
      (1)   Failure to respond to notification of an activated alarm shall be
considered a violation of this provision and shall result in a penalty of fifty
dollars ($50.00).
      (2)   The members of the fire department shall respond as promptly as
possible to any and all alarm actuations. However, there will be a service
charge for excessive false alarms or nuisance alarms to which the fire
department is required to respond. There shall be no penalty for the first
false alarm by the system in any one fiscal year. Thereafter there shall be a
penalty for each false alarm in said fiscal year in the amount of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00). (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-74. Service Available:
Each alarm business shall have licensed alarm agents and supplies and equipment
so located as to be able to respond to a request for repair or adjustment on
any alarm system that such an alarm business sold, maintained, or inspected
within four (4) hours of the request for this service. They shall respond
within four (4) hours of the request, except that if the request occurs within
the hours that the protected premises is open for business or otherwise
substantially occupied, repair or adjustment may be made at any time prior to
closing of the protected premises. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-75. Permits:
There shall be no permit required of any alarm businesses, alarm agents or
subscribers for the purposes of this division. The provisions of this division
shall not affect the provisions of any other article within the code of
ordinances of the city of Rock Island and the required permitting as called for
under any other provisions contained therein. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-76. Notice Of Information Change:
Whenever any change occurs relating to the written information requested by
this division, the subscriber shall give written notice thereof to the fire
prevention division of the fire department within fifteen (15) days after such
change or at any hearing conducted under this division if such hearing is
conducted before the notice has been given. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-77. Appeals Procedure:
   (a)   The appellant shall have a period of ten (10) days after the issuance
of a complaint for violation in order to present to the chief of the fire
department or his designee as to the circumstances surrounding the incident,
which the appellant considers to be beyond the control of the system user or
its alarm agent. The chief shall have the authority to dismiss the complaint of
violation upon good cause shown.
   (b)   Failure to file a letter of appeal within the said fifteen (15) days
shall constitute a waiver of appellant's right to review, but the city manager,
in his discretion, may nevertheless grant such review.
   (c)   If the city manager affirms the decision of the chief of the fire
department, the appellant may have a hearing before the code hearing division
(see section
4-148 of this code) on said matter. If the city manager does not approve the
decision of the chief, he shall transmit this decision to the chief, who will
comply with same. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
