ARTICLE IX. MASSAGE THERAPY BUSINESSES 3
 
Notes
3 See also ch. 7, “Health Generally”, of this Code.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-291. Purpose:
   The State of Illinois licenses massage therapists and their businesses in
accordance with the Illinois Massage Licensing Act. These licensed
professionals perform an important service in addressing the health and well
being of Rock Island residents. Unfortunately, there are businesses that
advertise they provide massage therapy and/or therapeutic services, but
actually engage in various illegal activities. This article is not intended to
discourage a legitimately licensed massage therapist or massage therapy
business from providing their services in the City of Rock Island. The purpose
of this article is to identify and address businesses that engage in the
practice of massage therapy without a license and/or are involved in illegal
activities. Businesses providing massage therapy yet conducting various types
of illegal activity are harmful to both the City of Rock Island and the massage
therapy profession. (Ord. 058-2019, 10-28- 2019)
Sec. 8-292. Definitions:
   Massage Therapy: A system of structured palpation or movement of the soft
tissue of the body. The system may include, but is not limited to, techniques
such as effleurage or stroking and gliding, petrissage or kneading, tapotement
or percussion, friction, vibration, compression, and stretching activities as
they pertain to massage therapy. These techniques may be applied by a licensed
massage therapist with or without the aid of lubricants, salt or herbal
preparations, hydromassage, thermal massage, or a massage device that mimics or
enhances the actions possible by human hands. The purpose of the practice of
massage, as licensed under the Illinois Massage Licensing Act, is to enhance
the general health and well-being of the mind and body of the recipient.
"Massage" does not include the diagnosis of a specific pathology. "Massage"
does not include those acts of physical therapy or therapeutic or corrective
measures that are outside the scope of massage therapy practice as defined in
the Illinois Massage Licensing Act.
   Massage Therapist: An individual who has been licensed by the State of
Illinois to perform massage therapy.
   Massage Therapy Business: A place of business where massage therapy is
practiced or administered. (Ord. 058-2019, 10-28-2019)
Sec. 8-293. Licensing:
   (a)   No person shall employ or contract with a person to perform massage
therapy unless the person is a licensed massage therapist. No person shall
perform massage therapy unless the person is a licensed by the State of
Illinois, unless exempted by the Illinois Massage Licensing Act. No person
shall engage in or offer to engage in the practice of massage therapy or use
the initial "LMT" or the words "licensed massage therapist", "massage
therapist", "masseur", "masseuse" or any other word or title that implies or
represents that a person practices massage therapy at the business, unless the
person possesses a state license.    
   (b)   Each massage therapist shall keep their license in possession at all
times while doing business in the city and shall, upon the request of
prospective customers or city staff, exhibit the license as evidence of
compliance with all requirements of this article.    
   (c)   A massage therapy business shall immediately produce upon request by
city staff the following information.    
      (1)   Name of the business.
      (2)   Names of the business owners.
      (3)   Names and mailing addresses of all individuals who have an
ownership interest in the business.    
      (4)   Names of all massage therapists employed or contracted by the
business and their State license numbers.    
      (5)   Names and addresses of all other persons who work on the business
premises whether employees or independent contractors of the business along
with a description of the work performed.
      (6)   Government issued photo identification card for all employees or
independent contractors of the business to verify and confirm identify of
individuals referenced above. (Ord. 058-2019, 10-28-2019)
Sec. 8-294. Hours of Operation:
Massage therapy businesses shall not be open for business nor shall patrons be
permitted on the premises between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) P.M. and
five o’clock (5:00) A.M. (Ord. 058-2019, 10-28-2019)
Sec. 8-295. Penalties:
   (a)   If the requested business information described in Sec.
8-293  of this article is not immediately produced to city staff upon request,
the business premises may be placarded. If the business information that is
produced is either inaccurate or incomplete, the business may be placarded.
   (b)   The Chief of Police or their designee shall place in a highly
noticeable location a placard stating "Unlicensed Massage Therapy Business: It
is unlawful to provide or receive massage therapy services at this location.
Violators are subject to criminal and/or civil penalty per the Rock Island
Massage Business Ordinance." This notice shall remain posted until required
business information is obtained by the city or other legal use has been
established.    
   (c)   No person shall remove the placard without approval of the Police
Chief or their designee.
   (d)   No person shall continue to offer or receive "massage therapy"
services after a massage therapy business has been placarded unless the Police
Chief or their designee has approved the removal of the placard.
   (e)   Any person found continuing to offer or receive "massage therapy"
services after that establishment has been placarded may be subject to a simple
misdemeanor charge pursuant to state law. (Ord. 058-2019, 10-28-2019)
Secs. 8-296 – 8-355. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. ESTABLISHMENT PERMIT
Sec. 8-316. Required.
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, or to
permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, in or upon any premises in
the city, the operation of a massage establishment as defined in this article,
without first having obtained a permit from the chief of police, after approval
by the health officer.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-317. Application--Filing; fee.
   (a)   Every applicant for a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage
establishment shall file an application in duplicate under oath with the chief
of police under a form provided by said chief of police and pay a nonrefundable
filing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to the city collector, who shall
issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application filed with the chief
of police.
   (b)   The chief of police shall within five (5) days refer copies of said
application to the health department, building inspection department, fire
department and planning department. These departments shall within thirty (30)
days inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a massage establishment
and make written recommendations to the chief of police concerning compliance
with the codes that they administer.
   (c)   Within ten (10) days of receipt of the recommendations of the
aforementioned departments, the chief of police shall notify the applicant that
his application is granted, denied or held for further investigation. The
period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional thirty
(30) days unless otherwise agreed to by the applicant. Upon the conclusion of
such additional investigation the chief of police shall advise the applicant in
writing whether the application is granted or denied.
   (d)   Whenever an application is denied or held for further investigation,
the chief of police shall advise the applicant in writing of the reasons for
such action.
   (e)   The failure or refusal of the applicant to promptly give any
information relevant to the investigation of the application or his or her
refusal or failure to appear at any reasonable time and place for examination
under oath regarding the said application or his or her refusal to submit to or
cooperate with any inspection required by this article shall constitute an
admission by the applicant that he or she is ineligible for such permit and
shall be grounds for denial thereof by the chief of police.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-318. Same--Contents.
   (a)   The application for a permit to operate a massage establishment shall
set forth the exact nature of the massage to be administered and the proposed
place of business and facilities therefor.
   (b)   In addition to the foregoing, any applicant for a permit, including
any partner or limited partner of a partnership applicant, and any officer or
director of a corporate applicant and any stockholder holding more than ten
(10) percent of the stock of a corporate applicant shall furnish the following
information:
      (1)   Name and address.
      (2)   Written proof that the individual is at least eighteen (18) years
of age.
      (3)   All residential addresses for the past three (3) years.
      (4)   The applicant's height, weight, color of eyes and hair.
      (5)   The business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the
three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application.
      (6)   The massage or similar business license history of the applicant;
whether such person, in previously operating in this or an other city or state
under license, has had such license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor
and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension
or revocation.
      (7)   All criminal or city ordinance violation convictions, forfeiture of
bond and pleadings of nolo contendere on all charges, except minor traffic
violations.
      (8)   The fingerprints and photograph of the applicant.
      (9)   If the applicant is a corporation, or a partner of a partnership is
a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown
in its articles of incorporation.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-319. Facilities.
No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an
inspection by the appropriate city inspectors reveals that the establishment
complies with each of the following minimum requirements:
   (1)   Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths and showers
shall be made waterproof with approved waterproofed materials and shall be
installed in accordance with the city's building code. Plumbing fixtures shall
be installed in accordance with the city's plumbing code.
      a.   For toilet rooms, toilet room vestibules and rooms containing
bathtubs, there shall be a waterproof floor covering, which will be carried up
all walls to a height of at least six (6) inches. Floor shall be covered up on
base with at least three-fourth-inch cover. The walls of all toilet rooms and
rooms containing bathtubs shall be finished to a height of six (6) feet with a
smooth, non-absorbent finish surface of Keene cement, tile or similar material.
      b.   Steam rooms and shower compartments shall have waterproof floors,
walls and ceilings approved by the inspector.
      c.   Floors or wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one
(1) or more floor drains properly connected to the sewer. (Exception: Dry heat
rooms with wooden floors need not be provided with pitched floors and floor
drains.
      d.   A source of hot water must be available within the immediate
vicinity of dry and wet heat rooms to facilitate cleaning.
   (2)   Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When five
(5) or more employees and patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the
same time, separate toilet facilities shall be provided. A single water closet
per sex shall be provided for each twenty (20) or more employees or patrons of
that sex on the premises at any one time. Urinal may be substituted for water
closets after one water closet has been provided. All toilet rooms shall be
equipped with self-closing doors opening in the direction of ingress to the
toilet rooms. Toilets shall be designates as to the sex accommodated therein.
   (3)   Lavatories or washbasins provided with both hot and cold running water
shall be installed in either the toilet room or the vestibule. Lavatories or
washbasins shall be provided with soap in a dispenser and with sanitary towels.
   (4)   All portions of massage establishments and baths shall be provided
with adequate light and ventilation by means of windows or sky lights with an
area of not less than one-eighth of the total floor area, or shall be provided
with approved artificial light and a mechanically operating ventilating system.
When windows or skylights are used for ventilation, at least one-half of the
total required window area shall be operable. To allow for adequate
ventilation, cubicles, rooms and areas provided for patrons' use not served
directly by a required window, skylight or mechanical system of ventilation
shall be constructed so that the height of partitions does not exceed seventy-
five (75) percent of the floor-to-ceiling height of the area in which they are
located.
   (5)   All electrical equipment shall be installed in accordance with the
requirements of the city's electrical code.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-320. Issuance; duration.
Upon receipt of the recommendations of the departments referred to in section
8-317, and the certificate of the health officer that the establishment is in
compliance with all of the requirements of section 8-296, the chief of police
shall issue a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment,
unless he finds:
   (1)   That the operation as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would
not have complied with all applicable laws, including but not limited to, the
building, health, planning, housing, zoning and fire codes of the city; or
   (2)   That the applicant and any other person who will be directly or
indirectly engaged in the management and operation of a massage establishment
has been convicted of:
      a.   A felony.
      b.   An offense involving sexual misconduct with children.
      c.   Prostitution, soliciting for a prostitute, pandering, keeping a
place of prostitution, pimping or other offense opposed to decency and
morality.
The chief of police, at his discretion, may issue a permit to any person
convicted of any of the crimes in paragraph (2)(a)--c) if he finds that such
conviction occurred at least four (4) years prior to the date of application,
the applicant has had no subsequent convictions and the applicant has shown
evidence of rehabilitation sufficient to warrant the public trust. Every
massage establishment permit issued pursuant to this subdivision will terminate
at the expiration of one year from the date of its issuance, unless sooner
suspended or revoked.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Cross references--Buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; fire prevention
and protection, ch. 6; health, ch. 7; planning and development, ch.11;
zoning, app. A .
Sec. 8-321. Transfer.
No permit for the operation of a massage establishment issued pursuant to the
provisions of this article shall be transferable except with the written
consent of the chief of police and approval of the health officer, provided,
however, that upon the death or incapacity of the permittee the massage
establishment may continue in business for a reasonable period of time to allow
for an orderly transfer of the permit.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-322. Revocation; suspension.
   (a)   Any permit issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or
suspended by the chief of police after a hearing for good cause or in any case
where any of the provisions of this article are violated or any employee of the
permittee, including a masseur or masseuse, is engaged in any conduct at
permittee's place of business which violates any of the provisions of this
article or any state law which provides for imprisonment, and permittee has
actual or constructive knowledge of such violation or the permittee should have
actual or constructive knowledge by due diligence, or where any applicant has
made a false statement on an application for a permit under this article or in
any case where the permittee or licensee refuses to permit any duly authorized
police officer or health inspector of the city and the county to inspect the
premises or the operations therein. Such permit may also be revoked or
suspended by the chief of police, after hearing, upon the recommendations of
the health officer that such business is being managed, conducted or maintained
without regard for the public health or health of patrons or customers or
without due regard to proper sanitation or hygiene.
   (b)   Any violation of this article by any employee of the permittee,
including a masseur or masseuse, shall be cause for suspension of the permit
for not more than thirty (30) days in the first instance. Any subsequent
violation of this article by any employee of the permittee, including a masseur
or masseuse, shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the permit.
   (c)   The chief of police, before revoking or suspending any permit, shall
give the permittee at least ten (10) days written notice of the charges against
him or her and the opportunity for a public hearing before the chief of police,
at which time the permittee may present evidence bearing upon the questions. In
such cases, the charges shall be specific and in writing.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Secs. 8-323--8-335. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. MASSEUR OR MASSEUSE PERMIT
Sec. 8-336. Required; fee.
Any person, including an applicant for massage establishment permit, who
engages in the practice of massage as defined in this article, shall file an
application for a masseur or masseuse permit with the chief of police upon a
form provided by said chief of police and shall pay a nonrefundable filing fee
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for an original application and twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) for a renewal application, to the city collector, who shall
issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application filed with the chief
of police.
(Ord. of 1-7-77, § 1; Ord. No. 91-14, § 8, 2-11-91)
Sec. 8-337. Application form.
The application for a masseur or masseuse license shall contain the following:
   (1)   Name and residence address.
   (2)   Social security number and driver's license number, if any.
   (3)   Applicant's weight, height, color of hair and eyes.
   (4)   Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of
age.
   (5)   Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the three (3)
years immediately preceding the date of application.
   (6)   Whether such person has ever been convicted of any crime, except
misdemeanor traffic violations. If any person mentioned in this paragraph has
been so convicted, a statement must be made giving the place and court in which
such conviction was had, the specific charge under which the conviction was
obtained and the sentence imposed as a result of such conviction.
   (7)   The name and address of the recognized school attended, the date
attended and a copy of the diploma or certificate of graduation awarded the
applicant showing that the applicant has completed not less than seventy (70)
hours of instruction.
   (8)   The chief of police shall have the right to take fingerprints and a
photograph of the applicant and the right to confirm the information submitted.
(Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-338. Issuance:
The chief of police may issue a masseur or masseuse permit within twenty one
(21) days following a hearing unless he finds that the applicant for a masseur
or masseuse permit has been convicted of an offense involving the use of force
and violence on the person of another that amounts to a felony. (Ord., 1-17-
1977)
Sec. 8-339. Revocation:
A masseur or masseuse permit issued by the chief of police shall be revoked or
suspended where it appears that the masseur or masseuse has been convicted of
any offense which would be cause for denial of a permit upon an original
application, has made a false statement on an application for a permit or has
committed an act in violation of this article. The chief of police in revoking
or suspending a masseur or masseuse permit shall give the permit holder a
written notice specifying the grounds therefor. Such person may within ten (10)
days of such revocation or suspension file a written request with the chief of
police for a public hearing before the chief, at which time the masseur or
masseuse may present evidence at the hearing upon the question. The decision of
the chief of police upon such hearing shall be a final appealable order. (Ord.,
1-17-1977)
Secs. 8-340 - 8-355. Reserved:
ARTICLE X. PAWNBROKERS 1
 
Notes
1 205 ILCS 510/1; 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5 et seq.
Sec. 8-356. Definition:
Any person who lends money on deposit or pledge of personal property, bonds,
notes or other valuable things or securities, or who deals in the purchasing of
personal property on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated
price, is, for the purposes of this article, a pawnbroker. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-
2)
Sec. 8-357. License - Required:
No person shall exercise or carry on the business of pawnbroker within the city
without being duly licensed therefor. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-1)
Sec. 8-358. License - Duration; Bond; Fee:
The city clerk with the approval of the city council shall grant a pawnbroker's
license to any person of good character who may apply therefor, upon said
person giving bond with approved security in the sum of five hundred dollars
($500.00), conditioned upon the faithful observance of all ordinances of the
city applicable to the business so licensed and paying to the city collector
the sum required for said license. Said license may be issued for six (6)
months or for one year, but not beyond the end of the municipal year, and the
applicant shall pay therefor, for one year, two hundred dollars ($200.00) and
for six (6) months, one hundred dollars ($100.00). (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-3; Ord.,
2-23-1976)
Sec. 8-359. Hours Of Business:
No person licensed under this article shall receive on deposit or pledge any
personal property or other valuable thing before six o'clock (6:00) A.M. nor
after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. during January, February, March, April,
October, November and December of each year, nor before five o'clock (5:00)
A.M. nor after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. during the months of May, June, July,
August and September of each year. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-9)
Sec. 8-360. Time Of Redemption Or Removal Of Pledge:
No personal property received in deposit or pledge by any person licensed under
this article shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or removed from the
place of business of such licensed person for twenty four (24) hours after a
report required to be delivered to the chief of police shall have been
delivered as required by 205 Illinois Compiled Statutes 510/7. (1963 Code § 6-2
(L)-8)
Sec. 8-361. Dealings With Minors 2 :
No person licensed under this article shall take or receive in pawn or purchase
any article, property or effects from any minor, or claimed by any minor. (1963
Code § 6-2(L)-10)

Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
ordinance relating to peddlers, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized
as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at

ARTICLE XII. TAXICABS 4 , 5
 
Notes
4 See § 9-34, cab stands, of this code.
5 65 ILCS 5/11-42-4, 5/11-42-6.
Sec. 8-396. License - Required:
No automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle shall be used for the
transportation of persons for hire within the city, whether said vehicle
secures its passengers from a public stand or stands upon the street or whether
the same is kept in a private garage, unless every such vehicle is licensed as
provided in this article. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-1)
Sec. 8-397. License - Application; Fee; Term; Bond; Insurance 6 :
   (a)   The owner of any automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle for
which it is desired to secure a license under this article shall make
application to the city clerk setting forth therein the name of such owner or
owners, a description of the vehicle for which it is desired to secure a
license and the place where such vehicle is kept, if the same is kept in a
private garage. The applicant shall be provided the application form by said
city clerk. The city clerk, upon receipt of such application, shall issue or
cause to be issued a license for such vehicle upon payment by the applicant of
a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum. Such license fee shall be
paid to the city collector, and upon payment thereof, a license shall be
issued, attested by the city clerk, authorizing the use of such vehicle in
accordance with the provisions of this article until the expiration of such
license. And each license when granted shall expire at the end of the municipal
year following the issuance of such license.
   (b)   Provided, however, that the owner of any such automobile, autocar,
cab, motor vehicle or other similar vehicle shall first exhibit to the city
clerk a certificate issuing from the office of the secretary of state of
Illinois, or an affidavit of said owner certifying that he, his agent, servant
or operator has fully complied with the requirements of the Illinois Compiled
Statutes governing chauffeurs engaged in driving automobiles, motor vehicles or
similar vehicles for hire, and further certifying that said owner, his agent or
operators have posted good and sufficient bond or policy of insurance to the
office of the secretary of state of Illinois pursuant to the requirement of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes governing the same. Said requirements of said
Illinois Compiled Statutes are incorporated as requirements of this section by
reference thereto. Failure of any owner or operator licensed hereunder to file
such certificate or affidavit with the city clerk, after ten (10) days' notice
given to him by said clerk to so file, shall be deemed sufficient ground for
revocation of any license issued hereunder. Failure to perform the requirements
of this section shall be deemed an offense and shall subject any such offender
to the penalties provided for a violation of this code. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-2;
Ord., 2-23-1976)
 
Notes
6 See § 2-2, "Municipal Year", of this code.
Sec. 8-398. Limitation Of Licenses:
   (a)   The total number of taxicab licenses which shall be issued by the city
shall not exceed fifty (50).
   (b)   Prior to the granting of a license to new applicants for licenses
under the provisions of this article, the application shall be referred to the
city council for its investigation and recommendation. All new applicants shall
submit their fingerprints to the Rock Island police department and submit the
required, nonrefundable processing fee for the purpose of conducting a criminal
history check prior to the issuance of a taxicab license. (1963 Code § 6-4(T)-
4; Ord. 006-2017, 2-13-2017)
Sec. 8-399. Taxicab Drivers - Investigation:
At the time a taxicab driver is hired by any licensee under this article, said
licensee shall submit to the chief of police the name of said driver and any
background information said licensee has concerning said driver and also an
authorization in writing from said driver authorizing the police department to
make a background check of said driver, including checking of any available
criminal record, along with the required, nonrefundable processing fee for the
purpose of conducting said criminal history check. Upon receipt of said
information, authorization and the required fee, the chief of police shall make
or cause to be made a careful and diligent inquiry as to the character and
record of said driver for honesty, sobriety and capability, and if it shall be
found that such applicant is lacking in any of such respects, the chief of
police shall notify the licensee of the information that resulted from said
investigation. (Ord. 006-2017, 2-13-2017)
Sec. 8-400. Taxicab Drivers - License Fee:
The annual license fee for a taxicab driver shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) or
ten dollars ($10.00) if purchased after October 31 of the same license year,
and such annual licensing period shall commence on May 1 of each year. (1963
Code § 6-2(T)-14; Ord., 8-10-1981; Ord. 87-34, 4-6-1987)
Sec. 8-401. Taxicab Drivers - Record:
   (a)   The chief of police shall keep at his office a record in which shall
be kept the name and residence of each licensed driver or operator together
with the names of persons endorsing his application, and shall carefully note
opposite each such licensed driver's name such information as he may gain
concerning said licensee and as may be necessary to provide a complete record
of said licensee's conduct and qualifications as a driver or operator.
   (b)   The chief of police may suspend or revoke any taxicab driver's license
when in his opinion the licensee does not have the qualifications specified in
this article for said license. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-13)
Sec. 8-402. Taxicab Drivers - Transfer Of License:
It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer any taxicab driver's license
from one person to another. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-15)
Sec. 8-403. Safety Inspection:
   (a)   All vehicles used and licensed as taxicabs shall at all times be
maintained in proper mechanical condition. It shall be necessary to present the
city clerk an affidavit that the particular vehicle used has a license to
operate as a taxicab for said vehicle.
   (b)   The chief of police shall have the authority to order the owners of
any vehicles used as taxicabs in the city to take said vehicles out of
operation if said vehicles are found to be in unsafe mechanical condition. Said
vehicles shall remain out of operation until proper repairs on said vehicles
are made to place said vehicles in proper mechanical condition. (1963 Code § 6-
2(T)-3)
Sec. 8-404. Public Stands:
   (a)   Use: Any automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle licensed
under the provisions of this article may stand at such places, and at no other
places, as may from time to time be designated by the council for that purpose.
   (b)   Location:
      (1)   General: The following places are public stands where taxicabs,
autocars and all other vehicles let to hire or used for transporting persons or
property for hire shall stand while waiting for such employment:
         a.   One parking space on the west side of Seventeenth Street between
Second and Third Avenues immediately north of the Sheraton Hotel driveway.
         b.   One parking space on the south side of Third Avenue between
Nineteenth and Twentieth Streets.
         c.   Two (2) parking spaces on the north side of Second Avenue between
Nineteenth and Twentieth Streets.
         d.   Two (2) parking spaces on the south side of Second Avenue
immediately west of Nineteenth Street.
The chief of police shall assign the above spaces to the respective taxicab
companies or concerns. When such spaces or stands have been so assigned, no
other taxicab company or concern shall use any other taxicab space, except the
space or spaces to which they have been assigned as aforesaid.
      (2)   Public Places: Public stands shall also be deemed to exist at
hotels, theaters and other public places at such times and for such length of
time as may be reasonably necessary for the receiving and discharging of
passengers at such places.
   (c)   Parking - Distance From Corner: No automobile, autocar, cab or other
similar vehicle entitled to use such stands shall be permitted to stand
anywhere thereon in such manner as to obstruct the entrance to any building,
structure or place, nor shall any automobile, autocar or other similar vehicle
entitled to use stands be permitted to stand within twenty feet (20') of any of
the intersecting streets or avenues upon which any of the stands are located.
   (d)   Parking - Off Street Facilities: No automobile, autocar, cab or other
similar vehicle licensed under the provisions of this article shall park in or
occupy any of the off street parking facilities of the city. (1963 Code § 6-2
(T)-5; Ord. 85-19, 6-24-1985; Ord. 88-73, 12-19-1988)
Sec. 8-405. Designation Of Car:
Every automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle licensed under the
provisions of this article shall have the name of the owner thereof plainly
painted in letters at least one and one-half inches (11/2") in height, and the
number at least four inches (4") in height, in a conspicuous place on the
outside of each side of such vehicle, and such name and number shall be kept so
painted plainly and distinctly at all times while such vehicle is in use during
the continuance of such license. Upon the expiration of such license (unless
same is forthwith renewed) such name and number shall be at once erased from
such vehicle and such vehicle shall not thereafter be used with such name or
number thereon. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-6)
Sec. 8-406. Property Left In Car By Passenger:
Whenever any package, article or baggage or goods of any kind shall be left in
or upon any vehicle licensed under the provisions of this article, the operator
of such vehicle shall, upon discovery of such package, baggage or goods,
forthwith deliver the same to the shift commander at the police station in the
city.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 7)
Sec. 8-407. Posting of rates; overnight parking.
   (a)   Number of passengers, rates posted. No operator or person in charge or
control of any automobile, autocar, cab, motor vehicle or other similar vehicle
licensed hereunder shall contemporaneously convey more than five (5) passengers
scheduled for more than five (5) destinations, and no charge for any additional
passengers in excess of one and not in excess of five (5) shall be made where
all said passengers board the vehicle licensed hereunder at the same place of
origin and all are discharged at the point of termination of any one trip. A
copy of the schedule of rates herein provided to be charged in the said zones
herein established shall be placed and kept in each vehicle licensed hereunder
in a conspicuous place in each of the said vehicles as to be at all times
openly visible to any or all of the public using said vehicles for public
transportation.
   (b)   Overnight parking. Between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.,
each taxicab company operating in the city may have one (1) cab parked at each
of the following locations:
      (1)   Zone No. 1, which shall be on Second Avenue between Eighteenth and
Nineteenth Streets.
      (2)   Zone No. 2, which shall be Sixteenth Street between Second and
Third Avenues.
      (3)   Zone No. 3, which shall be Seventeenth Street between Second and
Third Avenues.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 8; Ord. of 12-6-65, § 1; Ord. of 12-11-72, §
1; Ord. of 1-21-74, §§ 1--3; Ord. of 8-11-75, § 1; Ord. of 9-12-77, §§ 1, 2;
Ord. of -15-79, § 1; Ord. of 5-21-79, § 1; Ord. of 2-9-81, § 1; Ord. No. 83-49,
§§ 1, 2, 12-19-83)
Sec. 8-408. Seating of passengers.
No person operating under a taxicab license, shall, as principal, agent or
employee, permit any person to stand or sit upon the runningboard, fender or
hood of the automobile, autocar or other similar vehicle while said vehicle is
in operation. (Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 9)
Sec. 8-409. Advance payment; giving information.
Any person licensed under this article may demand his legal fare to be paid in
advance by any person seeking to employ him, and may refuse to convey any
person who shall fail to comply with such demand. Any person so licensed shall
give to any person requesting the same, his name and the number of his license.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 10)
Sec. 8-410. Records.
Each operator of a licensed vehicle used and operated as a taxicab shall keep
records on a daily basis indicating on said records the time and place each
passenger is picked up and delivered and the amount charged for each fare.
These records shall be kept by owners of said vehicle for one (1) year.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 11)
Sec. 8-411-8-415. Reserved.
ARTICLE XIII. TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 1
 
Notes
1 State law reference--Authority of city to license and regulate itinerant
  merchants, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-416. Definitions.
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation of this article:
   Residence: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes, by
one (1) or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure.
   Transient merchant: Any person, the nature of whose business activity
indicates the intent to remain in business in the city for less than one (1)
year, who:
      (1)   Offers for sale tangible personal property or personal services, or
      (2)   Takes or attempts to take orders for the sale of tangible personal
property or services, including advertising or subscriptions to be furnished or
performed in the future.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(R), § 2; Ord. No. 82-44, § 1, 10-25-82)
Sec. 8-417. Penalty.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon
conviction, be subject to imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days, or a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each sale or solicitation of
a sale made without a license or bond in violation of this article shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 82-44, § 14, 10-25-82)
Sec. 8-418. Sales.
   (a)   No person shall engage in activities regulated under this article on
public property without first procuring special authorization from the city
council.
   (b)   No person shall shout, or use any sound device upon any of the public
places of the city or upon any private premises in said city, where sound of
sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom to be capable of being
plainly heard from the public places, for the purpose of attracting attention
to any goods, wares, merchandise or services which such person proposes to
sell.
   (c)   No person shall engage in business as a transient merchant in defiance
of any notice exhibited at a residence or business indicating that peddlers or
solicitors are not welcome or not invited.
   (d)   No person shall engage in the activities regulated under this article
from door to door prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any weekday or at
any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.
(Ord. No. 82-44, § 4, 10-25-82)
Sec. 8-419. Fixed location.
   (a)   No transient merchant shall engage in business at a fixed location
without the written permission, by lease or otherwise, of the owner or person
in control of the property. This written agreement shall be signed by the
parties and shall include the dates the transient merchant shall be conducting
business. This agreement shall be displayed by the transient merchant at such
fixed location when he is doing business there.
   (b)   A transient merchant doing business at a fixed location shall provide
sufficient off-street parking space for his employees and customers.
   (c)   Any display of tangible personal property, or signs or advertisements
therefor, shall be at least fifteen (15) feet from the curbline. All signs and
advertisements used in connection with the business licensed in this article
shall comply with the appropriate sections of this Code.
   (d)   The owner or person in control of the property shall furnish bathroom
facilities for the use of the transient merchant.
   (e)   A transient merchant doing business at a fixed location shall do so
only in areas properly zoned for business activity. A transient merchant
selling food items shall comply with all applicable provisions of the city's
health code.
(Ord. No. 82-44, § 5, 10-25-81)
Sec. 8-420. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-421. Required; Application:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a
transient merchant in the city without first obtaining a license as provided in
this division.
   (b)   An application for a transient merchant license shall give the
following information:
      (1)   The name or names of the person having the management or
supervision of applicant's business, whether such person will act as
proprietor, agent, consignee or employee, during the time that it is proposed
it will be carried on in the city; the local address or addresses of such
person while engaged in such business.
      (2)   The permanent address or addresses of such person; whether such
person will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee and the credentials
establishing such relationship; the name and address of the person for whose
account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under
the laws of what state the same is incorporated.
      (3)   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
said business shall be conducted.
      (4)   The place or places other than the permanent place of business of
the applicant, where applicant within three (3) years next preceding the date
of said application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof
and giving the post office box number and street address of any building or
office in which said business was conducted.
      (5)   A statement of the nature and character of the tangible personal
property or service to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the
city; whether the goods are new, damaged or rejects; whether the same are
proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample; where the goods or
property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where goods or
products are located at the time said application is filed.
      (6)   Whether or not the person having management or supervision of the
applicant's business, whether such person will act as proprietor, agent,
consignee or employee, has been convicted of a felony within the five (5) years
immediately preceding the date of said application or of the violation of any
law or ordinance relating to the same or similar business to be conducted by
applicant, the nature of such offense and the punishment therefor.
         a.   All applicants, whether such person will act as proprietor,
agent, consignee or employee, shall submit their fingerprints to the Rock
Island police department and submit the required, nonrefundable processing fee
per submission for the purpose of conducting a criminal history check prior to
the issuance of a transient merchant license.
      (7)   Whether the applicant has ever applied for a license under this
article, which has been denied.
      (8)   Whether the applicant has ever held a license under this article,
which has been revoked. (1963 Code §§ 6-2(R)-1, 6-2(R)-3; Ord. 82-44, 10-25-
1982; Ord. 006-2017, 2-13-2017)
Sec. 8-422. Bond:
   (a)   Except as provided in this article, each applicant for a transient
merchant license or a blanket license hereunder shall file with the city clerk
a bond running to the city, in the penal sum therein set forth, executed by
applicant as principal, and by a corporate surety upon which service of process
may be made in the state, the bond to be approved by the city attorney,
conditioned that the applicant shall comply with the provisions of all of the
ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state, regulating and concerning
the sale of goods, subscriptions, wares, merchandise or personal property of
any nature, including foodstuffs, or for services, including advertising, and
will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of
ordinances or statutes or any of them together, with all judgments and costs
that may be recovered against applicant by any person or persons for damage
growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person
transacting such business with applicant, whether said misrepresentation or
deception was made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or
employees, either at the time of making the sale, or the solicitation of the
sale, or through any advertisements of any character whatsoever, printed or
circulated with reference to the subject matter of such sale or any part
thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use
of the aggrieved person. Such bond shall be further conditioned to indemnify
and pay the city for any penalties or costs occasioned by the enforcement of
this article and shall not be retired until after a lapse of one year from the
expiration of each license.
   (b)   The following persons shall be exempt from the requirement of posting
bond: Transient merchants selling subscriptions, tangible personal property or
services, where each sale does not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) to any person
or to any member of any purchaser's immediate family within any consecutive
three (3) month period and where, in addition, no payment, down payment or
deposit whatsoever is required to be made or paid until the property is
actually delivered or the services are actually performed.
   (c)   Any person claiming an exemption under the provisions of this section
shall make request therefor in writing and shall state in said request that the
applicant shall not make any sales in violation of the provisions of this
section.
   (d)   All licenses issued where the transient merchant is exempt from the
posting of bond under this section shall contain the following language: "No
bond has been furnished the city of Rock Island by the holder of this license".
   (e)   The penal sum of the bond required under the provisions of this
article is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or two (2) times the value of the
tangible personal property or service to be sold or offered for sale or the
average inventory to be carried by the transient merchant as shown by the
application, whichever amount is greater.
   (f)   The applicant for a blanket license shall in all cases furnish a bond
described in subsection (a) of this section in the penal sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 82-44, § 9, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 8-423. Duplicate And Individual Licenses:
A transient merchant license may be issued to a person carrying on the business
of transient merchant in this city through employees. Such employees shall
carry a duplicate license issued to the person, which license shall be obtained
at the city clerk's office. If the business of transient merchant in this city
is carried on through agents who are not employees or by consignees, or by an
unincorporated firm or association, each person so conducting the business of
transient merchant in this city shall be required to have a separate license,
but not post a separate bond if one is posted by the corporation. (Ord. 82-44,
§ 10, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 8-424. Blanket License:
   (a)   The owner or person in control of any real property located in the
city, upon which a permanent business and building is located, who conducts
events regulated and required to be licensed under this article, or who leases
the premises to transient merchants for such regulated events, may procure a
blanket annual license, and the individuals conducting the various concessions
there will not be required to obtain individual licenses, under the following
conditions:
      (1)   The owner or person in control of such real property shall be
required to submit in writing to the city clerk, on forms provided by the
clerk, the locations of the premises upon which such activities are to be
conducted, the names and addresses of the officers and directors or other
governing body of the owner of the premises and the name, permanent address and
business address of the person in charge of managing such property. Said person
shall also sign a statement that, in the event the license is granted, he will
comply with all the provisions of this article and that he guarantees that the
transient merchant leasing property from him shall also comply with all the
provisions of this article.
      (2)   The licensee shall make the provisions of this article a part of
any agreement for the use of the premises for any purpose to which the
provisions of this article are applicable.
      (3)   It shall be the responsibility of licensee not to permit any person
to operate or conduct a business on the premises as transient merchant who is
not entitled to conduct such business under the blanket license.
   (b)   Any person conducting or sponsoring an activity described in
subsection (a) of this section may secure a single event blanket license for
the same uses and purposes and on the same terms and conditions as the annual
blanket license. A single event blanket license shall be valid for a period of
six (6) months and may be used for fourteen (14) cumulative days during said
six (6) month period. (Ord. 82-44, § 11, 10-25-1982; Ord. 82-74, § 1, 2-28-
1983)
Sec. 8-425. Exemptions:
Persons engaged in the following described activities are exempt from the duty
of applying for a transient merchant license:
   (1)   Persons selling at wholesale to merchants for the purpose of resale.
   (2)   Persons selling or distributing newspapers.
   (3)   Persons selling tangible personal property or services to business
enterprises.
   (4)   Persons who sell, at their permanent residence in the city, works of
art or craft made or created by such person or a member of such person's
immediate family.
   (5)   Persons licensed by the state to sell real estate or insurance or
licensed as transient vendors of drugs.
   (6)   Persons selling or distributing livestock feeds as defined by the laws
of the state 1 .
   (7)   Persons selling or delivering tangible personal property or services
through a permanent business licensed by the city.
   (8)   Persons selling at events for which a blanket license has been
obtained.
   (9)   Persons selling or distributing on their property fresh fruit or
vegetables cultivated by such person.
   (10)   Persons selling tangible personal property at a garage, basement or
yard sale held at one of the person's premises.
   (11)   Persons conducting and selling admissions to or for theatricals,
shows, rides, sports and games, concerts, circuses, carnivals or any other
public amusement where no sales of other products are involved and such sales
are made on the premises where the event is to be conducted.
   (12)   Persons selling food and beverages at a food service establishment
regulated pursuant to the health code of the city.
   (13)   A religious, charitable, patriotic, social service, civic or
political nonprofit organization. (Ord. 82-44, § 12, 10-25-1982)
 
Notes
1 505 ILCS 30/1 et seq.
Sec. 8-426. Issuance; Fees; Display:
   (a)   If an application for a license under this article contains a complete
statement of the information required and all material required to be submitted
therewith is filed with the city clerk, the clerk, subject to the provisions of
section
8-421 of this chapter, shall issue within twenty one (21) days, upon posting of
the bond required by section
8-422 of this chapter, the license. The license issued hereunder shall not be
transferable. There shall be no refund of the license fee.
   (b)   Before a license shall be issued, applicant shall pay to the city
collector a license fee according to the following schedule:
      (1)   Blanket License:
         a.   Single event blanket license, fifty dollars ($50.00).
         b.   Blanket annual license, three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      (2)   Transient Merchant's License:
         a.   For one day, twenty five dollars ($25.00); for each additional
day, five dollars ($5.00).
         b.   For one month, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
         c.   For three (3) months, two hundred dollars ($200.00).
         d.   For six (6) months, two hundred seventy five dollars ($275.00).
         e.   For one year, four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00).
      (3)   Duplicate License: Five dollars ($5.00).
   (c)   Each transient merchant shall at all times while doing business in the
city keep in the possession of such person the license required by this article
and shall, upon request, display the license as evidence of compliance with the
requirements of this article. (Ord. 82-44, §§ 3, 7, 8, 10-25-1982; Ord. 007-
2013, 3-4-2013)
Sec. 8-427. Denial; Revocation:
   (a)   The city manager may deny, within twenty one (21) days, a license to
any applicant under this article who has:
      (1)   Held a license under this article that has been revoked within two
(2) years of the date of the present application.
      (2)   Failed to make a complete application.
      (3)   During the past two (2) years, a history of:
         a.   Fraudulent applications for similar licenses.
         b.   Misrepresentation of the quality of merchandise or services
offered for sale.
         c.   Crimes involving personal injury.
   (b)   The city manager may revoke any license issued under the provisions of
this article by sending a notice of revocation by certified mail to the license
holder at his last known address, return receipt requested, or by personal
service on the license holder or its officers for any of the following causes:
      (1)   Information showing that the license was erroneously issued
initially.
      (2)   For any violation of the provisions of this article.
      (3)   For any violation of any city or state law regulating the sales
activities of the license holder.
   (c)   The license shall stand denied or revoked unless within five (5) days
after denial or receipt of the notice of revocation from the city manager the
applicant or holder files a written request for a public hearing on the city
manager's action. A public hearing shall be conducted before the city council
on whether a license should be denied, reinstated or revoked, as the case may
be. The city council may order the license issued or reinstated either
conditionally or unconditionally, or revoke the license. Ten (10) days' notice
of the time and place of the public hearing shall be given to the license
holder, who shall have an opportunity to appear before the city council and
present any evidence or arguments he may have why the action taken by the city
manager should not be approved by the city council. (Ord. 82-44, § 13, 10-25-
1982)
Secs. 8-428--8-430. Reserved.
ARTICLE XIV. TREE REMOVERS, TREE TRIMMERS, ETC. 1
 
Notes
1 State law reference--Tree experts, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 111, § 6701 et seq.
Sec. 8-431. Definitions:
As used in this article:
   Tree Remover: Any person, firm or corporation that, for profit, removes a
tree stump or a tree standing in any street, alley, parkway, boulevard or other
public or private place in the city of Rock Island.
   Tree Trimmer: Any person, firm or corporation that, for profit, diagnoses
the condition of a shade, forest or ornamental tree and recommends or
supervises the treatment of any such tree, by feeding or fertilizing, or by
pruning, trimming, bracing, treating cavities or other methods, or protects or
attempts to protect any such trees from damage by insects or disease by
spraying or any other method. (1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(U), §§ 1, 3; Ord., §
1, 2-11-1965)
Sec. 8-432. Tree Remover Generally:
   (a)   No person engaged in the business of removing trees shall remove any
tree standing in any street, alley, parkway, boulevard or other public or
private place in the city without first obtaining a tree remover's license from
the city clerk. No tree remover's license shall be issued by the city clerk to
any person until said clerk is shown evidence that said person has in effect
insurance by a reputable insurance company authorized to do business in the
state, covering public liability of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00)
per person and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per accident, and also
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) liability coverage for property damage. In
addition thereto said applicant shall show sufficient evidence of insurance
coverage for workers' compensation claims. Said insurance coverage shall be
kept in effect at all times while said licensee is engaged in the business as
aforesaid in the city. The license fee for such business or occupation shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year.
   (b)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
      (1)   The United States Of America, the state, the county or the city,
any department, bureau or agency of any of the foregoing or any official
representative of any of the foregoing in the pursuit of his official duties.
      (2)   Any person who engages in tree removing as defined above on his own
premises.
      (3)   Any public utility, including its authorized employees and agents,
when engaged in tree removal for the purpose of line clearance and in order to
ensure the continuity of utility service to the public.
      (4)   Any person holding a valid city tree trimming license. (1963 Code,
ch. VI, art. II(U), § 4; Ord. 87-34, § 5, 4-6-1987; Ord. 004-2011, 2-7-2011)
Sec. 8-433. Tree Trimmer Generally:
   (a)   No person engaged in the business of trimming trees shall trim, feed
or treat in any manner any trees standing in any street, alley, parkway,
boulevard or other public or private place in the city without first obtaining
a tree trimmer's license from the city clerk. The license fee for such business
or occupation shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year. Any person being
issued a tree trimmer's license shall show the city clerk sufficient evidence
that said person has in effect insurance by a reputable insurance company
authorized to do business in the state, covering public liability of twenty
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per person and fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00) per accident, and also twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00)
liability coverage for workers' compensation claims. Said insurance coverage
shall be kept in effect at all times while said licensee is engaged in the
business as aforesaid in the city.
   (b)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
      (1)   The United States Of America, the state, county or city, any
department, bureau or agency of any of the foregoing or any official
representative of any of the foregoing in the pursuit of his official duties.
      (2)   Any person who engages in tree trimming as defined above on his own
premises.
      (3)   Any public utility, including its authorized employees and agents,
when engaged in tree trimming for the purpose of line clearance and in order to
ensure the continuity of utility service to the public. (1963 Code, ch. VI,
art. II(U), § 2; Ord., § 1, 10-12-1981; Ord. 87-34, § 6, 4-6-1987; Ord. 004-
2011, 2-7-2011)
Sec. 8-434. Reserved:
Sec. 8-435. Tree Trimmings Removed By Licensee:
Any person having a license as provided in this article shall immediately and
at his own expense remove all tree trunks, limbs, branches, twigs or brush and
dispose of same at a place designated by the chief building inspector or at
such other place as is provided for the disposal of same. (1963 Code, ch. VI,
art. II)
Sec. 8-436. Planting And Maintenance Of Trees On Public Property - Permit 1 :
   (a)   Required: No person shall plant or set out any trees in any street,
alley, parkway, boulevard or other public place without first procuring a
permit therefor from the director of public works or his designated
representative.
   (b)   Application: Any person desiring to acquire a permit as aforesaid
shall make application to the director of public works or his designated
representative therefor and include therein the number of trees to be planted
or set out; the location, grade and variety of each tree, the method of
planting and such other information as the director of public works or his
designated representative shall find reasonably necessary to determine whether
a permit shall issue.
   (c)   Conditions For Issuance: Upon proper application being made as
aforesaid, the director of public works or his designated representative shall
issue the permit provided for herein, when he finds that the proposed planting
conforms to the specifications and general regulations set forth hereunder.
      (1)   No trees shall be planted in a boulevard where sewer or water lines
presently exist or where future plans indicate the need of said lines.
      (2)   Trees shall be set out so as not to cause undue maintenance and so
as not to interfere with any utilities.
      (3)   The director of public works or his designated representative may
require the applicant to furnish a detailed planting plan which shall
accurately show:
         a.   The proposed street, together with its subdivision of pavement,
curb, gutter, parking strip and sidewalk areas to a definite indicated scale.
         b.   The variety of each tree proposed to be planted and of those
already existing within the proposed street lines.
         c.   The distance between trees in any one row. (1963 Code, ch. XII,
art. I; Ord., 4-9-1964; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
 
Notes
1 65 ILCS 5/11-72-1.
Sec. 8-437. Planting And Maintenance Of Trees On Public Property - Procedures:
   (a)   Generally: All work done under a permit issued under section 8-436 of
this chapter shall be performed in strict accordance with the terms thereof and
with the following regulations:
      (1)   The trunks of all trees planted must not be less than two and one-
half inches (2 1/2") in diameter, when measured one foot (1') above the ground.
      (2)   No tree shall be placed in such a location where, in the opinion of
the city engineer, said tree shall cause a traffic hazard when planted, or in
the future.
      (3)   All trees shall be planted at least thirty feet (30') apart. Trees
of the larger growing varieties shall be spaced more than thirty feet (30')
apart if considered desirable by the director of public works or his designated
representative.
      (4)   No tree shall be planted where the space between the curb and
sidewalk is less than six feet (6'). Trees of the large growing varieties shall
be permitted only where the space between the sidewalk and the curb is adequate
to appropriately accommodate them.
      (5)   No tree shall be planted nearer than three feet (3') from the curb
line or the outer line of the sidewalk.
      (6)   No tree shall be planted on any street or public place except the
following varieties: sugar maple, pin oak, red oak, ginkgo, honey locust
(thornless varieties), columnar maple, littleleaf linden, hopa crab, Washington
hawthorne and any other varieties specifically approved by the director of
public works or his designated representative; provided, however, that Chinese
elm, box elder, willow, poplar, and similar fast growing, brittle wood species,
which may be subject to attack by insects or diseases, are prohibited.
   (b)   Duties Of Owners: All persons planting trees under authority of
section 8-436 of this chapter and this section shall assume the following
duties:
      (1)   To trim said trees so as to prevent a traffic hazard or
interference with the proper lighting of public highways by any streetlights
and so that the clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be a minimum
of twelve feet (12').
      (2)   To treat or remove any tree so diseased or insect ridden as to
constitute a safety hazard or a hazard to other trees or plants planted on
public property.
   (c)   Compliance: When the director of public works or his designated
representative shall find it necessary to order the trimming, preservation or
removal of trees which constitute a hazard under subsection (b) of this
section, he shall serve a written order to correct the dangerous condition upon
the person to whom a permit to plant has been issued. Said notice shall be
given by mailing a copy of said order, by registered mail, to the owner of the
abutting property as indicated by the property tax assessment records of the
county. When a person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within
the time specified in the order, the director of public works or his designated
representative shall remedy said condition or contract with others for such
purpose and charge the cost thereof to the person to whom the order is
directed. (Ord., 4-9-1964; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Secs. 8-438-8-440. Reserved:
ARTICLE XV. RAFFLES 1
 
Notes
1 Prior ordinance history: Ord. 82-64, 1-10-1983; Ord. 82-68, 1-24-1983; Ord.
  82-73, 2-28-1983; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 97-31, 4-14-1997.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-441. Definitions:
When used in this article and unless otherwise distinctly expressed, the
following words and phrases shall have the meanings set out herein:
   Net Proceeds: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
   Nonprofit, Charitable, Educational, Religious, Fraternal, Veterans And
Labor: Shall have the same meaning ascribed to them in 230 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 15/2(b).
   Raffle: A form of lottery, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
28-2(b) conducted by an organization licensed under this article, in which:
      (1)   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance;
      (2)   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
   Rock Island County Model Raffle Ordinance: An ordinance in substantially the
same form, and containing the same provisions and limitations as are set forth
in this subject ordinance to be enacted by any municipality located within Rock
Island County, Illinois, and intended to regulate the conduct of raffles within
the jurisdiction of the respective municipality. (Ord. 078-2011, 10-10-2011)
Sec. 8-442. Penalty:
Violation of any provision of this article shall subject the person, firm, or
organization to a fine in a sum not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-443. Conduct Of Raffles, Generally:
The conducting of raffles licensed under this article is subject to the
following restrictions:
      (1)   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted
to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
      (2)   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization
may participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
      (3)   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating
in the management or operation of the raffle; however, this shall not prohibit
the payment of rent or a permit fee for use of facilities to hold a raffle if
said rent or fee is not dependent upon the raffle proceeds and is binding upon
the parties at the time made.
      (4)   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified
on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the license.
      (5)   A person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age may
participate in the conducting of raffles or chances only with the permission of
a parent or guardian. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may be
within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-444. Manager:
All operations of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of
a single raffle manager designated by the organization. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-445. Records:
   (a)   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose,
amount, and date of payment.
   (b)   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license therefor, issued by the department of revenue of the state,
and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records
of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who
accounts for other revenues of the organization.
   (c)   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to
its membership, and to the licensing local unit of government, its receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from raffles and the distribution of net proceeds
itemized as required in this section.
   (d)   Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
(Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Secs. 8-446-8-450. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-451. License Required:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to conduct a raffle or
chance in the city without having first obtained a license therefor pursuant to
this article or in violation of the terms of such license. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-
1997)
Sec. 8-452. Reciprocity With Other Municipalities In County:
Any person, firm or corporation who has in his immediate possession a valid
license issued to the person, firm or corporation by another municipality or
political subdivision located in Rock Island County, Illinois, which
municipality or political subdivision has enacted the Rock Island County model
raffle ordinance (this article), shall be exempt from the requirements of this
division to have obtained a license from the city. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-453. Eligibility:
Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor,
fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without profit
to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of
five (5) years immediately before making application for a license and which
have had during that entire five (5) year period, a bona fide membership
engaged in carrying out their objectives. Licenses shall be issued to a
nonprofit fundraising organization that the licensing authority determines is
organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an
identified individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial
hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster. (Ord.
97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-454. Restrictions On Issuance:
No such license shall be issued to:
   (1)   Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
   (2)   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter;
   (3)   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection (1) or
(2) of this section, has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest or in
which such a person is active or employed;
   (4)   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1) or (2) of
this Section, is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or not;
   (5)   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1) or (2) of
this Section, is to participate in the management or operation of a "raffle" as
defined in this Article. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-455. Applications:
   (a)   Application for such licenses shall be made to the City Clerk no later
than thirty (30) days prior to the commencement of sales or advertisement of
sale of raffle chances.
   (b)   The application for license must specify the area or areas within the
City in which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of determination
of winning chances and the location or locations at which winning chances will
be determined.
   (c)   The application for license must contain a sworn statement attesting
to the not-for-profit character of the prospective license organization and
shall be signed by the presiding officer and secretary of the organization.
   (d)   The application for license must state the residence of the applicant
and all addresses of offices within the licensing municipality and, if the
raffle drawing is to be conducted within the licensing municipality, the
address of the location of the drawing.
   (e)   Prior to approval, any application which indicates that the sale of
raffle chances would be in an area outside the corporate limits of the City, or
which indicates that the location or locations of determining winning chances
is outside the corporate limits of the City, shall be referred to the licensing
authority of such jurisdiction for comment as to zoning status, licensed status
of location, and compliance with licensing regulations.
   (f)   The City Clerk shall act on a license application within thirty (30)
days from the date of application and shall notify all jurisdictions affected
thereby of said action. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-456. Fee:
Fees shall be charged for the making of application and the issuance of a
raffle license as follows:
   (1)   Five dollars ($5.00) for a temporary raffle license for a single
raffle;
   (2)   Fifty dollars ($50.00) for an annual raffle license as defined in
Section
8-457 of this Article;
   (3)   No fee will be charged for the making of application and the issuance
of a raffle license for the medical emergency/financial hardship. (Ord. 97-68,
7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-457. Validity; Duration:
A license authorizes the licensee to conduct "raffles" as defined in this
Article. Licenses issued pursuant to this Article shall be valid for one raffle
or for a specified number of raffles to be conducted during a specified period
not to exceed one year, and may be suspended or revoked for any violation of
this Article. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Secs. 8-458-8-465. Reserved:
ARTICLE XVI. WATERPROOFING OF BUILDINGS 1
 
Notes
1 See also
  Chapter 4 of this Code.
Sec. 8-466. Permit Required:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of waterproofing
basements, interiors or exteriors, or cause the same to be done without first
obtaining a separate permit for each building or structure to be waterproofed
from the Building Official. (Ord. 87-91, 10-12-1987)
Sec. 8-467. Obtaining A Permit:
To obtain a permit, the contractor shall have on file in the office of the
Building Official, a general contractor's bond in the amount of two thousand
dollars ($2,000.00). Notification of the construction for each year, or the
cancellation of this bond, must be confirmed by the office of the Building
Official.
   (1)   Application For A Permit: To obtain a permit, the applicant shall file
an application therefor in writing on a form furnished by the Building Official
for that purpose. Every application shall:
      a.   Identify and describe the work to be covered by the permit for which
application is made.
      b.   Describe the land on which the proposed work is to be done by legal
description, street address or similar description that will readily identify
and definitely locate the proposed building or work.
      c.   Indicate the use or occupancy for which the proposed work is
intended.
      d.   Be accompanied by plans, diagrams, computations and specifications
if required by the Building Official. The Building Official may require plans,
computations and specifications to be prepared and designated by an engineer or
architect licensed by the State to practice as such.
      e.   State the value of the waterproofing measure.
      f.   Be signed by permitter, or his authorized agent, who may be required
to submit evidence to indicate such authority.
   (2)   Permit Issuance: The application, plans and specifications and other
data filed by an applicant for permit shall be reviewed by the Building
Official. Such plans may be reviewed by other departments of the City to verify
compliance with any applicable ordinances under their jurisdiction. If the
Building Official finds that the work described in an application for a permit
and plans, specifications and other data filed therewith conform to the
requirements of this Code and other pertinent laws and ordinances, and that the
fees specified in section 304 of the Uniform Building Code have been paid, he
shall issue a permit therefor to the applicant. (Ord. 87-91, 10-12-1987)
ARTICLE XVII. PEDICABS
Sec. 8-468. Definitions:
   City: The City of Rock Island, Illinois.
   Pedicab: Any vehicle that is a manually operated bicycle-type vehicle
pulling a cart for two (2) passengers equipped with handles and other equipment
required by State law by slow-moving vehicles to operate on the street.
   Pedicab Operating License: A license granted to a person and authorizing a
person to operate a pedicab on the streets of the City. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-469. Licenses Required:
The operation of any pedicab vehicle upon the streets of the City for
transporting persons for hire or as a contractual service is a violation of
this Article unless operating in accordance with a valid license issued
pursuant to this Article. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-470. Application For License:
Applications for pedicab business licenses shall be made to the City Clerk on a
form provided by the City Clerk. In addition to other information required by
this Article, the application shall contain the following information:
   (1)   The name and address of the applicant.
   (2)   The applicant's work or corporate history for the past five (5) years.
If the applicant is a corporation, the information shall also be given for the
chief administrative officer who will be in charge of the Rock Island
operations. The corporation shall list all its officers and all other
businesses operated by the corporation. If the corporation is a foreign
corporation, a copy of the certificate to do business in the State shall be
provided.
   (3)   A list of all felony and misdemeanor convictions including traffic
violations by the applicant for the past ten (10) years. If the applicant is a
corporation, such information shall be given for the chief administrative
officer in charge of the Rock Island operations.
   (4)   The number of pedicabs to be operated pursuant to the license and the
seating capacity of each.
   (5)   A schedule of rates and charges to be made to passengers, which rates
shall not be changed without ten (10) days' prior notice to the City Clerk.
The applications shall be verified under oath and include a written agreement
by the applicant to operate the business, if licensed, strictly in accordance
with this Article, and indemnify and hold harmless the City for all judgments,
liens and expenses arising out of the operations permitted by the license.
(Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-471. Pedicab Routing And Operations Schedules:
   (a)   Pedicab business shall operate only within the area of the City
located within 1st Avenue to 7th Avenue and 11th Street to 26th Street and also
the City bicycle path. For any special events that the pedicab business wishes
to service, said business shall contact the City Clerk at least four (4) days
