before said special events and submit a temporary route to be used by the
pedicab business during said special events. The City Clerk will then review
the temporary route with the City Traffic Engineering Committee and the Police
Department prior to authorizing same.
   (b)   The pedicab business in the City shall operate only between the hours
of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight of each day.
(Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-472. Operation Of Pedicab Businesses:
Pedicab businesses shall be operated only with the regulations given in this
Section.
   (1)   A copy of the pedicab license shall be displayed on all pedicabs used
in such business. The City Clerk, upon issuance of the license, shall issue
that number of duplicates as requested in the application identifying each
pedicab identified in the application.
   (2)   Each pedicab used in such business shall have a valid pedicab license
issued pursuant to this Article.
   (3)   Each pedicab shall be operated by the holder of a valid coach
operator's license issued pursuant to this Article, who shall have such license
on his/her person at all times when operating such vehicle.
   (4)   When carrying persons for hire or by contract, the vehicle shall be
operated only in the approved area of operations.
   (5)   Pedicabs shall pick up and discharge passengers only upon the curb
lane, while lawfully parked at designated stands.
   (6)   Pedicab vehicles, when in motion, shall be operated only in the curb-
most traffic lane on any public street; and the driver shall obey all
applicable State and local traffic laws, ordinances and regulations.
   (7)   No pedicab vehicle shall be operated on a public street unless a valid
liability insurance policy as specified in this Article is on file with the
City Clerk.
   (8)   It shall be the duty of the driver of the pedicab to inform any person
hiring the carriage of all the rates and charges before any service is
rendered, which shall be the same as those on file with the City Clerk.
   (9)   Drivers shall carry rate cards and exhibit them on demand.
   (10)   Occupancy of the pedicab shall not exceed the rated seating capacity
of the vehicle.
   (11)   No passenger shall be allowed to ride on any part of the vehicle when
in motion except seated inside the vehicle.
   (12)   Drivers shall not solicit patronage in a loud tone of voice or in any
manner to annoy or obstruct the movement of a person, or follow any person for
the purpose of soliciting patronage.
   (13)   Drivers are prohibited from smoking while carrying passengers.
   (14)   No person may drink any alcoholic liquor while such person is
operating a pedicab. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-473. Insurance:
Before any permit for a pedicab shall be issued, the owner shall file with the
City Clerk an insurance policy issued by an insurance company licensed to do
business in this State, providing insurance coverage for each and every pedicab
owned, operated or leased by the applicant with a minimum of one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for the injury or death of any one person; and
three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for the injury or death of any
number of persons in any one accident, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00)
for property damage resulting from any one accident, regardless of whether the
pedicab was being driven by the owner, his/her agent, employee, lessee or
permittee.
The policy shall contain a provision requiring the City to be named as an
additional insured for the sole purpose of the City being notified by the
insurance company of any cancellation, termination, or expiration of the policy
thirty (30) days prior to that event. The cancellation or other termination of
any insurance policy issued for or in compliance with the provisions of this
Section shall automatically terminate any license issued for the pedicab
covered by such insurance policy unless another policy complying with the
provisions of this Section shall be provided and in full force and effect at
the time of such cancellation or termination. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-474. Issuance Of License:
Upon receipt of the completed application for the pedicab business license,
approval of the route and operations schedule, filing of insurance as required,
and payment of the application and license fees, the City Clerk shall issue a
pedicab business license to the applicant. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-475. Operation On The Streets Of The City:
   (a)   No pedicab shall be operated upon the streets of the City for
transporting person(s) for hire or by contract unless licensed by the City
Clerk.
   (b)   Each pedicab will be equipped with a slow-moving vehicle sign approved
by the State and attached to the rear of the vehicle. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-476. Pedicab Operator's License:
   (a)   No person shall drive a pedicab carrying persons, for hire or by
contract, unless he/she is the holder of a valid pedicab operator's license
issued pursuant to this Section.
   (b)   The application for the pedicab operator's license shall be made under
oath to the City Clerk and shall verify, or establish that the applicant:
      (1)   Possesses a valid, current operator's license issued by the State.
      (2)   Is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
      (3)   Is free of defective vision, defective hearing, and any other
infirmities that would render him/her unfit for safe operation of a public
vehicle.
      (4)   Is free of alcohol or drug addition.
      (5)   Has not, within the ten (10) years immediately preceding his/her
application, been convicted of any felony, or operating a motor vehicle while
under the influence of alcohol or a drug.
      (6)   Has not received more than three (3) moving traffic violations in
the immediately preceding twelve (12) months or five (5) moving traffic
violations in the immediately preceding twenty four (24) months of application.
      (7)   Has delivered to the City Clerk a certificate signed by the pedicab
licensee or other sufficient evidence that such person is qualified to operate
a pedicab.
   (c)   Upon approval of the application and payment of the necessary fee, the
City Clerk shall issue a pedicab operator's license to the applicant.
   (d)   Any person not having been duly issued a pedicab operator's license or
a person whose license as such driver has been revoked, any person whose
license has been suspended, or any person who has had his/her state driver's
license suspended or revoked (even if he/she has restricted driver's permit),
and who during the time of such suspension or revocation drives a pedicab upon
the streets shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a simple misdemeanor.
(Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-477. Denial, Suspension Or Revocation:
   (a)   Any violation of this Article by the holder of a license issued
hereunder shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the license by the
City Clerk.
   (b)   Any denial of license application may be appealed within fourteen (14)
days to the City Council. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-478. Annual License Fees:
The annual fee for a pedicab business license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
Each additional pedicab shall be licensed for fifty dollars ($50.00). A pedicab
operator's license shall be issued for an annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Secs. 8-479-8-485. Reserved:
ARTICLE XVIII. SALE/POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES,
VAPE DEVICES, SMOKING HERBS AND ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS
Sec. 8-486. Definitions:
   For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
   Alternative nicotine product: A product or device not consisting of or
containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine,
whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting,
sniffing, or by any other means. Alternative nicotine product does not include:
cigarettes as defined in Section 1 of the Cigarette Tax Act [35 ILCS 130/1] and
tobacco products as defined in Section 10-5 [35 ILCS 143/10-5] of the Tobacco
Products Tax Act of 1995; tobacco product and electronic cigarette as defined
in this Section; or any product approved by the United States Food and Drug
Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence
product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely
for that approved purpose.
   Electronic cigarette:
      (1)   Any device that employs a battery or other mechanism to heat a
solution or substance to produce a vapor or aerosol intended for inhalation;
      (2)   Any cartridge or container of a solution or substance intended to
be used with or in the device or to refill the device; or
      (3)   Any solution or substance, whether or not it contains nicotine
intended for use in the device. Electronic cigarette includes, but is not
limited to, any electronic nicotine delivery system, electronic cigar,
electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, electronic hookah, vape pen, or similar
product or device, any components or parts that can be used to build the
product or device, and any component, part, or accessory of a device used
during the operation of the device, even if the part or accessory was sold
separately. Electronic cigarette does not include: cigarettes as defined in
Section 1 of the Cigarette Tax Act; tobacco product and alternative nicotine
product as defined in this Section; any product approved by the United States
Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a
tobacco dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being
marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose; any asthma inhaler
prescribed by a physician for that condition and is being marketed and sold
solely for that approved purpose; any device that meets the definition of
cannabis paraphernalia under Section 1-10 of the Cannabis Regulation and Tax
Act [410 ILCS 705/1-10]; or any cannabis product sold by a dispensing
organization pursuant to the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act [410 ILCS 705/1-
1 et seq.] or the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act [410 ILCS
130/1 et seq.].
   Minor: Any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
   Nicotine: Any form of the chemical nicotine, including any salt or complex,
regardless of whether the chemical is naturally or synthetically derived.
   Smoking herbs: All substances of plant origin and their derivatives,
including but not limited to broom, calea, California poppy, damiana, hops,
ginseng, lobelia, jimson weed and other members of the Datura genus, passion
flower and while lettuce, which are processed or sold primarily for use as
smoking materials.
   Tobacco accessories: Cigarette papers, pipes, bongs, holders of smoking
materials of all types, cigarette rolling machines, and other items, designed
primarily for the smoking, inhaling, or ingestion of tobacco products,
alternative nicotine products or other substances.
   Tobacco product: Any product containing or made from tobacco that is
intended for human consumption, whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed,
dissolved, inhaled, snorted, sniffed, or ingested by any other means,
including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, chewing
tobacco, pipe tobacco, snuff, snus, and any other smokeless tobacco product
which contains tobacco that is finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf and
intended to be placed in the oral cavity. Tobacco product includes any
component, part, or accessory of a tobacco product, whether or not sold
separately. Tobacco product does not include: an alternative nicotine product
as defined in this Section; or any product that has been approved by the United
States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as
a tobacco dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being
marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose.
   Vape Devices: Vapes, Vape Pens, or alternative vapor transmission modalities
that are electronically-operated devices which contain a cartridge or open
space filled with nicotine and/or other chemicals which are turned into vapor
or steam that inhaled and exhaled.
    Vending Machine: Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-service
device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment,
dispenses tobacco products, alternative nicotine products or any electronic
nicotine device.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-487. License Generally:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give
away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away
or delivering any products regulated by this Chapter. No license shall be
issued for the sale of tobacco products, vaping devices, tobacco accessories or
alternative nicotine products at any location within one hundred feet (100')
from the property boundaries of any school. It shall be unlawful to permit
smoking, vaping, or otherwise ingesting any tobacco, electronic cigarette, or
alternative nicotine products on the premises at an establishment which also
sells tobacco, electronic cigarettes, vaping devices, tobacco accessories or
alternative nicotine products without first obtaining a Class A or Class B
license.
   (b)   A license shall be purely a personal privilege and shall not
constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or
execution; nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or
involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-488. Types Of Licenses And Fees:
   There shall be two (2) categories of tobacco dealer's licenses, Applications
are available with the Office of the City Clerk. The license shall expire on
April 30 each year. If a license fee is received late, the license holder may
be subject to a late fee of ten percent (10%) of the invoiced license fee and
may be subject to renewal license being denied.
   (1)   Class A License (Incidental): Class A licenses are required in order
to engage in the retail sale and/or display of tobacco products, tobacco
accessories, electronic cigarettes, vaping devices or alternative nicotine
products where such sales and displays are incidental to the principal use of
the premises, such as a grocery store or convenience store, which devotes less
than twenty percent (20%) of its floor space or display area to such products
and which derives less than fifty percent (50%) of its gross revenue from the
sale of tobacco products, tobacco accessories, electronic cigarettes, vaping
devices or alternative nicotine products. The annual license fee for Class A
shall be one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00), payable in accordance with
this Chapter. The total number of Class A licenses to be issued is thirty (30).
   (2)   Class B (Retail Tobacco Shop/Store). Class B licenses are required in
order to engage in the retail sale and/or displace of tobacco products, tobacco
accessories, electronic cigarettes, vaping devices or alternative nicotine
products where such sales and displays are a primary use of the premises such
as a tobacco shop, which devotes more than twenty percent (20%) of its floor
space or display area to such products OR which derives more than fifty percent
(50%) of its gross revenue from the sale of tobacco products, tobacco
accessories, electronic cigarettes, vaping devices or alternative nicotine
products. The annual license fee for Class B shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00), payable in accordance with this Chapter. The total number of Class B
licenses to be issued is two (2).
   The restrictions on the number of licenses shall not limit the right to
renewal of any existing license nor to the issuance of a license to the
purchase of an established licensed business as an going concern, but as
licenses are revoked, expire without renewal, or for any other reason cease to
exist, the total number of tobacco licenses in that class will be reduced until
the cap on the class is met.
   Exceptions to Limits: The City Council may, in their discretion, grant the
creation of an additional license in either class, if, it is found that the
creation of such license is necessary for the public convenience of the
residents of Rock Island and is in the best interest of the City of Rock
Island.
(Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-489. Responsibility For Agents And Employees:
   (a)   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation
of any of the provisions of this article by an officer, director, manager or
other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act
of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as
if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023)
Sec. 8-490. Suspension; Revocation Of License; Fines, Costs:
   (a)   Once a licensee has been notified of a violation of this article, they
shall have five (5) days to file a written notice of appeal. If no hearing is
requested, the Mayor or designee may suspend, revoke, or issue a written
reprimand to any license issued under the provisions of this chapter, if the
Mayor or designee determines that the licensee has violated any of the
provisions of this article. In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license,
the Mayor or designee may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed
shall not exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each
day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
   (b)   If no hearing is requested by the licensee and the Mayor determines
that a letter of reprimand is warranted or the license should be suspended or
revoked, he shall issue a written order within five (5) days stating the
reasons for the determination, and shall cause a copy of such order to be
served upon the licensee within ten (10) days. In the event a penalty is
imposed, the order shall specify the date by which the penalty shall be paid.
If the penalty is not paid by the specified date, the license shall be
suspended for a time determined by the Mayor or designee. All penalties shall
be paid at police headquarters.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-491. Hearing Procedures:
   (a)   If a hearing is requested, in writing, before the Code Hearing Officer
the Code Hearing Officer shall schedule a hearing on said matter within thirty
(30) days. Said hearing shall be open to the public and a Court Reporter shall
transcribe the proceedings.
   (b)   If the Code Hearing Officer determines that the licensee has violated
any of the provisions of this chapter, the Code Hearing Officer may suspend,
revoke or issue a written reprimand to any license issued under the provisions
of this chapter or, in lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, impose a
fine on the licensee not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a
separate violation.
   (c)   The Code Hearing Officer shall determine the costs incurred by the
City for said hearing, including, but not limited to: Court Reporter fees, the
cost of transcript records, attorney fees, the cost of preparing the mailing
notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the City or
such lesser sum as the Code Hearing Officer may allow.
   (d)   The licensee shall pay said costs to the City within thirty (30) days
of notification of the costs by the Code Hearing Officer. Failure to pay said
costs within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this article
and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of
additional fines.
   (e)   Witnesses shall be sworn; but the hearing shall be informal, and the
strict rules of evidence shall not apply.
   (f)   In the event the licensee wishes to appeal a decision of the Code
Hearing Officer, said licensee shall pay the cost of the preparation and
transcription of the record of the hearing and shall appeal to the Circuit
Court under the provisions of the Administrative Review Act.(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-
1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023)
Sec. 8-492. Use Of Premises After Revocation:
   (a)   When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license
shall be granted to said licensee for the period of six (6) months thereafter
for the conduct of the business of selling “any products” as defined in this
Chapter. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023)
Sec. 8-493. Prohibited Sales, Delivery - Signs:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell,
offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or
alternative nicotine products to any person under the age of twenty-one (21)
years.
   (b)   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein
shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products,
tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products and on or upon every
vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be
plainly visible and shall state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, VAPING DEVICES, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES and
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE YEARS OF AGE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW.
   The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background, said
letters to be at least one inch (1") high.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-494. Age Limits:
   (a)   Minimum Age To Sell Tobacco Products, Vaping Devices Tobacco
Accessories, or Alternative Nicotine Products: It shall be unlawful for any
licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee
of such licenses, to engage, employ or permit any person under twenty-one (21)
years of age to sell Tobacco Products, Vaping Devices, Tobacco Accessories, or
Alternative Nicotine Products in any licensed premises.
   (b)   Purchase Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age
of twenty-one (21) years to possess any Tobacco Products, Vaping Devices,
Tobacco Accessories, or Alternative Nicotine Products, or to misrepresent their
identity or age, or to use any false or altered identification for the purpose
of purchasing tobacco products.
   (c)   Possession Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person under
twenty-one (21) years of age to possess any Tobacco Products, Vaping Devices
Tobacco Accessories or Alternative Nicotine Products.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-495. Certain Free Distributions Prohibited:
    (a)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business
of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco
products, vaping devices, tobacco accessories, smoking herbs or alternative
nicotine products, or any employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in
the course of such licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or
deliver tobacco products, vaping devices, tobacco accessories, smoking herbs or
alternative nicotine products free of charge to any person on any right of way,
park, playground or other property owned by the city or the school district.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-496. Vending Machines-Locking Devices:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give
away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving away or
delivering tobacco products or alternative nicotine products by use of a
vending machine, unless such vending machine is equipped with a manual,
electric or electronic locking device controlled by the licensee so as to
prevent its operation by persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years.
   (b)   Any premises where access by persons under the age of twenty-one (21)
years is prohibited, shall be exempt from the requirements of subsection (a) of
this section.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord. 59-2025, 6-9-2025)
Sec. 8-497. Remedies For Violation:
   Any violation of the provisions of this article, except as otherwise
provided in this section, shall be punishable by a minimum fine of two hundred
dollars ($200.00). In the event any person is accused of a violation hereof and
does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued
for the violation, that person so accused may pay to the city at police
headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for and in
full satisfaction of said violation.
(Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 96-83, 10-28-1996; Ord. 006-2023, 3-13-2023; Ord.
59-2025, 6-9-2025)
ARTICLE XIX. TATTOO ESTABLISHMENTS AND TATTOO ARTISTS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-498. Definitions:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
   Aseptic Technique: A practice that prevents and hinders the transmission of
disease-producing microorganisms from one person or place to another person or
place.
   Certificate Of Inspection: Written approval from the health authority that
said tattooing establishment has been inspected and meets all of the terms of
this article relating to physical facilities, equipment and layout for
operation of such business. Said writing shall be on a form designated by the
health authority for such purpose.
   City: The city of Rock Island, Illinois.
   Facial Tattoo: Any tattoo applied above the jawline, anterior to the ear and
frontal hairline including the eyelids, eyebrows or lips.
   Health Authority: The health inspector or authorized representative.
   Operator: Any individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation or
association that owns or operates an establishment where tattooing is
performed.
   Sanitize: To treat a clean surface and destroy pathogenic microorganisms.
   Single Service Items: Articles intended for one time, one person use and are
to be discarded after use.
   Tattoo Artist: Any individual who performs or practices the art of
tattooing, on the person of another.
   Tattoo, Tattooed, Tattooing: An indelible mark or decorative design created
by the introduction of dyes or pigments beneath the surface of the skin with
the aid of needles or other devices. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-499. License Required; Fees:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of
operating a tattooing establishment within the city without first paying an
annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and payable to the city
clerk's office upon written approval from the health authority and to engage in
such business in accordance with the provisions hereof.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any tattooing within
the city without a tattoo license, respectively, which shall be issued pursuant
to the provisions of this article, or to employ any person as a tattooer, who
has not paid for such tattoo artist's annual license fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) for each artist, and payable to the city clerk's office, upon written
approval from the health authority.
   (c)   No tattoo artist shall practice tattooing in any place other than a
tattoo parlor having a valid license.
   (d)   No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo to any person who appears to be
or admits to being under the influence of intoxicating substances, including,
but not limited to, alcohol, drugs, paints and glues.
   (e)   No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo in violation of section 12-10 of
the Criminal Code of 1961.
   (f)   Immediately after tattooing, the tattoo artist shall advise the
client, in writing, on the care of the tattoo and instruct the client to
consult a physician at the first sign of infection. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-
2000)
Sec. 8-500. Display Of License:
Every person to whom a license shall have been granted shall display said
license in a conspicuous place. Failure to display said license shall be
grounds for revocation. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-501. Exceptions To Provisions Of Article:
The requirements of this article shall have no application and no effect upon
and shall not be construed as applying to any person, firm or corporation
licensed by the state to practice medicine or licensed by the state to practice
any of the healing arts. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-502. Application:
Any person desiring to obtain or renew a license to operate a tattooing
establishment or a tattoo artist's license shall make application to the city
clerk who shall refer all such applications to the health inspector for an
appropriate investigation. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-503. Contents Of Application:
   (a)   The application for a tattooing license required by this article shall
contain the following information:
      (1)   Full name and current address;
      (2)   The two (2) previous addresses of the applicant immediately prior
to the current address;
      (3)   Written proof that the applicant is over the age of eighteen (18)
years;
      (4)   Applicant's height, weight and color of eyes and hair;
      (5)   The tattooing license history of the applicant, including whether
such person in previous operation in this or another area has had his license
revoked or suspended, the reason thereof, and any business activity or
occupation subsequent to the action of suspension or revocation;
      (6)   A certificate of a medical doctor designating that the applicant
has recently been examined and is free of any contagious or communicable
disease which in the opinion of the medical doctor can be transmitted during
the tattooing process. Immunization for hepatitis B is strongly recommended.
(Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-504. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES
Sec. 8-505. Tattooing Hygiene Procedure:
   (a)   All tattoo artists shall comply with the following:
      (1)   No employee, while infected with a disease in a communicable form,
or who is a carrier of a disease which can be transmitted during the tattooing
process; and no employee while affected with a boil, infected wound or acute
respiratory infection shall provide tattooing to a client.
      (2)   No employee shall provide tattooing to any skin surface that shows
evidence of any rash, boils, infections or other unhealthy conditions or
disease.
      (3)   Employees shall thoroughly wash their hands and the exposed
portions of their arms with soap and warm water before starting work, during
work as often as is necessary to keep them clean, and after smoking, eating,
drinking and using the toilet. Employees shall keep their fingernails clean and
trimmed.
      (4)   Employees providing tattooing shall, in addition to thoroughly
washing, use single-use latex or vinyl examination gloves, as a barrier to
potentially infective blood.
      (5)   Employees shall not use tobacco in any form, or eat or drink while
tattooing a client. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-506. Tattooing Procedure:
   (a)   The tattoo artist shall explain in writing the following to each
client before a tattoo application and maintain a copy of the informed consent
signed by the client for at least five (5) years:
      (1)   The application procedure.
      (2)   Possible tissue reactions, infections and dye reactions following
application.
      (3)   Importance of after-application care.
   (b)   The area of skin to be worked on shall first be thoroughly washed and
scrubbed for a period of two (2) minutes with warm water to which has been
added an antiseptic liquid soap. A sterile single-use sponge shall be used to
scrub the area. After shaving and before the tattooing is begun, a solution of
seventy percent (70%) alcohol or other effective germicidal solution shall be
applied to the area with a single-use sponge used and applied with a sterile
instrument;
   (c)   For tattooing, single-service or individual containers of dye or ink
shall be used for each patron, and the container therefor shall be discarded
immediately after completing work on a patron; any dye in which the needles
were dipped shall not be used on another person;
   (d)   Whenever a new sterile tube is used that contains a different color of
dye or ink, a separate or new sterile needle shall also be used. Excess dye or
ink shall be removed from the skin with an individual single-use sterile sponge
or a disposable paper tissue which shall be used only on one person and then
immediately discarded. After completing work on any person, the tattooed area
shall be washed with sterile gauze saturated with an antiseptic soap solution
approved by the health officer, or a seventy percent (70%) alcohol solution.
The tattooed area shall be allowed to dry and petroleum jelly from a
collapsible or plastic tube shall be applied, using sterile gauze. A sterile
gauze dressing shall then be fastened to the tattooed area with adhesive;
   (e)   Only clean single-service stencils may also be used;
   (f)   Only sterilized needles and tubes or tips, in good condition, shall be
used for tattooing;
   (g)   Persons tattooed shall be provided with printed instructions regarding
tattoo care during the healing process and shall be instructed to consult a
physician if signs and symptoms of an infection develop;
   (h)   Single-use needles, razors or other sharp materials must be disposed
of immediately upon completion of tattooing within EPA and OSHA approved sharps
disposal containers.
   (i)   Used tattoo needles and other infectious waste shall be stored,
treated, and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of title XV of the
environmental protection act 1 which regulates the management and disposal of
infectious waste. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
 
Notes
1 415 ILCS 5/56 et seq.
Sec. 8-507. Facial Tattoos:
(Rep. by Ord. 089-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 8-508. Physical Facilities:
All tattoo parlors shall comply with all of the following requirements in order
to qualify for a license:
      (1)   The tattooing room and waiting areas shall be separated by a solid
partition or barrier that prevents unauthorized entry into the tattooing room
and provides privacy for clients.
      (2)   All floors, walls, ceilings, and procedure surfaces shall be
constructed from materials that are easily cleanable, smooth, nonabsorbent,
durable, light colored, and in good repair. The tattoo establishment shall be
maintained in a sanitary condition.
      (3)   A separate, readily accessible hand sink with hot and cold running
water, shall be provided at each workstation, for the exclusive use of the
tattoo artist for hand washing and preparing the client for tattooing. The hand
sink will be under pressure with a mixing valve or combination faucet. Soap, an
approved hand drying device such as disposable paper towels, and a refuse
container with a cover shall be provided at each hand sink.
      (4)   All tattooing establishments shall be provided with at least one
utility sink or curbed cleaning facility with a floor drain for the cleaning of
mops or similar wet floor cleaning equipment and for the disposal of mop water
or similar liquid waste.
      (5)   Adequate lighting and ventilation shall be provided within the
tattoo establishment.
      (6)   No animals of any kind shall be allowed in a tattoo establishment
except for canine accompanying the visually disabled.
      (7)   Effective measures shall be taken by the tattoo operator to prevent
and maintain the tattoo establishment free of pest and/or rodent infestations.
      (8)   An adequate number of lockers or other suitable facilities shall be
provided and used for orderly storage of employees' clothing and other
belongings.
      (9)   Smoking and the use of tobacco in any form shall be prohibited in
the tattooing room.
      (10)   Any other business or dwelling shall be completely separated from
the tattoo parlor by at least a solid partition from the floor to the ceiling.
Only tattooing shall be permitted in a tattooing room. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-
14-2000)
Sec. 8-509. Equipment:
   (a)   All service table surfaces shall be constructed of nonporous, easily
cleanable material, and sanitized after each client.
   (b)   All inks, dyes, needles and equipment shall be specifically
manufactured for performing body art procedures and shall be used according to
the manufacturer's instructions. All dyes or pigments used in tattooing shall
be nontoxic, free from adulteration and made from materials generally regarded
as safe.
   (c)   Sterile single-service or sterile individual containers of dye or ink
shall be used for each patron. Ink cups shall be for single patron use with the
ink cup holder constructed from material that is easily cleanable and
nonabsorbent.
   (d)   All tubes, needle bars and instruments used in the tattoo procedure
that are not sterile single patron use and disposable shall be thoroughly
cleaned and steam sterilized or dry-heat sterilized between patrons. After
sterilization, equipment used in the tattoo procedure shall be stored in a dry,
clean cabinet or other tightly covered container reserved for the storage of
such instruments. Each tattoo artist will be provided with a storage cabinet
for the exclusive storage of instruments, dyes, pigments, carbon, stencils, and
other paraphernalia used in the parlor.
   (e)   Needles shall be disposable, sterile, single patron use or shall be
reusable needles and shall be thoroughly cleaned and steam sterilized or dry-
heat sterilized between patrons. Needles, tubes, and tips shall be constructed
in a manner that permits easy cleaning and sterilization. Needles and
assemblies designed to be disposable shall be used one time, on one person
only, and then discarded in accordance with subsection 8-506(i) of this
division.
   (f)   Razors shall be single patron use and disposable, or shall have the
handle of the razor sterilized with a new blade used for each patron. Alum or
other material used to stop the flow of blood shall be used only in liquid or
powder form.
   (g)   Topical ointment or medications shall be packaged for single patron
use. All bandages and dressings shall be sterile and single use.
   (h)   All instruments used for tattooing shall remain stored in sterile
packages until just prior to the performance of the tattoo procedure. All
instruments, equipment and facilities shall be maintained in a clean and
sanitary condition. When assembling instruments used for the tattoo procedure,
the artist shall wear disposable medical gloves and use medically recognized
techniques to ensure that the instruments and gloves are not contaminated.
(Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-510. Sterilization Procedure:
   (a)   Each tattoo parlor engaged in the practice of tattooing shall utilize
sterilization equipment adequate in size to accommodate needles, tubes, tips
and other related utensils and equipment and only sterilization equipment with
the capacity to make a permanent record of the temperatures and pressures in
the machines may be used. All records shall be permanently retained by the
licensee and made available for inspection by the health authority on demand.
   (b)   After each use, the needles and assemblies shall be cleansed to remove
protein residue (blood and tissue) and sterilized.
   (c)   One of the following methods of sterilization shall be used:
      (1)   Autoclave - steam under pressure.
         a.   One hundred twenty one degrees Celsius (121°C) (250°F) at greater
than ten (10) psi for not less than thirty (30) minutes after the chamber of
the autoclave has been evacuated of air and has reached temperature; or as
specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual.
      (2)   Dry heat sterilization.
         a.   One hundred seventy degrees Celsius (170°C) (338°F) for not less
than two (2) hours after the sterilizer has reached temperature; or
         b.   As specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual.
      (3)   Other methods approved by the health authority.
   (d)   Sterilization shall be monitored by the use of chemical and heat
sensitive (color change) indicators with each batch of equipment sterilized or
by other methods approved by the department.
   (e)   Sterilized equipment shall be stored wrapped or covered in a manner
that ensures the equipment will remain sterile until used. Each batch shall be
labeled with the date of sterilization. If exposed to any potential source of
contamination, the equipment shall be resterilized before use.
   (f)   Sterile equipment stored, in an approved manner and not used within
thirty (30) days after sterilization, shall no longer be considered sterile and
shall be resterilized before use.
   (g)   An equipment fault manual shall be kept by licensee and made available
at all times to the health authority containing a record of all sterilization
equipment failures and the remedies taken to correct the failure.
   (h)   Sterilizers shall be monitored monthly by an independent testing
laboratory. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-511. Inspections:
During the business hours of the tattooing establishment, the health authority
may conduct periodic inspections for the purpose of determining whether or not
said establishment and the persons performing the art of tattooing thereon are
in compliance with all applicable health provisions contained within this
article and other pertinent ordinances. It shall be unlawful for any person or
operator of a tattooing establishment wilfully to prevent or restrain the
health officer from entering any licensed establishment where tattooing is
being performed for the purpose of inspecting said premises, after proper
identification is presented to the operator. Where the health authority has
reasonable grounds to believe that a communicable disease has possibly been
transmitted at a licensed tattoo parlor it may require testing of the tattoo
artist and employees. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-512. No Guarantee Or Warranty:
The purpose of this article is to protect the public interest by reducing the
dangers involved in unregulated practice of tattooing. Neither the issuance of
a license, the making of an inspection without finding violations, or any other
act by the health officer or by any other city official shall constitute a
guarantee or warranty that any equipment or any treatment is safe or effective,
or that any tattooing establishment will perform without making errors. (Ord.
12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
DIVISION 4. REVOCATION OF LICENSE
Sec. 8-513. Hearing Prerequisite To Revocation Of License; Notice:
No license shall be revoked until after due notice and a hearing shall have
been held before the administrative hearing officer to determine just cause for
such revocation. Notice of such hearing shall be given in writing and served at
least ten (10) days but not more than twenty (20) days prior to the date of the
hearing thereof. The notice shall state the grounds of the complaint against
the holder of such license and shall designate the time and place where such
hearing will be had. Said notice shall be served upon the license holder by
delivering the same personally or by leaving such notice at the place of
business or residence of the license holder in the custody of a person of
suitable age and discretion. In the event the license holder cannot be found,
and the service of such notice cannot be otherwise made in the manner herein
provided, a copy of such notice shall be mailed, registered and postage fully
prepaid, addressed to the license holder at his place of business or residence
at least ten (10) days prior to the date of such hearing. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1,
2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-514. Grounds Of Revocation:
The license of a tattooing establishment may be revoked for any legitimate
reason, including, without limitation, any one or more of the following
grounds:
      (1)   That the holder is addicted to the habitual use of intoxicating
liquors, narcotics or stimulants to such an extent as to incapacitate such
person for the performance of his professional duties for any period of time.
      (2)   That the holder is guilty of fraudulent, false, misleading or
deceptive advertising.
      (3)   That the holder is guilty of wilful negligence in the practice of
tattooing or has been guilty of employing, allowing or permitting any
unlicensed person to perform tattooing in his establishment.
      (4)   That liquor is being sold or consumed within the establishment.
      (5)   That the establishment has abandoned the practice of tattooing or
that the individual licensee has abandoned the same practices. For the purposes
of this subsection, "abandonment" shall mean that the activities regulated
hereunder, or any of them, have ceased or otherwise not conducted for a period
of sixty (60) days at the establishment in question, or where an individual
licensee has abandoned the activities regulated hereunder, or any of them, for
a like period.
      (6)   That the licensee, whether an establishment or individual, has
violated any provision of this article, whether or not an action has been
commenced in circuit court.
      (7)   Any licensee, whether an establishment or individual, who has had
its license revoked three (3) times shall be ineligible for any license
hereunder for a period of five (5) years beginning with the effective date of
the third revocation. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-515. Tattooing Establishments Practicing When Provisions Of Article
Become Effective:
Any person, firm or corporation who is actually engaged in the practice of
tattooing at the time of final passage of ordinance 12-2000 and meets all the
requirements except as to adequacy of facilities, and upon payment of the
prescribed fee, shall be granted a license. Such person shall have thirty (30)
days from the effective date of ordinance 12-2000 from which this article is
derived to bring his facilities into compliance with this article. (Ord. 12-
2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
DIVISION 5. REGULATION; PENALTY
Sec. 8-516. Federal, State And Local Regulation:
Wherever federal, state, or local laws, ordinances, rules or regulations
conflict with the provisions of this article, then the law, ordinance, rule or
regulation which is most strict shall apply, and it shall not be a defense to
an action under this article, or to a request for suspension or revocation of
the license(s) provided herein, that this article does not specifically
enumerate the proscribed, prohibited or regulated conduct. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1,
2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-517. Penalty:
In addition to the revocation and suspension of any license, any person
violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less then twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues. Complaints for violation of
provisions of this article may be brought to the administrative hearing
officer. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
ARTICLE XX: RECREATIONAL CANNABIS BUSINESSES
Sec. 8-518.   Purpose:
   It is the intent and purpose of this article to provide regulations
regarding the cultivation, processing and dispensing of adult-use cannabis
occurring within the corporate limits of the City of Rock Island. Such
facilities shall comply with all regulations provided in the Illinois Cannabis
Regulation and Tax Act (P.A. 101-0027) (Act), as it may be amended from time-
to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder, and the regulations provided
below. In the event that the Act is amended, the more restrictive of the state
or local regulations shall apply.
(Ord. 055-2019, 10- 28-2019; Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-519.   Definitions:
   Cannabidiol (CBD): A chemical derived from cannabis that is used primarily
for medical purposes. CBD has less pronounced psychoactive effects than THC.
   Cannabis: Any species of the family Cannabaceae including but not limited to
Cannabis sativa, Cannabis indica, and Cannabis ruderalis used for recreational,
medicinal, or industrial purposes. This term shall refer to marijuana, hashish,
and other substances that are identified as including any parts of the plant,
whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of
the plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or
preparation of the plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol
(THC) and all other naturally produced cannabinol derivatives, whether produced
directly or indirectly by extraction or independently by chemical synthesis or
by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis; however, "cannabis" does
not include the mature stalks of the plant, fiber produced from the stalks, oil
or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compound, manufacture,
salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks (except the
resin extracted from it), fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of the
plant that is incapable of germination. "Cannabis" does not include industrial
hemp as defined and authorized under the Illinois Industrial Hemp Act.
"Cannabis" also means concentrate and cannabis-infused products.
   Cannabis Business Establishment: An adult-use cannabis cultivation center,
consumption business, craft grower, processing organization, infuser
organization, dispensing organization, or transporting organization.
   Cannabis Craft Grower: A facility operated by an organization or business
that is licensed by the Illinois Department of Agriculture to cultivate, dry,
cure and package cannabis and perform other necessary activities to make
cannabis available for sale at a dispensing organization or use at a processing
organization, per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it
may be amended from time-to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   Cannabis Cultivation Center: A facility operated by an organization or
business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of Agriculture to
cultivate, process, transport and perform necessary activities to provide
cannabis and cannabis-infused products to licensed cannabis business
establishments, per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it
may be amended from time-to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   Cannabis Dispensing Organization: A facility operated by an organization or
business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of Financial and
Professional Regulation to acquire cannabis from licensed cannabis business
establishments for the purpose of selling or dispensing cannabis, cannabis-
infused products, cannabis seeds, paraphernalia or related supplies to
purchasers or to qualified registered medical cannabis patients and caregivers,
per the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended
from time-to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   Cannabis Infuser Organization Or Infuser: A facility operated by an
organization or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Agriculture to directly incorporate cannabis or cannabis concentrate into a
product formulation to produce a cannabis-infused product, per the Cannabis
Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended from time-to-
time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
   Cannabis Processing Organization Or Processor: A facility operated by an
organization or business that is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Agriculture to either extract constituent chemicals or compounds to produce
cannabis concentrate or incorporate cannabis or cannabis concentrate into a
product formulation to produce a cannabis product, per the Cannabis Regulation
and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended from time-to-time, and
regulations promulgated thereunder.
   Compliance Inspection: An on-site or remote inspection conducted by the City
or its authorized agents to ensure compliance with applicable City ordinances,
regulations, and state laws.
   Dispensary License: A license issued by the City authorizing the operation
of a Cannabis Dispensing Organization within City limits.
   Hemp: Otherwise known as "industrial hemp," this material is made from
Cannabis with a delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) concentration of not more
than 0.3 percent on a dry weight basis that has been cultivated under a license
issued under the Illinois Industrial Hemp Act or is otherwise lawfully present
in the State of Illinois, and includes any intermediate or finished product
made or derived from industrial hemp. Hemp shall not be subject to this
article.
   On-Site Consumption Dispensing Business: Any premises wherein cannabis is
sold at retail for consumption on the premises as the principal use. Such
businesses include but are not limited to cannabis cafes, cannabis smoking
lounges, cannabis vaping lounges, and cannabis clubs. These facilities may also
engage in packaged cannabis sales.
   Packaged Product Dispensing Business: Any premises where sale of packaged
cannabis products is the principal use. Consumption of cannabis at these
premises is prohibited.
   Provisional Dispensary License: A temporary, conditional license issued to
allow an applicant to conduct due diligence in preparation for a potential
cannabis dispensing organization, including but not limited to zoning, land
use, and state licensure requirements.
   Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC): A chemical derived from cannabis that is used
primarily for recreational purposes. THC is the principal psychoactive chemical
in cannabis.
   Transportation Organization Of Transporter: An organization or business that
is licensed by the Illinois Department of Agriculture to transport cannabis on
behalf of a cannabis business establishment or a community college licensed
under the Community College Cannabis Vocational Training Pilot Program, per the
Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, (P.A. 101-0027), as it may be amended from
time-to-time, and regulations promulgated thereunder.
(Ord. 055-2019, 10-28-2019; Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-520.   Zoning Regulations:
   (a)   Cannabis craft growing facilities and cultivation centers shall be a
permitted use in all agricultural and industrial zoning districts.
   (b)   Cannabis infuser organizations, processing organizations, and
transportation organizations shall be a permitted use in all industrial zoning
districts.
   (c)   Packaged product dispensing businesses shall be a permitted use in all
industrial and business zoning districts.
   (d)   On-site consumption dispensing businesses shall be a permitted use in
all industrial zoning districts and all business zoning districts except the B-
1: Neighborhood Business District.
   (e)   Co-Location of a Dispensing Organization and a Craft Grower Center or
an Infuser Organization, or both, shall be permitted. In such case, the floor
space requirements of Section
8-521, Subsection (b) shall not apply, but the co-located establishments shall
be the sole use of the tenant space. Such co-located establishments shall be a
permitted use in all agricultural and industrial zoning districts.
   (f)   All cannabis business establishments shall be located at least one
hundred feet (100') in distance from any residential zoning district.
(Ord. 055-2019, 10-28-2019; Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-521.   General Regulations:
   (a)   Packaged cannabis sales shall be permitted only at licensed packaged
product dispensing businesses. Consumption of cannabis shall be permitted only
at licensed on-site consumption businesses or elsewhere as authorized by the
Illinois Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act.
   (b)   At least seventy-five percent (75%) of the floor area of any tenant
space occupied by a cannabis business establishment shall be devoted to the
activities of said business as authorized by the Illinois Cannabis Regulation
and Tax Act. A facility may not conduct any sales or distribution of cannabis
other than as authorized by the Illinois Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act.
   (c)   Cannabis Business Establishments shall install building enhancements,
such as security cameras, lighting or other improvements to ensure the safety
of its employees and customers as well as its environs. Said improvements shall
be determined based on the specific characteristics of the building floor plan
and the site on which it is located and shall be consistent with the
requirements of the Illinois Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act.
   (d)   Cannabis Business Establishments shall keep their State issued license
and registration documents in a conspicuous location in an area of the business
accessible to consumers and/or state and city officials at all times.
   (e)   Cannabis Business Establishments shall immediately produce upon
request by city staff the following information.
      (1)   Name of the business.
      (2)   Names of the business owners.
      (3)   Names and mailing addresses of all individuals who have an
ownership interest in the business.
      (4)   Names and addresses of all other persons who work on the business
premises whether employees or independent contractors of the business along
with a description of the work performed.
      (5)   Government issued photo identification card for all employees or
independent contractors of the business to verify and confirm identify of
individuals referenced above.
   (f)   All Cannabis Business Establishments shall comply with the Illinois
Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, as it may be amended from time-to-time, and
the regulations therein.
(Ord. 055-2019, 10-28- 2019; Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-522. Dispensary Licenses:
   (a)   Every Cannabis Dispensing Organization shall obtain a Dispensing
License from the City of Rock Island prior to operation within City limits.
   (b)   No more than two (2) Dispensary Licenses shall be issued and in effect
within the City at any given time.
   (c)   Provisional License required: An applicant must obtain a Provisional
Dispensary License before becoming eligible for consideration for a Dispensary
License.
   (d)   No entity shall be awarded a Dispensary License without first holding
a valid and active Provisional Dispensary License.
   (e)   Authority to Issue or Deny Licenses: The decision to issue, deny, or
renew a Provisional Dispensary License or a Dispensary License shall be made by
the City Manager or their designee, at their full and sole discretion. Issuance
of any license is not guaranteed and may be denied even if the applicant meets
all technical requirements.
   (f)   Fee: Each holder of a Dispensing License or Provisional Dispensing
License shall pay an annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable upon
application, and every year thereafter on May 1st.
(Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-523. Provisional Dispensary License:
   (a)   Purpose: A Provisional Dispensary License allows an entity to perform
necessary due diligence, including satisfying zoning, land use, and state
regulatory requirements, prior to becoming eligible for a Dispensary License.
Provisional licenses are non-transferable.
   (b)   Term and Renewals:
      (1)   Initial Term: Two (2) years;
      (2)   Renewals: Up to five (5) two-year renewals;
      (3)   Renewals are discretionary and based on demonstrated good faith
progress.
   (c)   Good Faith Efforts: Applicants must show active efforts toward
establishing a dispensary, such as:
      (1)   Evidence of site control;
      (2)   Progress with IDFPR licensing;
      (3)   Zoning and land use filings;
      (4)   Engagement of legal, financial, and regulatory advisors;
   (d)   Non-Renewal: A renewal may be denied if the City Manager or designee
determines insufficient progress has been made.
   (e)   Holding a Provisional License does not guarantee future approval of a
Dispensary License.
   (f)   A Provisional Dispensary License will only be issued if the City has
not met its cap on Dispensary Licenses. If there is one active Dispensary
License than no more than one Provisional Dispensary License will be awarded.
If there are no active Dispensary Licenses, the City may award two (2)
Provisional Licenses.
(Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-524. Dispensary License Evaluation Criteria:
   The City Manager or designee may consider the following factors in
evaluating a Dispensary License Application:
   (1)   Zoning and land use compliance;
   (2)   Suitability of the proposed location;
   (3)   Security and operational planning;
   (4)   Applicant's experience and qualifications;
   (5)   Financial readiness and business planning;
   (6)   Community impact and engagement;
   (7)   Regulatory compliance history;
   (8)   Public safety and traffic concerns; and
   (9)   Any other relevant factors in the City's interest.
(Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-525. Appeals Process:
   Any applicant denied a Provisional Dispensary License, renewal, or
Dispensary License may file an appeal with the City Clerk within thirty (30)
days of the date of the denial notice. The appeal shall state the grounds and
include supporting documentation.
   The City Council shall hear and decide the appeal. It may affirm, reverse,
or modify the City Manager's decision.
   The decision of the City Council shall be final and binding.
(Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Sec. 8-526. Dispensary License Terms, Renewals, And Compliance:
   (a)   Term: Each Dispensary License shall be valid for a period of one (1)
year from the date of issuance, unless either suspended or revoked.
   (b)   Annual Renewal Required: Dispensary Licenses must be renewed annually
with the City Clerk. The licensee shall submit a renewal application no less
than sixty (60) days prior to expiration. Renewal shall be subject to:
      (1)   Demonstrated compliance with all City ordinances and applicable
state laws;
      (2)   Satisfaction of all fees and taxes owed to the City; and
      (3)   No outstanding violations or unresolved citations.
   (c)   Grounds for Revocation: The City Manager or designee may suspend or
revoke a Dispensary License at any time for any of the following reasons:
      (1)   Violation of any City ordinance, zoning restriction, or regulation;
      (2)   Violation of applicable state cannabis laws or regulations;
      (3)   Submission of false or misleading information to the City;
      (4)   Operating in a manner that constitutes a public nuisance or risk to
public health or safety.
   (d)   Revocation Procedure: Prior to revocation, the City shall issue a
written notice stating the grounds of the proposed revocation and provide the
licensee with the opportunity to respond in writing within ten (10) business
days. The City Manager may, at their discretion, hold an informal hearing.
After review, the City Manager may issue a final decision. The licensee may
appeal the decision under the process described in Section
8-525.
(Ord. 62-2025, 6-24-2025)
Secs. 8-527 – 8-535. Reserved:
ARTICLE XXI: SHORT-TERM RENTALS
(Rep. by Ord. 070-2020, 12-21-2020)
Secs. 8-536 – 8-560. Reserved:
ARTICLE XXII. COMMERCIAL INDUSTRIAL REVOLVING LOAN FUND (CIRLF) COMMITTEE
Sec. 8-561. Purpose:
   There is hereby created a Commercial Industrial Revolving Loan Fund (CIRLF)
Committee to oversee the CIRLF Program as described in the Program policies and
procedures as approved by the City Council. The City Council delegates final
decision-making authority to the Committee for the purposes of fulfilling its
duties as herein described. (Ord. 007-2022, § 1, 2-28-2022)
Sec. 8-562. Duties and Powers:
   The Committee shall have the following duties and powers:
      (1)   Reviewing loan packets and making determinations of loan awards.
      (2)   Approving or denying foreclosure actions, waivers, and/or
modifications of loan terms.
      (3)   Recommendation of program policy that is not related to, or does
not change the regulatory requirements of the Department of Housing and Urban
Development (HUD).
      (4)   Advising and consulting with the Mayor, City Council, City Manager,
and department staff on all matters involving the Program and loans approved
through the Program objectives and outcomes.
      (5)   Providing an annual summary report to the Mayor and City Council.
(Ord. 007-2022, § 1, 2-28-2022)
Sec. 8-563. Membership:
   The Committee shall consist of five (5) voting members who are required to
be residents of the City of Rock Island. The Committee membership shall consist
of:
      (1)   City of Rock Island Council member (serves a two-year term).
      (2)   A representative of a local lending institution.
      (3)   Rock Island CEO or CPA member.
      (4)   A Rock Island business owner.
      (5)   A citizen with financial back ground to represent the community.
(Ord. 007-2022, § 1, 2-28-2022)
Sec. 8-564. Compensation:
   Committee members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 007-2022, § 1, 2-
28-2022)
Sec. 8-565. Terms:
   The members of the Committee shall be appointed by the Mayor and approved by
the City Council. Special appointments to the Committee shall be made by the
Mayor and approved by the City Council as vacancies may occur. Committee
members shall serve terms of three (3) years. Each committee member shall not
serve more than two consecutive, three-year terms. (Ord. 007-2022, § 1, 2-28-
2022)
Sec. 8-566. Officers:
   (a)   Generally: Officers shall consist of a Chair and Vice Chair elected by
the Committee who shall each serve a term of one (1) year and shall be eligible
for reelection. Elections shall be held annually.
   (b)   Chair: The Chair shall preside over meetings. In the absence of the
Chair, the Vice Chair shall perform the duties of the Chair. If both are
absent, a temporary Chair shall be elected by those present.
   (c)   Staff Liaison: The Community Economic Development Department's
Economic Development Manager shall be assigned as a staff liaison to the
Committee. The liaison will ensure that the CIRLF Policies and Procedures are
adhered to. The liaison shall also:
      (1)   Take minutes of each Committee meeting, originals of which shall be
kept in the Office of Community and Economic Development Department and make
these available to the public;
      (2)   Provide administrative and technical assistance to the Committee to
assist it in making the decisions and findings as provided herein;
      (3)   Publish and distribute to the Committee members copies of the
minutes, reports, and decisions of the Committee;
      (4)   Give notice as provided herein or by law for all meetings conducted
by the Committee;
      (5)   Advise the Mayor of vacancies on the Committee and expiring terms
of Committee members;
      (6)   The liaison shall have no vote. (Ord. 007-2022, § 1, 2-28-2022)
Sec. 8-567. Meetings:
   The Committee shall meet no less than four (4) times each year at City Hall
and such further times as meetings are called by the Chair or a majority of the
members of said Committee. A quorum shall consist of a simple majority of the
voting members of the committee. A majority vote shall be required for loan
approval. One Committee member with financial experience will be required to be
present at any meeting in which a loan application is being reviewed for loan
approval. All meetings shall conform to the Open Meetings Act. (Ord. 007-2022,
§ 1, 2-28-2022)

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 9-1. Definitions:
Whenever in this chapter the following terms are used, they shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   Loading Zone: That space or area defined by ordinance as being reserved for
the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or
materials.
   Parkway: That part of the street which lies between the property line and
the curb.
   Property Line: The line marking the boundary between any street and the lots
or property abutting thereon.
   Public Building: A building used by the city or by any park district, school
district, the state of Illinois or the United States government. (1963 Code,
ch. XI, art. I)
Sec. 9-2. Penalty 3 :
Except as otherwise provided herein:
Any individual violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6)
months for any offense.
Any firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined
not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (1963 Code, ch.
XI, art. X)

provisions which by their nature can have no application to the city, are
hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter with the same force
and effect as if set forth at length herein. It shall be unlawful for any
person to violate any of the provisions of the Illinois vehicle code.
Any person charged with any of the following violations:
