4 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., 5/20-204.
Sec. 9-4. Miscellaneous Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
ordinance establishing or eliminating stop intersections, yield right of way
intersections, bus stops, through streets, cab stands or other motor vehicle or
traffic restrictions at specific locations, or authorizing traffic signals, or
prohibiting a right turn on a red light, or relating to a mass transit
district; and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full
force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this code. This
chapter is intended to and shall be in addition to all other ordinances, rules
and regulations concerning traffic, parking and the use of the streets, and
shall not be taken to repeal any other ordinance or part of any ordinance
unless in direct conflict therewith. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. XII)
Sec. 9-5. Tickets:
For offenses other than driving while intoxicated or reckless driving, police
officers, after making note of the license number of the vehicle (and name of
the offender where possible), may issue a traffic violation ticket notifying
the offender to appear in court at the time designated for hearing such cases.
Such officer may sign a complaint for the issuance of a warrant if the offender
does not appear at the time and place so specified. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. X)
Sec. 9-6. Riding On Fenders, Etc.:
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, hood, top,
running boards or outside step of any vehicle. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. IV)
Sec. 9-7. Toy Vehicles Generally:
It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates or a coaster, sled or other toy
vehicle to go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. (1963 Code, ch. XI,
art. IV)
Sec. 9-8. Vehicles Prohibited On Certain Streets:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any truck, except for the purpose
of making a delivery and then for one block only, on any street so designated
by ordinance and properly signposted. For the purposes of this section the term
"truck" refers to any truck required to have a class "D" license under the
provisions of the Illinois vehicle code. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. VII; Ord. 88-
57, § 1, 9-1-1988)
Sec. 9-9. Scene Of Fire:
The fire department officer in command, or any fireman designated by him, may
exercise the powers and authority of a policeman in directing traffic at the
scene of any fire or where the fire department has responded to any emergency
call for so long as fire department equipment is on the scene, in the absence
of or in assisting the police. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. I)
Sec. 9-9.1. Sound Amplification Systems:
   (a)   Prohibited: No driver of any motor vehicle within the city of Rock
Island shall operate or permit the operation of any sound amplification system
which can be heard outside the vehicle from seventy five feet (75') or more,
when the vehicle is present upon a highway, unless such system is being
operated to request assistance or warn of a hazardous situation. This section
does not apply to authorized emergency vehicles.
   (b)   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more
than three hundred dollars ($300.00). In the event a person accused with a
violation of this section does not wish to contest the allegation, said person
may pay to the city of Rock Island police headquarters, within seven (7) days
of the issuance of the notice of violation, a penalty in the sum of seventy
five dollars ($75.00), which payment shall be in full satisfaction of the
violation. (Ord. 98-87, § 1, 10-26-1998; Ord. 98-90, § 1, 11-2-1998; Ord. 72-
2001, § 1, 9-17-2001)
Sec. 9-9.2. Unlawful Use Of Electronic Communication Devices:
   (a)   As used in this section "electronic communication device" means an
electronic device, including, but not limited to, a handheld wireless
telephone, handheld personal digital assistant, or a portable or mobile
computer, but does not include a global positioning system or navigation system
or a device that is physically or electronically integrated into the motor
vehicle.
   (b)   A person may not operate a motor vehicle on a roadway while using an
electronic communication device.
   (c)   This section does not apply to:
      (1)   A law enforcement officer or operator of an emergency vehicle while
performing his or her official duties;
      (2)   A driver using an electronic communication device for the sole
purpose of reporting an emergency situation and continued communication with
emergency personnel during the emergency situation;
      (3)   A driver using an electronic communication device in hands free or
voice operated mode, which may include the use of a headset;
      (4)   A driver of a commercial motor vehicle reading a message displayed
on a permanently installed communication device designed for a commercial motor
vehicle with a screen that does not exceed ten inches tall by ten inches wide
(10" x 10") in size;
      (5)   A driver using an electronic communication device while parked on
the shoulder of a roadway;
      (6)   A driver using an electronic communication device when the vehicle
is stopped due to normal traffic being obstructed and the driver has the motor
vehicle transmission in neutral or park;
      (7)   A driver using two-way or citizens band radio services;
      (8)   A driver using two-way mobile radio transmitters or receivers for
licensees of the federal communications commission in the amateur radio
service;
      (9)   A driver using an electronic communication device by pressing a
single button to initiate or terminate a voice communication; or
      (10)   A driver using an electronic communication device capable of
performing multiple functions, other than a handheld wireless telephone or
handheld personal digital assistant (for example, a fleet management system,
dispatching device, citizens band radio, or music player) for a purpose that is
not otherwise prohibited by this section.
   (d)   A person who violates this section shall be fined a maximum of seventy
five dollars ($75.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation and does
not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for
the violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city, at police
headquarters, a penalty in the sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for and in
full satisfaction of the violation. (Ord. 029-2014, 3-24-2014)
Sec. 9-10. Bicycles-Bicycle Sales-Registration:
   (a)   Bicycle Dealer's License: It shall be unlawful to deal in sales of
three (3) or more bicycles within any calendar year without a bicycle dealer's
license. "Bicycle", for the purpose of this section, is any bicycle twenty
inches (20") or more in size.
   (b)   License Procedure:
      (1)   License Application: The application for a license hereunder shall
be made in writing to the City Clerk on a form provided by the City Clerk's
Office. Licenses are nontransferable.
      (2)   License Fee: The license fee for a bicycle dealer's license shall
be free and the license shall remain in effect from the date of issue until the
business is closed, sold, or ownership is transferred.
   (c)   Mandatory Registration Of Bicycles: It shall be mandatory for all
bicycle dealers dealing in the retail sale of bicycles within the City, to
register all bicycles size twenty inches (20") and over at the time of sale.
The registration forms and bicycle license plates shall be made available to
the businesses at no cost through the Police Department. The completed
registration forms shall be picked up twice a month by a member of the Police
Department. It shall be the responsibility of the business owner and/or manager
to notify the Police Department if they are in need of additional registration
forms and/or license plates. Persons registering a bicycle at the bicycle
dealer or at police headquarters shall not be charged a fee.
   (d)   Fine: Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions
of these ordinances relating to bicycle dealer's license and procedures shall
be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (e)   Operation Of A Bicycle Without A License: No person who resides within
this City shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street, highway, road, etc., or
upon any public way set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles unless such
bicycle has been licensed and a license plate is attached thereto as provided
herein. That in the event a bicycle has been purchased outside the corporate
limits of the City or was sold within the City and has not been processed for a
license plate as set forth above, the bicycle shall be licensed through the
procedure set below:
      (1)   Registration Agency: Applications for registration should be issued
by the Chief of Police.
      (2)   Application Form: The application for a bicycle license shall be on
a form provided by the City.
      (3)   Proof Of Ownership: The Chief of Police shall refuse to issue a
license where he has reason to believe the applicant is not the owner of, or
entitled to possession of, the bicycle.
      (4)   Inspection: The Chief of Police or an officer assigned such
responsibility shall inspect each bicycle before licensing the same and shall
refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines is in unsafe mechanical
condition.
      (5)   Registration Plate Or Tag: Upon issuing a bicycle license, the
Chief of Police must also issue a plate or tag, which shall be firmly attached
to the bicycle in a manner as to be plainly visible from the rear.
      (6)   Records: The Chief of Police shall keep a record of the number of
each license, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom
issued and the number on the frame of the bicycle for which issued.
      (7)   Duration-Transfer Of Ownership; Renewal: A bicycle license shall
remain valid as long as it remains the property of the initial owner. If sold,
traded, given away, etc., the new owner shall reregister the bicycle in their
name.
      (8)   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall
be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) or more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). In the event a person accused with a violation
of this section who does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time
that complaint is issued for said violation, said person may pay to the City at
the Rock Island police headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifteen dollars
($15.00) for and in full satisfaction of said violation. In the event a person
is found guilty of violating the provisions of this section a second or more
time, he or she shall be fined in an amount equal the minimal fine. (1963 Code
art. 11-8; Ord., 2-23-1976; Ord., 8-14-1978; Ord. 96-64, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-69,
7-28-1997)
Sec. 9-11. Car Owner Responsibility Assignment:
This chapter is declared necessary for the preservation of the public peace,
health, safety and welfare of the people of the City, and is intended to
address a public nuisance created by individuals operating motor vehicles upon
the streets and highways of this City. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-
14-1997)
Sec. 9-12. Public Nuisance:
   (a)   A motor vehicle that is used in the violation of any of the offenses
contained in this section shall be declared a public nuisance and the owner of
record shall be subject to having said vehicle impounded for lengths of
impoundment described in section 9-13 of this article and shall also be liable
to the City for the penalties indicated in section 9-13 of this article to
include the fees for the towing and storage of the vehicle and fines.
      (1)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle who
is in violation of section 9-9.1 of this article.
      (2)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle
where the windows of the motor vehicle are obstructed in violation of the
Illinois Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-503(a) and (b).
      (3)   The driver of a motor vehicle who is in violation of the Illinois
Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101 entitled "Drivers Must Have
Licenses and Permits" and the violator has an invalid driver's license or the
violator's driver's license has been expired for more than six (6) months.
      (4)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is
in violation of section 10-90, "Truancy Prohibited", of this Code.
      (5)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is
in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 555/1 - Child Curfew Act and/or
subsection 10-59(a) of this Code, entitled "Curfew for Persons Under Seventeen
Years of Age".
      (6)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle
while being twenty (20) years of age or younger is in possession of alcohol in
violation of subsection 3-10(c), "Purchase And Consumption By Minors
Prohibited", of this Code.
      (7)   The driver of a motor vehicle who is in violation of the Illinois
Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303 entitled "Driving While
Driver's License, Permit Or Privilege to Operate a Motor Vehicle Is Suspended
Or Revoked".
      (8)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is
in violation of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 550/4(a), (b), (c), (d) or (e), entitled "Possession of Cannabis" and/
or Illinois Cannabis Control Act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/5(a), (b),
(c), (d) and (e), entitled "Manufacture Or Delivery of Cannabis". Possession of
cannabis up to ten grams (10 g) shall not be subject to this section.
      (9)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle who
is in violation of the Illinois Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
11-501 entitled "Driving While Under the Influence of Alcohol, Other Drug Or
Drugs, Intoxicating Compound Or Compounds Or Any Combination Thereof".
      (10)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is
in violation of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1(a)(4), entitled "Unlawful Use of Weapons".
      (11)   The motor vehicle is used in the commission of, or attempt to
commit a violation of Illinois Criminal Code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1.2, entitled "Aggravated Discharge of a Firearm" and/or Illinois Criminal
Code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5, entitled "Reckless Discharge of
a Firearm".
      (12)   The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is
in violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 570/402, entitled "Possession Unauthorized by This Act".
      (13)   The motor vehicle unlawfully flees or attempts to flee and elude a
peace officer in violation of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-204 or 5/11-204.1.
   (b)   The driver or other person in possession of the motor vehicle shall be
arrested or cited for the violations of the State Statute(s) or City ordinance
(s) as indicated in subsections (a)(1) through (a)(13) of this section. (Ord.
96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 98-88, 10-26-1998; Ord. 72-2001,
9-17-2001; Ord. 18-2004, 2-2-2004; Ord. 051-2012, 7-23-2012; Ord. 024-2018, 6-
11-2018)
Sec. 9-13. Length Of Impoundment And Fines:
   (a)   Whenever a vehicle is used in violation of subsections 9-12(a)(1)
through (a)(13) of this chapter the registered owner's vehicle shall be
impounded for the following lengths of time and a penalty imposed against the
registered vehicle owner as indicated herein:
      (1)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1), (a)(2) or (a)(3) of this
chapter, motor vehicle impounded for three (3) days and a fine of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00).
      (2)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(4) or (a)(5) of this chapter, motor
vehicle impounded for seven (7) days and a fine of two hundred dollars
($200.00).
      (3)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(6) or (a)(7) of this chapter, motor
vehicle impounded for fourteen (14) days and a fine of five hundred eighty
dollars ($580.00).
      (4)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(8) or (a)(9) of this chapter, motor
vehicle impounded for twenty (20) days and a fine of five hundred eighty
dollars ($580.00).
      (5)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(10) or (a)(11) of this chapter,
motor vehicle impounded for thirty (30) days and a fine of five hundred eighty
dollars ($580.00).
      (6)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(12) of this chapter, motor vehicle
impounded for thirty (30) days and a fine of five hundred eighty dollars
($580.00).
      (7)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(13) of this chapter, motor vehicle
impounded for thirty (30) days and a fine of five hundred eighty dollars
($580.00). (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 18-2004, § 2, 2-
2-2004; Ord. 24-2004, § 1, 2-16-2004; Ord. 051-2012, 7-23-2012)
Sec. 9-14. Fines And Subsequent Violations:
All lengths of impoundment and fines imposed shall double upon any subsequent
violation of this article. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 9-14.1. Impoundment With Respect To Sound Amplification Systems
Violations:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this or other ordinances, there shall
be no impoundment of an owner's vehicle for the vehicle's operation as a public
nuisance in violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1) of this chapter when that
vehicle has not been so operated as a public nuisance in violation of
subsection 9-12(a)(1) of this chapter for a period of two (2) or more years.
However, the owner of a vehicle that is not impounded because of the preceding
sentence shall pay a fine of seventy five dollars ($75.00) if the vehicle is
found to have been operated as a public nuisance in violation of subsection 9-
12(a)(1) of this chapter. For second and subsequent operations of a given
owner's vehicle as a public nuisance in violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1) of
this chapter that occur within two (2) years of the most recent violation of
that section, all other provisions of sections 9-11 through 9-20 of this
chapter shall be fully operable. (Ord. 72-2001, § 1, 9-17-2001)
Sec. 9-15. Seizure, Impoundment And Hearings Request:
Whenever a police officer has reasonable suspicion to believe that a vehicle is
subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this article, the police officer
shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility controlled by the
City or its agents. When the vehicle is towed, the police officer shall notify
the person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the
alleged violation, if there is such a person, and the owner of said vehicle of
the fact of the seizure and the vehicle owner's right to post a cash bond as
indicated in subsections 9-16(a)(1) through (a)(6) of this chapter to retrieve
possession of their vehicle pending a hearing to be held by the City's Code
Hearing Officer. When the vehicle is not impounded for a first offense pursuant
to section 9-14.1 of this chapter, the police officer shall notify the
vehicle's owner that second and subsequent uses of the vehicle as a public
nuisance in violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1) of this chapter that occur
within two (2) years of the most recent use as a public nuisance shall result
in the impoundment of the vehicle pursuant to this section. The notification
shall also explain the vehicle owner's right to a hearing with respect to the
alleged violation. When a vehicle is impounded, the officer shall also notify
the owner and person in control of the vehicle of the owner's right to a
probable cause hearing as set forth in subsection 9-17(i) of this chapter.
(Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 72-2001, § 1, 9-17-2001)
Sec. 9-15.1. Vehicle Involved In An Unlawful Attempt To Flee And Elude A Peace
Officer:
   (a)   Declared A Nuisance: A vehicle involved in an unlawful attempt to flee
and elude a peace officer in violation of section 11-204 or 11-204.1 of the
Illinois Motor Vehicle Code 1  and is not immediately stopped by the police and
the driver placed under arrest is declared to be a public nuisance under
subsection 9-12(a)(13) of this chapter and said vehicle is subject to being
immediately towed by the police.
   (b)   Vehicle Subject To Seizure And Impoundment: Whenever a police officer
has observed a vehicle engaged in an unlawful attempt to flee and elude and
believes that there exists probable cause to tow said vehicle, and locates said
vehicle on a public thoroughfare or within a parking lot under City ordinance
control or a parking lot open to the general public within the City of Rock
Island, Illinois, before the end of his or her watch, then said vehicle may be
seized and impounded by the Rock Island Ppolice Department. Notice shall be
given to the person in control of the vehicle and the owner of the vehicle as
described in subsection (g) of this section.
   (c)   Incident Report: Whenever a police officer has observed a vehicle
engaged in an unlawful attempt to flee and elude and said vehicle is not
located by the police before the end of his or her watch, said officer shall at
the end of his or her watch prepare a written incident report which provides a
record, if possible, of the make, model, year, color, state of registration,
license plate number, identification of the driver, location of the incident
and the date and time of the incident. Said report shall include information
sufficient to support the determination of probable cause to tow, including
information of the officer's attempts to stop the vehicle at the time of the
occurrence, and that the driver failed or refused to stop after the officer
activated the squad car's emergency signal equipment and that pursuit of the
vehicle was abandoned for public safety reasons.
   (d)   Interim Seizure: Upon completion of the report, the officer shall give
the report to the watch commander or his or her designee for interim seizure
and impoundment authorization of said vehicle. Once authorized, said vehicle
may be seized and impounded by police based upon the reporting officer's
probable cause for a period of ninety six (96) hours prior to the filing of a
"notice of intent to impound" as described in subsection (e) of this section.
If said vehicle is towed within the ninety six (96) hour period and before a
"notice of intent to tow" is filed as described in subsection (e) of this
section, notice shall be given to the person in control of the vehicle and the
owner of the vehicle as described in subsection (g) of this section. "Notice of
intent to tow" under subsection (e) of this section may be filed at any time
after the officer prepares his or her written incident report.
   (e)   Notice Of Intent To Impound: If said vehicle is not located within
ninety six (96) hours, the police department may file a "notice of intent to
impound" with the administrative clerk of MUNICES. Once filed, said vehicle may
be seized and impounded by police if located on a public thoroughfare or within
a parking lot under city ordinance control, or a parking lot open to the
general public within the city of Rock Island, Illinois, pending a plenary
hearing as described in subsection 9-17(b) of this chapter. The notice of
intent to impound shall include the following information:
      (1)   A statement that the operator on the date, time, and approximate
location of the incident in question failed or refused to stop operation of the
vehicle when ordered to do so by the police officer;
      (2)   A description of the vehicle as contained in the police officer's
report;
      (3)   Notice that a plenary hearing on the merits to contest the
eligibility for impoundment of the motor vehicle shall be scheduled on a
specified date at one o'clock (1:00) P.M. in the city hall chambers of the city
of Rock Island, Illinois, 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, Illinois. Said hearing
date shall be scheduled as described in subsection 9-17(b) of this chapter;
      (4)   Notice that if said vehicle, as described in the notice of intent
to impound, is located on a public thoroughfare or within a parking lot under
city ordinance control or a parking lot open to the general public within the
city of Rock Island, Illinois, at any time prior to the scheduled plenary
hearing as described in subsection (e)(3) of this section, that said vehicle is
subject to immediate impoundment and seizure;
      (5)   That the owner is entitled to have a preliminary hearing and/or
post bond to retrieve the vehicle prior to the scheduled plenary hearing as
described in subsection (g) of this section.
   (f)   Delivery Of Notice: Upon filing the "notice of intent to impound" with
the administrative clerk of MUNICES, notice shall be sent by regular mail to
the vehicle's owner of record. The notice is presumed delivered upon it being
deposited with the United States postal service with proper postage being
affixed thereto.
   (g)   Preliminary Hearing And Posting Of Bond:
      (1)   Whenever any officer of the Rock Island police department has
probable cause to believe that a vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment
pursuant to subsection (b), (d) or (e) of this section, and said vehicle is
located on a public thoroughfare or within a parking lot under city ordinance
control or a parking lot open to the general public within the city of Rock
Island, Illinois, said officer shall seize said vehicle and provide for its
towing and impoundment. When the vehicle is towed the officer shall notify the
person in control of the vehicle and the owner of the vehicle of the owner's
right to request a preliminary hearing to determine if there was probable cause
to believe that a driver of said vehicle was involved in an unlawful attempt to
flee and elude a police officer and of his or her right to post a cash bond as
indicated in section 9-16(a)(7) of this chapter to retrieve possession of said
vehicle prior to any preliminary hearings or plenary hearings on the merits.
Notice shall also be given to the owner of said vehicle of the date and time of
the plenary hearing on the merits as described in subsection 9-17(b) of this
chapter. All hearings on the merits will be held on the scheduled date and time
in the city hall chambers of the city of Rock Island, Illinois.
      (2)   All requests for preliminary hearing shall be in writing and
delivered to the Rock Island police department within twenty four (24) hours of
the seizure. All preliminary hearings shall be held within seventy two (72)
hours, excluding weekends and holidays, after the written request for hearing
is delivered to the police department.
      (3)   All preliminary hearings will be conducted by the administrative
code hearing officer.
      (4)   The vehicle so seized shall be impounded pending completion of any
preliminary hearings or plenary hearings on the merits and for the minimum time
of impoundment set by subsection 9-13(a)(7) of this chapter if a violation of
this section is found.
      (5)   If, after proceeding with a preliminary hearing, the administrative
hearing officer determines there was probable cause to tow, or if no timely
request for preliminary hearing is filed by the owner, said matter will be
scheduled for plenary hearing on the merits. Said hearing date shall proceed as
described in subsection 9-17(b) of this chapter.
      (6)   All hearings conducted under this section shall proceed in
accordance with the rules and procedures described in subsections 9-17(b)
through (h) of this chapter. (Ord. 051-2012, 7-23-2012)

Sec. 9-16. Bonding Procedure:
   (a)   Whenever the owner of a vehicle seized pursuant to this article wishes
to retrieve their vehicle prior to the evidentiary hearing they may do so by
posting a cash bond at police headquarters in the amount indicated herein. Once
the bond has been posted, the vehicle shall be released without charge until an
evidentiary hearing is held by the city code hearing officer.
      (1)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1), (a)(2), or (a)(3) of this
chapter, bond of two hundred forty five dollars ($245.00).
      (2)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(4) or (a)(5) of this chapter, bond
of three hundred fifty five dollars ($355.00).
      (3)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(6) or (a)(7) of this chapter, bond
of eight hundred forty dollars ($840.00).
      (4)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(8) or (a)(9) of this chapter, bond
of nine hundred thirty dollars ($930.00).
      (5)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(10) or (a)(11) of this chapter,
bond of one thousand eighty dollars ($1,080.00).
      (6)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(12) of this chapter, bond of one
thousand eighty dollars ($1,080.00).
      (7)   Violation of subsection 9-12(a)(13) of this chapter, bond of one
thousand eighty dollars ($1,080.00). (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-
1997; Ord. 58-00, § 1, 8-14-2000; Ord. 01-10, § 1, 2-5-2001; Ord. 05-2003, § 1,
1-27-2003; Ord. 25-2004, § 1, 2-16-2004; Ord. 004-2006, § 1, 1-23-2006; Ord.
081-2008, § 1, 12-22-2008; Ord. 051-2012, 7-23-2012)
Sec. 9-17. Hearing And Notification:
   (a)   Within ten (10) business days after a vehicle is seized and impounded
pursuant to this article, or not impounded by operation of section 9-14.1 of
this chapter, the city shall notify by certified mail, return receipt
requested, the owner of record, any lienholders or other legally entitled
persons of the date, time and location of a hearing that will be conducted
pursuant to this section. When the city does not know the identity of the
registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled person, the city will
cause the vehicle registration records of the state of Illinois to be searched
by the secretary of state for purposes of obtaining the required ownership
information.
   (b)   A hearing shall be scheduled and held, unless continued by order of
the city code hearing officer, on the first and third Friday of each month on
the Friday following the day the vehicle was seized if not within seven (7)
days. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the
hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The hearing shall be open to
the public and a court reporter shall transcribe the proceedings. If the city
of Rock Island shall enter into an intergovernmental agreement providing for
the shared use of the code enforcement hearing officer, the notice and hearing
date rules established pursuant to the intergovernmental agreement shall apply
to this subsection.
   (c)   If, after the hearing, the city code hearing officer determines by a
preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle had been stolen prior to the
alleged violation, he shall enter an order dismissing the procedure. If,
however, he determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was
not stolen prior to the violation, he shall enter an order requiring the
vehicle to continue to be impounded for the applicable length of time provided
for in this section and until the owner pays the fees imposed under sections 9-
13 and 9-14 of this chapter if the vehicle is still in the custody of the city.
If the vehicle is not in the city's custody then subsection (d) of this section
shall apply.
   (d)   If a bond had been posted and the owner has possession of the vehicle,
the city code hearing officer shall enter an order deducting the fees imposed
under sections 9-13 and 9-14 of this chapter as if the vehicle was actually
held for the time period specified from the cash bond that was posted.
   (e)   In the event the defendant wishes to appeal the decision of the city
code hearing officer under the provisions of the administrative review act,
said defendant shall pay the cost of the preparation and transcription of the
record of the hearing and shall appeal to the circuit court.
   (f)   If the city code hearing officer determines that there is no such
probable cause, the vehicle will be returned without penalty or other fees.
   (g)   The penalty and fees shall be a debt due and owed to the city.
However, if a cash bond has been posted the bond shall be applied to the fine.
If the city code hearing officer determines that the vehicle was not used with
the permission, express or implied, of the owner, he or she shall order the
return of the vehicle or cash bond. In the event it shall become necessary for
the city to collect the debt by filing an action in the circuit court, they
shall be entitled to recover, in addition to the amount due, court costs and
reasonable attorney fees.
   (h)   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, any lienholder
of record may obtain possession of any seized and impounded vehicles they have
a legal lien interest in by: 1) submitting to the city verified proof that they
have commenced foreclosure proceedings against the registered owner of said
vehicle, 2) payment of the towing and storage fees for the periods of time said
vehicle was to be held under section 9-13 of this chapter and 3) providing a
written agreement to refund to the city the net proceeds of any foreclosure
sale, over and above the amounts necessary to satisfy any liens, to be applied
by the city to satisfy any penalties and costs imposed under sections 9-13 and
9-14 of this chapter.
   (i)   In addition to the hearing procedures set forth in the preceding
subsections of this section, every owner who has his or her car impounded
pursuant to this chapter shall be entitled to a probable cause hearing before
the city's code hearing officer, or if he or she is not available, before an
impartial Illinois licensed attorney at law, on the question of whether or not
the vehicle has been operated as a public nuisance in violation of section 9-12
(a) of this chapter. This hearing, if requested, shall occur no later than two
(2) business days from the time of the owner's request for such a hearing. The
owner's request for a probable cause hearing must be made in writing to the
city of Rock Island police department within three (3) days of receiving notice
of the right to such a probable cause hearing. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-
50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 98-57, § 1, 8-24-1998; Ord. 33-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 72-
2001, § 1, 9-17-2001; Ord. 081-2010, 12-13-2010)
Sec. 9-18. Unclaimed Vehicles:
Any motor vehicle that is not reclaimed within thirty (30) days after the
expiration of the time during which the owner of record may seek judicial
review of the city's action under this article, or the time at which a final
judgment is rendered in favor of the city, or the time a final administrative
decision is rendered against an owner of record who is in default may be
disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle as provided by law. As used in this
article, the "owner of record" of a vehicle means the record titleholder. (Ord.
96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 9-19. Fees And Storage:
Fees for towing and storage of a vehicle under this article shall be the same
as those charged per the contract for towing service with the city in effect at
the time of same violation. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 9-20. Severability:
If any provision or part of this article shall be found unconstitutional or
outside the corporate or home rule powers of the city, the remaining provisions
shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-
14-1997)
Sec. 9-21. Authority To Impound Fleeing Vehicles:

ARTICLE II. PARKING 1
 
Notes
1 625 ILCS 5/1-208.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 9-26. Penalty:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, any person who violates any of the
parking ordinances of the city, other than a private parking ordinance
violation, a zoned parking ordinance violation, or a violation of downtown
restricted parking use ordinance, and who receives a ticket therefor, shall pay
a fine of twenty dollars ($20.00). In the event the fine is not paid within
seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay
as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of forty
dollars ($40.00). Any person violating the private parking ordinance in the
city shall pay a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00). In the event the fine is
not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the
vehicle shall pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation
the sum of forty five dollars ($45.00). Any person who violates any of the
parking ordinances of the city at a location where tow away placards have been
posted on parking control signs shall pay a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). In
the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice,
the operator of the vehicle shall pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction
of such violation the sum of seventy dollars ($70.00). Any person who receives
a ticket for parking at any curb within five feet (5') of a fire hydrant shall
pay a fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00). In the event the fine is not paid
within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle
shall pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum
of fifty five dollars ($55.00). This section shall not apply to provisions in
this article with different penalties from the above. All fines for parking
violations may be paid by credit card by calling the finance department for the
city of Rock Island, Illinois. An additional five dollar ($5.00) processing fee
will be charged for this service. (Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-27. Miscellaneous Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
ordinance prohibiting or regulating parking on specified public or private
property, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full
force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this code. (Ord.
92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-28. Liability Of Owner:
Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the
provisions of this article, the person in whose name such vehicle is
registered, as well as the operator of the vehicle and the vehicle itself,
shall be subject to the penalty for such violation. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Arts. X
and XII; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-29. Unattended Vehicles:
No vehicle shall be left unattended while the motor of such vehicle is running,
and no vehicle shall be left without a driver on any hill or incline unless the
vehicle is secured against moving. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. IV; Ord. 92-12, 1-
20-1992)
Sec. 9-30. Impoundment Of Vehicles Generally:
   (a)   An unattended vehicle stopped, standing or parked, or occupying any
portion of any street, in violation of any of the provisions of any of the
ordinances of the city, including, without limitation, traffic and parking
ordinances and nontraffic ordinances such as those prohibiting the obstruction
of a fire hydrant, or left parked overnight in any city parking lot is hereby
declared to be a nuisance, which may be abated by any agent or employee of the
city designated to enforce the parking ordinances of the city by impounding
such vehicle and by removing and conveying such vehicle or by causing such
vehicle to be removed and conveyed to a vehicle pound. A vehicle pound is
hereby declared to be any suitable place designated by the city as a vehicle
pound. The owner or operator of such vehicle may have the same removed from the
impoundment by paying the costs and expenses of the towage and impounding of
such vehicle, together with all fines and penalties, as provided in this
chapter.
   (b)   In all cases of violations herein referred to, the right to impound
shall be in addition to any other remedy provided in this chapter, or any other
remedy provided by law. Whenever any vehicle, while being used without the
consent of the owner, shall be stopped, standing, or parked in violation of any
of the provisions of this chapter, such owner shall not be subject to the
penalty for such violations. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. X; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992;
Ord. 93-11, 3-1-1993)
Sec. 9-31. Abandoned Vehicles:
(Rep. by Ord. 39-00, § 1, 6-26-2000)
Sec. 9-31a. Inoperable Motor Vehicles:
(Rep. by Ord. 39-00, § 1, 6-26-2000)
Sec. 9-32. No Parking Places:
At any time it shall be unlawful for any person to permit any vehicle to stand
in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with
other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a policeman or traffic
signal:
      (1)   In any intersection.
      (2)   In a crosswalk.
      (3)   Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or the approach
thereto.
      (4)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone.
      (5)   Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal or a through street
sign on the approaching side.
      (6)   Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection.
      (7)   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
      (8)   At any curb within five feet (5') of a fire hydrant.
      (9)   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
      (10)   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing.
      (11)   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
department station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any
such station within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance.
      (12)   On any sidewalk or parkway except as provided in section
9-33 of this division.
      (13)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
      (14)   At any bus stop.
      (15)   On any bicycle or pedestrian path.
      (16)   In a Rock Island city park in violation of posted parking
requirements. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. VI; Ord., 5-19-1975; Ord., 12-15-1975;
Ord., 1-9-1978; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 93-11, 3-1-1993; Ord. 030-2007, §
1, 4-23-2007)
Sec. 9-33. Parking On Public Property:
Parking of motor vehicles may be allowed on parkways, boulevards or other areas
of dedicated right of way not being used as part of the traveled way when
authorized by special ordinance. Such ordinance may place conditions,
restrictions and limitations on parking. (Ord., 1-9-1978; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-
1992)
Sec. 9-34. Cabstands; Bus Stands; Limited Parking At Bus Stops:
   (a)   Generally: No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in
any area designated by special ordinance as a cabstand, and no vehicle other
than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone
except as provided in subsection (b) of this section.
   (b)   Limited Parking At Bus Stops; Signs:
      (1)   The following bus stop parking locations located in the city may
hereinafter be used for open parking after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. each day.
         a.   Downtown, as being bounded by 15th Street on the west, 24th
Street on the east, 1st Avenue on the north and 5th Avenue on the south, and
including twenty one (21) bus stops.
         b.   At 1230 30th Street.
         c.   On 14th Avenue at 40th Street.
      (2)   If a bus parking location is to be available at certain times for
public parking, signs shall be added below the bus stop signs indicating the
times that the bus parking location is available for public parking and any
applicable parking time limitations. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. VI; Ord. 89-11,
3-20-1989; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-35. Parking At Curb:
No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to the curb
except on one-way streets where parking is permitted on both sides thereof, and
it shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park any vehicle in a street
other than parallel with the curb and with the right hand wheels of the vehicle
within twelve inches (12") of the regularly established curb; except that upon
those streets that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked
at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks with the front wheels at the
curb. Trucks may back to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading for
actual periods of time necessary for loading or unloading, but in no case shall
they interfere with the movement of traffic. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. VI; Ord.
92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-36. Vehicles For Sale:
(Rep. by Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-37. Loading Zones:
   (a)   During the times specified in this section, it shall be unlawful for
the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time
longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to
exceed three (3) minutes, and for the driver to stand any vehicle of the second
division, as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-217, being used for
carrying freight, goods, wares or merchandise for a period of time longer than
is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30)
minutes, in any of the following places:
      (1)   In any public alley during any hour of the day or night except that
the delivery vehicle shall not block access to and from the alley at any time.
      (2)   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to any hotel at any time.
      (3)   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to a public building, between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except on Sunday.
      (4)   Directly in front of the entrance to any theater for the purpose of
loading or unloading of passengers or for the purpose of purchasing theater
tickets for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes.
      (5)   At any other location in the city as is designated by special
ordinance. Such ordinance may designate the hours that the area shall be used
as a loading zone. At any other time, the area can be used generally for
parking.
   (b)   Any person operating a vehicle other than a second division vehicle to
pick up or deliver goods or merchandise may apply at the finance department for
a permit to display in the windshield stating that the vehicle is an authorized
delivery vehicle. Such permit will be granted when proof of such use is
presented to the finance department and upon payment of a ten dollar ($10.00)
fee per year.
   (c)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
fined fifteen dollars ($15.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven
(7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay as
the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of thirty
five dollars ($35.00). (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. VI; Ord., 8-30-1971; Ord., 1-
26-1976; Ord., 5-2-1977; Ord., 9-25-1978; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 100-2001,
§ 1, 12-17-2001; Ord. 20-2002, § 1, 3-18-2002; Ord. 08-2003, § 1, 2-10-2003;
Ord. 005-2010, § 2, 1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-38. Alleys:
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley except as provided in section 9-
37 of this chapter and shall then park only in such manner or under such
conditions as to leave available not less than ten feet (10') of the width of
the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic; and no person shall
stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the
driveway entrance to any abutting property. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. VI; Ord.
92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-39. Double Parking:
It shall be unlawful for any person to double park any vehicle in the city at
any time. Any person violating this provision shall be fined fifteen dollars
($15.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date
of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in
full satisfaction of such violation the sum of thirty five dollars ($35.00).
(Ord. 005-2010, § 3, 1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-40. Fire Lanes:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on any area designated
as a fire lane by special ordinance in the city. Any agent or employee of the
city designated to enforce the parking ordinances of the city is hereby
authorized to cause any motor vehicle parked in a fire lane in this city to be
towed from the fire lane. In such a case, the owner of the vehicle shall be
assessed the cost of towing and any storage charges in relation thereto plus a
fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00). In the event the fine is not paid within
seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay
the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of fifty
five dollars ($55.00). (Ord. 013-2011, 2-21-2011; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-41. Snow Removal 1 :
   (a)   In the event of two inches (2") or more of snow, it shall be unlawful
for any person to park or allow a motor vehicle to remain on any street or
avenue in the central business district between the hours of ten o'clock (10:
00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. The "central business district" shall be
defined as the area circumscribed by and including the following:
      1st Avenue, 14th Street to 21st Street
      5th Avenue, 14th Street to 21st Street
      14th Street, 1st Avenue to 5th Avenue
      21st Street, 1st Avenue to 5th Avenue
   (b)   In the event of two inches (2") or more of snow, it shall be unlawful
for any person to park or allow a motor vehicle to remain on any marked snow
route until the snow has been cleared.
   (c)   This section shall affect other parking restriction ordinances that
are presently in effect in the city, except bus stop and loading zone
ordinances.
   (d)   Whenever the city manager or mayor perceives an emergency to exist in
the city or in any section or sections thereof because of snow, freezing rain,
sleet, ice, snowdrifts or other natural phenomena which create hazardous
conditions or impede the free movement of fire, police, health, emergency or
other vehicular traffic or otherwise endanger the safety and welfare of the
public, the city manager or mayor may declare an emergency to exist. Notice of
the existence of an emergency and the terms and termination thereof shall be
given to the print, radio and television media, which shall be requested to
cooperate with the city in the dissemination of such information to the public.
When given, such notice shall constitute due and proper notice of the emergency
and the terms and conditions thereof.
   (e)   Any agent or employee of the city designated to enforce the parking
ordinances of the city is hereby authorized to cause any motor vehicle in
violation of this section to be towed from any snow route. In such a case the
owner of the vehicle may be assessed the cost of towing and any storage charges
in relation thereto plus a fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00). In the event
the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the
operator of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction
of such violation the sum of fifty five dollars ($55.00). (Ord., 12-17-1979;
Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 20-2002, § 1, 3-18-2002; Ord. 08-2003, § 1, 2-10-
2003; Ord. 005-2010, § 5, 1-18-2010; Ord. 013-2011, 2-21-2011; Ord. 058-2015,
12-14-2015)

Sec. 9-42. Parking On Private Property 2 :
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall park a motor vehicle on private
property controlled by a private parking ordinance passed by the city council
without the consent of the property owner. The owner of said property shall pay
an annual fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to the city of Rock Island
and shall post a sign or signs on said premises indicating that:
      (1)   Parking is prohibited without the consent of the property owner;
      (2)   Parking a motor vehicle without the consent of the property owner
is a violation of city ordinance;
      (3)   The owner of any vehicle violating the provisions of this section
shall be subject to a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00); and
      (4)   Any vehicle violating the provisions of this section may be
impounded and the owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for all costs of
the towing and impoundment.
The size, design, number and location of these signs shall be approved by the
Rock Island public works department.
   (b)   The owner of any vehicle violating the provisions of this section
shall be subject to a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00). In the event that
the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the owner
of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such
violation the sum of forty five dollars ($45.00).
Any vehicle violating the provisions of this section may be impounded as
described in section 9-30 of this chapter. (Ord., 2-19-1979; Ord. 87-54, 4-6-
1987; Ord. 91-13, 2-11-1991; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 92-112, 8-24-1992;
Ord. 36-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 20-2002, § 1, 3-18-2002; Ord. 08-2003, § 1, 2-
10-2003; Ord. 005-2010, § 6, 1-18-2010; Ord. 006-2011, 2-7-2011; Ord. 058-2015,
12-14-2015)

Sec. 9-43. Parking Large Trucks In Residential Zones:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to:
      (1)   Park any truck, except public service vehicles, with an allowable
gross vehicle weight of ten thousand (10,000) pounds or more, abutting or
adjacent to any lot zoned under residential classifications as set forth in the
zoning ordinance of the city, except for the purpose of making a delivery, and
then only for such length of time as it takes to complete delivery.
      (2)   Park a garbage or refuse truck on any public or private property in
the city unless the property is zoned I-1 or I-2, as defined in the zoning
ordinance of the city.
   (b)   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject
to a fine of twenty dollars ($20.00). In the event the fine is not paid within
seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay
as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of forty
dollars ($40.00).
   (c)   For each day that any such truck remains parked in such an area, it
shall be considered a separate violation under the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 82-79, 3-14-1983; Ord. 83-13, 5-23-1983; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 96-
40, 6-10-1996; Ord. 20-2002, § 1, 3-18-2002; Ord. 005-2010, § 7, 1-18-2010;
Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-44. Parking Enforcement Attendants; Positions Created:
There is hereby created the position of parking enforcement attendant. A
sufficient number of attendants shall be employed. These attendants may be
employed by the city or may be third party contract employees. These attendants
shall issue parking tickets against any person or persons violating any of the
rules, regulations or ordinances pertaining to parking as set forth in this
article. Such parking tickets shall be placed upon the windshield of any motor
vehicle found parked in violation of such regulations and ordinances. The
attendants shall not be members of the police department, nor shall they have
the power to make arrests or direct or regulate traffic; but their
authorization and duties shall be limited strictly to those set forth in this
section. (Ord. 052-2014, 7-14-2014)
Sec. 9-45. Impoundment For Unpaid Violations:
   (a)   Whenever it is determined that any vehicle has accumulated five (5) or
more parking tickets or fifty dollars ($50.00) or more worth of accumulated
parking violations as defined in the provisions of this code, the public works
director shall serve notice of such condition to the registered owner of the
vehicle. Service may be made by certified or registered mail or by personal
service. The notice shall state the date and nature of each ticket and the
amount presently due and shall inform the vehicle owner of the following
procedures:
      (1)   The vehicle owner may obtain a review of the tickets by giving
written notice to the public works director within fifteen (15) days of the
date of receipt of the notice of unpaid tickets, requesting a conference with
the public works director.
      (2)   If within fifteen (15) days of the date of the receipt of the
notice of unpaid tickets, the vehicle owner has not either given written notice
requesting a conference or paid the full amount of the unpaid tickets, it shall
be deemed that he has waived the right to a conference, and the full unpaid
amount of the tickets shall be due immediately.
      (3)   If the vehicle owner fails to either give written notice requesting
a conference or to pay the full amount of the unpaid tickets within the
prescribed time period, such vehicle shall be subject to impoundment.
   (b)   The public works director shall schedule a conference to be held not
less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days after receiving written
notice from the vehicle owner requesting the conference. After a review of the
tickets at the conference, the public works director shall determine the amount
due up to the full amount of the unpaid tickets and shall inform the vehicle
owner of the decision. Unless other arrangements for the payment are made by
the public works director and approved by the finance director, the amount
shall be paid within fifteen (15) days. If, after reaching an agreement
concerning payment of the tickets, the vehicle owner fails to make any payment
when due, the vehicle of such owner shall thereupon be subject to impoundment
until all payments then due are made. The public works director and the finance
director shall have full authority to make binding agreements concerning
payments due, if any, and may agree to payments and other terms which they deem
to be in the best interests of the city.
   (c)   When any vehicle owner within fifteen (15) days of the date of receipt
of the notice of unpaid tickets required by subsection (a) of this section has
not either paid the full amount of the unpaid tickets or given written notice
to the public works director requesting a conference, or when any vehicle owner
after an agreement with the public works director as described in subsection
(b) of this section fails to make any payment when due and such payment has not
yet been made, the vehicle of such owner thereafter found parked and unattended
on a public right of way in the city, within the municipal parking ramp or
within a city parking lot, by any agent or employee of the city designated to
enforce the parking ordinances of the city, may be impounded.
   (d)   Impoundment shall constitute either impoundment by immobilization or
by towing.
      (1)   Impoundment by immobilization shall be accomplished by the
attachment of a mechanical device such as a denver boot consisting of clamps or
jaws and a locking device which, when attached to the wheel of a vehicle,
prevents the vehicle from being driven. If a vehicle that has been impounded by
immobilization has not been reclaimed within twenty four (24) hours, the
immobilization device may be released and the vehicle may be impounded by
towing.
      (2)   Impoundment by towing shall be accomplished by removing and
conveying such vehicle or by causing such vehicle to be removed and conveyed to
a vehicle pound. A vehicle pound is hereby declared to be any suitable place
designated by the city as a vehicle pound.
   (e)   Any vehicle impounded pursuant to the provisions herein may be
reclaimed by the registered owner or operator by appearing at the police
department. At such time, the owner or the operator shall sign a certificate
that he/she is the owner or operator of the impounded vehicle, pay all charges
and costs incurred in impounding the vehicle, and pay all outstanding parking
fines and late payment penalties. In lieu of paying these charges, costs,
fines, and penalties, the owner or operator may execute a binding payment
agreement. The agreement shall be a standard prepared in advance by the public
works director with the approval of the finance director, and it shall contain
a payment schedule and the penalties for failure to fulfill the conditions of
the agreement.
   (f)   The public works director and finance director may designate others to
exercise powers and perform functions provided in this section.
   (g)   The fine for impoundment by immobilization shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and the fine for impoundment by towing shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 92-112, 8-24-1992; Ord. 08-
2003, § 1, 2-10-2003)
Sec. 9-46. Suspension Of Driver's License:
   (a)   Notice Of Intent To Impound: Once the registered owner of a vehicle
has been delivered the notice of intent to impound a vehicle for unpaid parking
violations through certified mail, registered mail, or personal service and
allows the fifteen (15) day time period to expire without seeking further
review or breaks an agreement concerning the payment of tickets, the public
works director may initiate driver's license suspension with the Illinois
secretary of state and/or file a petition in the circuit court to have the
unpaid fines and penalties rendered as a judgment in favor of the city.
   (b)   Notice Of Impending Suspension: A notice of impending driver's license
suspension shall be sent to the owner for any fine or penalty that remains due
and owing on ten (10) or more parking violations. This notice shall be sent by
first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary
of state. Failure to pay the fine or penalty owing within forty five (45) days
of the notice's date will result in the public works director notifying the
secretary of state that this person is eligible for initiation of suspension
proceedings.
   (c)   Report Of Public Works Director: The report of the public works
director notifying the secretary of state of unpaid fines or penalties shall be
certified and shall contain the following information:
      (1)   The name, last known address and driver's license of the person who
failed to pay the fine or penalty and the registration number of any vehicle
known to be registered to such people in this state;
      (2)   The name of the municipality making the report;
      (3)   A statement that the municipality sent a notice of impending
driver's license suspension to the person named in the report at the address
recorded with the secretary of state; the date which the notice was sent; and
the address to which the notice was sent.
   (d)   Suspension Challenge: The vehicle owner may challenge the notice of
impending driver's license suspension within forty five (45) days of the date
of the notice. Challenges will be strictly limited to:
      (1)   The person not having been the owner or the lessee of the vehicle.
      (2)   The person having already paid the fine or penalty for the ten (10)
or more violations indicated on the certified report.
   (e)   Obtain Judgment: The public works director may commence a proceeding
in the circuit court for the purpose of obtaining a judgment after the fifteen
(15) day time period during which an administrative review may be sought. This
shall not prevent the city from consolidating multiple license plates or
parking violations against a person in such proceeding. (Ord. 95-27, 4-10-1995)
Sec. 9-47. Increased Fine For Unauthorized Use Of A Parking Place Reserved For
Handicapped Persons:
Any person making an unauthorized use of a parking place reserved for
handicapped persons in violation of the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1303.3 shall be fined the sum of three hundred fifty dollars
($350.00). (Ord. 013-2011, 2-21-2011)
Sec. 9-48. Parking Unattended Trailers On Public Right Of Way Prohibited:
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a trailer that is detached
from its towing vehicle within any alley, highway, street, right of way, or
public property located within the city.
   (b)   Every trailer parked in violation of this section is hereby declared
to be a nuisance which may be abated by any police officer or parking
enforcement attendant by removing and impounding such vehicle as described in
section 9-30 of this chapter.
   (c)   A trailer is excepted from this prohibition when it is actively
engaged in deliveries, lawn maintenance, construction or other trade activity
upon property immediately abutting the parked trailer. However, at all times,
the roadway shall be free for the passage of other vehicles, traffic control
signs and signals shall not be obstructed and sightlines for intersections
shall not be obstructed.
   (d)   The owner of any vehicle violating the provisions of this section
shall be subject to a fine of twenty dollars ($20.00). In the event that the
fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the owner of
the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such
violation the sum of forty dollars ($40.00). (Ord. 35-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord.
31-2002, § 1, 4-8-2002; Ord. 005-2010, § 8, 1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-
2015)
Secs. 9-49 - 9-80. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. ZONE PARKING
Sec. 9-81. Definitions:
For the purpose of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   Operator: Every person who shall operate, drive or be in control of any
vehicle upon any street.
   Park: The standing of any vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon any street
for a period of time greater than is reasonably necessary for the loading or
unloading of persons or materials.
   Parking Lot: That area of city owned property located off street and
designated for the parking of motor vehicles.
   Permit: That authorization issued by the city to operators of vehicles
complying with the provisions of this division.
   Street: Any public street, avenue, road, boulevard, highway or other public
place located in the city and established for the use of vehicles.
   Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported upon a street. A bicycle or motor bicycle shall be termed a
vehicle.
   Zone: Any area designated and marked for parking of a particular and
specific duration. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-82. Zones Generally:
The city council shall establish parking zones upon such streets of the city as
it shall select. The council may add to, change or abandon such parking zones.
In selecting, changing or abandoning such parking zones, the council shall be
guided and governed by location, amount of traffic, demand for parking spaces,
congestion of traffic, use of the street, and other traffic conditions. (Ord.
86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-83. Parking Zones Established:
Thirty (30) minute, one hour, two (2) hour and four (4) hour parking zones
shall hereby be established and identified by the placement of appropriate
parking control signs within the zones. The establishment of such zones in no
way supersedes the existence of any previously established no parking zones,
loading zones, bus lanes or otherwise restricted parking zones. (Ord. 058-2015,
12-14-2015; Ord. 023-2016, 5-9-2016)
Sec. 9-84. Marking Spaces:
The city council shall have lines or markings painted or placed upon the curb
or street for the purpose of designating each parking space, and each vehicle
parked at any parking space shall park within the lines or markings so
established. It shall be a violation of this division for any person to park
any vehicle in such a position that the same will not be within the area so
designated by such lines or markings. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12,
§ 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-85. Location Of Vehicle:
When a parking space in any parking zone is parallel with the adjacent curb or
sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked with the
foremost part of such vehicle alongside of and as near as is practicable to the
front of the parking space. When a parking space in any parked zone is diagonal
to the curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be
parked at and as near as possible to the curb. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986;
Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-86. Parking Time Limit - Generally:
Upon entering any posted zone parking space, a vehicle may occupy such space
for a period of time not to exceed the posted time limit for the zone. (Ord.
86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-87. Parking Time Limit - Enforcement:
   (a)   All parking zones shall be enforced during the times posted in the
zone. The parking zones shall not be enforced on New Year's Day, Memorial Day,
Fourth Of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve Day
and Christmas Day.
   (b)   During these times, enforcement personnel will patrol designated
streets. Vehicles which have occupied any given parking space in excess of the
posted parking limitation shall be considered as parking overtime and beyond
the period of legal parking and shall be in violation of this division. (Ord.
86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992; Ord. 92-112, § 4, 8-24-
1992)
Sec. 9-88. Overtime Parking, Penalties:
The city council shall hereby adopt the following progressive fine structure
for overtime parking violations:
      (1)   See section 10-107.11, "Schedule Of Penalties For Ordinance
Violations", of this code. (Ord. 013-2011, 2-21-2011; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-
2015)
Sec. 9-89. Moving Of Vehicles Prohibited:
It shall be unlawful for any person to move any vehicle from any designated
zone parking space to any other such space for the purpose of extending the
legal parking limit beyond the posted time limit. Upon observance of or
detection of such offense in accordance with section 9-87 of this chapter, the
operator of the vehicle shall be issued a notice of violation and shall pay a
fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00). In the event the fine is not paid within
seven (7) days of the date of notice, the operator shall pay as the penalty for
and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of forty five dollars
($45.00). (Ord. 005-2010, § 10, 1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-89.1. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. PERMIT AND FEE PARKING
Sec. 9-90. Definitions:
For the purpose of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   Operator: Every person who shall operate, drive or be in control of any
vehicle upon any street.
   Park: The standing of any vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon any street
for a period of time greater than is reasonably necessary for the loading or
unloading of persons or materials.
   Parking Lot: That area of city owned property located off street and
designated for the parking of motor vehicles.
   Permit: That authorization issued by the city to operators of vehicles
complying with the provisions of this division.
   Street: Any public street, avenue, road, boulevard, highway or other public
place located in the city and established for the use of vehicles.
   Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported upon a street. A bicycle or motor bicycle shall be termed a
vehicle.
   Zone: Any area designated and marked for parking of a particular and
specific duration. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-91. Designation Of City Parking Facilities:
The city council shall establish the following locations as parking facilities:
      (1)   Lot A, located south of 2nd Avenue between 16th Street and 16 1/
2 Street.
      (2)   Lot C, located at the southwest corner of the intersection of 1st
Avenue and 20th Street.
      (3)   Lot E, located at the northwest corner of the intersection of 18th
Street with 7th Avenue.
      (4)   Lot F, located at the northeast corner of the intersection of 18th
Street with the Great River Plaza.
      (5)   Lot G, located along the alley connecting 17th and 18th Streets
south of 1st Avenue.
      (6)   Municipal parking ramp, located between 16th and 17th Streets and
3rd and 4th Avenues. (Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-92. Permit System Established:
   (a)   The city council shall hereby establish a parking permit system by
which specific permits authorize parking in specific designated locations. A
permit shall be obtained from the finance department upon payment of the
appropriate fee. Permits shall be displayed on the front left side of the
vehicle's dashboard or displayed in a vinyl case and affixed to the lower left
corner of the rear window of the vehicle. The permit system shall be
established as follows:
      (1)   Construction permit authorizes the permit holder to park a
construction vehicle in any city owned parking lot, ramp, or on street parking
space for any length of time.
      (2)   Daily/visitor permit authorizes the permit holder to park in any
city owned parking lot, ramp, or on street parking space for one day only.
      (3)   Rover permit authorizes the permit holder to park in any city owned
parking lot, ramp or on street parking space for any length of time.
   (b)   Parking permits have the following exceptions:
      (1)   Permit holders may not park in any space designated for handicapped
parking unless displaying the proper identifying tags or license plates.
      (2)   Permit holders may not park in any marked loading zone, no parking
zone, bus lane or other restricted parking area. (Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-93. Permit Fees:
The city council does hereby establish the following fee schedule for parking
in the municipal parking facilities:
 
(1) Construction parking permits  $20.00 per month
(2) Daily/visitor parking permits 5.00   per day
(3) Rover parking permits         80.00  per month
 
(Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
