DIVISION 4. RESIDENTIAL PARKING LIMITATIONS
Sec. 9-97. Designation Of Residential Parking Only Areas:
The city council may, after the presentation of a petition supporting a
residential parking only area signed by residents representing two-thirds (2/3)
of the dwelling units in the proposed area, designate those streets where
residential parking only shall be in effect at all times or during specified
hours. The traffic engineering committee shall notify all property owners
within the proposed area of the petition, committee recommendation, and pending
city council action. Residential parking only ordinance shall not be used to
restrict parking in that part of the city that is contained within the area
described in this ordinance.
Sec. 9-97.1. Minimum Size For Residential Permit Parking Area:
The minimum size for residential permit parking areas shall be the lesser of
ten (10) contiguous parcels of property or lots or one complete block unless
otherwise approved by the city council. (Ord. 92-78, 4-27-1992)
Sec. 9-98. Residential Parking Permit:
The city council may designate residential parking areas as either type A area
or a type B area.
      (1)   Type A Area: The resident or residents of a dwelling unit which
abuts or is adjacent to a designated residential parking only area may obtain
from the finance department of the city, by payment of a five dollar ($5.00)
fee, a parking permit for each owned, leased, rented or assigned vehicle. This
permit will allow parking adjacent to applicant's residence only without
restriction. These permits shall not be transferable to other vehicles. Each
resident issued a parking permit will also receive without additional fee two
(2) visitor parking permits which may be displayed only upon vehicles not
registered to residents of the dwelling and may be transferred between
vehicles. Visitor parking permits may be displayed only on vehicles used by
persons not at the home of the resident to whom the permit was issued, and
parking is limited to that area which abuts or is adjacent to the resident's
property only. In the event that a resident does not own any vehicles, two (2)
visitor permits may be obtained by payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee.
      (2)   Type B Area: The resident or residents of a dwelling unit which
abuts or is adjacent to a designated residential parking only area may obtain
from the finance department of the city, by payment of a five dollar ($5.00)
fee, a parking permit for each owned, leased, rented or assigned vehicle. This
permit will allow parking without time restriction in any otherwise legal
parking space within the designated area. These permits shall not be
transferable to other vehicles. Each resident issued a parking permit will also
receive without additional fee two (2) visitor parking permits which may be
displayed only upon vehicles not registered to residents of the dwelling and
may be transferred between vehicles. Visitor parking permits may be displayed
only on vehicles used by persons not at the home of the resident to whom the
permit was issued. In the event that a resident does not own any vehicles, two
(2) visitor permits may be obtained by payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee.
(Ord. 87-53, 5-18-1987; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 95-61, 8-28-1995)
Sec. 9-99. Permit Issued Annually:
Residential parking permits must be renewed annually by payment of a five
dollar ($5.00) fee and are applicable only to the designated street. (Ord. 87-
53, 5-18-1987; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-100. Penalty For Unauthorized Use:
The penalty for unauthorized use of a permit shall be a fine of not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 87-53, 5-18-1987; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
ARTICLE III. PEDESTRIANS 1
 
Notes
1 625 ILCS 5/11-208 and 5/11-1001 et seq.
Sec. 9-101. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
ordinance establishing pedestrian crossings, and all such ordinances are hereby
recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set
out at length in this code. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. XI)
Sec. 9-102. Adult Crossing Guards:
There are hereby created the positions of adult crossing guards, who shall
operate the traffic control at designated school crossings in the city. They
shall be supervised by a city employee or official designated by the city
manager to act in this capacity in addition to his present duties. These
persons shall be responsible for maintaining the traffic control at designated
crossings. They shall be responsible for the enforcement of the proper use of
school crossings, and this function shall be separate and distinct from the
police department. The persons working pursuant to this section, whether they
receive compensation or not, are not members of the police department but shall
work under the direction of the police department. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. XI)
Sec. 9-103. Standing On Sidewalk:
It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near
as reasonably possible to the building line or curb line, if such standing
interferes with the use of said sidewalk by other pedestrians. (1963 Code, ch.
XI, art. V)
Secs. 9-104-9-110. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. PARADES, RUNS, ETC., PERMIT
Sec. 9-111. Permit Required:
No person shall use the public streets in the city for runs, marches, parades
and air activities without having first obtained a permit from the city clerk.
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine
of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). (Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983)
Sec. 9-112. Application:
Any organization or individual desiring to sponsor an activity shall file an
application for a permit with the office of the city clerk on a form provided
by the clerk. (Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983)
Sec. 9-113. Notice Requirement:
   (a)   Any application for a permit shall be filed with the city clerk at
least sixty (60) days prior to the scheduled event. This sixty (60) day period
or any portion thereof may be waived by the city council.
   (b)   In the case of applications for new events and/or new routes, the
sponsor of said new event shall notify the residents and/or businesses located
along said race route, parade route, or other, for that specific activity, in
writing, at least three (3) weeks prior to city council consideration. Prior to
council consideration, sponsor shall notify and obtain written approval or
disapproval from the residents and/or businesses and submit a copy of same to
the city clerk. Any resident and/or business who objects to said event shall
have the opportunity to be heard at the city council meeting during which time
the event is to be considered. (Ord. 095-2014, 12-15-2014)
Sec. 9-114. Liability Insurance:
No permit shall be issued until the sponsor of the scheduled event files with
the city clerk evidence of liability insurance coverage for the event in an
amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one
person or five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for any one accident,
with the city being listed as an additional insured, claims or damages which
may arise out of the event. (Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983)
Sec. 9-115. Review By Police; Issuance:
At such time as an application is filed, it shall be forwarded to the traffic
unit supervisor of the police department for review and estimation of service
costs excluding a public works service and police vehicles used but including
charges for auxiliary police and off duty police officers' time. In addition,
the traffic unit supervisor may contact the event sponsor regarding any
suggested changes in routing or any other suggested changes. After the review
as aforesaid, the application shall be returned to the city clerk, who shall
then contact the event sponsor regarding the estimated cost. If the cost figure
is acceptable to the sponsor, and the sponsor agrees to pay same, the
application and cost estimate shall be forwarded to the city manager for final
review and placement on the council agenda. If the city council approves the
event, the city clerk shall issue a permit allowing the event to take place.
After the event has taken place, the sponsor shall be billed for the actual
police and public works services rendered. (Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983; Ord. 96-50,
7-22-1996)
Sec. 9-116. Reimbursement Of Excess Costs:
(Rep. by Ord. 96-50, 7-22-1996)
ARTICLE V. NEIGHBORHOOD NUISANCE VEHICLES
Sec. 9-117. Purpose:
The city of Rock Island is committed to maintaining the attractiveness,
aesthetics, and safety of all residential neighborhoods and promoting the
health and safety of its citizens. Pursuant to its home rule authority, the
city hereby declares vehicles stored, parked, housed, and repaired as defined
herein which are in violation of this article, to be public nuisances and the
city will abate these nuisances by towing or having the owner of the vehicle or
property abate the nuisance. Pursuant to that authority, the city council finds
that such regulations, restraint or prohibition is necessary and desirable to
promote or enhance the public good. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-118. Regulated:
Except as permitted by the zoning ordinances, no person shall park, store,
leave or permit the parking, storage or leaving of any vehicle of any kind
which is an abandoned vehicle on private property, abandoned vehicle on city
property, hazardous vehicle, vehicle having evidentiary value, inoperable motor
vehicle, or unregistered vehicle, whether upon public or private property
within the city except as authorized herein. The presence of such vehicle in
violation of the provisions hereof is hereby declared a public nuisance which
may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this article.
This section shall not apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on
private property or to any vehicle stored on the premises of a business
enterprise actively operated on the subject premises and being properly
operated in the appropriate business zone pursuant to the zoning ordinance of
the city and engaged in such business enterprise as would properly be
associated with the storage of such vehicles. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord.
39-00, § 3, 6-26-2000; Ord. 78-2000, § 1, 10-9-2000)
Sec. 9-119. Definitions:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this article:
   Abandoned Vehicle On City Property: One that is left on property owned or
operated by the city (except for a city street or alley) for longer than two
(2) hours or in a city owned parking lot for longer than twelve (12) hours,
without permission of the city.
   Abandoned Vehicle On Private Property: A vehicle parked or otherwise located
on private property that has not been moved for a period of seven (7) days.
   Abandoned Vehicle On Street Or Alley: An abandoned vehicle is one that is
abandoned on any highway, street or alley or other public right of way.
Continuous standing of a vehicle on a highway, street or alley or any public
right of way for over a seventy two (72) hour period shall be prima facie
evidence of abandonment of such vehicle.
   Administrative Hearing Officer: Defined and created pursuant to section
10-107 et seq., of this code.
   Hazardous Vehicle: Any motor vehicle on private or public property that is
declared to be a health or safety hazard by a duly authorized police officer,
community service officer, or city inspector, when the vehicle is found to be:
      (1)   A breeding ground or harbor for mosquitoes or other insects,
snakes, rats, or other pests; or
      (2)   A point of weed growth and/or other vegetation over ten inches
(10") in height; or
      (3)   A point of collection for pools or ponds of water; or
      (4)   A point of concentration of gasoline, oil or other flammable or
explosive materials; or
      (5)   So situated that there is a danger of the vehicle falling or
turning over; or
      (6)   A place in which debris, bottles or other solid waste is discarded
and is present within the vehicle or immediately next to or around the vehicle;
or
      (7)   A source of danger for children through entrapment in areas of
confinement that cannot be opened from the inside or from exposed surfaces of
metal, glass or other rigid materials.
   Inoperable Motor Vehicle: A vehicle from which the engine, wheels or other
essential parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other
parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is
incapable of being driven under its own power for a period of at least seven
(7) days. Inoperable motor vehicle shall not include: 1) a motor vehicle which
has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own power in
order to perform ordinary service or repair operations, 2) any motor vehicle
that is kept concealed within a building when not in use, or 3) a motor vehicle
on the premises of a place of business engaged in repairing, wrecking or
junking of motor vehicles where properly zoned.
   Owner: An individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
governmental agency or any combination thereof, as evidenced by the title to
the vehicle. If no title to the vehicle is available, then the last record
owner as contained in the records of the secretary of state of the state in
which the vehicle was last titled shall be rebuttably presumed to be the
current owner.
   Seized Vehicle: Any vehicle which is seized as a result of an arrest,
pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 et seq., recovery of a stolen
vehicle, or any other lawful seizure.
   Unregistered Vehicle: One that:
      (1)   Does not have an attached current registration (license plate)
valid in any state; or
      (2)   Does not have displayed a current temporary registration valid in
any state; or
      (3)   Has a registration (license plate) which is expired pursuant to the
laws of the issuing state.
   Vehicle: A machine propelled by power, other than human power, designed to
travel by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and to transport persons or
property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobile,
truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, RV, SUV, snowmobile, personal
watercraft, conversion van, boat, camper, mobile home, pop-up camper, pickup
truck, and wagon.
   Vehicle Having Evidentiary Value: Any vehicle which is seized so it can be
searched for evidence of a crime (hit-and-run, blood, fingerprints, etc.).
(Ord. 34-00 § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 39-00, § 2, 6-26-2000)
Sec. 9-120. Authority To Abate The Nuisance By Towing:
The chief of police or his designee is hereby authorized to immediately tow
away, or cause to be towed away, any vehicle on any public street, public
place, or private property at any time:
      (1)   When the motor vehicle is a hazardous vehicle, or "abandoned
vehicle on city property", as defined herein;
      (2)   When the motor vehicle is an evidentiary vehicle;
      (3)   When the motor vehicle is a seized vehicle;
      (4)   When the vehicle is on private residential property and is parked
there without consent of the property owner, proprietor or agent of the
property, provided:
         a.   That signs approved by the city posted on the property give
notice that parking is prohibited, and
         b.   That the person requesting the tow signs a statement that he is
the owner, proprietor, or agent of the property with the authority to request
the tow. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-121. Pretow Notice Of Removal:
In all other instances of a violation of this article, the chief of police or
his designee is hereby authorized to tow away, or cause to be towed away, any
vehicle on any public street, public place, or private property at any time but
shall first give notice of removal to the registered owner of the vehicle, if
the owner can be ascertained and if the vehicle is located on private property,
to the owner or occupant of the private property where the vehicle is located
at least seven (7) days before the vehicle is removed.
      (1)   It shall constitute sufficient notice when a copy of the notice
outlined in the pretow notice of removal is posted upon the vehicle itself and
on a conspicuous place upon the private property on which the vehicle is
located; and
      (2)   A duplicate copy of the pretow notice of removal is sent by
registered mail to the registered owner of said vehicle if one can be
determined based on the information on the vehicle such as the registration
(license plate) or VIN number; and
      (3)   A duplicate copy of the pretow notice of removal is sent by
certified mail to the lien holder if one can be determined based on the
information on the vehicle such as the registration (license plate) or VIN
number.
The notice of removal shall identify the vehicle, the statutory grounds for
removal, the right of the vehicle owner to request a pretow hearing before the
administrative hearing officer to contest the grounds for removal prior to the
removal date, and the method of making such a request.
In the event that the vehicle owner requests a pretow hearing, the removal
shall be delayed until the next scheduled hearing date of the administrative
hearing officer, at which time the administrative hearing officer shall conduct
a hearing as hereinafter provided to determine whether grounds exist for
removal. If the administrative hearing officer finds that grounds exist for
removal, the vehicle may be immediately removed. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-122. Notice Of Hearing:
Whenever a vehicle is towed without pretow notice of removal, the police
department shall provide to the owner of record of the vehicle the notice
described in this section no later than twenty four (24) hours after the time
of the tow and any lien holder of record within seventy two (72) hours, except
that when a motor vehicle is towed after three o'clock (3:00) P.M. on a Friday,
Saturday, Sunday or holiday or the day before a holiday, the notice described
herein shall be provided no longer than the second working day after the tow.
Whenever a vehicle is towed after a pretow notice of removal has been given,
the notice described in this section shall be provided to the owner and any
lien holder of record within four (4) working days of the tow.
      (1)   Notice: The notice shall include:
         a.   Description of the motor vehicle including year, make, model,
registration (license plate number), expiration date, and vehicle
identification number (VIN);
         b.   The present location of the motor vehicle;
         c.   The basis for the removal of the vehicle;
         d.   The right of the owner to a hearing;
         e.   The consequences of the failure to request a hearing;
         f.   The consequences of the failure to reclaim a motor vehicle;
         g.   A deadline of seven (7) days from the date of notice, by which
the owner must respond.
      (2)   Delivery Of Notice: The notice required in subsection (1) of this
section shall, at the discretion of the police department, be given by
certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal delivery. The date of
personal delivery or the date of mailing of the certified letter shall be the
date of providing notice.
      (3)   Posting Of Notice: A notice containing the requirements set forth
for the notice, described in subsections (1)d through (1)g of this section,
shall be posted at the Rock Island police department and at all tow/impound
areas.
      (4)   Notices On Failure To Act:
         a.   Consequences Of Failure To Request A Hearing: If the registered
or legal owner, lien holder, or person who is otherwise entitled to possession
of a motor vehicle does not request a hearing within seven (7) days of the
delivery or mailing of notice, the right to such hearing shall be forfeited. A
registered or legal owner, lien holder, or person who is otherwise entitled to
possession of a motor vehicle must pay the total cost of the tow and any
storage incurred.
         b.   Consequences Of Failure To Reclaim A Motor Vehicle: If the
registered or legal owner, lien holder, or person who is otherwise entitled to
possession of a motor vehicle does not claim and take possession of said motor
vehicle within fifteen (15) days after the tow hearing, the motor vehicle shall
be considered abandoned and shall be disposed of pursuant to state statute.
(Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-123. Post-Tow Hearing:
A hearing shall be held after a vehicle is towed pursuant to this article, if
the owner requests a post-tow hearing to determine the validity of such tow and
any tow or storage charges.
      (1)   The administrative hearing officer shall conduct the post-tow
hearing. The hearing officer shall have the authority to require the presence
of the enforcement officer issuing the citation or any other city personnel or
witnesses at such hearing. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable
opportunity to be heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not
apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The hearing
shall be open to the public and a court reporter shall transcribe the
proceedings.
      (2)   Hearings shall take place as follows:
         a.   In those instances where the vehicle has been released upon the
deposit of a cash bond in an amount equal to the tow and storage charge, the
hearing shall take place within forty five (45) days from the date of request
following the tow after the posting of cash bond.
         b.   In those instances where the vehicle remains impounded, the
hearing shall take place within twenty one (21) days from the date of request
immediately following the tow.
      (3)   The city must establish said authority by the preponderance of the
evidence and shall establish a prima facie case upon the showing of the
documents related to the tow.
      (4)   If the city's administrative hearing officer determines that there
is no such probable cause, the vehicle will be returned without penalty or
other fees.
      (5)   In the event the defendant wishes to appeal the decision of the
city's administrative hearing officer under the provisions of the
Administrative Review Act, said defendant shall pay the cost of the preparation
and transcription of the record of the hearing and shall appeal to the circuit
court.
      (6)   The penalty and fees shall be a debt due and owed to the city.
However, if a cash bond has been posted the bond shall be applied to the fine.
If the city's administrative hearing officer determines that the vehicle was
not in violation of this article the administrative hearing officer shall order
the return of the vehicle or cash bond. In the event it shall become necessary
for the city to collect the debt by filing an action in the circuit court, it
shall be entitled to recover, in addition to the amount due, court costs and
reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-124. Bonding Procedures:
Whenever the owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle towed pursuant
to sections
9-120 and
9-121 of this article wishes to retrieve their vehicle prior to the post-tow
hearing, they may do so by posting a cash bond at police headquarters in an
amount twice the fees charged for towing and storage pursuant to the contract
for towing services with the city in effect at the time of the tow for a period
of thirty (30) days from the date of the tow. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-125. Responsibility For Costs Not Recovered:
Any costs incurred by the city for removal, impoundment or destruction of
vehicles under this article not otherwise recovered, shall be paid by the
registered owner, person legally entitled to possession, or lien holder of the
vehicle unless the administrative hearing officer determines that no violation
has occurred. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-126. Parking, Storing, Housing Of Vehicles:
It shall be a violation of this article for a property owner or renter to park,
store, or house upon their property vehicles that are: inoperable,
unregistered, abandoned vehicle on private property, or hazardous, as defined
herein, except a property owner or renter may park, store, or house upon their
property no more than one unregistered vehicle that does not fit into any of
the other categories defined herein unless the vehicle is enclosed in a
building and not visible by the public. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-127. Detrimental Health Nuisances Associated With Vehicle Repair In
Residentially Zoned Neighborhoods:
Whenever the pursuit of any vehicle repairs or the maintenance of any vehicle
results in the spilling of solvents, oil, gasoline, or other hazardous
substances on the ground (public or private property), or the condition of
things at a specific location where vehicle repairs are being conducted result
in a condition detrimental to the health of any person, the same shall be
deemed a health nuisance and shall be abated. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-128. Enforcement:
A police officer, community service officer, or inspector, shall have the
authority to: 1) issue a parking ticket to the owner of a vehicle described
herein for violations of this article when the vehicle is parked on public or
city property, or 2) issue a city ordinance citation to the owner of a vehicle
described herein or to the property owner where the vehicle is located for
violations of this article when the vehicle is parked on private property.
However, the processing of all tows shall be handled through the abandoned
vehicle division of the Rock Island police department. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-
2000; Ord. 068-2006, § 1, 9-11-2006)
Sec. 9-129. Penalty And Fines:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of
an offense and shall be subject to a fine. Each act in violation of any of the
provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense.
A violation of abandoned vehicle on city property, abandoned vehicle on street
or alley, or hazardous vehicle when the vehicle is on public property shall be
charged by the issuance of a parking ticket, as with other parking violations.
The fine for violation of these articles shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
A violation of abandoned vehicle on private property or hazardous vehicle when
the vehicle is on private property shall be charged by the issuance of a city
ordinance citation, as with other motor vehicle violations. The first violation
of this article shall be a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). In
the event a person is accused of a first violation of this article and does not
wish to contest the allegation, then the person so accused can pay to the city
of Rock Island police headquarters a penalty sum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) to be paid within seven (7) days of the first violation for and in
full satisfaction of the violation. The fine for any second and subsequent
violation of this article within two (2) years of the first violation shall not
exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
These fines shall be in addition to any towing and storage charges. (Ord. 34-
00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 068-2006, § 1, 9-11-2006)
ARTICLE VI. NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLES
Sec. 9-130. Purpose:
Whereas, the city council of Rock Island, after considering volume, speed and
character of traffic on streets within the city of Rock Island finds that
neighborhood vehicles as defined herein, may safely travel on and across the
streets within the city with the regulations set forth herein and that the
public safety will not be jeopardized by operation of said vehicles in
accordance with said regulations except on roadways prohibited by this article.
(Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Sec. 9-131. Definitions:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this article:
   Neighborhood Vehicle: A self-propelled, electrically powered four-wheeled
motor vehicle (or a self-propelled gasoline powered four-wheeled motor vehicle
with an engine displacement under 1,200 cubic centimeters) which is capable of
attaining in one mile a speed of more than twenty (20) miles per hour, but not
more than twenty five (25) miles per hour, and which conforms to federal
regulations under title 49 CFR part 571.500. (Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Sec. 9-132. Prohibited Roadways:
   (a)   General Authorization: Except as expressly prohibited in this section
it shall be lawful for any person who holds a valid driver's license issued in
this or any other state to operate a neighborhood vehicle on any street within
the city. (Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Sec. 9-133. General Limitations:
   (a)   No person shall operate a neighborhood vehicle on any street having a
posted speed limit of thirty five (35) miles per hour or greater, provided that
nothing herein shall prohibit a person from driving a neighborhood vehicle
across a street with a posted speed limit of thirty five (35) miles per hour or
greater.
   (b)   All persons operating neighborhood vehicles shall comply with the
applicable requirements of section 11-1426.1 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., hereinafter referred to as the
Illinois vehicle code.
   (c)   No neighborhood vehicle may be operated on a street unless, at a
minimum it has the following: brakes, a steering apparatus, tires, a rearview
mirror, red reflectorized warning devices in the front and rear, a "slow
moving" emblem (as required of other vehicles in section 12-709 of the Illinois
vehicle code) on the rear of the neighborhood vehicle, a headlight that emits a
white light visible from at least one hundred feet (100') from the rear, brake
light, and turn signals. When operated on a roadway, a neighborhood vehicle
shall have its headlight and tail lamps lighted as required by section 12-201
of the Illinois vehicle code.
   (d)   A person who drives or is in physical control of a neighborhood
vehicle on a roadway while under the influence is subject to sections 11-500
through 11-502 of the Illinois vehicle code.
   (e)   No neighborhood vehicle shall be left on the roadway in such a way
that it disrupts the normal flow of traffic. All costs related to the removal
of any neighborhood vehicle shall be the responsibility of the owner. (Ord.
027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Chapter 10
OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS 1
 
Notes
  Annotations-The city may regulate the permitting of steam to be released from
  railroad locomotive engines. Chicago, R.I. & P. Ry. Co. v. Steckman, 125 Ill.
  App. 299; affirmed, 224 Ill. 500, 79 N.E. 602 (1906).
  A railroad speed limit ordinance is applicable to the case of a railroad
1 employee injured while at his employment on a railroad right of way. Potter
  v. Chicago, M. & St. P. Ry. Co., 208 Ill. App. 363 (1917).
  Where a railroad train was running at a greater rate of speed than the
  maximum permitted by ordinance, a prima facie case of negligence was
  established against the railroad company. Edwall v. Chicago, R.I. & P. Ry.
  Co., 208 Ill. App. 489 (1917).
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. Misdemeanor Defined Generally 1 ; Penalty:
Except as otherwise provided in this Article, each of the sections in this
Article shall be deemed to state a misdemeanor or misdemeanors, which, if
severally or jointly committed by any person or persons within the territorial
jurisdiction of the City, shall subject the offender or offenders, severally to
a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. The court, in lieu of imposing any
fine provided in this Article, may, in its discretion, impose a sentence of
community service. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I; Ord. 99-11, § 1, 2-22-1999)

Sec. 10-6. Obscenity 1 :
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit obscenity within the
City. A person commits obscenity when, with knowledge of the nature of contents
thereof, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable inspection which would
disclose the nature of contents thereof:
      (1)   He or she sells within the City any obscene book, magazine,
pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video recording,
filmstrip or slide.
      (2)   He or she offers or attempts to sell within the City any obscene
book, magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film,
video recording, filmstrip or slide.
      (3)   He or she distributes or gives away within the City any obscene
book, magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film,
video recording, filmstrip or slide.
      (4)   He or she offers to or attempts to give away within the City any
obscene book, magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture
film, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
      (5)   He or she prints or publishes within the city any obscene book,
magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video
recording, filmstrip or slide.
      (6)   He or she exhibits or shows within the City any obscene photograph,
drawing, motion picture, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
      (7)   He or she produces, directs, or plays a part within the City in any
obscene play.
      (8)   He or she advertises for sale within the City any obscene book,
magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video
recording, phonograph record, filmstrip or slide.
      (9)   He or she advertises for viewing within the City any obscene motion
picture, video recording, play, filmstrip or slide.
      (10)   He or she publicly performs an obscene act or otherwise publicly
presents an obscene exhibition of his or her body within the City.
      (11)   He or she buys or procures in the City for resale in the City any
obscene book, magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph, motion picture film, video
recording, filmstrip, slide or phonograph record.
      (12)   He or she buys, leases, or procures in the City for showing in the
City, for gain, any obscene motion picture, video recording, filmstrip or
slide.
   (b)   As used in this Section material is "obscene" when:
      (1)   It depicts or describes any of the following types of sexual
conduct:
         a.   Ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated,
including intercourse, oral copulation, sodomy;
         b.   Masturbation;
         c.   Excretory functions; or
         d.   Exhibition of the human genitals; and
      (2)   To the average person, applying contemporary community standards,
the dominant theme of the material taken as a whole appeals to the prurient
interest in sex; and
      (3)   The material is patently offensive because it affronts contemporary
community standards in its description or representation of the sexual conduct;
and
      (4)   The material taken as a whole lacks serious literary, artistic,
political, or scientific value.
   (c)   Any person who commits obscenity or any act thereof as defined herein
is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than three hundred
dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) 1 . (1963 Code,
Ch. XII, Art. I; Ord. 83-62, 2-20-1984)

  Art. I, § 9(k).
Sec. 10-7. Forfeiture Of Licenses Upon Conviction Of Certain Violations:
In case of the conviction of any person for a violation of any of the
provisions of sections 10-4, 10-6 and 10-63 of this chapter, such person shall,
in addition to the penalty prescribed for such violation, incur a forfeiture of
any city license that he may hold. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I)
Sec. 10-8. Cruelty To Animals Generally 1 :
No person shall overload, overdrive, overwork, cruelly beat, torture, torment,
mutilate or cruelly kill any animal or cause or knowingly allow the same to be
done. No person shall cruelly work or cruelly abandon any old, maimed, infirm,
sick or disabled animal, or cause or knowingly allow the same to be done, or
unnecessarily fail to provide any animal in his charge or custody, as owner or
otherwise, with proper food, drink or shelter. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I)

Sec. 10-9. Firearms; Explosives; Slingshot; Fireworks; Bow And Arrow; Air Gun:
   (a)   Prohibited: No person shall, in any part of the city, fire or
discharge any cannon, gun, pistol or other firearm, or set off, fire or explode
any torpedo, firecracker, fireball, rocket or other fireworks whatsoever 1 .
However, the discharge of firearms by the members of any military organization
when on parade and in accordance with the command of the commanding officer, or
by any city officer or other person in the discharge of any legal duty or
necessary and lawful act done in a proper and careful manner, shall not be
deemed a violation hereof 2 . No person shall in any part of the city possess
any torpedo, firecracker, fireball, rocket or other fireworks whatsoever.
Fireworks as defined in the fireworks regulation act, 425 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 30/2.
   (b)   Air Guns And Toy Guns: It shall be unlawful for any person to
discharge on the streets, avenues, alleys or other public grounds any air gun
or toy gun from which is sent a lead or metal missile.
   (c)   Slingshots; Bow And Arrow; Exception: It shall be unlawful for any
person to shoot a slingshot or bow and arrow within the corporate limits of the
city. However, archery may be practiced if done in a safe place and under the
competent supervision of an adult. The prohibition against shooting a bow and
arrow within the city limits shall not apply to the hunting of deer with a bow
and arrow in accordance with subsection (d) of this section.
   (d)   Archery Deer Hunting: A person may discharge a long, recurve, compound
bow, or crossbow as permitted by the Illinois department of natural resources
regulations and the laws of the state of Illinois, within the corporate limits
of the city during the course of harvesting deer if the following requirements
are met:
      (1)   The person must possess a valid deer archery permit issued by the
state of Illinois and must comply with all of the conditions of the permit and
all applicable laws and regulations of the Illinois department of natural
resources relating to archery deer hunting.
      (2)   The person must possess a deer hunting permit issued by the city.
The cost for this permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). The application
procedure necessary for obtaining a permit shall be according to the city of
Rock Island deer management rules and restrictions for deer hunting in
subsection (f) of this section.
      (3)   The number of locations or "sites" for deer hunting to be permitted
shall be set by the city council on an annual basis. There shall be fourteen
(14) permitted "sites" with no more than eight (8) "sites" located on private
property. The size of each "site" whether on public or private property, must
have a minimum of three (3) contiguous acres. City staff shall identify and
approve all "sites".
      (4)   Each hunter shall be authorized to hunt from an approved "stand"
located on the permitted hunting "sites". Each "stand" located on an approved
"site" shall have a minimum platform height of six feet (6'). No person shall
knowingly direct an arrow across the boundary of or off the designated "site".
Only one hunter per "stand" at any one time will be allowed. If multiple
"stands" are to be located on a "site", each "stand" shall have a density of no
less than five (5) acres.
      (5)   Locating appropriate hunting "sites" will be the responsibility of
the hunter. The hunter shall provide "site" information to the chief of police
who will forward it to the community and economic development department who
will determine if the "site" information complies with this section and the
rules and procedures for deer hunting in subsection (f) of this section. The
"site" information submitted by the hunter shall include a description and
address of the proposed hunting "site".
      (6)   Hunting will only be allowed on those specific days designated as
deer bow season by the Illinois department of natural resources and the city of
Rock Island, Illinois.
      (7)   The total number of deer to be harvested as well as the number of
male and female deer allowed to be harvested per hunter shall be set by rule in
subsection (f) of this section.
      (8)   The manner for removal of a harvested deer shall be set by rule in
subsection (f)(1)b of this section.
This subsection (d) shall only be in force for the bow and arrow deer hunting
seasons as approved by city council.
   (e)   Penalty: The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this
section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a
violation of this section and does not wish to contest said allegation prior to
the time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so accused
may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation.
   (f)   Deer Management Rules And Restrictions: The city of Rock Island
permits an archery hunting program for deer in an effort to better control the
deer population within the boundaries of the city, contingent, however, upon
annual council review. The intent is to give control of hunting to the property
owners, yet enable archery hunters to harvest the deer for their use or to
provide meat for social agencies.
Hunting sites will be selected based on criteria including deer concentration,
safety, and overall impact. There are stipulations required of hunters in an
effort to make the program as safe as possible, yet achieve the goal of
thinning the number of deer within the city limits.
      (1)   Hunters:
         a.   Obtaining A Permit: Hunters must obtain a permit in order to
participate in the Rock Island deer management program. In order to obtain a
permit, hunters will need to provide the following:
            1.   Written permission from the property owner of the site they
desire to hunt.
            2.   Hunters are encouraged to obtain permission from adjacent and
abutting property owners, these properties will be considered part of the
hunting site.
            3.   Proficiency certification from an approved provider.
            4.   Copy of Illinois hunting license.
            5.   Completed Rock Island deer management application form.
         b.   Hunting Rules And Regulations:
            1.   Hunters must adhere to all state of Illinois and department of
natural resources guidelines, rules, and restrictions.
            2.   Hunters must obtain appropriate state permits and tags.
            3.   Hunters must have a valid city of Rock Island permit.
            4.   Hunters will harvest at least two (2) does before harvesting a
buck.
            5.   All deer harvested as part of the deer management program must
be checked in at the two (2) identified fire stations (entire deer).
            6.   All remains must be removed from the hunting site.
            7.   Hunters will obtain permission from property owners before
tracking or retrieving a deer that travels out of the approved hunting area.
Illinois is not a right to retrieve state.
      (2)   Hunting Sites: Sites will be approved by the city based upon
criteria including deer concentration, safety, and overall impact.
         a.   Restrictions And Requirements:
            1.   Consist of no less than three (3) contiguous acres.
            2.   One hundred (100) yards from a school, park, or church, unless
approved.
            3.   Situated in a manner that all shots are taken at a downward
angle.
            4.   Shots must not be taken in a way they may carry into an open
or occupied area.
            5.   Only one hunter active per site at any time.
            6.   Certain sites may have a time restriction when hunting is
allowed.
            7.   All sites will be signed with signage obtained from the Rock
Island police department. This signage will be placed in a manner that is
visible to neighboring and abutting property owners when hunters are active.
            8.   Hunters cannot use nails, screws or other hardware to affix
stands. Only straps or other noninjuring attachment may be used in trees.
         b.   Multiple Hunters:
            1.   Additional hunters may be allowed when using a separate stand
at a density of no less than one hunter per five (5) acres.
            2.   Property owners may coordinate with multiple hunters to
utilize a site, but only one hunter may actively use a stand at any one time.
      (3)   Property Owners:
         a.   Property owners reserve the right to deny hunting on their
property.
         b.   Property owners wishing to hunt or allow hunting on their
property must submit their site for approval to the deer management program
manager.
         c.   The city will notify property owners that are adjacent and
abutting an approved hunting site in advance via letter.
         d.   Property owners with objections or concerns regarding hunting in
their vicinity should state their concern in writing or contact the deer
management program manager.
      (4)   Public Lands: Hunters who are unable to locate a suitable site
within Rock Island are eligible to hunt on selected public lands such as golf
courses or other specifically identified areas. The hunters will follow all of
the requirements identified for hunting on private land. In addition, the
following procedures will be used to determine who will hunt on those lands.
Larger private properties such as cemeteries may follow a similar process.
         a.   Hunting stand areas will be identified by the "controlling
agency", a department, board, or designated individual.
         b.   Hunter will enter their name into a lottery for a chance of being
awarded permission to place a hunting stand on designated areas.
         c.   Names will be selected through a drawing with each of the names
noted in order.
         d.   Hunters who are awarded an area, must obtain their city of Rock
Island permit before any hunting takes place.
         e.   If a hunter exhausts their supply of deer tags and the season is
still open, they are to notify the controlling agency. The controlling agency
is then responsible for contacting the next eligible hunter.
         f.   The hunter will notify the controlling agency in advance when
they plan to be active. This may be done in person or through a mutually agreed
upon process.
      (5)   Unpermitted Hunting:
         a.   Any hunting which takes place without appropriate permits will be
considered poaching and treated as such.
         b.   Any hunting on property which is not approved by the city will be
considered poaching and treated as such.
         c.   Hunting on property without the property owners explicit
permission is impermissible.
         d.   Any violation of the deer management program rules and guidelines
will result in the permanent revocation of city hunting privileges and subject
the hunter to a possible fine for violating the enabling ordinance.
   (g)   Southwest Area Hunting Exemption: Recognizing that the Southwest Area
of the City has a unique collection of natural settings and a rural character,
the City Council may designate parcels in said Area as exempt from municipal
hunting restrictions under the following rules and conditions.
      (1)   An exemption may be granted only to parcels south of the Rock
River, or on islands located within said river, that are ten (10) acres in size
or larger. An exemption shall not be granted for properties north of said river
or which are smaller than ten (10) acres under any circumstances.
      (2)   An exemption shall allow the property owner to hunt any wild game
on said property using any means sanctioned by the Illinois Department of
Natural Resources provided that such hunting is undertaken in full compliance
with all the regulations of said Department and State law applicable to either
private or public lands.
      (3)   In addition to said regulations of said Department, the property
owner shall be required to maintain a distance of three hundred yards (300 yd),
or nine hundred feet (900'), from property lines, roadways, railways, and
inhabited dwellings while actively engaged in hunting activities. Permanent
signs shall also be placed at every entrance to the subject property and along
the boundary of said property at intervals of one hundred yards (100 yd), or
three hundred feet (300'), clearly identifying that hunting is taking place on
the property. Said signs shall be subject to the approval of both the City and
said Department.
      (4)   For the purposes of this exemption, "hunting" shall be considered
an "activity" as opposed to a "use" as understood by the Zoning Code and
therefore shall not be regulated by said Code.
      (5)   The process for granting an exemption shall be as follows.
         a.   A property owner with a qualifying property shall submit an
application to the City Clerk's Office requesting an exemption. Said
application shall include, but not be limited to, proof of ownership, a
complete legal description, and a plat of survey.
         b.   The Clerk shall send notices of the application to all municipal
property owners within two hundred and fifty feet (250') of the subject
property, as measured from its periphery, informing them of the application and
requesting that they respond in favor or in opposition to the hunting exemption
being requested. The notice shall also inform adjacent municipal property
owners when a public hearing as described below shall take place. "Municipal
property owner" shall mean property owners whose properties are within the
municipal boundary. The Clerk shall also submit a public notice for inclusion
in a local newspaper in general circulation that shall be published no less
than two (2) weeks prior to the time of the public hearing.
         c.   The Clerk shall notify the Police Department of the application
and request that they provide comments and recommendations regarding the
request.
         d.   The Clerk, having received responses from adjacent municipal
property owners and the Police Department, shall prepare a report for the City
Council. The report shall make a recommendation to approve or deny the request
based on the standards set forth in this subsection. Any additional recommended
conditions shall also be included.
         e.   Within sixty (60) days of the application being received, the
City Council shall hold a public hearing regarding the application. Citizens
shall be allowed to speak both in favor and in opposition to the request.
Citizens who file an interested party form shall also be allowed to cross
examine the applicant asking them to provide additional information and answer
any and all pertinent questions.
         f.   Following the close of the public hearing, the Council shall
deliberate on whether to grant the exemption informed both by the public
hearing and the report submitted by the City Clerk's Office.
         g.   The Council may impose any additional conditions they deem
appropriate or as recommended by the City Clerk and Police Department.
Conditions shall not in any way be in conflict with the regulations of the
Illinois Department of Natural Resources or State law.
         h.   Approval of the exemption shall require a simple majority vote of
the entire Council and adoption of an ordinance. The City Clerk's Office shall
have the ordinance recorded with the County Recorder's Office upon passage.
Said ordinance shall describe any and all additional conditions imposed by the
Council. The exemption shall remain in place for the subject property
regardless of changing ownership unless rescinded by majority vote of the
Council as described below. The exemption shall not be automatically rescinded
in the event that the zoning of the subject property is changed or development
of the property takes place. In the event that two adjacent properties have
separate exemptions, are combined, and their exemptions have different
conditions, the more restrictive conditions shall apply to the combined
property. The Council may be asked to make an interpretation of the conditions
if the owner of the subject property disagrees with the City Clerk as to what
the "more restrictive conditions" of the combined exemptions are.
      (6)   An exemption may be rescinded if the subject property is subdivided
or combined with another property that does not have an exemption of its own.
The process for rescinding an exemption shall be as follows.
         a.   In the event a property with a hunting exemption is subdivided or
combined with another property that does not have an exemption of its own, the
City Clerk shall send a notice to the owner of the subject property informing
them that the exemption shall be invalidated unless they apply for the
exemption to be reinstated for the subject property as it is now constituted.
The property owner shall have thirty (30) days from the date of the Clerk's
notice to submit a new application. If an application is not received, the
exemption shall be automatically rescinded and a second notice sent to the
property owner informing them of the fact. The Council shall thereafter adopt
an ordinance formally rescinding the exemption which shall then be recorded
with the County Recorder's Office upon passage by the Clerk.
         b.   If a new application is received, the Clerk shall follow the same
approval process required for a first-time application.
      (7)   An exemption may be rescinded following petition from an adjacent
property owner under limited circumstances. An adjacent property owner may
petition the Council to rescind the exemption if they propose to build a new
dwelling within two hundred and fifty feet (250') of the subject property, as
measured from its periphery. An adjacent property owner may also petition the
Council to rescind the exemption if they propose to subdivide their property.
The property to be subdivided must be within two hundred and fifty feet (250')
of the subject property, as measured from its periphery. The petition in this
case must be submitted with a plat of survey completed by a licensed land
surveyor detailing the proposed subdivision. The proposed subdivision must be
in compliance with the City's subdivision code.
         a.   In the event a petition in either of the above circumstances is
submitted, the City Clerk shall send a notice to the owner of the subject
property informing them that a petition to rescind their exemption has been
received and that the Council shall hold a public hearing to consider whether
or not to approve the petition thus rescinding their exemption.
         b.   The Clerk shall send notices of the petition to all municipal
property owners within two hundred and fifty feet (250') of the subject
property, as measured from its periphery. The notice shall also inform adjacent
municipal property owners when a public hearing as described below shall take
place. The Clerk shall also submit a public notice for inclusion in a local
newspaper in general circulation that shall be published no less than two (2)
weeks prior to the time of the public hearing.
         c.   The Clerk shall notify the Police Department of the petition and
request that they provide comments and recommendations regarding the petition.
         d.   The Clerk shall prepare a report for the City Council. The report
shall make a recommendation to approve or deny the petition based on the
standards set forth in this subsection.
      e.   Within sixty (60) days of the petition being received, the City
Council shall hold a public hearing regarding the petition. Citizens shall be
allowed to speak both in favor and in opposition to the petition. Citizens who
file an interested    party form shall also be allowed to cross examine the
property owner with the exemption or the petitioner asking them to provide
additional information and answer any and all pertinent questions.
         f.   Following the close of the public hearing, the Council shall
deliberate on whether to approve the petition informed both by the public
hearing and the report submitted by the City Clerk's Office.
         g.   The Council may deny the petition, but impose additional
conditions to the exemption they deem appropriate or as recommended by the City
Clerk and Police Department.
         h.   Approval of the petition or modification of the exemption shall
require a simple majority vote of the entire Council and adoption of an
ordinance. The City Clerk's Office shall have an ordinance recorded with the
County Recorder's Office upon passage.
      (8)   An exemption may be rescinded by the Council if the owner of the
subject property is found to be in violation of any of the rules and conditions
of this subsection.
         a.   In the event that a violation is alleged to have occurred, the
City Clerk shall send a notice to the owner of the subject property informing
them of the allegation and request that they remedy said violation within
thirty (30) days providing proof of having done so. If the Clerk determines
that the violation has not been remedied, the Clerk shall send a second notice
informing the subject property owner that the Council shall hold a public
hearing to consider whether or not to rescind their exemption.
         b.   The Clerk shall send notices of the public hearing to all
municipal property owners within two hundred and fifty feet (250') of the
subject property, as measured from its periphery, informing them about when it
shall take place. The Clerk shall also submit a public notice for inclusion in
a local newspaper in general circulation that shall be published no less than
two (2) weeks prior to the time of the public hearing.
         c.   The Clerk shall notify the Police Department of the public
hearing and request that they provide comments and recommendations.
         d.   The Clerk shall prepare a report for the City Council. The report
shall detail the alleged violation and how it is a violation based on the rules
and conditions set forth in this subsection. The report may recommend that the
exemption be rescinded or that additional conditions be imposed.
         e.   Within sixty (60) days of the date of the Clerk's second notice
to the subject property owner, the City Council shall hold a public hearing
regarding the petition. Citizens shall be allowed to speak both in favor and in
opposition to the exemption being rescinded. Citizens who file an interested
party form shall also be allowed to cross examine the property owner asking
them to provide additional information and answer any and all pertinent
questions.
         f.   Following the close of the public hearing, the Council shall
deliberate on whether to rescind the exemption informed both by the public
hearing and the report submitted by the City Clerk's Office.
         g.   The Council may choose not to rescind the exemption, but impose
additional conditions to the exemption they deem appropriate or as recommended
by the City Clerk and Police Department.
         h.   Approval of the petition or modification of the exemption shall
require a simple majority vote of the Council and adoption of an ordinance. The
City Clerk's Office shall have an ordinance recorded with the County Recorder's
Office upon passage.
      (9)   There shall be no limit on the number of properties within the
Southwest Area that may be granted a hunting exemption. (1963 Code, ch. XII,
art. I; Ord., 12-21-1970; Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord., 1-11-1982; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-
1984; Ord. 91-136, 12-9-1991; Ord. 94-106, 12-12-1994; Ord. 062-2013, 11-18-
2013; Ord. 016-2014, 3-17-2014; Ord. 022-2015, 4-20-2015; Ord. 052-2021, 9-14-
2021)

Sec. 10-10. Obstruction Of Roadways:
   (a)   Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to
walk along and upon an adjacent roadway and hinder the passage of vehicles or
obstruct the passage or business of any person.
   (b)   Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and
upon a roadway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the
roadway or the shoulder facing traffic that may approach from the opposite
direction and shall not hinder the passage of vehicles or obstruct the passage
or business of any person.
   (c)   No person shall hinder the passage of vehicles or obstruct the passage
or business of any person in any public street or sidewalk in the city, by
flying kites, throwing stones, throwing snowballs, using skateboards, using in-
line skates, playing ball or in any other manner. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I;
Ord. 97-51, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 10-11. Obstruction Of Roadways - Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of section 10-10 of this
chapter shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a
violation of section 10-10 of this chapter and does not wish to contest the
allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, the
person so accused may pay to the city, at police headquarters a penalty in the
sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for and in full satisfaction of the
violation. (Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984; Ord. 91-136, 12-9-1991; Ord.
97-51, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 10-12. Getting On Or Holding Onto Vehicles - Prohibited:
No person shall, within the limits of the city, seize, hang upon, get upon,
hold, tie or fasten to any railroad car, engine, motor vehicle, carriage,
buggy, wagon, sleigh, sled or other vehicle or conveyance while the same is in
motion or attempt so to do, or attach to any such vehicle or conveyance any
sleigh or sled, and ride thereon, unless he shall be acting in compliance with
law and his duty in so doing. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I)
Sec. 10-13. Getting On Or Holding Onto Vehicles - Penalty:

violation of section 10-12 of this chapter and does not wish to contest the
allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, the
person so accused may pay to the city, at police headquarters, a penalty in the

(Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984)
Sec. 10-14. Coasting On Streets - Prohibited:

except as designated by the mayor and council. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I)
Sec. 10-15. Coasting On Streets - Penalty:

cellar door, hatchway, pit, vault or excavation upon or adjoining any sidewalk,
street, alley or public place of the city. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I)

Sec. 10-18. Abandoned Or Unattended Refrigerators 1 Or Airtight Containers-
Generally:
No person shall leave or permit to remain outside any dwelling, building or
structure or within any unoccupied dwelling, building or structure under his
control in a place accessible to children, any abandoned or unattended icebox,
refrigerator or other container of sufficient size to admit a small child,
which has an airtight closing door, snaplock or other locking device, without
first removing the airtight closing door, snaplock or other locking device from
the abandoned icebox, refrigerator or airtight container. (1963 Code, ch. XII,
art. I)

Sec. 10-20. Assault; Battery 1 :
   (a)   No person shall commit an assault or battery. A person commits an
assault when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places
another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. A person commits
battery if he intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any
means: 1) causes bodily harm to an individual, or 2) makes physical contact of
an insulting or provoking nature with an individual.
   (b)   The minimum fine for committing the violation of assault shall be
fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation as
aforesaid and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a
complaint is issued for the violation, the person so accused may pay to the
city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for
and in full satisfaction of the violation.
   (c)   The minimum fine for committing the violation of battery shall be one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). In the event a person is accused of a
violation as aforesaid and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the
time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so accused may
pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation. (1963
Code, ch. XII, art. I,; Ord., § 2, 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-1984)

Sec. 10-21. Disturbing The Peace:
No person shall create, maintain, assist or participate in the creation of a
loud or raucous noise, or loud or raucous talking, or loud or raucous singing
on the public streets at any time or place so as likely to disturb the public
peace or quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling,
hotel, or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity.
No person shall allow or cause to be used or operated any radio receiving set,
musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker or other machine or device for the
producing or reproducing of sound, on any residential property in such a manner
as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at
any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the
person who is in the residence in which such machine or device is operated and
who is a voluntary listener thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument,
phonograph, loudspeaker, machine or device between the hours of ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. in such a manner as to be plainly
audible at a distance of ten feet (10') from the property on which it is
located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section.
No person shall create, maintain, assist or participate in the creation of a
loud or raucous noise, or loud or raucous talking, shouting, or loud or raucous
singing on any residential property in such a manner as to disturb the peace,
quiet and comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling,
hotel, or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity.
Exemption: Persons who have obtained a sound amplification permit shall be
exempt during the duration of the permit. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I; Ord. 90-
55, § 1, 8-13-1990; Ord. 50-2004, § 1, 5-3-2004)
Sec. 10-21.1. Public Urination And Defecation Prohibited:
It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate on any street,
alley, sidewalk, parkway, public parking lot, or other public place other than
in a facility designed for that purpose. (Ord. 52-2004, § 1, 5-3-2004)

is accused of a violation of section
10-21 and/or
10-21.1 of this article and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to

Sec. 10-23. Loitering:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to loiter or congregate about
or upon any public building or public property, any stairway, doorway, window
or in front of any business or dwelling house, theater, church or street corner
or elsewhere, and by so doing obstruct or interfere with the free passage of
persons entering or occupying such building or premises, or by language,
conversation or conduct to annoy, insult or disturb persons passing along the
streets or alleys or occupying, residing in or doing business in any of such
houses or places. The fine for violating this section will be from fifty
dollars ($50.00) up to five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 060-2011, 8-8-
2011)
Sec. 10-23.1. Loitering For Drug Activities:
   (a)   Acts Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to loiter in, on or
near any thoroughfare or place open to the public or near any public or private
place in manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of engaging in
drug related activity defined as offenses in the Illinois controlled substances
act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570.
   (b)   Circumstances: Among circumstances that may be considered in
determining whether such purpose is manifested are that the person:
      (1)   Is a known drug user, possessor, or seller. For purpose of this
chapter, a "known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller" is a person who
has, within the knowledge of the arresting officer, been convicted in any court
within this state or any other state of any violation involving the use,
possession or sale of any of the substances referred to in the Illinois
controlled substances act, or such person has been convicted of any violation
of any of the provisions of those sections or substantially similar laws of any
political subdivision of this state or of any state; or a person who displays
physical characteristics of drug intoxication or usage, such as "needle
tracks"; or a person who possesses drug paraphernalia.
      (2)   Is currently subject to an order prohibiting his or her presence in
a high drug activity geographic area.
      (3)   Behaves in such a manner as to raise a reasonable suspicion that he
or she is about to engage in or is then engaged in an unlawful drug related
activity, including, by way of example only, acting as a "lookout".
      (4)   Is physically identified by the officer as a member of a "gang" or
association which has as its purpose illegal drug activity.
      (5)   Transfers small objects or packages for currency in a furtive
fashion.
      (6)   Tries to conceal himself or herself or any object which reasonably
could be involved in an unlawful drug related activity.
      (7)   Is in an area that is known for unlawful drug use and trafficking.
      (8)   Is on or in premises that have been reported to law enforcement as
a place suspected of unlawful drug activity.
      (9)   Is in, or within six feet (6') of, any vehicles registered to a
known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller, or a person for whom there is
an outstanding warrant for a crime involving drug related activity.
   (c)   Enforcement: Enforcement of this section shall be by an officer of the
Rock Island police department and the Quad City metropolitan enforcement group.
(Ord. 93-27, § 1, 4-12-1993)
Sec. 10-24. Noisy Animals-Generally 2 :
No person shall, in the city, keep any dog, whelp, bitch, calf, hog or any
other animal which, by barking, howling or other noises, shall disturb the
peace and quiet of the neighborhood. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I)

Sec. 10-26. Disorderly Conduct 3 :
   (a)   A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
      (1)   Does any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb
another and to provoke a breach of the peace.
      (2)   Transmits in any manner to the fire department of any city, town,
village or fire protection district a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time
of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that
such fire exists.
      (3)   Transmits in any manner, to another, a false alarm to the effect
that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that
its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such
transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such bomb
or explosive is concealed in such place.
      (4)   Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or
public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed,
knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds
for believing that such an offense has been committed.
      (5)   Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful
purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window
or other opening in it.
      (6)   Conducts himself or herself in a disorderly manner, makes, aids,
countenances or assists in making any improper noise, riot or disturbance in
the city or congregates with others in any of the streets, alleys or public
places of the city for unlawful purposes, or for a lawful purpose in a riotous
or tumultuous manner, to the annoyance of the citizens or travelers therein, or
aids or abets the same.
      (7)   Delivers any public speech or holds any public meeting or gathering
or gatherings on any streets or avenues within the city without first obtaining
from the city council a permit. If the city council shall grant a permit, then
the permit shall designate upon which street or avenue any such meeting or
gathering may be held or conducted. An application to the city council for the
place at which the meeting or gathering is to be held or conducted shall be
filed with the city clerk not less than twenty four (24) hours before the time
of the meeting or gathering.
      (8)   Makes any kind of false alarm not described above by outcry, bell,
other sounding instrument or other means for disturbing the peace of the city.
   (b)   The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsections (a)
(1), (a)(6) 4 and (a)(7) of this section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In
the event a person is accused of a violation of those subsections and does not
wish to contest the allegations prior to the time a complaint is issued for the
violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city at police
headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full
satisfaction of the violation.
   (c)   The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsections (a)
(2), (a)(3), (a)(4), and (a)(5) of this section shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of those subsections
and does not wish to contest the allegations prior to the time a complaint is
issued for the violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city at
police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
and in full satisfaction of the violation. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I; Ord., §
1, 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-1984; Ord. 91-136, § 1, 12-9-1991)

Sec. 10-28. Time of closing for places of amusement--Generally.
No person shall, by himself, his agent or servant, keep open or permit or
suffer any person to remain at any public place of amusement kept or owned by
him at a later hour than 2:00 a.m., except as otherwise provided in this Code.
The mayor may, in his discretion, upon proper application to him in writing,
grant a special written permit to keep the same open to some hour that shall be
specified therein, such permit to be good for one (1) night only, such permit
and application to be filed with the city clerk before taking advantage of the
provisions thereof.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 26)

Sec. 10-30. Concealed weapons--Prohibited.
No person shall within the limits of the city carry or wear under his clothes,
or concealed about his person, any pistol, revolver, bowie knife, dirk or other
deadly weapon, nor shall he in a threatening or boisterous manner display or
flourish any deadly weapon. This shall not apply to police officers when on
duty. Any such weapon worn, carried or displayed by any person in violation of
this section shall be kept and retained by the chief of police pending final
adjudication of the violation.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 28)
Sec. 10-31. Same--Penalty.
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of section
10-30 shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). In the event a person is
accused of a violation of section
10-30 and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint
is issued for the violation, the person so accused may pay to the city, at
police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation.
(Ord. of 1-12-81, § 3; Ord. No. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-84; Ord. No. 91-136, § 1, 12-9-

Sec. 10-32. Resisting or obstructing a police officer; aiding in arrest;
impersonation of officer.
   (a)   No person shall knowingly resist or obstruct the performance of any
police officer or member of the police department nor shall in any way
interfere with or hinder or prevent him from discharging any authorized act
within his official capacity. No person shall interfere with the mayor, the
chief of police, any police officer or any person authorized and required to
enforce the laws of the city, nor prevent, hinder or delay such person in the
execution of the duties required of him by any of the ordinances of the city or
laws of the state.
   (b)   A peace officer making a lawful arrest may command the aid of persons
over the age of eighteen (18). A person commanded to aid a peace officer shall
have the same authority to arrest as that peace officer. No person shall
neglect or refuse to give such aid or assistance when commanded to do so.
   (c)   No person shall falsely represent himself to be a member of the police
department of this city or shall, maliciously or with the intent to deceive,
use or imitate any of the signs, signals or devices adopted and used by any
such person.
   (d)   The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsection (a)
shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). In the event a person is accused
of a violation of subsection (a) and does not wish to contest the allegation
prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so
accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation.
   (e)   The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsection (b)
shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), and for subsection (c), one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of
subsection (b) or (c) and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the
time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so accused may
pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars
($50.00) or one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for and in full satisfaction of
the violation.
(Code 1963, Ch. VII, Art. I, § 4 and Ch. XII, Art. I, § 29; Ord. of 1-12-81, §
1; Ord. of 1-11-82, § 1; Ord. No. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-84; Ord. No. 91-136, § 1, 12-
9-91)
Editor's note--At the discretion of the editor, the provisions of § 1 of Ord.
No. 83-57, adopted Feb. 6, 1984, have been treated as amendatory of § 10-32
subsections (d) and (e). Ord. No. 83-57 was not specifically amendatory of this
Code.
Cross reference--Police, ch. 12.
State law references--Assisting police officer, 725 ILCS 5/107-8; resisting or
obstructing public officers, 725 ILCS 5/31-1 et seq.; false personation of
public officer or employee, 725 ILCS 5/32-5; refusing to aid a peace officer,
725 ILCS 5/31-8.
Sec. 10-33. Destruction or injury of property--Prohibited.
   (a)   Generally. No person shall willfully or maliciously destroy, injure,
deface or interfere with any bridge, engine house or other public building,
fire engine, fire hose or other property of the city, or any public property or
public work.
   (b)   Tampering With Telephones. It shall be unlawful for any person to
insert, or to attempt to insert into the coin box or money receptacle of any
telephone any slug, button or other substance or to manipulate or operate, or
to attempt to manipulate or operate, in any manner whatever any telephone
instrument or any mechanism or device connected or commonly used therewith,
with the intent to obtain telephone service without paying therefor. It shall
be unlawful for any person to inset, or attempt to insert, into the coin box or
money receptacle of any telephone, any slug, button, wire, hook or other
implement or substance with the intent to obtain from such coin box or money
receptacle a legal tender coin of the United States.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 30)
State law reference--Obtaining telecommunication services with intent to
defraud, 720 ILCS 365/1.

10-33 and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint
