Sec. 13-38. Penalties For Weeds And Grass Violations:
   The Building Official may provide for the removal of weeds and grass over
ten inches (10") in height on private property within the City. The term "weeds
and grass" shall be defined to include all annual and perennial vegetation
other than trees and shrubs. This term shall not be defined to include
cultivated flowers and gardens including but not limited to native plantings
used as wildlife habitat; used to control soil erosion; and/or used to manage
storm water. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be
subject to the following penalties.
   (a)   Upon detection of a weeds and grass violation, the respective property
owner shall be issued a courtesy notice directing them to abate the violation
within seven (7) days of the date of the courtesy notice. No fine shall
accompany the courtesy notice.
   (b)   If the property owner fails to abate the nuisance within seven (7)
days of the courtesy notice, the City shall be empowered to abate the nuisance.
The Building Official and the Public Works Director, or their respective
designees, shall direct the abatement by either City staff or a contractor. The
costs incurred by the City to abate the nuisance shall be charged to the
property owner on their municipal utility bill, in the form of a lien on the
property, or in any other manner consistent with the Code of Ordinances.
Further, the City Attorney is authorized and directed to initiate litigation in
court to recover costs incurred. The cost of abatement will be accompanied by a
fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or ten percent (10%) of the cost of
abatement, whichever amount is greater.
   (c)   A property owner who has been cited and had a nuisance abated on their
property by the City three (3) or more times in a one (1) year period shall be
considered a habitual violator. Habitual violators shall receive notice that
they are so considered and said notice shall inform them that all subsequent
violations shall result in immediate abatement by the City without additional
courtesy notices. The costs incurred by the City to abate the nuisance and the
associated fine shall be charged to the property owner in the same manner as
above. Designation as a habitual violator may be discontinued when the property
owner in question has not been cited for a minimum of one (1) year.
   (d)   Property owners may appeal a weeds and grass citation to the Community
and Economic Development Director. Said appeal must be in writing and explain
how there is not a weeds and grass violation present using photographic
evidence. The appeal must be delivered to the Director prior to the end of the
seven (7) day period following the issuance of the courtesy notice. Appeals
received late shall not be considered. The Director shall have seven (7) days
to review the appeal during which time no abatement or further enforcement
action by the City shall be taken. The Director may reject the appeal on the
grounds that a weeds and grass violation is present or, if convinced that no
violation is present, dismiss the citation. If the appeal is rejected and the
nuisance violation remains present, the City may proceed with abatement
immediately.
(Ord. 85-11, 5-13-1985; Ord. 87-38, 4-13-1987; Ord. 87-47, 4-27-1987; Ord. 88-
28.1, 5-23-1988; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 91-53, 5-6-1991; Ord. 34-2001, §
1, 4-23-2001; Ord. 77-2004, § 1, 7-26-2004; Ord. 087-2014, 12-1-2014; Ord. 036-
2019, 7- 8-2019; Ord. 028-2023, 7-24-2023)
Sec. 13-39. Use Of Public Works Compactor:
(Rep. by Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 13-40. Billing And Collection Procedures:
   (a)   Billings for refuse charges shall be rendered by the finance
department on a monthly or quarterly basis at the discretion of the finance
department.
   (b)   When refuse charges are not paid on or before the due date stated on
the bill, a penalty shall be added. Failure to receive a bill does not entitle
the owner or customer to a remission of penalty.
   (c)   In the event that the city deems it necessary to refer past due refuse
charges to the city attorney or a collection agency for collection, the city
may additionally recover its actual expenses so incurred, including court
costs, collection agency fees and reasonable attorney fees.
   (d)   Billings for grass and weed charges shall be rendered by the finance
department and shall be billed in a common statement and collected with the
water service charge, if applicable.
   (e)   When grass and weed charges are not paid on or before the due date
stated on the bill, a late fee penalty shall be added. Unpaid charges and
penalties may result in termination of the water service. Failure to receive a
bill does not entitle the owner or customer to a remission of penalty.
   (f)   Upon refusal or neglect of any person to cut weeds or grass, the
Public Works Director may cause the weeds or grass to be cut and shall collect
from the property owner the cost for service. The charge for that service shall
be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per man hour necessary to complete the work,
with a minimum charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per parcel. These costs
shall be billed to the property owner along with an additional lien charge per
parcel. If mowing charges are fully paid within thirty (30) days, the lien
charge will be removed. If mowing charges are not fully paid within thirty (30)
days, a second billing notice will be sent to the property owner. Upon refusal
or neglect of any person to pay such second notice within seven (7) days, the
city clerk may cause a lien to be placed on the parcel, which lien shall be
superior to all subsequent liens and encumbrances except tax liens if a notice
of lien is filed in the Office of the County Recorder of Deeds within twelve
(12) months of the date of completion of cutting weeds or grass by the city.
The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
      (1)   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification
thereof.
      (2)   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service.
      (3)   The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the
city.
   (g)   However, the lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights
in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to the weed or grass cutting
prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien of the city shall not be valid
as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienholder whose rights in and
to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Upon payment of
the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property
after the notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released and the
release may be filed on record as in the case of filing notice of lien. (Ord.
008-2010, § 3, 2-8-2010; Ord. 036-2019, 7-8-2019)
Sec. 13-41. Appeal:
   If an individual receiving a notice of fees disputes the amount of any
assessed fees or late charges, they may file a written appeal to the City
Manager in writing stating the nature of the dispute, the amount or amounts
dispute and all facts which the appealing party believes support their claim
that the charges or fees were assessed in error. All appeals must be made to
the City Manager's office by letter addressed to the City Manager with a copy
of the account number and disputed bill attached. All appeals to the City
Manager must be made within fourteen (14) calendar days of the date the
disputed charges were first mailed to the individual or individuals filing the
appeal. Failure to file an appeal in this fourteen (14)-day time period shall
constitute a waiver of the parties' right to contest the charges. The City
Manager shall issue a written ruling on any written appeal within seven
business days of receiving a written notice of dispute and required by this
section. The City Manager shall mail his decision to the appealing party at the
address stated on the billing statement issued by the finance department. The
City Manager's decision shall constitute a final appealable administrative
judgment for the purposes of administrative review by the district court. (Ord.
036-2019, 7-8-2019)
Se c. 13-42. Service Charges Billed In Common:
The refuse charge may be billed on a common statement and collected along with
other charges. If the refuse charge is included on a common statement and the
customer payment is insufficient to pay the total of all portions of the
statement, the payment will be applied in the following priority:
   Refuse charge
   Stormwater charge
   Sewer charge
   Water charge
   Water service repair program charge
   Sewer lateral repair program charge
(Ord. 008-2010, § 3, 2-8-2010; Ord. 036- 2019, 7-8-2019)
Secs. 13-43 – 13-50. Reserved:
ARTICLE III. STREETS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 13-51. Names Generally:
The streets of this city, unless otherwise specifically designated by
ordinance, shall be named and designated as follows: The streets running north
and south shall be called "streets", and they shall be numbered from "one"
upward, commencing at First Avenue as the avenue bordering on the Mississippi
River and numbering toward the south. Half-streets and avenues and courts may
be specially designated by the council. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. I)
Sec. 13-52. Street Name Signs:
The names of all streets and avenues as the same have been established by
ordinance shall be plainly designated by suitable metal signs conspicuously
placed. There shall be at least one such sign placed at each street
intersection. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. I)
Sec. 13-53. Houses And Lots To Be Numbered:
The following shall be the plan of numbering the houses, lots and parts of lots
fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the city: The numbering of
streets running north and south shall commence at First Avenue; and the numbers
shall run from one hundred (100) up to two hundred (200), so far as necessary,
and shall be used consecutively for the distance of the first block or
fractional block, the even numbers for the right-hand or west side of the
street, and the odd numbers for the left-hand or east side of the street. One
number shall be left for and applied to each twenty feet (20') of distance; and
in any case where a building or place of business occupies less than twenty
feet (20'), a fraction number shall be used. The numbers from two hundred (200)
to three hundred (300) shall in like manner be used for the second block and in
like manner for succeeding blocks, consecutively. The numbering of avenues
running east and west shall be done in like manner, commencing at First Street,
even numbers being used for the right-hand or south side of the avenue and odd
numbers for the left-hand or north side of the avenue. Each lot and part of lot
fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the city not already
correctly numbered shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this
division. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. I)
Sec. 13-54. Numbers To Be Affixed To Buildings:
   (a)   Each of the figures of every street address number shall be not less
than three inches (3") in height and plainly marked so as to be easily read and
be firmly and conspicuously affixed on the front part of the buildings to which
the same are attached.
   (b)   When notified by the chief building inspector to install house
numbers, it shall be the duty of the owners or occupants of all buildings
fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the city to proceed and
number their buildings as herein required within thirty (30) days after such
notice has been given.
   (c)   No person being the owner or occupant of any building now erected and
fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the city, which is not
already correctly numbered, who, after being notified as aforesaid that the
proper street numbers are of record in the city hall, shall for thirty (30)
days refuse or neglect to number any building or buildings owned or occupied by
him in conformity with the provisions of this division, or shall number any
such building with any number other than that designated by the aforesaid
record. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I)
Sec. 13-55. Permanent Improvements; Water Pipes, Etc.:
   (a)   Whenever any street or alley in the city is to be permanently improved
by paving or otherwise, one copper water service pipe shall be laid from the
water main on such street or alley to one foot (1') from the lot line for each
lot or part of lot having a separate water service, and all iron water service
pipes in the streets so to be improved shall be removed to the lot line on each
side of such street or alley.
   (b)   The cost of laying such copper water service pipes shall be borne by
the owners of the property to be served; and if after a reasonable notice from
the city to lay such copper service pipe any property owner shall neglect or
refuse to lay the same, the city may proceed to lay it and collect the cost
thereof from the property owner. The city may order the installation of copper
service pipes as a separate improvement, by special assessment, in the judgment
of the council. All connections with water, sewer or gas pipes and all other
supply and outlet pipes of whatever kind or nature along the streets so to be
improved must be made and laid when the streets, alleys, etc., are open and
excavated for the improvements, or prior thereto. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I)
Sec. 13-56. Railroads 1 :
   (a)   Not To Obstruct Streets: No railroad corporation, railroad engineer,
railroad conductor or other person shall obstruct any public highway in the
city, by stopping any train upon or by leaving any car or locomotive engine
standing on its tracks where the same intersects or crosses such public
highway, for a period longer than ten (10) minutes.
   (b)   Sewers Under Tracks: No railroad company operating within the limits
of the city shall, in the construction of its roadbed or the maintenance of its
line or lines of railway, hinder or obstruct any waterway, sewer or gutter, but
shall provide, in accordance with specifications approved by the city council,
construct and maintain sufficient sluice ways, extensions of sewers or gutters
under its tracks and right of way at its own expense; and if the company fails
to do so, the city shall construct the same at the expense of the company.
   (c)   Speed: No railroad corporation, by itself or its agent, shall run any
passenger train within the limits of the city at a greater speed than ten (10)
miles per hour, nor any other train, locomotive, engine or car at a greater
rate than six (6) miles per hour.
   (d)   Penalty: Any railroad corporation that shall of itself, or by any
agent or employee, violate or fail to observe any of the provisions of this
section, and any agent or employee of any railroad corporation or other person
who shall violate or fail to observe the same, shall for each violation or
failure to observe the same, where no other penalty is imposed, be fined in the
sum of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor exceeding one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. III)

1 See also
  chapter 16, "Utilities", of this code.
Secs. 13-57-13-70. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. EXCAVATIONS 1 , 2
 
Notes
1 See also unsafe excavations, openings, etc., § 10-16 of this code;
  unauthorized excavation in street, § 10-35 of this code.
2 65 ILCS 5/11-80-7.
Sec. 13-71. Application For Permit:
   (a)   No person shall dig, excavate, remove, cut or in any manner tunnel
under or break the surface of any part of any street, highway, avenue, alley or
right of way unless an excavation permit to do so has been issued by the city
engineer or his designated representative, according to the conditions of this
division. The excavation permit shall show the date of application, the place
of the excavation, the estimated date when the same will be made, the permit
fee and name of the applicant, who shall state that the person has filed with
the city engineer a bond as required in this division.
   (b)   The excavation permit shall be void ten (10) days after the date of
issue if the initial work has not been started, and the person granted the
permit shall perform the work with all possible speed. From the time the public
right of way is excavated, the permit holder shall have seven (7) workdays
(weather permitting) to complete all work, including the permanent pavement
patch. The permit shall always be in the possession of the person in charge of
the work allowed, or in the possession of the individual working at the
location so that the permit may be produced for inspection at any time upon
request by authorized city officials.
   (c)   A separate excavation permit shall be required for each uninterrupted
alteration of the surface or undersurface of any street, avenue, highway or
alley; provided that when multiple cuts are made at approximately the same time
for purposes of repairing or servicing the underground utilities, one permit
fee shall apply for each three hundred foot (300') section of gas main over
which such multiple cuts are made. Similarly, minimum charges for resurfacing,
provided for hereinafter, shall apply to each such three hundred foot (300')
section.
   (d)   The fee for each permit issued shall be eighty dollars ($80.00), which
shall be paid to the engineering division of the public works department at the
time the permit is issued. No refunds shall be made on excavation permits.
   (e)   In case of a break of a gas main or of other emergency which might in
the opinion of the city engineer prove harmful to the public health or welfare
or cause serious damage, the city engineer or his representative may grant an
"emergency" permit verbally, to be entered subsequently as a written permit as
hereinabove provided.
   (f)   The city engineer shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to
exercise his judgment in the public interest, in the issuance of excavation
permits, with respect to the size, location, specifications and timing of
excavations or other qualifications affecting same. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art.
I; Ord., §§ 1 - 3, 4-12-1976; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987; Ord. 87-34, § 17, 4-
6-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988; Ord. 13-2003, § 1, 2-10-2003; Ord. 013-2009,
§ 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-72. Bond:
   (a)   No person shall be issued an excavation permit unless a bond has been
executed to the city, with a certificate that the bond is presently in full
force and effect, in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with
good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the city engineer and
conditioned on the faithful performance of all duties required by ordinances,
rules and regulations of the city engineer and the city. It shall be a further
condition of the bond that the obligors will hold the city harmless from any
and all damages sustained by reason of neglect or incompetence on the part of
such person in the performance of work done or careless or improper guarding of
excavations made or trenches dug, or by reason of any other cause whatsoever,
growing out of the negligence or carelessness of such person for the issuance
of a permit provided for in this division. The bond shall be further
conditioned that such person will promptly pay the city any and all sums or
amounts due or that may become due or owing by reason of, and under the terms
and conditions of this division, and in the manner and at the time or place as
provided for herein.
   (b)   No person shall be issued an excavation permit whose bond shall not
have been filed and approved as herein set forth, provided, that a plumber who
has executed a bond as provided in the plumbing ordinance and which contains
all of the conditions set forth in this division, shall be considered to have
met the requirements for bond. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 21,
3-23-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988)
Sec. 13-73. Notification Before Improvement:
Whenever improvement of any street, avenue, highway or alley is ordered by the
city council, it shall be the duty of the city engineer or his designee to
notify all pertinent utility companies and all property owners abutting the
improvements and other interested persons of such order advising them to take
steps, prior to the construction of said improvement, to perform all desired or
necessary excavations for placing pipes, conduits, sewers, wires or other
facilities in such public ways under, over, on or adjacent to the improvement.
Such persons so notified shall make such excavations before the improvement
work is begun, or at such time deemed convenient by the city engineer prior to
completion of the improvement. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 21,
3-23-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988)
Sec. 13-74. Backfilling And Resurfacing-By Private Utility Companies:
Private utility companies shall be responsible for backfilling, resurfacing and
safeguarding excavations made by these companies in street rights of way, and
also backfilling and safeguarding excavations made on boulevards or other city
property. These companies shall be liable for the maintenance of backfilling
and resurfacing for a period of four (4) years after the date the permit is
issued for the excavations, and shall hold the city harmless for all claims for
damages that may result because of excavations during that period. Backfilling
and resurfacing shall be done in accordance with specifications provided by the
city engineer. The sinking or deterioration within the aforesaid period of
years shall be held to be the responsibility of the utility company, who shall
upon direction of the city engineer reexcavate and properly refill and
resurface the street cut. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-
1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988; Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-75. Backfilling And Resurfacing - By Others:
The excavation permit holder shall be responsible for backfilling, resurfacing
and safeguarding excavations in the city right of way, and also backfilling and
safeguarding excavations made on boulevards or other city property. The
excavation permit holder shall be liable for the maintenance of backfilling and
resurfacing for a period of four (4) years after the date the permit is issued
for the excavations, and shall hold the city harmless for all claims for
damages that may result because of excavations during that period. The
excavation permit holder shall be responsible for the permanent repairs for a
period of four (4) years after the date the repair is completed. This
responsibility shall include all costs for reopening the street/excavation,
correcting the cause of the problem and replacing the permanent repair.
Backfilling and resurfacing shall be done in accordance with specifications
provided by the city engineer. Permanent repairs may only be conducted by a
licensed, bonded contractor in accordance with article V of this chapter.
      (1)   Inspection Request: The excavation permit holder shall notify the
engineering department twenty four (24) hours in advance of any work to be done
in order that an inspection may be scheduled.
      (2)   Temporary Repairs: All temporary pavement patch repairs shall be
completed as follows:
         a.   Backfill Within Two Feet Of Streets, Alleys, Sidewalks, Driveways
And Other Paved Surfaces: With the exception of the top eight inches (8") of
the excavation, the backfill material shall be sand meeting Illinois department
of transportation gradation FA-6 or an equivalent approved by the city
engineer. The backfill material shall be thoroughly compacted by methods
approved by the city engineer.
         b.   Backfill For Areas More Than Two Feet From Paved Surfaces: The
entire excavation should be backfilled with earthen material free from broken
concrete, asphalt, large rocks or other debris. The backfill material shall be
thoroughly compacted by methods approved by the city engineer.
         c.   Surface Restoration; Paved Surfaces: The excavation permit holder
shall be responsible for placing a temporary pavement patch and/or permanent
pavement patch on all pavement excavations as soon as the repair has been
completed. The temporary patch shall conform to the following minimum
standards:
            1.   Street and alley patches: Two inches (2") of well compacted,
cold mix asphalt placed on six inches (6") of well compacted stone.
            2.   Driveways and sidewalks: Two inches (2") of well compacted,
cold mix asphalt.
            3.   All temporary pavement patches completed between December 1 -
April 1 should be completed using six inches (6") of PCC pavement placed on six
inches (6") of well compacted stone.
The excavation permit holder is responsible for maintaining the temporary
patches until the permanent patch has been completed. During this maintenance
period, the permit holder shall make any repairs as soon as possible after
notification from the city. If the permit holder fails to make the necessary
repairs within twenty four (24) hours, the city will make the repairs and
charge the permit holder for all the costs, including any barricading and
signing necessary to protect the public.
         d.   Surface Restoration Outside Paved Areas: All areas disturbed by
the construction shall be resodded or reseeded at the discretion of the
adjacent property owner. Unless other arrangements can be documented, the
permit holder is responsible for watering the restored area until the new
growth is well established. (Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-76. Service Classification:
   (a)   There shall be a charge by the city for the following services
rendered for the repair of excavations at rates to be set from time to time by
the city council:
      (1)   Saw cutting.
      (2)   Pavement removal and PCC replacement.
      (3)   Pavement removal and PCC replacement with bituminous surface.
      (4)   Pavement removal and brick replacement.
      (5)   Pavement removal and seal coat replacement.
      (6)   Pavement removal and PCC sidewalk replacement.
      (7)   Pavement removal and PCC driveway replacement.
      (8)   Adjust castings.
      (9)   Construction inspection.
   (b)   The public works department shall compute the amounts to be billed
based on the above schedule of charges and shall promptly mail invoices to the
persons named on the excavation permits, itemizing the services rendered in
behalf of each permittee and the charges therefor.
   (c)   Services rendered in behalf of the city's sewer and water utilities
shall be charged against the sewer and water operation and maintenance funds
respectively at the same rates as provided for above with the amounts credited
to the engineering fund. Such payments and credits shall constitute interfund
transfers. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord., § 1, 9-3-1964; Ord., § 4, 4-12-
1976; Ord., § 1, 2-9-1981; Ord. 87-22, § 13, 3-23-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-
1988)
Sec. 13-77. Barricades And Signs, Etc.:
The excavation permit holder shall ensure that the work is performed with
minimal inconvenience and safety hazard to the public. The permit holder shall
provide, erect, and maintain all barricades and signs necessary to protect the
work and the public. If the signing and barricading at any excavation is found
to be inadequate and the permit holder is unable or unwilling to correct the
problem immediately, the city will make the necessary corrections; and all the
costs for this work will be charged to the permit holder.
No street or alley may be closed without the permission of the city engineer.
Fire hydrants, gutters, and storm inlets adjacent to the work may not be
obstructed without the permission of the city engineer. (Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-
1988)
Secs. 13-78-13-79. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. ROLL-OFF CONTAINERS
Sec. 13-80. Application For License:
   (a)   No person shall place a roll-off box, storage cube or similar
container on the property of the city of Rock Island without a license issued
by the city engineer.
   (b)   No person shall be issued a license to place containers on the
property of the city of Rock Island until the city engineer has received a
certificate of insurance indicating that the owner of the container has
liability insurance coverage of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
per accident for accidents involving containers placed on the property of the
city of Rock Island and the city of Rock Island is identified as an additional
insured on the insurance policy.
   (c)   The fee for the license shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per
calendar year.
   (d)   The placement and condition of containers placed on the property of
the city of Rock Island must comply with the city of Rock Island roll-off
container policy in section 13-82 of this division. (Ord. 051-2006, § 1, 7-24-
2006)
Sec. 13-81. Correction Of Deficiencies:
   (a)   In the event that a container is located on the property of the city
of Rock Island in violation of this division or the city of Rock Island roll-
off container policy, the public works department may correct the deficiency or
remove the container without prior notice to the container owner.
   (b)   Within thirty (30) days after correction of the deficiencies or
container removal, the city engineer shall notify the owner of the container of
the costs of the deficiency correction or container removal, including
administrative costs, and the deadline for payment.
   (c)   The city attorney is authorized to and may initiate litigation in the
small claims court of the 14th judicial circuit to recover costs. In addition,
the city may contract with any licensed collection agency for the collection of
the costs and the collection agency may recover from the property owner, in
addition to those sums, reasonable collection expenses, including court costs
and attorney fees. (Ord. 051-2006, § 1, 7-24-2006)
Sec. 13-82. Roll-Off Container Policy:
Effective September 1, 2006, roll-off boxes, storage cubes and similar
containers ("container") may be placed on city property under the following
conditions:
      (1)   The owner of the container must have a valid license to place
containers on city property issued by the city engineer.
      (2)   The container must have legible markings indicating the name and
business address of the owner and a twenty four (24) hour emergency contact
telephone number.
      (3)   The container may not impede use of a sidewalk, alley or driveway.
      (4)   The container may not be placed within ten feet (10') of a fire
hydrant.
      (5)   The container may not be placed within twenty feet (20') of an
intersection.
      (6)   If placed on a street, the container must be placed in a legal
parking area within one foot (1') of the curb or edge of the roadway.
      (7)   The container must have reflective stripes and/or reflectors on all
corners that are clearly visible at night to approaching motorists.
      (8)   The outside of the container must be clean and free of graffiti.
      (9)   The container may not create a safety hazard.
      (10)   Containers may not remain on city property for more than fourteen
(14) consecutive days without the written approval of the city engineer.
In the event that a container on city property violates this policy, the public
works department may correct the deficiency or remove the container and the
container owner will be responsible for the costs. (Ord. 051-2006, § 1, 7-24-
2006)
Sec. 13-83. Criminal Penalties:
Any person violating this division shall, upon an adjudication of guilt or a
plea of no contest, be fined a minimum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
to a maximum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). Each separate
day on which a violation is committed or continues shall constitute a separate
offense. (Ord. 051-2006, § 1, 7-24-2006)
Secs. 13-84-13-90. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. SIDEWALKS 3
 
Notes
3 65 ILCS 5/11-84-1 et seq.
Sec. 13-91. Penalty:
Every violation of any provision of this article shall subject the offender to
a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00), and not more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00), for each offense. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. II)
Sec. 13-92. Permits For Sidewalks, Drives, Curb Cuts 4 :
   (a)   No person shall construct a sidewalk, driveway entrance or curb or cut
a curb on a public right of way in the city without first having obtained a
written permit therefor issued by the director of public works or his
designated representative, and unless such person shall hold a valid concrete
flat work license in accordance with article V of this chapter. The fee for a
permit for construction of driveway entrances or sidewalks shall be three cents
($0.03) per square foot with a minimum fee of sixty five dollars ($65.00). The
fee for a permit for cutting a curb shall be sixty five dollars ($65.00) for
each twenty five (25) continuous feet of curb or fraction thereof. Prior to
obtaining a permit for such construction the applicant shall submit to the
director of public works or his designated representative a rough sketch
showing the contemplated construction with dimensions and measurements
indicating proposed location, extent and type of work to be done. The director
of public works or his designated representative shall set line, grade and
specifications for all sidewalks, driveway entrances and curbs on public
property, and he shall provide for proper inspection of construction of
sidewalks, driveway entrances and curbs and of curb cutting.
   (b)   No permit or fee shall be required for the construction of sidewalks
in new subdivisions, provided such sidewalks are shown on the approved
subdivision plans and are located on property to be dedicated to the city in
conjunction with such subdivision approval, and provided further that such
sidewalk or driveway entrances are actually constructed at the same approximate
time that the other street improvements are constructed, pursuant to the city's
regulations governing new subdivisions.
   (c)   When a driveway entrance is constructed, or a curb is cut to permit a
driveway entrance, any existing sidewalk must be removed, and the area where
the sidewalk existed shall be repaved according to specifications of the
director of public works or his designated representative and it shall then be
considered as part of the driveway entrance. In such case, a sidewalk permit
shall not be required but only a permit for a driveway entrance. (1963 Code,
ch. XIII, art. II; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987; Ord. 87-34, § 18, 4-6-1987;
Ord. 91-14, §§ 4, 5, 2-11-1991; Ord. 99-08, § 1, 2-15-1999; Ord. 13-2003, §§ 2,
3, 2-10-2003; Ord. 013-2009, § 2, 2-2-2009; Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)

4 See also appendix B, "Subdivisions", of this code.
Sec. 13-93. Concrete Flat Work Bonds  2  :
(Rep. by Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)

Sec. 13-94. Construction:
All sidewalks shall be laid to the line and grade of, and shall conform to, the
specification of the director of public works or his designated representative.
(1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 13-95. Width:
Sidewalks hereafter constructed in the city shall be of cement or concrete and
shall have the following minimum widths in the territory described:
      (1)   In areas zoned for single-family residence four feet (4').
      (2)   In areas zoned for multiple-family use, five feet (5').
      (3)   In areas zoned for commercial or business use, ten feet (10').
Whenever the right of way so permits in residential zones, the sidewalks shall
be constructed so that the edge nearest the property line is not less than one
foot (1') from the property line. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II)
Sec. 13-96. Location Of Gutters, Shade Trees:
All gutters hereafter constructed shall be located on the lines between that
part of the street devoted to vehicle travel and that part set off for sidewalk
purposes. No trees shall be planted or placed in any street, boulevard or
parkway in the city unless authorized by the city. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art.
II)
Sec. 13-97. Damage To Sidewalks:
If any person shall break or otherwise damage any tile, concrete, brick, plank
or any part of any sidewalk, footpath or curbing, he shall within twenty four
(24) hours thereafter cause the same to be well and sufficiently repaired and
mended; and no person shall break, damage or remove any concrete, brick, tile,
stone or plank, or any part or portion of any walks in the city, except for the
purpose of replacing the same with new material, under the direction of the
director of public works or his designated representative and in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 87-22,
§ 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 13-98. Stoops, Platforms, Railings, Cellar Doors:
No stoop, porch, platform, railing, cellar door or steps shall be allowed to
extend from any building or lot into or upon any sidewalk; nor shall any cellar
door rise or project above the surface of the sidewalks; however, upon good
cause shown, the city council may grant a permit to owners of commercial
buildings to make an opening on the sidewalks adjacent to their property if the
opening is adequately covered and sufficiently protected when open in a manner
that is satisfactory to the director of public works or his designated
representative and the owner makes a written agreement to hold the city
harmless for any liability arising out of the opening and has insurance
coverage for the liability in an amount satisfactory to the director of public
works or his designated representative. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 87-
22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 13-99. Windows, Showcases, Steps:
No bay window or other window shall extend into, upon or over any sidewalk, nor
shall any sign, except as provided in this code, nor shall any show bill,
showcase or other thing be placed upon or project over the sidewalk in front of
or from the wall of any building, nor shall any steps be hereafter constructed
or placed upon or over any sidewalk, street or other public way. (1963 Code,
Ch. XIII, Art. II)
Sec. 13-100. Personal Property On Public Sidewalks:
   (a)   No person shall place upon or suspend over any sidewalk, any goods or
merchandise, or cause or permit the same to be done or place or deposit on any
sidewalk, or cause or permit the same to be done, any personal property of any
nature whatsoever.
   (b)   Newspaper vending machines may be allowed on sidewalks after the owner
thereof receives prior authorization from the city clerk subsequent to the
submission of a liability insurance policy with limits approved by the city
attorney. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 83-25, § 1, 7-11-1983)
Sec. 13-101. Painting, Etc.:
No person shall paint, paste, post, print or nail any handbill or sign, poster,
advertisement or notice of any kind, or other matter or thing whatever, on, nor
in any manner whatever deface any curbstone, or any part or portion of any
sidewalk, or any tree, lamppost, telegraph pole, electric light pole, hydrant,
public building or any other thing or any private wall, door, building, gate or
fence. The owner of any sign, poster or advertisement placed in violation of
this section shall also be guilty of the violation if he knew or should have
known that the sign, poster or advertisement was placed on his behalf in
violation of this section. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 058-2005, § 1,
7-11-2005)
Secs. 13-102-13-115. Reserved:
ARTICLE V. FLAT WORK LICENSES
Sec. 13-116. Licenses For Sidewalks, Driveways, Curb Cuts, Excavation Repairs:
No person shall construct a sidewalk, driveway entrance or curb, cut a curb, or
conduct a permanent excavation repair on a public right of way in the city
unless such person shall hold a valid concrete flat work license, which may be
obtained from the director of public works or his designated representative by
filing a concrete flat work license application along with a current concrete
flat work bond and a license application fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00).
(Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-117. Concrete Flat Work Bonds:
Every person engaging in the business of the construction of concrete walks,
driveway entrances or curbs, conducting permanent utility repairs, or any
property owner installing his own sidewalks, driveway entrances or curbs before
entering upon the construction of any such concrete flat work in or upon any
public street or avenue in the city, shall file with the director of public
works a bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) running to
the city with sureties to be approved by the director of public works,
conditioned upon obligated satisfactory performance of all duties required by
the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city council, and that he will
suitably guard and protect any excavation or obstruction and defend, save, keep
harmless and indemnify the city from all actions, costs, damages and expenses
whatsoever, including attorney fees, which shall or may at any time happen to
come to it for or on account of any injuries or damages received or sustained
by any person or persons, caused by any negligence in either the execution or
protection of the work being done, and guarantee the material and workmanship
of the concrete flat work for a period of four (4) years ensuing after the date
of its acceptance by the public works department. The bond shall be approved by
the director of public works or his designated representative before being
filed. The bond shall be on file in the public works department and shall be
renewed from year to year during the time of work of concrete flat work as
above referred to. (Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
ARTICLE VI. RESPONSIBLE BIDDER
Sec. 13-118. Defining Responsible Bidder:
The definition of responsible bidder is expanded in the case of bidders for
construction projects, new facilities or renovation of current facilities and
road projects over twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00).
In determining who is the lowest responsible bidder, the city may consider
those factors set out in 55 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1022(b).
Additionally, the city may also consider the following factors in determining
who is the lowest bidder:
      (1)   Certificate/proof to transact business within the state of
Illinois.
      (2)   Evidence of compliance with:
         a.   Federal employer tax identification number or social security
number (for individuals).
         b.   "Equal opportunity employer" provisions.
      (3)   Certificates of insurance indicating the following coverages:
general liability, workers' compensation, automobile, hazardous occupation,
product liability and professional liability.
      (4)   Participation in apprenticeship and training programs applicable to
the work to be performed on the project which are approved and registered with
the United States department of labor's office of apprenticeship and training.
The required evidence includes a copy of all applicable apprenticeship
standards and agreements for any apprentice(s) who will perform work on the
public works project.
      (5)   Compliance with all the provisions of the Illinois prevailing wage
act, including wages, medical and hospitalization insurance and retirement for
those trades as covered in the act.
      (6)   Disclosure of the names and addresses of each subcontractor from
whom the contractor has accepted a bid and/or intends to hire on any part of
this project.
      (7)   A copy of the written program for the prevention of substance
abuse.
         a.   The bidder shall certify that only workers that are enrolled and
tested in company based controlled substance and alcohol testing programs will
be allowed to participate on the project.
      (8)   Statements as to past performances, which shall give an accurate
and complete record of all work projects completed in the last three (3) years
by the contractor.
      (9)   The contractor and officers of the contractor disclose any tax lien
or delinquency in the last five (5) years.
      (10)   Bidder shall certify that all employees expected to perform work
on the project have completed a ten (10) hour or greater OSHA safety program
within the last five (5) years. Only workers that have satisfactorily completed
a ten (10) hour or greater OSHA safety program will be allowed to participate
on the project. The bidder must have copies of employee OSHA cards on file, and
the city may request the bidder provide copies of employees' OSHA cards;
failure to produce an employee's OSHA card may result in a determination that
the bidder is not a responsible bidder.
      (11)   Bidder shall demonstrate the efforts taken to employ local workers
with strong consideration given to bidders employing residents of the city of
Rock Island.
      (12)   Bidder provides written record of compliance with state of
Illinois DBE requirements for public works projects, including the hiring of
women and minority workers to perform the contracted work.
      (13)   Any other factors which are relevant to the determination of a
bidder's ability to carry out the requirements of the project in accordance
with what may be expected or demanded under the terms of the contract.
It shall be the sole responsibility of the contractor to comply with all the
submission requirements at the time it submits its bid to the city of Rock
Island.
(Ord. 052-2016, 11-21-2016)
Sec. 13-119. Reserved:
ARTICLE VII. PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY
Sec. 13-120. Purpose:
   The purpose of this Article is to prohibit the obstruction of public rights-
of-way and establish the City’s authority to remove any unauthorized items to
ensure free and safe access to public spaces.
(Ord. 57-2025, 6-10-2025)
Sec. 13-121. Definitions:
   For the purpose of this chapter:
   Public Right-of-Way shall mean any area legally dedicated for public use,
including but not limited to streets, sidewalks, alleys, pathways, ravines, and
other spaces accessible by the public for passage or use.
   Obstruction shall mean any item, object, or debris, including but not
limited to junk, scrap, equipment, trailers, recreational vehicles, boats,
structures, and construction materials, that partially or wholly blocks,
restricts, or impedes free passage along the public-right-of way.
(Ord. 57-2025, 6-10-2025)
Sec. 13-122. Prohibition Against Obstruction:
   (a)   No person or entity shall place, store, deposit, or otherwise leave
any item that obstructs any portion of the public right-of-way unless otherwise
permitted by the City under a valid permit, license, or written agreement.
   (b)   This prohibition applies to, but is not limited to, obstructions in
the right-of-way related to adjacent business activities or personal use.
   (c)   This section does not apply to vehicles legally parked on public
streets.
(Ord. 57-2025, 6-10-2025)
Sec. 13-123. City’s Right to Remove Obstructions:
   (a)   Authorization to Remove: The City or its designated agents have the
right to remove or cause to be removed any item obstructing the public-right-of
way without prior notice if such item poses an immediate hazard or threat to
public safety.
   (b)   Notice of Violation: In cases where an obstruction does not pose an
immediate hazard, the City may issue a notice to the responsible party to
remove the item within three (3) days. Failure to comply may result in the City
removing the obstruction at the owner’s expense.
   (c)   Cost Recovery: The City shall be entitled to recover all reasonable
costs associated with the removal, storage, and disposal of any obstruction.
Unclaimed items may be disposed of after seven days by the City.
(Ord. 57-2025, 6-10-2025)
Sec. 13-124. Penalties:
   Any individual or entity found in violation of this Ordinance shall be
subject to a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation,
day for day, for as long as the item impedes the public-right-of way, in
addition to any costs incurred by the City for the removal of obstructions.
(Ord. 57-2025, 6-10-2025)
Sec. 13-125. Enforcement:
   Unless otherwise in conflict with this Article, the City shall follow the
procedures outlined in Chapter 10, Article VI, Sec.
10-107, “Administrative Adjudication of Violations of City Ordinances” before
imposing any fine or cost of removal.
(Ord. 57-2025, 6-10-2025)
ARTICLE XIII. MUNICIPAL GROCERY OCCUPATION TAXES
Sec. 15-126. Municipal Grocery Retailers' Occupation Tax Imposed:
   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
groceries at retail in this municipality at the rate of one percent (1%) of the
gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this
section is in effect. The imposition of this tax is in accordance with and
subject to the provisions of Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-24).
(Ord. 46-2025, 4-29-2025)
Sec. 15-127. Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax:  
   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the
business of making sales of service, who, as an incident to making those sales
of service, transfer groceries as an incident to a sale of service. The rate of
this tax shall be the same rate identified in division (a), above. The
imposition of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of
Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24).
(Ord. 46-2025, 4-29-2025)
Sec. 15-128. Illinois Department of Revenue to Administer Both Taxes:  
   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an
incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue
of the State of Illinois. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full
power to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 46-2025, 4-29-2025)
Sec. 15-129. Clerk to file Ordinance with Illinois Department of Revenue:  
   As required under Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/
8-11-24), the Clerk is hereby directed to file a certified copy of this chapter
with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before or October 1, 2025.
(Ord. 46-2025, 4-29-2025)
Sec. 15-130. Effective Date:
   The taxes imposed by this Ordinance shall take effect on the later of:
   (a)   January 1, 2026;
   (b)   The first day of July next following the adoption and filing of this
chapter with the Department of Revenue, if filed on or before the preceding
April 1st; or,
   (c)   The first day of January next following the adoption and filing of
this chapter with the Department of Revenue, if filed on or before the
preceding October 1st.
(Ord. 46-2025, 4-29-2025)

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. PARK AND RECREATIONAL SYSTEM
Sec. 14-16. Establishment:
There is hereby established in the city a recreation system in the lands,
public parks or buildings heretofore designated or set apart by the city for
use as playgrounds or recreation centers. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I)
Sec. 14-17. Park And Recreation Board 1 -Creation:
There is hereby established in the city a park and recreation board to be known
as the Rock Island park and recreation board, which board shall consist of six
(6) members to be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the city
council, to serve without compensation. The board shall have the power to
provide, maintain, improve and conduct parks, playgrounds and recreation
centers in the city. Any money appropriated by the city council for such
purposes shall be expended under the board's direction. At the close of each
fiscal year, and at any other time when requested by the city council, the
board shall make a report to the council of all monies received and expended by
the board. The board shall use the central accounting facilities provided by
the city clerk's office. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. II; Ord. 001-2017, 1-23-
2017)
 
Notes
1 65 ILCS 5/11-95-3.
Sec. 14-18. Park And Recreation Board-Term Of Office 2 :
The term of office of the members of the park and recreation board shall be for
a period of five (5) years or until their successors are appointed and
qualified, except that the members of the board first appointed shall be
appointed for such terms that the term of one member shall expire annually
thereafter. If any vacancy occurs in the office of any member, the mayor shall
appoint a successor to serve for the unexpired term. (1963 Code, ch. III, art.
I)
 
Notes
2 65 ILCS 5/11-95-3.
Sec. 14-19. Park And Recreation Board-Oath And Bond 3 :
Each member appointed to the park and recreation board shall before entering
upon the duties of his office take the oath of office required by law and shall
execute to the city a bond in a sum not less than five hundred dollars
($500.00), with one or more sureties, to be approved by the city council,
conditioned as required by law. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I)
 
Notes
3 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
Sec. 14-20. Park And Playground Rules:
   (a)   No person, in any park or playground in the city, shall:
      (1)   Permit unleashed and/or unaccompanied animals on any such premises.
      (2)   Throw stones or missiles by hand, slingshot or otherwise.
      (3)   Carry or discharge firearms or set off fireworks. This prohibition
against discharge of a firearm as provided herein shall not apply to the
hunting of deer with a bow and arrow in accordance with the provisions of
subsection 10-9(d) of this code.
      (4)   Cut, mark, break, climb upon or in any way injure or deface trees,
shrubs, plants, flowers, buildings, fences, bridges or other structures or
property, whether real or personal, on any such premises.
      (5)   Remove from any such premises sod, trees, plants or other movable
property, or pick flowers of any kind on any such premises.
      (6)   Race with horses, bicycles, automobiles, motorcycles or similar
vehicles; drive or ride on drives on any such premises at more than fifteen
(15) miles per hour; nor shall horseback riding be permitted except on
established bridle paths.
      (7)   Sell, consume or be in possession of beer, wine or other
intoxicating liquor, or enter or be upon the premises of any park or playground
while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. The sale and possession of
beer, wine or other intoxicating liquor is permitted if it is purchased from
employees of the Rock Island park and recreation department or from a qualified
vendor or licensee issued a temporary liquor license, and only in those areas
previously so designated by the Rock Island park and recreation board. The Rock
Island park and recreation board may also approve the "gifting" of liquor for
private rentals at previously designated park and recreation areas or
facilities as stipulated by operational policy. After receiving approval by the
park and recreation board, all applications for "gifting" of liquor at a
private rental must be received by the liquor commissioner's office no later
than seven (7) days in advance of the scheduled event. Upon approval, an
approval letter from the liquor commissioner will be sent to the applicant and
the policy department.
      (8)   Lie or sleep on tables or benches on any such premises.
      (9)   Tell fortunes or play any games of chance.
      (10)   Distribute circulars or advertisements or post notices, bills or
other paper upon any structures or tree on any such premises, or advertise by
any other means.
      (11)   Take any bird eggs or bird nests; fish in the lagoons, unless
permitted at such times as designated by the park and recreation board; kill or
disturb any waterfowl, birds or wildlife.
      (12)   Light any fires on any such property other than in established
fireplaces.
      (13)   Place ashes, garbage, papers or rubbish of any kind on any such
premises other than in containers provided for that purpose.
      (14)   Drive or park motor vehicles on the grass areas.
      (15)   Wear inappropriate clothing. Bathing clothes are permitted in
established bathing pool areas.
      (16)   Be on any premises between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., unless authority is granted and the party is under
proper supervision. The playgrounds will be open and closed for use at the
direction of the playground supervisor, and anyone in the playgrounds when they
are closed will be considered as trespassing on such property.
      (17)   No golf shall be played in any of the parks, nor shall practicing
of golf be permitted, except in areas designated by the park board.
      (18)   No baseball or softball games shall be permitted, except in areas
established for the playing of such games.
      (19)   Conduct himself in a disorderly manner in any building or within
any such premises.
      (20)   Allow any boats with motors in or operated in Lake Potter in
Sunset Park north of a line across the neck of the lake, which is marked with
buoys and a rope, other than in areas specifically designated therefor.
      (21)   Waterski, water plane, swim or ride a surfboard within Lake Potter
in Sunset Park or in the channel connecting the lake with the Mississippi River
except for events approved by the Park Board.
      (22)   Operate a motorboat at a speed in excess of eight (8) miles per
hour within Lake Potter or in the channel connecting the lake with the
Mississippi River.
      (23)   Drive a tractor or tractor and semitrailer through any park in the
City nor park any tractor or tractor and semitrailer in any park in the City
without the specific authorization of the City Council.
      (24)   Operate a bicycle or motorized vehicle on the Sunset Park "walk-
jog" path.
      (25)   Allow a dog to litter on the Sunset Park "walk-jog" path.
      (26)   Fish off any of the docks in Sunset Marina or Schwiebert
Riverfront Park.
      (27)   Be in or upon that portion of Sunset Marina in Sunset Park as
described on exhibit A on file with the City Clerk and made a part of this
section by reference, except those persons who have boats and have leased
docking area in Sunset Marina or their invited guests and suppliers and
customers of the City's lessees.
      (28)   Dock overnight, or use a courtesy dock for more than a four (4)
hour period, except for marina facilities designated for that purpose.
      (29)   Boats may not be left unattended for more than ten (10) minutes at
boat ramp docks.
      (30)   Sell merchandise, goods, services, food or other articles in any
City park without the written permission of the Park and Recreation Director.
      (31)   Enter any secured, enclosed structure owned or controlled by the
Park Board, or under the supervision of the Park Board without the written
permission of the Park and Recreation Director.
      (32)   Hold any boating event, fishing tournaments, contest or
competition which uses boats, sailboats, or other craft on Potter Lake without
written permission of the Park Board.
      (33)   Park for more than three (3) hours at a time at the Lincoln Park
tennis court lot, the Webber Park parking lot, or other lots designated with
specific time limits.
      (34)   Disobey posted parking requirements, unless otherwise authorized
by the Park and Recreation Director or the Park and Recreation Board.
      (35)   Raft boats together while tied to a dock or ramp.
      (36)   Drink alcoholic beverages while on the docks or ramps.
      (37)   Grill or cook on the docks or ramps.
      (38)   Swim or dive off of any docks or ramps.
      (39)   Congregate, sunbathe, picnic or loiter on the docks.
      (40)   Allow unattended children on the docks.
      (41)   Block access on the docks.
      (42)   Dock a boat after twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight at Schwiebert
Riverfront Park without first obtaining permission to do so from the Park
Board.
      (43)   Use the docks during Park Board approved special events.
      (44)   Fish off of Potter's Lake boat ramp docks. Fishing is only allowed
off of Potter's Lake pedestrian docks.
   (b)   The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this section
shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). In the event a person is accused of a
violation of this section and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to
the time a complaint is issued for the violations, the person so accused may
pay to the City, at police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of seventy five
dollars ($75.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation. (1963 Code, ch.
III, art. I; Ord., 7-12-1976; Ord., 10-25-1976; Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord., 2-8-
1982; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984; Ord. 87-65, 8-10-1987; Ord. 88-03, 1-4-1988; Ord.
99-88, 11-8-1999; Ord. 025-2007, 4-9-2007; Ord. 034-2009, 5-4-2009; Ord. 083-
2011, 11-7-2011; Ord. 063-2013, 11-18-2013; Ord. 030-2014, 3-24-2014; Ord. 056-
2018, 9-24-2018)
Sec. 14-21. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any
ordinance designating the names and boundaries of City parks, and all such
ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the
same extent as if set out at length in this Code. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I)
Sec. 14-22. Special Use Activity:
No special use activity shall take place in any park, playground, special
facility or other property under jurisdiction of the Park and Recreation Board
without the issuance of a special use permit by the Park and Recreation Board.
Any person or organization desiring to have a special use activity shall submit
a special use application to the Park and Recreation Board for review and final
disposition. The board shall consider the special use application at its first
meeting held after the filing of said application. The board shall have the
authority to establish a fee for the special use facility commensurate with
their costs to the Rock Island Park and Recreation Department. For the purpose
of this section, a "special use" activity shall be defined as any activity,
event, speech, gathering, observance, ceremony or entertainment event not
sponsored by the Rock Island Park and Recreation Department. This type of
activity is distinguished from "routine use" by:
      (1)   The use of the facility is not within the intended use of the
facility and such use restricts or limits the intended use of a park facility
by the general public;
      (2)   The use of additional mechanical equipment, portable generators,
staging, tentage, food dispensing equipment, loudspeakers, or other items not
available on the site; or
      (3)   The advertising and promotion of the activity, identifying the park
location as the site of the event.
Any person, firm, corporation or organization violating the provisions of this
section shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 88-39, 7-11-1988)

2 75 ILCS 5/1-1, 5/1-6.
Sec. 14-37. Board Of Directors-Created 3 , 4 :
There is hereby created a board of directors to consist of nine (9) members for
the Rock Island Public Library. The board of directors shall be appointed by
the mayor with the approval of the city council as provided by state statute,
and shall be chosen from the citizens at large, with reference to their fitness
for such office, and not more than one member of the city council shall be at
any one time a member of the board. Directors shall hold office for three (3)
years as provided by law. The mayor may remove any board member on any formal
charge as provided by law. Vacancies in the board of directors occasioned by
removals, resignation or otherwise shall be reported to the mayor and be filled
in like manner as original appointments. No director shall receive compensation
as such. (1963 Code, ch. II, art. III)

Sec. 14-39. Penalty For Injury To Or Failure To Return Library Materials 1 :
Any person who shall carelessly, wilfully or maliciously cut, tear, write upon,
deface, injure or destroy any book, pamphlet, periodical, newspaper, plate,
picture, engraving or any other property or thing of value belonging to or
under the control of the Rock Island public library and reading room or who
shall fail to return thereto any book, pamphlet, periodical, newspaper, plate,
picture, engraving or any other thing of value belonging to or under the
control of the library and reading room, according to the requirements of the
bylaws and rules thereof, or after a notice so to do, shall be subject to a
fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than one hundred dollars
($100.00). All such fines shall, when collected, be paid to the city treasurer
and by him credited to the library fund. (1963 Code, Ch. III, Art. II)

Sec. 14-71. Establishment; Name:
There is hereby established in the city the Hauberg Civic Center, situated on
the Hauberg homestead in the city, and conveyed by Catherine H. Sweeney and
John H. Hauberg, Jr., to the Hauberg Civic Center Corporation, the stock of all
of which corporation is now owned and possessed by the city. The real estate is
situated in the city, bounded and described as follows:
Beginning at the northeast corner of Section 2, Township 17 North, Range 2 West
of the Fourth Principal Meridian; then south on the section line 965.4 feet,
more or less to the centerline of Thirteenth Avenue, formerly known as Twelfth
Avenue extended east; thence west 334.9 feet more or less to the centerline of
Twenty-third Street produced southerly; thence north 408.2 feet, more or less,
along said centerline, so produced, to the intersection thereof with the
centerline of Twelfth Avenue, formerly known as Eleventh Avenue; thence east
along the centerline of Twelfth Avenue, 178.25 feet; thence north 530.9 feet
along the centerline of alley to township line first abovementioned; thence
east along said township line 168.25 feet to the place of beginning.
Also a parcel in the city, bounded and described as follows:
Beginning at a point on the east side of Twenty-second Street, 541.8 feet south
of the intersection of the township line between Section 35, Township 18 North,
Range 2 West of the Fourth Principal Meridian and Section 2, Township 17 North,
Range 2 West of the Fourth Principal Meridian; thence south 408.2 feet to the
centerline of Thirteenth Avenue, formerly known as Twelfth Avenue extended
east; thence east at right angles 324 feet more or less to the centerline of
Twenty-third Street extended south; thence north at right angles 408.2 feet to
the centerline of Twelfth Avenue; thence west to the point of beginning.
Also Lots 41 and 42 in Hale's Addition to the city, excepting the south 25 feet
thereof, in the county. Subject to a perpetual easement from John H. Hauberg
and Sue D. Hauberg to the city to lay, maintain, operate, repair and remove a
twenty four inch (24") water pipe in a strip of land ten feet (10') in width,
as described in a deed recorded in book 224 of mortgages on page 187 in the
office of the recorder of deeds in and for the county.
(1963 Code, Ch. III, Art. III)
Sec. 14-72. Purpose:
The Hauberg Civic Center shall be used and maintained to promote citizen
activity in the fields of graphic arts, music, literature, dramatics, local and
Indian history, natural history, horticulture, social sciences and such other
cultural, patriotic and educational purposes as may from time to time be deemed
advantageous, and shall be used for meetings of groups interested in the same,
particularly groups that have no headquarters of their own. (1963 Code, Ch.
III, Art. III)
Sec. 14-73. Governing Body 1 :
The Hauberg Civic Center shall be governed by the Rock Island park board who
shall oversee programming, set fees, policy and maintain the building. (1963
Code, Ch. III, Art. III; Ord. 99-88, § 1, 11-8-1999)

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 15-1. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any
ordinance establishing a special service area, and all such ordinances are
hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as
if set out at length in this code. (1984 Code)
Sec. 15-2. Retailers' Occupation Tax:
   (a)   (1) Effective July 1, 2010, a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an
item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this
state's government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one and
twenty five one-hundredths percent (1.25%) of the gross receipts from such
sales made in the course of such business, while this section is in effect; and
      (2)   Effective July 1, 2010, a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged in this municipality in the business of making sales of service, at the
rate of one and twenty five one-hundredths percent (1.25%), effective July 1,
2010, of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by
such serviceman as an incident to sale of service.
      (3)   Such "home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax" and the "home
rule municipal service occupation tax" shall not be applicable on the sales of
food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is
sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been
prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription
medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials,
syringes and needles used by diabetics.
      (4)   The imposition of these home rule taxes are in accordance with the
provisions of 5/8-11-1 and 5/8-11-5, respectively, of the Illinois municipal
code  1  .
   (b)   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed
as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the department of
revenue of the state. The department of revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this section. (Ord. 011-2010, § 1, 3-
8-2010)

1 65 ILCS, as amended.
Sec. 15-3. Service Occupation Tax:
   (a)   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this city in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost
price of all tangible personal property transferred by those servicemen either
in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an
incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-5. The exclusion contained in section 2(e) of the
"service occupation tax act" approved July 10, 1961, as amended  2  , shall not
apply to property within the city. The farm machinery and equipment exclusion
contained in section 3-5 of said act, as amended  3  , shall not apply to
persons engaged in the business of making sale of service within the city.
   (b)   Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service
occupation tax for the benefit of this city shall file, on or before the last
day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue
required by section 9 of the "service occupation tax act" approved July 10,
1961, as amended  4  .
   (c)   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state
department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (1963 Code, ch. X;
Ord., 7-14-1967; Ord., 7-18-1967; Ord., 4-8-1968; Ord., 8-25-1969; Ord., 2-19-
1979; Ord., 1-26-1981)

Sec. 15-4. Use Tax:
   (a)   A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 upon the privilege of using in the city any item of
tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a
retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's
government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price
of such tangible property with "selling price" to have the meaning as defined
in section 2 of the use tax act, approved July 14, 1955  5  .
   (b)   Such tax shall be collected by the state department of revenue for the
city and shall be paid, or an exemption determination must be obtained from the
state department of revenue, before the title or certificate of registration
for the personal property is issued.
   (c)   The farm machinery and equipment exclusion contained in section 3 of
the "use tax act" approved July 14, 1955, as amended  6  , shall not apply to
the privilege of using in the city any item of tangible personal property which
is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a retailer and which is titled or
registered with an agency of this state's government. (Ord., 10-14-1974; Ord.,
1-26-1981)

department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the

2 35 ILCS 155/1 et seq.
Sec. 15-7. Fire Insurance Tax 3  4 :
   (a)   All corporations, companies and associations not incorporated under
the laws of this State and which are engaged in the City in effecting fire
insurance shall pay to the Treasurer of the City a tax or license fee amounting
to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts received by their agency in the City;
and at that rate such corporations, companies and associations shall pay upon
the amount of all premiums which during the year ending on every July 1, shall
have been received for any fire insurance effected or agreed to be effected on
property situated within the City by or with such corporations, companies or
associations, respectively, in accordance with an act of the general assembly
of the State entitled "An act to enable cities, towns and villages, organized
under any general or special law to levy and collect a tax or license fee from
foreign fire insurance companies for the benefit of organized fire
departments".
   (b)   The money paid over to the City as a result of the tax levied by this
Section shall be set aside and appropriated for the maintenance, use and
benefit of the Fire Department. The City Treasurer shall pay the funds received
from the aforementioned tax to the treasurer of the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax
Revenue Administration Board. The Board treasurer will deposit the funds in the
Foreign Fire Insurance Fund, and such funds shall be invested in the same
manner and under the same guidelines as the City investment policies. The funds
shall be under the care and supervision of the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax
Revenue Administration Board as hereinafter created and shall be expended for
the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department. The Board shall, in
accordance with City budget and appropriations procedures, annually prepare a
budget for the funds which shall be considered by the City Council together
with the Fire Department budget, and the approved expenditures shall be
included in the annual budget ordinance.
   (c)   There is hereby established a Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Revenue
Administrative Board which shall consist of seven (7) Trustees. The Fire Chief
shall be a voting Trustee by virtue of rank. The Fire Chief may appoint a
designated proxy in his place for attendance and voting at any meeting as he
sees fit. Six (6) Trustees shall be elected at large by the sworn members of
the Fire Department. The 2010 election subsequent to the revised statute has
established staggered terms for membership. Three (3) Trustee positions shall
be elected annually. Terms subsequent to the 2010 election shall be for two (2)
years. Elected Trustees shall serve until their successor is both elected AND
installed to the Board. If there are an insufficient number of candidates to
fill all Trustee positions, the number of Trustees may be reduced, but no fewer
than three (3) Trustees. Elections and the filling of vacant Trustee positions
shall be in accordance with the Bylaws adopted by the Board.
   (d)   By statute, the Board Officers shall include a Chairman and Secretary/
Treasurer. They will be elected annually during the first meeting following the
general election by the newly installed Trustees of the Board. The Chairman
shall preside over all meetings of the Board as a whole. He will assume
leadership of the Board, and his authority over it will be given through the
Constitution and Bylaws of the Rock Island Fire Department Foreign Fire
Insurance Tax Revenue Administrative Board. In the absence of the Chairman,
meetings will be run by the Secretary/Treasurer, with full authority of the
Chairman. The Secretary/Treasurer shall record and keep accurate minutes of all
meetings conducted by the Board. Additionally, the Secretary/Treasurer shall
also be responsible for the receiving of all funds appropriated to the Board,
and implementing expenditures for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the
department upon the order of the Board. Information kept by the Secretary/
Treasurer for each meeting shall be in accordance with the Bylaws adopted by
the Board.
   (e)   The Board shall have the power to expend money provided by the foreign
fire insurance tax in accordance with written bylaws and to make gifts to the
city of property, supplies or money for the use, maintenance and benefit of the
Fire Department and to adopt bylaws establishing the manner of selection of a
chairman and the other officers of the Board; the rules of procedure for the
conduct of its meetings, the establishment of regular meeting times and places
and the manner of calling special meetings; the authority of its officers, and
other necessary matters dealing with the administration of the Fund; however,
the bylaws may not violate the following:
      (1)   A quorum of four (4) Trustees shall be present to conduct regular
business. A. quorum shall not exist without either the Fire Chief or his
designated proxy, being present.
      (2)   No bylaw or amendment thereto shall be effective until same has
been on file with the City Clerk for at least ten (10) days.
      (3)   The purposes for which funds may, and may not, be expended shall be
in accordance with the Bylaws adopted by the Board.
         a.   The Board shall have the duty to submit to the City Council on or
before January 31 of each year a report detailing meetings, actions, funds
received and funds disbursed for the previous year ending on December 31. In
addition, the Board shall require that accounts be kept in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles for government entities and use a
centralized accounting system provided by the City Finance Department. Further,
no purchase of equipment, supplies or other property shall be made unless upon
the order of the Board.
   (f)   The Board shall have the duty to submit to the City Council on or
before April 30 of each year a report detailing meetings, actions, funds
received and funds dispersed for the previous year ending on March 31. In
addition, the Board shall require that accounts be kept in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles for government entities and use a
centralized accounting system provided by the City Finance Department. Further,
no purchase of equipment, supplies or other property shall be made unless upon
the order of the Fire Department.
   (g)   The Board shall have the duty to require its treasurer to post a
surety bond acceptable to the City in the penal sum of twenty five thousand
dollars ($25,000.00) each conditioned on the faithful performance of the duties
of office and the payment of all monies received by such officer according to
law and ordinance. (1963 Code, Ch. X(I), §§ 1, 2; Ord. 91-19, §§ 1, 2, 2-25-
1991; Ord. 054-2019, 10-28-2019)

ARTICLE III. UTILITY TAX 1
 
Notes

  chapter 16
1  of this code; cable television franchise, appendix C, article I of this code;
