   (b)   Special Fees and Discounts: Elderly/Handicapped Users Discount will
remain the same. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002; Ord. 049-2021, 8-23-2021)
Sec. 16-35. City Collector To Have Charge Of Collections:
The city collector shall have charge of the collection of all water and/or
sewerage service bills. The city collector shall give a receipt for all monies
so paid to him. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-36. Bills And Collection Policies:
   (a)   Billings For Water Service: Billings for water service shall be
rendered by the finance department on a monthly or quarterly basis at the
discretion of the finance department.
   (b)   When A Bill Is Delinquent: If a bill for water service remains unpaid
for thirty (30) days or more after it is rendered, the city may shut off water
service to the property. If the city thereafter records a lien with the
recorder of deeds for the delinquent charges incurred, any subsequent purchaser
who takes title to the property after the lien is recorded, is responsible for
payment of all the delinquent charges and penalties. If water service has been
shut off and a lien has been recorded prior to the new purchaser taking title
to the property, water service shall not be restored to the property until all
delinquent charges and penalties, including shutoff charges, have been paid in
full and arrangements for restoring service has been made with the city. If a
subsequent purchaser of the property takes title after the delinquent charges
have been incurred by the prior owner, but before the city records a lien for
these unpaid charges, the subsequent purchaser shall not be responsible for
payment of the delinquent charges and, if applicable, water service shall be
reinstated to the property. Any unpaid charges for water service incurred by a
prior owner where a lien has not been filed before the property is sold or
transferred to a bona fide purchaser are the responsibility of the prior owner,
and the city retains the right to seek repayment of those charges by means
available to it by law.
   (c)   Notice Of Shutoff For Nonpayment: When city records reflect that
premises are occupied, the water to those premises shall not be shut off for
nonpayment without giving at least five (5) days' notice to the persons
residing therein. The notice shall be given by contacting the persons occupying
the premises personally, or by posting on the front door or in a public hallway
of the property, notice of the proposed shutoff action by the city. The notice
shall comply with 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 735/1.2 et seq. A fee of
thirty five dollars ($35.00) shall be charged for each shutoff notice.
   (d)   Monthly Bills: The city collector may put any water service on a
monthly payment basis, if it is judged to be in the best interest of the city
to do so. In such cases the bills shall be due not less than fifteen (15) days
following the date of the statement.
   (e)   Late Fee: When water bills are not paid on or before the due date
stated on the bill, a penalty of five percent (5%) shall be added. Failure to
receive a bill does not entitle the owner or customer to a remission of
penalty.
   (f)   Billing To Address Other Than Service Address: Written notice must be
given by the owner or authorized agent if it is desired that bills be forwarded
to any other address than the premises supplied.
   (g)   Payment In Advance: The city shall have full power and authority to
require payment in advance for the use of water furnished by it in and upon any
building, place or premises, and in case prompt payment for the same shall not
be made, it may shut off the water from such building, place or premises and
shall not be compelled again to supply the building, place or premises with
water until arrears together with the costs and expense of turning the water
off and on shall be fully paid.
   (h)   Special Service Bill: All bills for installation of special water
service connections or service repairs, special meter reading services and for
the installation and repair of meters shall be payable to the city collector as
soon as such work is completed and the bill is rendered, and if the bills are
not promptly paid, the city water supply may be turned off by the city until
all such bills have been paid.
   (i)   Combined Bill; Partial Payment: The water charge may be billed on a
common statement and collected along with other charges. If the water charge is
included on a common statement and the customer payment is insufficient to pay
the total of all portions of the statement, the payment will be applied
according to the priority shown in section 13-41 of this code.
   (j)   Issuance Of Bills: All water and sewer accounts will be billed as soon
as possible after readings are obtained. Each bill will be due not less than
fifteen (15) days after its issuance.
   (k)   Average Bills: If a current reading is not obtained, an average bill
will be issued, based upon the consumption history of the account. If for any
reason adequate history is not available, a bill will be issued for two
thousand five hundred (2,500) cubic feet of consumption. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-
11-2002; Ord. 029-2008, § 2, 4-21-2008; Ord. 009-2010, § 1, 2-8-2010; Ord. 065-
2012, 10-15-2012; Ord. 091-2014, 12-15-2014)
Sec. 16-37. Adjustment Of Water Charges:
In any case of a dispute over the amount of a bill, or over the accuracy of a
meter, the city shall at the request of the consumer test the meter, in the
presence of the consumer or his agent. If it is found upon such test that the
meter registers a greater amount of water than has actually passed through said
meter (allowing 2 1/2 percent for accuracy) the bill will be adjusted to
conform with the correct amount passing through the meter. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1,
3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-38. Responsibility In Turning On Water Services:
In turning on water services, the city shall not be responsible for any damage
that may occur by reason of improper fixtures, open or improper connections or
for any other causes. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-39. Discontinued Use Of Water:
Owners or customers desiring to discontinue the use of water shall give notice
thereof to the city collector, who shall cause the water to be turned off and
the meter removed. When water service is discontinued, all water and sewer
charges for such service shall become due and payable. A service charge shall
be made at the time service is discontinued, either at the customer's request,
or for nonpayment of charges. A charge fixed by the city council from time to
time shall be made for every special reading requested by a customer. The city
may withhold water supply until all unpaid bills against the property have been
paid. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-40. Water Meters:
   (a)   All water furnished consumers shall be metered other than water used
for construction purposes paid for pursuant to subsection 16-34(a) of this
article. All meters shall be furnished and set by the city or a licensed and
registered plumber but owners must provide a suitable location in the piping
system for same. Meters shall be placed on service pipes in accordance with the
standard drawings provided by the public works department. There shall be a
suitable place provided for the meter so as to keep it dry and clean, protected
from freezing, and readily accessible at all times to the city. All valves and
fittings necessary to comply with the requirements and to provide connection to
the meter, except a coupling or flange at each end of meter, shall be provided
by the owner of premises to be served.
   (b)   For services larger than two inches (2") in diameter, the city
reserves the right to install two (2) or more meters of smaller size. Where
meters are so placed, each meter shall have a valve or shutoff on both inlet
and outlet pipe in addition to the basement shutoff.
   (c)   Where a service pipe larger than two inches (2") in diameter is used,
the plumber shall call at the public works department for instructions
regarding the fittings and space to be provided for the water meters.
   (d)   In case two (2) or more meters are desired for measuring water to
different tenants in the same building from one service connection, they shall
be so placed that no one of them shall measure water which has passed through
another one. Each meter shall be equipped with a separate locking shutoff.
   (e)   Water meters shall be of the size and type necessary to ensure
accurate registration of the water requirements of the premises. Size of meters
for large buildings, apartments or flats shall be designated by the city at the
time of application for water supply, the size of meters so specified by the
city being always subject to change, from time to time, thereafter as the
demand or other conditions may develop to be out of accord with the provisions
of this article. The city reserves the right to require an increase in the size
of the meter, as in these rules provided, in any case where, in the discretion
of the city, the use of water in larger quantities places any meter under undue
or unusual strain. The size of the meter which shall in either event be
required shall be determined by the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-41. Owners To Protect Meters:
   (a)   The owner or occupant of premises where a meter is installed shall be
held responsible for its care and protection from freezing or hot water and
from other injury or interference from any person or persons. In case of any
injury to the meter, or in case of its stoppage or imperfect working, he shall
give immediate notice to the office of the finance department. In all cases in
which meters are broken or damaged by negligence of owners or occupants on
premises, or by freezing, hot water or any other injuries, the necessary
repairs to all city owned meters shall be made by the city, and the costs of
such repairs paid for by the owner or occupant. The charge shall be based on
the amount of damage at the current parts and labor cost, not to exceed the
cost of a new meter. If the meter is found to be damaged beyond repair, it
shall be billed at the current price of a new meter; the cost of such repairs
shall be paid for by such owner or occupant, and in case payment thereof is
neglected or refused, the water supply shall be turned off and shall not be
turned on until full payment has been made, including a fee fixed by the city
for turning on the water again. Damaged meters may be repaired by the city
without first giving notice thereof to the owner of the premises served by such
meter.
   (b)   No person shall in any way interfere with the proper registration of a
water meter, and no person except an authorized employee of the city shall
break a seal of a meter; however, in case of emergency a plumber registered in
the city may break such seal for draining pipes or stopping water leaks. The
plumber shall notify the public works department of this action the next
regular business day after breaking the seal and explain the nature of the
emergency.
   (c)   Whenever a water meter is installed on a water service on premises
that are to be remodeled, removed or destroyed, or where the service is
discontinued so that the water meter is no longer needed, the owner of such
premises shall give notice to the finance department to remove such meter, and
free access to such meter must be provided at least twenty four (24) hours
after notice is given so that the meter may be removed. The owner of the
premises shall be held responsible for the meter until such written notice is
given, and if the meter is covered or lost, he shall be required to pay for the
same at the actual value. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-42. Repairing Meters:
   (a)   Right Of Entry: The city reserves the right at any reasonable time to
enter any premises supplied by the city water and exchange any meter, for
repairs or other cause, as may be deemed necessary by the city.
   (b)   Meters Out Of Order: If any meter, at any time, fails to register the
quantity of water consumed, the same shall be determined and charges made based
on the average quantity registered during the last preceding year prior to the
date of failure, as the city collector shall order and direct. If an average is
not available, a bill will be issued for two thousand five hundred (2,500)
cubic feet of consumption.
   (c)   Leakage: No deduction shall be made on account of leakage after the
water has passed through and been registered by the meter. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1,
3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-43. Unlawful To Obstruct Meters, Etc.:
No person shall in any manner obstruct the access of any stopcock, hydrant,
water meter, dial or valve connected with any water pipes within the city by
means of any rubbish, refuse, building material, fuel or any other article,
thing or hindrance, particularly the obstruction of meters that will interfere
with the ready access to a meter at any and all times. Neglecting to comply
with this provision, the consumer at once becomes liable and the city water
supply will be turned off at the street, after notice has been given, until the
obstruction shall be removed. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-44. Water Lien For Unpaid Water Fees:
Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid for thirty (30) days after it
has been rendered, the unpaid charges can result in the city taking steps to
file a lien with the recorder of deeds reflecting nonpayment of those charges.
Prior to filing a lien, the city shall prepare and send in accordance with
state law, a delinquency notice to the owner of record of the property
receiving the water service, advising the owner that the water fees have become
delinquent and that nonpayment of the outstanding charges and penalties may
create a lien on the property. Said notice of delinquency shall advise the
owner that he or she has seven (7) days from the date of mailing of the notice
to pay all amounts owed or else a notice of lien will be filed with the
recorder of deeds. Said lien shall include any unpaid fees for services
rendered to the property after the mailing of the notice of delinquency. (Ord.
066-2012, 10-15-2012)
Sec. 16-45. Molestation Or Injury To Water Mains:
   (a)   Any person who may be working in any street of this city who may
molest or in any way damage the city water mains, or appurtenances thereto,
shall be responsible to the city for any and all such damages, and he, or his
heirs, representatives or assigns shall bear all expense of such replacement or
repair made necessary thereby, and he shall also be responsible for damage to
surrounding properties on account of the damage to water mains.
   (b)   Whenever any construction is taking place or where digging for any
reason is being done, the public works department shall estimate the location
of underground utility facilities owned by the city in accordance with the
JULIE (joint utility locating information for excavators; Illinois one call
system) obligations mandated by Illinois law. A reasonable charge for any such
service after the initial location above provided for shall be paid by the
person requesting such service. The city shall not be responsible for any costs
incurred by any person or party due to the inaccuracy of estimated locations
provided by the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-46. Fire Hydrants:
   (a)   All fire hydrants except those that are connected directly to an
internal fire protection system that is not owned by the city are hereby
declared to be public hydrants and shall be tested, maintained, repaired and
replaced as needed by the city. If a public fire hydrant is located on private
property, the owner of the private property shall allow the city unrestricted
access for the purpose of testing, maintaining, repairing and replacing the
hydrant.
   (b)   Fire hydrants that are directly connected to an internal fire
protection system that is not owned by the city must be tested and maintained
by the owner of the internal fire protection system in accordance with the
requirements of the fire department.
   (c)   If a public fire hydrant is attached to a water main that is not owned
by the city, the water main shall be maintained at the expense of the owner in
accordance with the requirements of the public works department. If any leaks
or other defects are not properly repaired at the expense of the owner within
ten (10) days after written notice from the public works department, the water
may be turned off by the public works department until such repairs have been
made. The expense of turning off the water shall be charged against such owner
and must be paid before water shall be turned on again.
   (d)   No person other than the members of the fire department, the public
works department or those specially authorized by the public works department
shall open any of the public fire hydrants or attempt to draw water from the
same or in any manner interfere with or injure any of the public fire hydrants
in the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-47. Waste Of Water:
No person shall allow the water to run to waste through defective pipes,
faucets or other fixtures; however, a reasonable time, not exceeding forty
eight (48) hours, shall be allowed to repair the same. In case of neglect or
refusal by the person to cause the fixtures to be repaired, the public works
department may withhold the water supply. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-48. Stopcock And Valve Services:
The city shall not be responsible for any accidents caused by stopcocks or
valve boxes that stand above the surface of the ground, pavement or sidewalks
and the property owners shall keep all stopcocks or valve boxes flush with the
surface at their location. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-49. Inspections Generally:
   (a)   Inspectors, foremen, meter readers or any other employee or agent of
the city whose duty it may be to enter upon private premises to make
inspections and examinations of water meters, pipes, fixtures or appurtenances
thereto, for any reason whatsoever in connection with the city water supply
will be provided with a badge or other credentials to identify them as
authorized agents and representatives of the city.
   (b)   Any officer, inspector, foreman, meter reader or authorized agent or
employee of the city upon presentation of his badge or other credentials
provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be given free access at
any and all reasonable hours to any premises supplied by the city water, for
the purpose of making any inspection thereof pertaining to the water system.
   (c)   In case any authorized agent or employee of the city is refused
admittance to any premises, or being admitted is hindered or prevented in
making such examination, the city may cause the city water supply to be turned
off from the premises after giving twenty four (24) hours' notice to the owner
or occupant of said premises.
   (d)   No person not an authorized agent or employee of the city shall have,
wear or exhibit any badge or credential of the city. It shall be the duty of
every such officer, agent or employee of the city upon resignation or dismissal
forthwith to surrender and deliver to the director of public works all badges
and credentials of the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-50. Connection Between City And Other Supply:
No person shall cause a connection to be made or allow one to exist with the
city water supply for commercial, domestic, sanitary, fire protection or boiler
feed purposes, or for any other purpose whatsoever, where water foreign to the
city water supply is used for a second source of supply. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-
11-2002)
Sec. 16-51. Connections With Other City Systems:
Any water connections now existing between the city and any adjoining city, and
those connections now existing in the industrial district, i.e., the double
check valve connections, shall be allowed to remain until a demand is made by
the city to sever or alter these connections, at which time they shall be
disconnected or changed as directed by such department or departments. (Ord.
18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-52. Installation Of Water Mains:
   (a)   Water mains shall be installed under the standard specifications of
the city for laying water mains and under the supervision and inspection of the
director of public works or his designated representative.
   (b)   All water mains of four inch (4") size or larger now in place or that
may be placed in public right of way or public utility easements, so dedicated,
excluding service and fire protection lines of four inch (4") size and larger,
shall become the donated property of the city. The responsibility, jurisdiction
and maintenance thereof shall thereafter be administered by the city public
works department.
   (c)   The city water mains hereafter installed shall be inspected and tested
by the director of public works or his designated representative. Any water
mains installed without inspection shall be opened by the contractor or plumber
for inspection, at his own expense, at the request of the director of public
works or his designated representative.
   (d)   No contractor or plumber shall turn on or off any valve of four inches
(4") or over, on any city owned water mains without the permission of the
public works department. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-53. Extensions; New Subdivisions:
The following is the policy adopted by the city council in regard to the
extension of water lines to and into new subdivisions of the city:
      (1)   The city council will consider the extension of water and/or sewer
service to the project area, provided a project of adequate magnitude is
proposed to assure a fair return on the city's investment within a reasonable
period of time.
      (2)   Where the line is brought to the project area by the city, the
developer will be expected to extend the line within the project area. Such
extensions must be in accordance with city specifications, must be looped in
accordance with sound hydraulic practices, in all aspects, including pipe sizes
and other approvals, to be under the jurisdiction of the director of public
works or his designated representative. The minimum size of water line
extensions will be eight inch (8") diameter. In those instances in which pipe
sizes specified by the director of public works or his designated
representative exceed eight inches (8"), such requirement will be submitted to
the city council, and if the city council agrees with the need for the larger
diameter line, the city will bear the cost of the difference between an eight
inch (8") line and the larger sized line specified.
      (3)   In the case of all subdivisions and line extensions, the city has
the right to authorize other subdividers to hook onto water lines extended and
installed by another subdivider if, in the opinion of the city engineer, the
lines are adequately sized to handle the added load. If the hook on is to a
line size larger than eight inches (8") in diameter, the city will follow the
same policy with respect to extending the line, as pertains under subsection
(2) of this section.
      (4)   Where the city extends a line at city expense, and at a later time,
properties fronting on the line request permission to hook on, the cost of the
line will be apportioned as follows:
         a.   The city will bear the cost of the line in excess of eight inch
(8") diameter.
         b.   The cost of the eight inch (8") line will be apportioned (1/2 to
each side) to properties fronting on the line. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-54. Water Shortage-Definition:
For the purpose of this article an inadequate supply of water shall be deemed
to exist when the city is unable to refill the reservoirs and storage tanks on
a daily basis because of the high demand for water due to weather conditions or
because the city's water facilities are inadequate to provide the refilling as
aforesaid due to other causes. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-55. Duties Of Manager:
It shall be the duty of the city manager to make a determination that an
inadequate supply of water exists in the city when the refilling process
described in the preceding section is not completed on a daily basis. After
making said determination, the provisions of sections
16-54 and 16-56 of this article shall not be enforced until the city manager
informs the news media of the city of the determination so that the residents
of the city will be notified of the determination. If conditions permit a delay
in enforcement, a notice shall also be published in a newspaper of general
circulation in the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-56. Use Of Water:
No person shall use the city water supply for the watering of lawns or
noncommercial washing of motor vehicles during that period of time when there
exists in the city an inadequate supply of water in the city's reservoirs and
storage tanks due to weather conditions or other causes. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-
11-2002)
Sec. 16-57. Backflow Prevention Device:
All plumbing installed within the city of Rock Island shall be installed in
accordance with the Illinois plumbing code, 77 Illinois administrative code
section 90. If in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code in the judgment of
the public works director, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary
for the safety of the public water supply system, the public works director
will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device
immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an
approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois
plumbing code, Illinois environmental protection agency and all applicable
local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved
devices upon installation and annually thereafter, at a minimum. The owner of
the premises shall maintain records to document that testing, servicing and
repairs are conducted as required.
      (1)   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the city of Rock Island enter the supply or distribution system
of said municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply
and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by
the public works director and the Illinois environmental protection agency.
      (2)   It shall be the duty of the public works director to cause surveys
and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the
public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a
matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years, or
as often as the public works director shall deem necessary. Records of such
surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least
five (5) years.
      (3)   The approved cross connection control device inspector shall have
the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection
to the public water supply or distribution system of the city of Rock Island
for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross connections, and
that the public works director or his authorized agent shall have the right to
enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public
water supply or distribution system of the city of Rock Island for the purpose
of verifying information submitted by the owner, lessees or occupants of any
property so served shall furnish to the public works director any information
which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on
such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within
the discretion of the public works director, be deemed evidence of the presence
of improper connections as provided in this section.
      (4)   The public works director of the city of Rock Island is hereby
authorized and directed to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant
thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation
of the provisions of this section is known to exist, and to take such other
precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of
contamination of the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to
such property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated
or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this section, and until a
reconnection fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) is paid to the city of Rock Island.
Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the director of
public works is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination or
pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the reasonable opinion
of the public works director or the Illinois environmental protection agency,
such action is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or
pollution of the public water supply. Neither the public water supply, the
director of public works, or its agents or assigns shall be liable to any
customer for any injury, damages or lost revenues which may result from
termination of said customer's water supply in accordance with the terms of
this section, whether or not said termination was with or without notice.
      (5)   The consumer responsible for back siphoned material or
contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply
system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed,
maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear
the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. (Ord. 90-37, § 1, 5-21-
1990; Ord. 79-2002, § 1, 9-16-2002)
ARTICLE III. SEWERS 1 , 2
 
Notes
1 See also breaking into, opening, etc., sewers, § 10-36 of this code; sewers
  under railroad tracks, § 13-56 of this code.
2 65 ILCS 5/11-141-1 et seq.
Sec. 16-81. Management Of Sewer:
The management and supervision of the sewer division of the city and any and
all property pertaining thereto shall be under the direction of the director of
public works. In addition to the foregoing, the director of public works shall
perform such other duties as may be required of him by the city manager. (1963
Code, Ch. IX, Art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 16, 3-23-1987; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990)
Sec. 16-82. Definitions:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used
in this article shall be as follows:
   (a)   Federal Government:
      (1)   Federal Act: The federal clean water act (33 USC 466 et seq.) as
amended (Pub. L. 95-217).
      (2)   Administrator: The administrator of the U.S. environmental
protection agency.
      (3)   Federal Grant: The U.S. government participation in the financing
of the construction of treatment works as provided for by title II, grants for
construction of treatment works, of the act and implementing regulations.
   (b)   State Government:
      (1)   State Act: The Illinois antipollution bond act of 1970.
      (2)   Director: The director of the Illinois environmental protection
agency.
      (3)   State Grant: The state participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided for by the state act and for making
such grants as filed with the secretary of state of the state of Illinois.
   (c)   Local Government:
      (1)   City: The city of Rock Island.
      (2)   Approving Authority: The director of public works.
   (d)   Person: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any
individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association,
society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
   (e)   NPDES Permit: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued
by the administrator, or, where appropriated by the director, after enactment
of the federal clean water act to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant
to section 402 of the federal act.
   (f)   Clarification Of Word Usage: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is
permissible.
               (g)      Wastewater And Its Characteristics:
      (1)   Wastewater: The spent water of a community. From this standpoint of
course, it may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from
residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together
with any ground water, surface water, and stormwater that may be present.
      (2)   Sewage: Used interchangeably with "wastewater".
      (3)   Effluent Criteria: Defined in any applicable NPDES permit.
      (4)   Water Quality Standards: Defined in the water pollution regulations
of Illinois.
      (5)   Unpolluted Water: Water quality equal to or better than the
effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of
receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to
the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
      (6)   ppm: Parts per million by weight.
      (7)   Milligrams Per Liter: A unit of the concentration of water or
wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand
milliliters (1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used
commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in
reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis.
      (8)   Suspended Solids (SS): Solids that either float on the surface of
or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are
removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of
suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the
IEPA division of laboratories "Manual Of Laboratory Methods".
      (9)   BOD (Denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand): The quantity of oxygen
utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius (20°C),
expressed in milligrams per liter.
      (10)   pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion
concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA division
of laboratories "Manual Of Laboratory Methods".
      (11)   Garbage: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial
preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and
sale of food.
      (12)   Properly Shredded Garbage: The wastes from the preparation,
cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that
all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally
prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2")
(1.27 centimeters) in any dimension.
      (13)   Floatable Oil: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it
will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved
pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat
if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the
collection system.
      (14)   Population Equivalent: A term used to evaluate the impact of
industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population
equivalent is 0.13 ccf of sewage per day, containing 0.20 pounds of BOD and
0.20 pounds of suspended solids.
      (15)   Slug: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any
period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times
the average twenty four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal
operation.
      (16)   Industrial Waste: Any solid, liquid or gaseous substance
discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing,
commercial or business establishment or process or from the development,
recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary
sewage.
      (17)   Major Contributing Industry: An industrial user of the publicly
owned treatment works that:
         a.   Has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average
workday; or
         b.   Has a flow greater than ten percent (10%) of the flow carried by
the municipal system receiving the waste; or
         c.   Has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in
standards issued under section 307(a) of the federal act; or
         d.   Is found by the permit issuing authority, in connection with the
issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving
the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with
other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of
effluent from that treatment works.
      (18)   ccf: The flow measurement unit of hundred cubic feet.
   (h)   Sewer Types And Appurtenances:
      (1)   Sewer: A pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste
liquids, including stormwater, surface water and ground water drainage.
      (2)   Public Sewer: A sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of
the city. It shall also include sewers within or outside the city boundaries
that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the city sanitary
(or combined) system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed
with city funds.
      (3)   Sanitary Sewer: A sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or
a combination of both, and into which stormwaters, surface waters, and ground
waters or polluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted.
      (4)   Storm Sewer: A sewer that carries stormwater, surface water and
ground water drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than
unpolluted cooling water.
      (5)   Combined Sewer: A sewer which is designed and intended to receive
wastewater, stormwater, surface water and ground water drainage.
      (6)   Building Sewer: The extension from the building drain to the public
sewer or other place of disposal.
      (7)   Building Drain: That part of the lowest piping of a drainage system
which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside
the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other
approved point of discharge, beginning five feet (5') (1.5 meters) outside the
inner face of the building wall.
      (8)   Stormwater Runoff: That portion of the precipitation that is
drained into the sewers.
      (9)   Sewerage: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the
collection, transportation and pumping of sewage.
      (10)   Easement: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land
owned by others.
   (i)   Treatment:
      (1)   Pretreatment: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before
introduction into the wastewater treatment works.
      (2)   Wastewater Treatment Works: An arrangement of devices and
structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge; sometimes
used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant"
or "pollution control plant".
   (j)   Wastewater Facilities: The structures, equipment, and processes
required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and
transport effluent to a watercourse.
   (k)   Watercourse And Connections:
      (1)   Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either
continuously or intermittently.
      (2)   Natural Outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake,
or other body of surface water or ground water.
   (l)   User Types:
      (1)   User Class: The type of user "residential", "institutional",
"governmental", "commercial", or "industrial" as defined herein.
      (2)   Residential User: All dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes,
apartments, and permanent multi-family dwellings.
      (3)   Commercial User: Includes transit lodging, retail and wholesale
establishments, or places engaged in selling merchandise or rendering services.
      (4)   Institutional/Governmental User: Includes schools, churches, penal
institutions, and users associated with federal, state, and local governments.
      (5)   Industrial Users: Includes establishments engaged in manufacturing
activities involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials of
substance into products.
      (6)   Control Manhole: A structure located on a site from which
industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an
interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for the
city representative to sample and/or measure discharges.
   (m)   Types Of Charges:
      (1)   Wastewater Service Charge: The charge per quarter or month levied
on all users of the wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed
as outlined in section
16-85  of this article and shall consist of the total of the basic user charge
and the capital charge.
      (2)   User Charge: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the
cost of operation, maintenance and replacement.
      (3)   Basic User Charge: The basic assessment levied on all users of the
public sewer system.
      (4)   Debt Service Charge: The amount to be paid each billing period for
payment of interest, principal and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding
debt.
      (5)   Capital Improvement Charge: A charge levied on users to improve,
extend or reconstruct the sewage treatment works.
      (6)   Capital Cost Charge: Charges for costs other than the operation,
maintenance and replacement costs, i.e., debt service and capital improvement
costs.
      (7)   Replacement: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment,
accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the
treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works
were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
replacement.
      (8)   Useful Life: The estimated period during which the collection
system and/or treatment works will be operated.
      (9)   Sewerage Fund: The principal accounting designation for all
revenues received in the operation of the sewerage system. (Ord. 90-33, 5-14-
1990)
Sec. 16-83. Sewer Service To Extend Across Entire Frontage:
No person shall extend a City sewer to service his property unless the sewer
line is extended across the entire frontage of the property at the property
owner's expense. In the event compliance with this provision is impossible
because of physical conditions or impractical because of unique circumstances,
the property owner may apply to the City Council for exemption from the
requirements of this section. (Ord., 10-13-1969; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990)
Sec. 16-84. Sewer Charges Generally:
Each user of the City's sewer service shall be charged for usage of the sewage
system at rates established under this article. Where the sewer user is also a
City water user, billing for sewage usage shall be coincidental with the
billing for water usage. In cases where a sewer user is not a water user,
billing shall be made monthly or quarterly as determined by the City Collector.
(1963 Code art. 9-1-3; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990; Ord. 001-2005, 1-17-2005)
Sec. 16-85. Rates Generally:
Sec. 16-85.1. Basis For Wastewater Service Charges:
The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the
wastewater facilities of the City shall consist of a service charge and a
volume charge.

   Sec. 16-85.2. Three-Part Rate: A three-part rate may be levied to those
users whose wastewater varies significantly from normal domestic concentrations
for BOD and SS. The three-part rate would consist of a service charge plus a
unit charge for volume, biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), and total suspended
solids (TSS).
Service charges for customers paying based upon the three-part rate will be
calculated by the Public Works Department on a case by case basis.
The concentration of wastes used for computing BOD and TSS charges shall be
established by waste sampling. Waste sampling shall be performed as often as
may be deemed necessary by the City and shall be binding as a basis for the BOD
and TSS charges. In the event a customer requests to be placed on a three-part
rate schedule, the cost of performing the necessary waste sampling shall be
charged directly to the customer.

Sec. 16-86. Special Rates:
   (a)   Criteria: These special rates may include, among others, where the
nature of the use of City water is such in the opinion of the Director of
Public Works that the resulting sewage or industrial waste has characteristics
making it more or less difficult to treat or purify than ordinary domestic
waste.
   (b)   Measurement Of Flow: The volume of flow used for computing volume
charges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even
increments of one cubic foot.
      (1)   If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures
any part, or all, of his water from sources other than the public waterworks
system, all or part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person
shall install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by
the City for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these
other sources.
      (2)   Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be
required by the City if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the
metered water consumption records.
      (3)   Metering devices for determining the volume of waste, if other than
a City owned water meter, shall be installed, owned and maintained by the
person. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed,
unless service is canceled, without the consent of the City.
   (c)   Dangerous Waste: No sewage or industrial waste having characteristics
tending, in the opinion of the Director of Public Works, to jeopardize the
successful and/or continued operation of the sewage treatment plant or any of
its units, including sewers leading to the same, shall be discharged into the
sewer system. Such waste may be pretreated by the user at his own expense and
discharged into the system. Plans, specifications and design data for the
pretreatment of waste shall be submitted to and approved by the Public Works
Department and by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency before any
construction work on the waste treatment plant is begun. (1963 Code art. 9-1;
Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990; Ord. 001-2005, 1-17-2005)
Sec. 16-87. Delinquencies:
Sec. 16-87.1. Lien  1  - Notice Of Delinquency: Whenever a bill for sewer
service remains unpaid for thirty (30) days after it has been rendered, the
unpaid charges will result in a lien for those charges in favor of the City
against the property where service was provided. This lien will include all
charges incurred subsequent to the period covered by the delinquent bill.
The City Collector shall file with the Recorder of Deeds of the County a
statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of
the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill and a notice that the City
claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for sewer service
incurred subsequent to the period covered by the bill.
The failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to
foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as stated in this section.
   Sec. 16-87.2. Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid
charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same; and the proceeds of the sale
shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in
the foreclosure of statutory liens. The City Attorney is authorized to
institute such proceedings in the name of the City in any court having
jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which a lien has been
recorded. (1963 Code art. 9-1; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990; Ord. 029-2008, 4-21-2008)
